webTitle: A referee's eye view at Upton Park

fields.headline: A referee's eye view at Upton Park
fields.trailText: Donald McRae goes behind the lines to talk to referee Neale Barry, who oversaw Saturday's match between West Ham and Bradford, about the problem of indiscipine in the Premiership.
fields.body:
The room was bare and cramped. Outside, in an echoing tunnel, the police and security men had gathered. Even an hour before a routine Premiership afternoon turned serious, they were prepared for trouble. As the clock ticked towards three, the noise of a growing crowd seeped through the closed door.

Inside their tiny box, by 2.45pm, the four officials in charge of West Ham's game against Bradford City had changed into their familiar uniforms. They waited quietly for the moment when, as referee, Neale Barry reached for the buzzer which sounded in the adjoining dressing rooms.

In the depths of an enduring crisis surrounding Premiership officiating, there was just enough time for Barry and his assistants to reflect a little longer. They knew they would be the first to be insulted and blamed by 22 bawling players, a couple of indignant managers and 25,000 vociferous supporters. "We're easy targets," Barry said. "We accept it because that's football.

The minute you pass your Class 3 exam and take your first game in the parks your skin starts to thicken. A lot of the abuse is no different from years ago. So saying that we're less understood now implies that we were understood in the first place. I don't think we've ever been understood or valued.

"But refereeing in the Premiership this season has certainly been far less enjoyable. In the old first division there used to be two cameras for Match Of The Day. Now Sky have 18. Every gesture I make will be seen by millions. And it seems, because of that scrutiny, everyone is jumping on the bandwagon."

Keith Hackett, a former international ref who has since become Barry's coach and an observer of refereeing standards in the Premiership, nodded wryly. Hackett has always been a big man and, in such a small space, he loomed large. But he almost shuddered when he stressed: "Christ, I wouldn't want to be a referee today..."

Considering how Hackett had amused us with dark tales of how a death threat had once been issued against him at West Ham, his emphatic denial that he missed refereeing carried real resonance. He had also been at the centre of the infamous brawl between Arsenal and Manchester United in 1990 which resulted in points being docked from both clubs. He has not become timid in retirement. Yet the fevered atmosphere of the Premiership is even less forgiving.

"The culture has changed," Hackett argued. "The traditional spectator used to pay his money and if his team lost he wanted to blame someone; the referee was the obvious culprit. There was nothing untoward in that; by Sunday it would be out of his system. But now these feelings roll on as the media feeds off itself. It's becoming an impossible situation.

"As referees we must join the debate. It's incumbent on us to help the public understand the intricacies of our job. We're trying to encourage referees to explain themselves. Instead of saying 'No comment' it's better they say this is the reason for that decision. But there seems to be a fog over the game..."

Although Hackett insisted that "the standard of officiating is far better than when I was a ref", excruciating gaffes have recently eroded refereeing credibility. Yet amid the justified calls for referees to be made accountable for their errors, a more disturbing trend has re-emerged.

"The way in which Manchester United players surrounded Andy d'Urso," Barry suggested, "was appalling. But compared to the manner in which they whipped up the Tranmere and Mike Reed incidents, it seemed that the mass confrontation at Old Trafford was cut off at the stocking-tops by the media."

Within 90 minutes of Barry's lament, the behaviour of United's players again prompted intense media interest; Stephen Lodge, another referee coached by Hackett, had the difficult chore of trying to police United's attempts to corrode his authority during their 3-0 defeat by Newcastle.

But that was nothing compared with the ugly skirmishes that tarnished Elland Road and Stamford Bridge, and resulted in Leeds, Tottenham, Chelsea and Wimbledon being charged with misconduct by the FA on Monday.

Barry's own "challenge", as he charitably described his encounter with Paolo di Canio, Igor Stimac and the rest, was at least leavened by a nine-goal thriller. It helped that, as he awaited the arrival of Harry Redknapp and Paul Jewell with their team-sheets, Barry regarded the managers "as two of the reasonable ones. They might make a sarcastic comment but they won't start ranting and raving.

"If you look at Gordon Strachan, Martin O'Neill and George Graham, it's cabaret. They play to the crowd. It's as if they want to show their fans and directors that they're emotionally involved. But we all have to be honest; everyone makes mistakes. After the Chelsea-Tottenham game I got home at 3am and put on a video of the match. I decided then I shouldn't have cautioned Steffen Iversen. I phoned the FA the next morning and told them to rescind the caution."

Graham, at least, acknowledged Barry's courage in changing his decision. "He didn't admire me at all," Barry snorted. "It was just a public relations exercise [for him]..."

Across such a suspicious divide, managers and players increasingly question the officials whose control they are meant to accept. "What is the point of referees?" Stimac asked on Saturday after Barry had rejected Di Canio's first three penalty appeals. Two of those judgments were undoubtedly correct but, for Stimac and Di Canio, Barry's refusal to cede to their demands was indicative of a "vendetta" against the Italian.

When asked before the game if players such as Di Canio became victims of their own reputation, Barry murmured: "You'd be an idiot as a referee not to notice individuals. When you prepare for any match you know some players are more likely to cause problems."

It was impossible not to notice Di Canio. Apart from opening up Bradford's defence at will, he screamed constantly at Barry. With Bradford leading 4-2 he took off his shirt and pleaded to be substituted when another penalty was declined. Yet, when Barry pointed later at the spot, Di Canio and Frank Lampard wrestled over the ball like petulant seven-year-olds. After Barry's intervention, Di Canio scored to spark West Ham's stunning 5-4 win.

Yet a darker strain had swept through the tunnel at half-time. As Barry and his assistants rushed for the dressing room only seconds after a Bradford penalty levelled the score at 2-2, a policeman urgently requested back-up.

"You never know what might happen," he muttered into his walkie-talkie, "if the players go for the ref."

"To be fair," Barry countered afterwards, "the rapport was good for most of the match."

As for Di Canio's more singular rapport, Barry laughed. "I've no idea what he was saying. It was in Italian. But he understands English. I said, 'I don't care what you say in Italian, but if you wave your arms around once more I'll give you a yellow card.'

"When you have a split-second to decide whether to show a card or award a penalty it's a gut reaction. I don't care if they pay me £10,000 or £10 as a referee [the Premiership match fee is £600], I'd still make the same decisions."

Hackett had suggested that appointing a number of fully professional referees was the most logical way of undermining dissent on the pitch.

"We have to move that way," Hackett emphasised, "because I don't think there's any perception as to how much time and effort it takes for referees to reach this level - and for such relatively small reward. They're not in it for the money but they shouldn't have to worry about money."

At five o'clock on Saturday, a shirtless Neale Barry looked as though he couldn't care less about money as he conjured up an expression to match the curious Mr Happy underpants he had chosen to wear for his Upton Park cracker.

In his own ordinary life he was a 41-year-old planner with British Steel. It was a safe bet that his daily routine in his "proper job" could not rival Saturday's sheer adrenalin rush - despite a massed West Ham protest which almost pinned him to an advertising hoarding.

"The good thing," Barry enthused, "was that I didn't back off. I found neutral ground on the goal-line and put my arm out. It held them off. I was really pleased with my performance. Even the booing just made the hairs on the back of my neck stand up. I said to myself, 'You're in a game here.' I'd rather have that kind of match than a 0-0 where nothing happens."

The war elsewhere sounded like it was being lost, but the refereeing world's own Mr Happy had survived more than another battle. He looked as if he had fallen in love with football all over again.

"Five-four!" Barry marvelled. "That was a game of English football. Di Canio won't see that in Italy. He might be crazy but he can play all right - as can a few others. Weren't there some marvellous strikes out there? Great goals, great game. That'll do for me..."

webTitle: England find Hick right at home

fields.headline: England find Hick right at home
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe overhauled as local boy makes good with an unbeaten 87

Zimbabwe 194-7 in 48 overs
England 199-5 in 46.3 overs
England won by five wickets
fields.trailText: When they are chasing in one-day cricket, England can resemble someone in forlorn pursuit of a No28 bus. Red of face, gasping for breath and pouring with perspiration, they often present a picture of comic ineptitude.
fields.body:
When they are chasing in one-day cricket, England can resemble someone in forlorn pursuit of a No28 bus. Red of face, gasping for breath and pouring with perspiration, they often present a picture of comic ineptitude.

Rather like Road Runner or the Keystone Kops, your money is invariably on the other lot. Yesterday, at the Queens Sports Club, they actually achieved their modest target. But it was still something of a belly-laugh.

The Duckworth-Lewis scoring method, the monster with two heads, complicated matters after rain had reduced the first in this series of four one-day matches to a 48-over affair.

England, chasing a recalculated 199 to win, ultimately got there with five wickets and nine balls to spare, as Graeme Hick struck Henry Olonga over mid-on for six to take the match.

They had come through a mini-crisis when rain threatened again with England trailing Zimbabwe on the Duckworth-Lewis scale of revised targets for interrupted games. After the 35th over they were 135 for five, and still one run behind the hosts. If terminal rain had fallen then Zimbabwe would have won.

It was at this stage that Hick, rather like a golfer filling in his card, took a piece of paper from his pocket to work out exactly what was required. He and Mark Ealham then attacked the bowling, particularly the left-arm spin of Dirk Viljoen. After a drinks break between the 37th and 38th overs, everyone was so confused that the batsmen returned to the wrong ends, with Ealham taking strike when it should have been Hick.

Ultimately, though, it was Hick's day. In his first international appearance for England in the country of his birth, he scored a commanding 87 not out from 108 deliveries, with four fours and two sixes. He needed this. In the recent triangular series in South Africa he scored only 62 in five innings, and in seven matches against Zimbabwe had made 78 runs at an average of 13.

He had to be at his best because England's batting again showed its traditional soft centre after the openers Nasser Hussain and Nick Knight had both chopped on.

Hick and Darren Maddy put on 53 for the third wicket in 12 overs but then three wickets fell for 19 runs. First Maddy paddled Grant Flower round to short fine leg for a belligerent 24. Then a nervous Vikram Solanki, back at the expense of Mark Alleyne, was bowled for 11 as he tried to force the same bowler through the off side, having been dropped on eight.

England looked in deep trouble at 109 for five when Craig White was well caught by Olonga for a duck. But Ealham, who scored a four and a six in his 46-ball knock of 36, provided the support Hick needed, and the pair added 90 runs in as many balls.

Hussain said afterwards: "I'm delighted for Graeme. He showed what a tremendous player he can be. He and Mark played really well." Hick admitted: "The pressure was on but the Duckworth-Lewis thing gave some urgency to our batting when it was needed."

Earlier Zimbabwe, who won the toss, scored 194 for seven on a typically slow pitch. Neil Johnson and Alistair Campbell gave them a good start but their best innings was played by Grant Flower.

He had struggled recently when opening the batting but playing down the order, alongside his brother Andy, he flourished by scoring an unbeaten 55 from 63 deliveries.

White was the best of the England bowlers, picking up a wicket in each of his first two overs. Bowling with real pace at times and with clever use of the slower ball at others, he finished with figures of three for 29 from nine overs. Alan Mullally, with three for 37, also bowled well but Darren Gough was expensive with none for 47.

Crucially, England succeeded in keeping Zimbabwe below 200 - on 11 successive occasions they have failed win the chase when more than 210 was needed. Now to see if they can do it all again here tomorrow, rain and Duckworth-Lewis permitting.

 The former Test off-spinner Geoff Miller has been confirmed as England's fourth selector on a two-year contract.

fields.headline: Gascoigne charged after Boateng clash
fields.trailText: Paul Gascoigne was given further reason to curse his self-destructive streak yesterday when the Football Association charged him with misconduct for the moment of madness that left him with a broken arm and his season in doubt.
fields.body:
Paul Gascoigne was given further reason to curse his self-destructive streak yesterday when the Football Association charged him with misconduct for the moment of madness that left him with a broken arm and his season in doubt.

The sight of Gascoigne ramming a forearm into George Boateng's temple during Middlesbrough's 4-0 home defeat by Aston Villa on Monday brought a response from the FA in keeping with their new policy of taking swift action against those accused of rank indiscipline.

Among the letters from well-wishers at the private hospital where Gascoigne had a steel plate inserted into his left radius yesterday, was an invitation to Lancaster Gate telling him he had 14 days to request a personal hearing.

"We are acutely aware that sadly Paul sustained a serious injury himself from the incident and wish him a speedy recovery," said an FA spokesman. "However, we are committed to investigating allegations of violent play in the interests of the game. Having viewed video footage of the incident, we believe there is a case to be answered."

The move comes 24 hours after the FA announced it was taking unprecedented action following several incidents of violence at the weekend. Leeds and Tottenham are facing misconduct charges after a brawl at Elland Road, as are Chelsea and Wimbledon after fighting erupted in the tunnel at Stamford Bridge. Ian Harte of Leeds and Chelsea's Dennis Wise, as well as Wimbledon's Kenny Cunningham and coach Mick Harford, face separate charges.

The FA may ask Chelsea to allow them to view video footage from a closed-circuit camera on the wall of the tunnel in which the Chelsea and Wimbledon players and staff clashed.

With Gascoigne's disciplinary record, the 32-year-old should steel himself for a stiff punishment. The FA banned the Wimbledon defender Ben Thatcher for two matches for elbowing Sunderland's Nicky Summerbee in his face during a match at Selhurst Park last month.

However, it is unlikely a ban will provide Gascoigne with undue concern considering he is likely to be unavailable for most, if not all, of the closing stages to Middlesbrough's fight against relegation. The official line on Teesside last night was that the operation had been a success and Gascoigne would be out for around six weeks.

His club are unlikely to take disciplinary action themselves after seeming to accept Gascoigne's protests of innocence.

webTitle: Robinson sees Charlton dolled up to the nines

fields.headline: Robinson sees Charlton dolled up to the nines
fields.trailText: Charlton 1 - 1 Fulham
fields.body:
Charlton continued their relentless march back to the Premiership last night with a hard-earned victory which gave them a club-record ninth successive league win. At a time when talk of docking points is all the rage, perhaps the Football Association should take a few off Alan Curbishley's side to make the promotion race more exciting.

This morning they sit seven points clear of Manchester City at the top, and although they were far from fluent here, a second-half goal by John Robinson gave them three points they just about deserved from an untidy match.

Talk among the Charlton fans beforehand was not of whether their team would win, but by how many. Six consecutive home victories tend to generate such optimism.

Yet Charlton cannot have expected an easy ride. Fulham arrived with the second best defensive record in the division, their progress being stunted more by deficiencies at the other end of the pitch.

But two consecutive 1-0 wins, courtesy of a penalty and a deflected free-kick, had given confidence to Fulham's players as well as their manager Paul Bracewell. And with Charlton's passing game out of sorts, the visitors took the early initiative.

They closed down quickly to deny Charlton rhythm and looked to exploit the pace of Barry Hayles in attack.

Typically, though, they failed to create a chance of note and it was Charlton who carved out the first opportunity. Chris Powell's cross reached Shaun Newton at the far post but his header flew over via a deflection off Terry Phelan.

After a scare at the other end when Hayles dispossessed Steve Brown, Martin Pringle should have given an improving Charlton the lead. Newton's clever pass gave the Swede a clear sight of goal but he tried to work the ball on to his right foot and failed to steer his shot past Fulham's on-rushing goalkeeper Maik Taylor.

The screams of anguish from Charlton's expectant supporters heightened as a half high on effort but short of quality and excitement drifted to its conclusion. At least the players, after this week's hullabaloo, were less voluble in disputing decisions.

For a team who have oozed goals in recent weeks, Charlton were disappointing short of creativity. And it was Fulham who threatened three minutes after the interval. Steve Finnan's pass picked out Geoff Horsfield accelerating into the area but Richard Rufus made a well-timed tackle.

Phelan shot wide not long after and Charlton, realising a change was necessary to trouble a well organised and increasingly dangerous Fulham, sent on Mathias Svensson for the ineffective Pringle.

When Carl Tiler came on for Anthony Barness minutes later to operate as a third centre-back, it was evident Charlton hoped to make inroads down the flanks. And the tactic quickly paid off.

fields.bodyText: Charlton continued their relentless march back to the Premiership last night with a hard-earned victory which gave them a club-record ninth successive league win. At a time when talk of docking points is all the rage, perhaps the Football Association should take a few off Alan Curbishley's side to make the promotion race more exciting. This morning they sit seven points clear of Manchester City at the top, and although they were far from fluent here, a second-half goal by John Robinson gave them three points they just about deserved from an untidy match. Talk among the Charlton fans beforehand was not of whether their team would win, but by how many. Six consecutive home victories tend to generate such optimism. Yet Charlton cannot have expected an easy ride. Fulham arrived with the second best defensive record in the division, their progress being stunted more by deficiencies at the other end of the pitch. But two consecutive 1-0 wins, courtesy of a penalty and a deflected free-kick, had given confidence to Fulham's players as well as their manager Paul Bracewell. And with Charlton's passing game out of sorts, the visitors took the early initiative. They closed down quickly to deny Charlton rhythm and looked to exploit the pace of Barry Hayles in attack. Typically, though, they failed to create a chance of note and it was Charlton who carved out the first opportunity. Chris Powell's cross reached Shaun Newton at the far post but his header flew over via a deflection off Terry Phelan. After a scare at the other end when Hayles dispossessed Steve Brown, Martin Pringle should have given an improving Charlton the lead. fields.headline: Rangers hit by Lowndes
fields.trailText: St Johnstone 1 - 1 Rangers
fields.body:
Nathan Lowndes deprived Rangers of victory at McDiarmid Park just as Tony Vidmar had again looked to have emerged the Ibrox outfit's unlikely saviour.

Having been on the field for barely a minute, Lowndes struck in the 86th minute when it appeared Rangers had overcome the loss of skipper Lorenzo Amoruso and a missed Jorg Albertz penalty.

That loss compounded Rangers' misery and they remained frustrated until the 58th minute when Vidmar, who has proved an unexpected source of important goals this term, produced his best yet of a productive campaign. His superb left-foot curler was one of the few moments of quality in a bad-tempered match, but it was not to prove enough to win the game as substitute Lowndes had the final say with his first touch.

Rangers were slow off the blocks and their first attack of note came in the 16th minute when Andrei Kanchelskis' snap shot was well held by Main after Vidmar's pass. After 22 minutes Albertz played in Durie who looked to have taken the ball too wide when he was upended by Main, a needless challenge resulting in a clear penalty.

The game became scrappy in the lead-up to the break, though Saints continued to be positive in their outlook, neat play from Connolly feeding O'Neil for a shot that Klos saved comfortably. McCann was brought on for Kanchelskis after 53 minutes and at once Rangers seemed to offer more of a threat, Durie rifling a shot wide of target.

Substitute McCann was brought down by Darren Dods and from the resulting free-kick by Giovanni Van Bronckhorst, Rangers found the breakthrough in stunning fashion. The ball looked to have drifted harmlessly away from goal when it reached Vidmar, who spun expertly before curling a fierce shot into the top right-hand corner of the net to make it 1-0.

On 86 minutes Saints hit back just as their hopes looked to have faded when Danny Griffin's free-kick found Lowndes who made no mistake in securing a point.

 Motherwell's Scottish Cup third-round replay with Arbroath was postponed an hour before the scheduled kick-off last night because of a waterlogged pitch at Fir Park. The clubs will make a fifth attempt today but snow is forecast.

 Cagliari's Diego Lopez has been suspended for three matches for his part in a dressing-room brawl which resulted in Venezia's Fabian Valtolina, who was banned for one match and fined around £1,600, being rushed to hospital.

webTitle: O'Connor strikes to strengthen Blues play-off push

fields.headline: O'Connor strikes to strengthen Blues play-off push
fields.trailText: Birmingham 1 - 0 Blackburn
fields.body:
Birmingham City strengthened their grip on a play-off place here last night by recording a sixth win in seven games.

The victory puts them just one point behind fifth-place Huddersfield; more importantly it has established a nine-point lead over Rovers, the team Birmingham's manager Trevor Francis believes are one of the main threats to his side making a second successive appearance in the play-offs.

There was little evidence of that, however, as the revival that followed the appointment of Tony Parkes has stalled.

Birmingham's goal was the second collector's item here in as many matches. On Saturday a rare headed goal by Dele Adebola earned victory over Bolton Wanderers; last night it was Martin O'Connor's turn.

Inspired, perhaps, by his few days in the sun with while making his international debut for the Cayman Islands last week the midfielder produced his first league goal of the season from open play.

In terms of the contest it was also City's first shot on target. Until then Rovers' keeper Alan Kelly had been largely untroubled as their five-man midfield strifled City's creative instincts.

There appeared little danger in the build up to the goal. The Scottish international defender Christian Dailly had little difficulty in heading out Simon Charlton's left-wing cross but Rovers' skipper Garry Flitcroft failed to complete the clearance, dwelling on the ball on the edge of the penalty area.

Spotting his Blackburn counterpart's hesitation, O'Conner capitalised with a fierce right-footed shot past the surprised and equally helpless Kelly.

Had Damian Duff taken advantage of Rovers' best move of the half 20 minutes earlier that would have been the equaliser.

The f-ormer Manchester United winger Keith Gillespie began the move down the right flank and Jason McAteer continued it with a well- flighted cross.

But Duff scooped the ball over Ian Bennett's cross bar from close range. Duff ended the half even more ignominiously, his shot from the inside- right channel going out for a throw-in on the left flank.

webTitle: Daft as a brush with the arm of the laws

fields.headline: Daft as a brush with the arm of the laws
fields.trailText: Martin Kelner How many times have we seen Gazza turn a game in a moment? And now we want him to do it again for England. For some crazy reason we think that this time Gazza will not be Gazza. But he always is.
fields.body:
So Paul Gascoigne is out of the reckoning now for the England match against Argentina next week. If he had had even a half-decent game against Villa on Monday and left the pitch with his limbs intact, there would have been at least a murmur demanding his inclusion.

He is the most gifted English footballer of the past 30 years. He can turn a game in a moment. We have seen him: for Tottenham in their 1991 FA Cup run, for England in Euro 96, as a youngster at Newcastle. And we want him to do it again. Deluded fools that we are, we even think it a possibility. We think that this time Gazza will not be Gazza.

But he always is. Daft as a brush, Bobby Robson called him, and it has turned out to be one of the kinder assessments. There are five pages of quotes about Gazza in Phil Shaw's Book of Football Quotations, from Richard Littlejohn's dismissive depiction of him as "a man capable of going three rounds with a urinal" to Danny Baker's view that Gazza is all right really, because he always "washes his own cereal bowl" chez Baker. But Robson had les mots justes on the subject.

Only Steve Jacobs, an alcohol addiction counsellor, comes closer to capturing the essence of the footballer. "The pattern of Gascoigne's life is terrifying," he said. "If his behaviour continues, the boy... will end up in the gutter, in prison or he will die. If he doesn't change, I'm certain he will never celebrate his 40th birthday."

Jacobs's rumblings should be tempered by the obligatory spell Gascoigne has since spent in the Priory Clinic (the BBC should send a camera crew there; they could make Shooting Stars and A Question of Sport on the same trip) but the self-destructive streak the counsellor identified survives. What other explanation could there be for Gazza's extraordinary behaviour on Monday night?

He always did bustle in midfield, arms akimbo - his vigorous, barely legal use of the elbows helped give him his edge - but he must have known that going further and aiming the elbow at George Boateng would get him into serious trouble, especially after a weekend of Premiership indiscipline that had the FA talking of tough action against offenders.

Edgar Allan Poe once wrote a story called The Imp Of The Perverse, in which the hero was unable to remain on the straight and narrow because every time his life appeared to be running smoothly a strange and irresistible impulse would come over him to do something wicked or stupid. It could have been written for Gazza.

So what now? He will not end up in the gutter. Our addiction counsellor friend, on a social worker's pay, can probably not conceive of the immense riches even a dunderhead such as Gazza can derive from a partially successful career as a footballer.

M illionaires tend not to end up in the gutter and, unlike George Best, Gazza will not even need to spend his Saturday afternoons watching the footy on Sky TV.

His agent Mel Stein reckons he will be back playing Premiership football in four weeks, but then Stein is probably also in negotiations for a Frank Sinatra comeback tour.

A more likely outcome will see Gazza finishing his career in the United States where, as luck would have it, there is a resurgence of interest in soccer after the success of the American women's team and the release of two feature films with a soccer theme. But do not bet against Gazza lousing up the whole deal by arriving in Harlem blind drunk wearing a comedy Ku Klux Klan outfit.

Another wayward star who might have to learn a new set of social conventions is Ian Wright, who may well make his debut for Burnley on Saturday against Wigan. Turf Moor, remember, was for years the domain of the meat-pie magnate Bob Lord, who dubbed the 60s Manchester United team "a bunch of teddy boys" because of their dangerous habit of combing their hair "duck's-arse" style (all except Bobby Charlton, of course). The Burnley winger John Connelly now runs a fish and chip shop, a retirement option one suspects Wright has not considered.

Things have changed in Burnley, but not that much. The Manchester poet John Cooper Clark says: "My manager says I'm too sophisticated to appear in Burnley or anywhere else where they still point at aeroplanes."

fields.headline: Refuges that turned into purgatory
fields.standfirst:
Report condemns oversights and inadequacies of a system that allowed children to be abused for 10 years

More about the Wales child abuse scandal
fields.trailText: The report published today into the biggest child sex scandal Britain has known described the children who lived in the Bryn Estyn home near Wrexham, north Wales, as living in purgatory.
fields.body:
On the outside it looked like a somewhat forbidding Elizabethan manor house set in ample grounds, but the children who lived in the Bryn Estyn home, near Wrexham, north Wales, were in purgatory, according to the report published today into the biggest child sex scandal Britain has known.

Between 1974 and 1984, Bryn Estyn, became "the worst centre of child abuse in north Wales over a period of 10 years, undetected by outsiders".

After a three-year tribunal of inquiry into abuse in children's homes and foster homes across north Wales, chaired by Sir Ronald Waterhouse, the report, Lost In Care, says: "The evidence before us has disclosed that for many children who were consigned to Bryn Estyn, in the 10 or so years of its existence as a community home, it was a form of purgatory or worse from which they emerged more damaged than when they had entered and for whom the future had become even more bleak."

After registering 259 complaints and listening to the painful testimony of 129 people, the tribunal concluded that widespread sexual abuse of boys occurred in children's residential establishments in the now-defunct region of Clwyd between 1974 and 1990. It also found that there were incidents of sexual abuse of girl residents, though they were comparatively rare. Physical and sexual abuse of young residents in the neighbouring county of Gwynedd also occurred.

Local authority homes in Clwyd most affected were Bryn Estyn, where two senior officers, Peter Howarth and Stephen Norris, sexually assaulted and buggered boys over a 10-year period and Cartrefle, where Norris continued to abuse boys from 1984 until his arrest in June 1990. The tribunal also found evidence of sexual abuse at Little Acton assessment centre, Bersham Hall, Chevet Hey and Upper Downing. And there was widespread sexual abuse of boys in private residential establishments in the Clwyd area and abuse of children in five foster homes.

The report also found physical abuse and the unacceptable use of force in six local authority community homes in Clwyd. Once again, Bryn Estyn was the worst offender. It had "a harsh institutional regime in which, for many, there was a heavy atmosphere of fear".

'Grossly poisoned'

About 140 former residents of Bryn Estyn between 1974 and 1984 made allegations of physical or sexual abuse and the inquiry listened to the evidence of 48 of them. The overwhelming majority of complaints were made against Peter Howarth, assistant then deputy principal at the home.

The report found: "The lives of these already disturbed children were grossly poisoned by a leading authority figure in whom they should have been able to place their trust. They felt soiled, guilty and embarrassed and some of them were led to question their own sexual orientation. Most of them have experienced difficulties in their sexual relationships and their relationships with children ever since and many have continued to rebel against authority. Even more seriously, their self-respect and ability to look forward to the future have been shattered."

Howarth invented a regime at the home where he would post a flat list which named boys who were invited to his flat for recreation. Staff did not remark on its inappropriateness, leading the inquiry to conclude that there was a conspiracy of silence.

"It was Howarth's daily practice to invite resident boys, usually from the main building, to his flat in the late evening for drinks (including some alcohol) and light food for the privilege of watching television and for other recreation such as playing cards, board games etc ... Attendance was part of the agreed programme of activities available to boys in the evening and the names of those attending would be entered into the activities log. The sessions would begin at about 8.30pm and the boys attending, usually five or six or even more at a time, were required to dress in their pyjamas without any underwear. If they were wearing underpants under their pyjamas, they were ordered to remove them."

The inquiry discovered that Howarth had a number of favourites, known as "bum boys" and it was they who were the main victims of his sexual assaults. The report says: "They would be detained on some pretext when others were leaving, at which point, buggery or some indecency would occur. Quite often, however, similar conduct would occur in the kitchen of the flat, for example, whilst others were still present in another room watching television."

Howarth was convicted in July 1994 of one offence of buggery and seven indecent assaults and received a total of 10 years in prison. He died in April 1997. Stephen Norris's offences at Bryn Estyn and other homes were of similar nature to Howarth's but his method of operation was different. The report found he was "a coarse man of poor general education who should never have been placed in charge of a unit providing for the needs of immature and disturbed boys".

Norris pleaded guilty in November 1993 to three offences of buggery, an attempted buggery and three indecent assaults involving three former Bryn Estyn boys and received seven years in prison. He had already served 3 years in prison imposed in October 1990 for sexual offences committed at Cartrefle.

The report concludes that for two senior members of staff to be habitually engaged in major sexual abuse of many of the young residents without detection was "truly appalling".

Applauding the bravery of those who gave testimony to the inquiry, the tribunal lays the blame for the failure to detect the abusers at the doors of a number of agencies. Staff at the homes were criticised for their failure to blow the whistle on their colleagues. It found there were few complaints of abuse from the children in the homes because they were discouraged from doing so. There were no procedures in any of the establishments to enable members of staff to voice concerns.

The inquiry also found that social services failed to provide at the most senior level effective and positive leadership to ensure that the first consideration was the welfare of the child. Senior management was subject to frequent changes and was confused and defective.

There were no coherent arrangements by Clwyd social services for the management, support and monitoring of their care homes which allowed Bryn Estyn, in particular, to be run without any guidance.

The Welsh office comes in for a great deal of blame, with the report saying it "cannot absolve itself of ultimate responsibility for the fate of children in care by referring to legislation that successive governments themselves initiated from time to time, whether or not with expert advice". It discovered that "lack of leadership" in the Welsh office meant "forward planning was allowed to wither and die".

The tribunal also concluded that central government must bear responsibility for what happened. It said that for more than half the period under review children's services were given insufficient priority, including a failure to take action before the children act 1989 to regulate private children's homes and a failure to take steps to ensure that adequate facilities were made available for the training of residential child care workers.

The tribunal found that the police investigation of child abuse in Clwyd from 1991 was carried out "thoroughly" and "sensitively".

The report, however, criticises investigations into complaints about Gwynedd made by care home head Alison Taylor. The police work, it says, was "sluggish and shallow" and "seriously defective". The role played by Det Supt Gwynne Owen was inappropriate and the size of the investigating team inadequate. There was no liaison with social services and relevant documents were not seized.

The inquiry found no evidence of a paedophile ring in north Wales which was said to have involved high-profile public figures but said it had very little documentary evidence to go on. It had no evidence "to establish that there was a wide-ranging conspiracy involving prominent persons and others with the objective of sexual activity with children in care".

There was nothing to suggest there was a paedophile ring operating recruitment at Bryn Estyn. But there was a paedophile ring in the Wrexham and Chester areas "in the sense that there were a number of male persons, many of them known to each other, who were engaged in paedophile activities and were targeting young males in their middle teens".

Recommendations

The report makes 72 recommendations. An independent commissioner for Wales should be appointed to ensure children's rights through the monitoring and oversight of the operation of complaints and whistleblowing procedures and the arrangements for children's advocacy.

Every social services authority should be required to appoint an appropriately qualified or experienced children's complaints officer to act in the best interests of the child.

An abused child should not be transferred to another placement unless it is in the child's best interests.

Every local authority should promote awareness by children and staff of its complaints procedures for looked-after children and the importance of applying them without any threat or fear of reprisals.

There should be the establishment and implementation of conscientiously clear whistleblowing procedures. And consideration should be given to making failure to report actual or suspected abuse an explicit disciplinary offence.

A field social worker should be assigned to every looked-after child while in care and for an appropriate period of time afterwards and should visit them not less than once every eight weeks.

The report says there is a need for coordinated action by the new local authorities responsible for social services in north Wales. It raises as a cause for concern the adequacy of financial resources allocated to children's services and recommends a review of pay structures.

The tribunal found that the provision for appropriate management training is required and says the problem of recruitment of suitable residential care staff for children needs to be addressed urgently.

It says that positive action to encourage whistleblowing is needed. There should be increased vigilance among teachers, members of the medical profession and police officers.

There should be an inter-agency review of the procedures followed and personnel employed in all investigations of this nature with a view to issuing practical procedural guidance for the future. Social service and police files should be preserved and police should be allowed access to social service files. It also recommends the sharing of information generally for criminal investigation and child protection purposes.

Social services departments should be reminded periodically that they must exercise vigilance in the recruitment and management of their staff with similar vigilance being applied to all applications for approval as foster parents.

There should also be appropriate and timely induction training. Senior staff of children's homes must be qualified social workers.

Main points

An independent children's commissioner for Wales should be appointed to oversee complaints and whistleblowing procedures

Every social services authority should be required to appoint a complaints officer to interview children alleging abuse

An independent regulatory body should be set up to inspect all children's homes, foster homes and other child services

Social workers should be required to visit every child in their charge and in care at least every eight weeks

Local authorities should have clear procedures to encourage staff whistleblowing

Most of them have experienced difficulties in their sexual relationships and their relationships with children ever since and many have continued to rebel against authority. Even more seriously, their self-respect and ability to look forward to the future have been shattered." Howarth invented a regime at the home where he would post a flat list which named boys who were invited to his flat for recreation. Staff did not remark on its inappropriateness, leading the inquiry to conclude that there was a conspiracy of silence. "It was Howarth's daily practice to invite resident boys, usually from the main building, to his flat in the late evening for drinks (including some alcohol) and light food for the privilege of watching television and for other recreation such as playing cards, board games etc ... Attendance was part of the agreed programme of activities available to boys in the evening and the names of those attending would be entered into the activities log. The sessions would begin at about 8.30pm and the boys attending, usually five or six or even more at a time, were required to dress in their pyjamas without any underwear. If they were wearing underpants under their pyjamas, they were ordered to remove them." The inquiry discovered that Howarth had a number of favourites, known as "bum boys" and it was they who were the main victims of his sexual assaults. The report says: "They would be detained on some pretext when others were leaving, at which point, buggery or some indecency would occur. Quite often, however, similar conduct would occur in the kitchen of the flat, for example, whilst others were still present in another room watching television." Howarth was convicted in July 1994 of one offence of buggery and seven indecent assaults and received a total of 10 years in prison. He died in April 1997. Stephen Norris's offences at Bryn Estyn and other homes were of similar nature to Howarth's but his method of operation was different. The report found he was "a coarse man of poor general education who should never have been placed in charge of a unit providing for the needs of immature and disturbed boys". Norris pleaded guilty in November 1993 to three offences of buggery, an attempted buggery and three indecent assaults involving three former Bryn Estyn boys and received seven years in prison. He had already served 3 years in prison imposed in October 1990 for sexual offences committed at Cartrefle. The report concludes that for two senior members of staff to be habitually engaged in major sexual abuse of many of the young residents without detection was "truly appalling". Applauding the bravery of those who gave testimony to the inquiry, the tribunal lays the blame for the failure to detect the abusers at the doors of a number of agencies. Staff at the homes were criticised for their failure to blow the whistle on their colleagues. It found there were few complaints of abuse from the children in the homes because they were discouraged from doing so. There were no procedures in any of the establishments to enable members of staff to voice concerns. The inquiry also found that social services failed to provide at the most senior level effective and positive leadership to ensure that the first consideration was the welfare of the child. Senior management was subject to frequent changes and was confused and defective. There were no coherent arrangements by Clwyd social services for the management, support and monitoring of their care homes which allowed Bryn Estyn, in particular, to be run without any guidance. The Welsh office comes in for a great deal of blame, with the report saying it "cannot absolve itself of ultimate responsibility for the fate of children in care by referring to legislation that successive governments themselves initiated from time to time, whether or not with expert advice". It discovered that "lack of leadership" in the Welsh office meant "forward planning was allowed to wither and die". The tribunal also concluded that central government must bear responsibility for what happened. It said that for more than half the period under review children's services were given insufficient priority, including a failure to take action before the children act 1989 to regulate private children's homes and a failure to take steps to ensure that adequate facilities were made available for the training of residential child care workers. The tribunal found that the police investigation of child abuse in Clwyd from 1991 was carried out "thoroughly" and "sensitively". The report, however, criticises investigations into complaints about Gwynedd made by care home head Alison Taylor. The police work, it says, was "sluggish and shallow" and "seriously defective". The role played by Det Supt Gwynne Owen was inappropriate and the size of the investigating team inadequate. There was no liaison with social services and relevant documents were not seized. The inquiry found no evidence of a paedophile ring in north Wales which was said to have involved high-profile public figures but said it had very little documentary evidence to go on. It had no evidence "to establish that there was a wide-ranging conspiracy involving prominent persons and others with the objective of sexual activity with children in care". There was nothing to suggest there was a paedophile ring operating recruitment at Bryn Estyn. But there was a paedophile ring in the Wrexham and Chester areas "in the sense that there were a number of male persons, many of them known to each other, who were engaged in paedophile activities and were targeting young males in their middle teens". Recommendations The report makes 72 recommendations. An independent commissioner for Wales should be appointed to ensure children's rights through the monitoring and oversight of the operation of complaints and whistleblowing procedures and the arrangements for children's advocacy. Every social services authority should be required to appoint an appropriately qualified or experienced children's complaints officer to act in the best interests of the child. An abused child should not be transferred to another placement unless it is in the child's best interests. Every local authority should promote awareness by children and staff of its complaints procedures for looked-after children and the importance of applying them without any threat or fear of reprisals. There should be the establishment and implementation of conscientiously clear whistleblowing procedures. And consideration should be given to making failure to report actual or suspected abuse an explicit disciplinary offence. A field social worker should be assigned to every looked-after child while in care and for an appropriate period of time afterwards and should visit them not less than once every eight weeks. The report says there is a need for coordinated action by the new local authorities responsible for social services in north Wales. It raises as a cause for concern the adequacy of financial resources allocated to children's services and recommends a review of pay structures. The tribunal found that the provision for appropriate management training is required and says the problem of recruitment of suitable residential care staff for children needs to be addressed urgently. It says that positive action to encourage whistleblowing is needed. There should be increased vigilance among teachers, members of the medical profession and police officers. There should be an inter-agency review of the procedures followed and personnel employed in all investigations of this nature with a view to issuing practical procedural guidance for the future. Social service and police files should be preserved and police should be allowed access to social service files. It also recommends the sharing of information generally for criminal investigation and child protection purposes. Social services departments should be reminded periodically that they must exercise vigilance in the recruitment and management of their staff with similar vigilance being applied to all applications for approval as foster parents. There should also be appropriate and timely induction training. Senior staff of children's homes must be qualified social workers. webTitle: Miller faces county grind as fourth man

fields.headline: Miller faces county grind as fourth man
fields.standfirst: New selector has time on his side
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey reports on the surprise appointment of Geoff Miller as an England selector and the man charged watching and assessing the performances of players in county cricket.
fields.body:
Accountability and flexibility will be the watchwords when Geoff Miller is appointed today as an England selector. The former Derbyshire and England all-rounder will join the England captain Nasser Hussain, the coach Duncan Fletcher and the chairman David Graveney on a four-man panel which will oversee a packed international summer which includes a total of seven Test matches against Zimbabwe and West Indies and 10 one-day internationals.

Miller is a dry, deadpan individual who makes more than a crust speaking on the after-dinner circuit, and it is the availability that stems from this which has prompted his surprise elevation.

His brief will be to watch and assess the performances of players in county cricket. International commitments make that impossible to any meaningful degree for Hussain or Fletcher, likewise to a lesser extent for Graveney despite the possibility that he will restrict his involvement during Tests to preparation and the first day.

The search for a fourth selector, instigated at the behest of captain and coach, embraced players past and present, umpires and the media. One popular, if fanciful, suggestion was Ian Botham, who had been acting as an official adviser to the selectors.

However, it was felt that the great majority, including Botham and others involved in the game itself or through the media, would be too bound by their schedules to be flexible enough to go to a particular match at 24 hours' notice.

Most of those with the time and inclination, on the other hand, did not fit into the prescribed age bracket. Miller has indicated he would have no problem over availability, and at 47 he is younger than the chairman and only a year older than a previous incumbent, Graham Gooch.

An early task will be to nominate the players to be awarded central England contracts for the next season, with an announcement due this month. There could be as many as 16, but no more than 10 or 11 are expected.

The timing may be problematical, because unless the selectors have licence this summer to choose as many of their Test side as necessary from outside those contracted - something that will not sit kindly with the counties, many of then critical of what they see as extravagant use of board income - they are effectively being asked to select sides in February.

It has yet to be decided whether contracts should be awarded strictly on merit: in other words, on the basis of past performance and an established place in the international framework, as with Mike Atherton and Alec Stewart. Or should recognition be given both to the potential of up-and-coming players and the welfare in particular of promising fast bowlers such as Alex Tudor and Steve Harmison? Noses are sure to be put out of joint.

The former England seamer Mike Hendrick has been appointed Scotland's coach.

fields.headline: Taylor spoils handiwork
fields.trailText: England's women threw away a strong position in the second of five one-day internationals when they were all out for 141 in 47 overs after earlier being on 120-3.
fields.body:
England's women threw away a strong position in the second of five one-day internationals when Claire Taylor - a BA in maths at Oxford and a multilinguist - played a shot that lacked intelligence.

From 120 for three, having been asked to bat on a brand new pitch, England were all out for 141 in 47 overs and lost by eight wickets. They are two down in the series.

With 14 of their 50 overs left Taylor, who was on 56, swung wildly at the veteran spinner Cathy Campbell and holed out to mid-on.

New Zealand had all the experience they needed in Debbie Hockley, in her 103rd one-day international. She was dropped at square leg when she had made 39 but went on to make 65 not out.

Allan Donald has rejected another attempt by South Africa to persuade him to play in two one-day international series against Australia.

The 33-year-old fast bowler said last month he would take an eight-month sabbatical from international cricket to spend an uninterrupted summer playing for Warwickshire. He is standing by the decision.

Donald flies out to India with South Africa today for a short tour, needing 10 wickets in two Tests to reach 300.

webTitle: Recalling life in the Colditz of care

fields.headline: Recalling life in the Colditz of care
fields.standfirst: More about the Wales child abuse scandal
fields.trailText: Kevin Maher, 31, was taken into care at five, when his parents split up. Aged 11 he was moved to Bryn Estyn and soon suffered at the hands of the regime.
fields.body:
Kevin Maher, 31, was taken into care at five, when his parents split up. Aged 11 he was moved to Bryn Estyn and soon suffered at the hands of the regime.

He said: "The psychological impact on me has been profound. I was never sexually abused, it was purely physical battering."

Once, he said, two members of staff bent his arms back and took turns to kick him in the chest.

He saw a member of staff rub his friend's face in the shards of a light bulb which he had accidentally smashed. "He was one of my best friends. He hanged himself when he was 27."

Keith Gregory, 42, who was at Bryn Estyn between 1972 and 1974, said he was beaten daily. He had been sent to the centre as a punishment for playing truant.

"I was beaten and caned over the back of my knees and neck. It was systematic abuse for minor offences.

"They used to make us run through a line of showers naked. One of the showers was boiling hot and the other was freezing cold. This would go on for an hour at a time. If we slowed down, we were whipped.

"I was sent there to make me go to school, but I never went to school again."

His brother Tony, 37, was sent there in 1977 and managed to resist the sexual advances of Peter Howarth, the deputy head. "I was physically abused and they tried to sexually abuse me but I fought off the staff."

Once, he and another boy were invited to Howarth's private flat and told to remove their underpants before returning to watch TV. He said they felt "dubious" about staying there but the boys sat together and refused even to go to the toilet on their own. "We didn't go into the kitchen because that is where he carried out his gang rapes," he said.

"He was always making sexual innuendos in conversation. He was trying to find out whether we were easy prey or not."

Stephen Messham, 37, a former Bryn Estyn resident, emerged as an unofficial figurehead for the victims. He said he was sexually assaulted by 49 men and physically assaulted by 26 people when in care. He described himself as a slave sold into abuse.

"I was at Bryn Estyn for two-and-a-half years and the name it got was the Colditz of care. It was abusive and threatening.

"I was Peter Howarth's No 1 boy for 14 months and was sexually abused by him almost every day."

Messham's credibility was questioned by the inquiry.

webTitle: Questions and answers that surround a catalogue of abuse against children

fields.headline: Questions and answers that surround a catalogue of abuse against children
fields.standfirst: More about the Wales child abuse scandal
fields.trailText: What was the Waterhouse inquiry all about?
fields.body:
What was the Waterhouse inquiry all about?

It was ordered in 1996 by William Hague, when he was Welsh secretary in the then Conservative government, into abuse of children in care after 1974 in the former county council areas of Clwyd and Gwynedd. This followed an outcry over a decision by Clwyd councillors, acting on legal advice, not to publish the report of a smaller inquiry lest it prompt court actions and a rash of compensation claims. The Waterhouse report calls for a review of such problems by the Law Commission.

How did it compare to other child abuse inquires?

It was by far the biggest. It sat for 203 days and took evidence from 575 witnesses, including 259 complainants alleging abuse when they were in care. Some 9,500 social services files were made available and the inquiry team scrutinised 3,500 statements made to police. In all, there were 43,000 pages of evidence of complaints about some 40 homes, as well as foster placements.

How did the scandal come to light?

Care workers in Clwyd were being convicted of sex abuse as long ago as 1976 and there were allegations and investigations in Gwynedd in the 1980s. But the scandal was only exposed after Alison Taylor, a children's home head in Gwynedd, pressed her concerns at the highest levels. The inquiry report finds that her complaints have been "substantially vindicated". But for her, there would have been no inquiry into Gwynedd and possibly not into Clwyd either.

Why did it take so long to emerge?

What the report calls a "cult of silence" at the most notorious home, Bryn Estyn, was all too typical. Few children made complaints. When the police first investigated Ms Taylor's concerns in 1986-87, the authorities constructed a "wall of disbelief" at the outset. The subsquent decision not to bring prosecutions was greeted with "inappropriate enthusiasm" by social services.

What kind of abuse did the inquiry hear about?

Almost everything imaginable, and much that was not. Most attention has focused on sex abuse of boys by staff and paedophiles outside the care system, but there was also sex abuse of girls and boys by women staff. The bulk of allegations concerned physical and emotional abuse, including hitting and throttling children, bullying and belittling them. Punishments included being forced to scrub floors with toothbrushes, or to perform garden tasks using cutlery. The inquiry team says the quality of care, and standard of education, were below acceptable levels in all the homes it investigated.

Was there a paedophile ring?

Rumours of a ring of abusers, including prominent public figures, have been rife. But the report says there is no credible evidence of any such network. It also dismisses suggestions that freemasonry was implicated in what went on. The report does, however, find there were paedophiles in Wrexham and Chester, many of whom were known to each other, who abused boys and shared information about victims.

Will the victims get compensation?

Some already have, as a result of court convictions of their abusers. Payments have typically been in the tens of thousands of pounds, though one or two have reached six figures. More claims are expected, particularly from people who were in the care of staff named in the inquiry report.

Have people lied to the inquiry to try to get compensation?

The report says not. While acknowledging a lack of direct corroboration of most allegations, the inquiry team says it was "impressed generally by the sincerity of the overwhelming majority" of witnesses claiming they were abused.

Could it happen again?

It is extremely unlikely, according to the Association of Directors of Social Services. Measures in place, and more to come, should make it impossible for the care system to escape scrutiny as it did in north Wales. But there remains the threat posed by individual abusers and the fear is that determined paedophiles have moved into other sectors, such as boarding schools and youth groups.

Any more inquiries in the pipeline?

Potentially plenty. According to the Association of Child Abuse Lawyers, there are 80 police investigations into institutional abuse. It says each one should prompt a public inquiry of its own, which for most victims would be "the closest they will get to real justice". But with the cost of the north Wales inquiry put at £13.5m, and rising, it is almost certain to be the first and last of its kind.

webTitle: Hunt for 24 care workers in child abuse scandal

fields.headline: Hunt for 24 care workers in child abuse scandal
fields.standfirst: More about the Wales child abuse scandal
fields.trailText: A hunt was on last night to find 24 former workers in north Wales children's homes after they were named as proven or suspected abusers in the public inquiry report into the 20-year care scandal in the former counties of Clwyd and Gwynedd.
fields.body:
A hunt was on last night to find 24 former workers in north Wales children's homes after they were named as proven or suspected abusers, or unsuitable to work with young people, in the long-awaited public inquiry report into the 20-year care scandal in the former counties of Clwyd and Gwynedd.

Local and health authorities across Britain are being given 48 hours to check their staff lists and report to the government on whether any of the individuals have jobs where they might have access to children.

The move followed publication of the report by a team led by Sir Ronald Waterhouse, a former high court judge, setting out how thousands of youngsters supposedly in the public care were abandoned to regimes of sexual, physical, and emotional abuse.

Paul Murphy, the Welsh secretary, told parliament that the report catalogued "deeds of appalling mistreatment and wickedness". Action was being taken to ensure there could be no repetition. "To those whose lives have been shattered, to the families of those who have died, and to all decent thinking people, of course we all say 'sorry'," he said.

The 937-page report names about 200 people under the privilege accorded the inquiry. Some have previously been identified in court cases, but others have merely been subject of complaints assessed by the team. Still others have been named because they held responsible positions, or because the team felt it necessary to do so to address rumours about them.

One person named is Huw Meurig Jones, former deputy head of the Little Acton assessment centre in Wrexham, who gave evidence to the inquiry denying three witnesses' allegations of physical and sexual abuse.

Mr Jones resigned in 1981 but is known to have since worked at a private school and sought employment as head of a children's home. While making clear it could not substantiate the allegations, the team says: "In our judgment it would be impossible for the public, with knowledge of the facts, to have the degree of confidence in his judgment and probity that is essential for employment in social work involving the care of children."

The 24 people being urgently traced, including three teachers, are being added to the lists held by the health and education departments of people who have given cause for concern regarding children.

There will inevitably be questions about why such action was authorised only yesterday, if the inquiry team has harboured doubts about the individuals for some time. The team completed taking evidence in April 1998.

The inquiry, which cost £13.5m, found evidence of widespread sexual abuse of boys in children's homes in Clwyd and some evidence of such abuse of girls. One of the most notorious abusers was Peter Howarth, former deputy head of the Bryn Estyn home, who was jailed for 10 years in 1994 but died in 1997.

Although there was no evidence of persistent sexual abuse in children's homes in Gwynedd, there was widespread physical abuse and some evidence of abuse, both physical and sexual, in foster homes.

The report finds no case for the rumoured existence of a paedophile ring in high circles, but does confirm that some male abusers in the Chester and Wrexham areas operated as a group, preying on teenage boys in care and the community at large.

In a conclusion which will be seized on by opponents of the reduction in the age of consent for gay sex from 18 to 16, the inquiry team draws parliament's attention to the damaging effect of abuse on one teenage boy "in circumstances which appear to have made him question his own sexuality for a period".

The team's 72 recommendations, applying technically to Wales alone but certain to have a broader impact, include a full review of what it would cost to bring children's services up to an acceptable level of performance.

The team also calls for the appointment of a children's commissioner. Although such a move has already been signalled in Wales, the health department proposes to create a children's rights director - a lesser role that has been criticised by children's charities.

Paul Murphy, the Welsh secretary, told parliament that the report catalogued "deeds of appalling mistreatment and wickedness". Action was being taken to ensure there could be no repetition. "To those whose lives have been shattered, to the families of those who have died, and to all decent thinking people, of course we all say 'sorry'," he said. The 937-page report names about 200 people under the privilege accorded the inquiry. Some have previously been identified in court cases, but others have merely been subject of complaints assessed by the team. Still others have been named because they held responsible positions, or because the team felt it necessary to do so to address rumours about them. One person named is Huw Meurig Jones, former deputy head of the Little Acton assessment centre in Wrexham, who gave evidence to the inquiry denying three witnesses' allegations of physical and sexual abuse. Mr Jones resigned in 1981 but is known to have since worked at a private school and sought employment as head of a children's home. While making clear it could not substantiate the allegations, the team says: "In our judgment it would be impossible for the public, with knowledge of the facts, to have the degree of confidence in his judgment and probity that is essential for employment in social work involving the care of children." The 24 people being urgently traced, including three teachers, are being added to the lists held by the health and education departments of people who have given cause for concern regarding children. There will inevitably be questions about why such action was authorised only yesterday, if the inquiry team has harboured doubts about the individuals for some time. The team completed taking evidence in April 1998. The inquiry, which cost £13.5m, found evidence of widespread sexual abuse of boys in children's homes in Clwyd and some evidence of such abuse of girls. One of the most notorious abusers was Peter Howarth, former deputy head of the Bryn Estyn home, who was jailed for 10 years in 1994 but died in 1997. Although there was no evidence of persistent sexual abuse in children's homes in Gwynedd, there was widespread physical abuse and some evidence of abuse, both physical and sexual, in foster homes. The report finds no case for the rumoured existence of a paedophile ring in high circles, but does confirm that some male abusers in the Chester and Wrexham areas operated as a group, preying on teenage boys in care and the community at large. In a conclusion which will be seized on by opponents of the reduction in the age of consent for gay sex from 18 to 16, the inquiry team draws parliament's attention to the damaging effect of abuse on one teenage boy "in circumstances which appear to have made him question his own sexuality for a period". The team's 72 recommendations, applying technically to Wales alone but certain to have a broader impact, include a full review of what it would cost to bring children's services up to an acceptable level of performance. The team also calls for the appointment of a children's commissioner. Although such a move has already been signalled in Wales, the health department proposes to create a children's rights director - a lesser role that has been criticised by children's charities.

webTitle: 'Punishment was the only thing I knew'

fields.headline: 'Punishment was the only thing I knew'
fields.standfirst:
The victim: Beatings and humiliations haunt mother who survived

More about the Wales child abuse scandal
fields.trailText: When Katrina finally won access to the file of her years in care one thing puzzled her. Most of the names of other children who had been with her in a series of grim and abusive care homes in north Wales had been blanked out.
fields.body:
When Katrina finally won access to the file of her years in care one thing puzzled her. Most of the names of other children who had been with her in a series of grim and abusive care homes in north Wales had been blanked out.

Eventually, it dawned on her: the children whose names remained were dead. Nothing could hurt them now.

"It seems almost as if only the ones who got out of Wales have survived," says Katrina, who gave evidence to the Waterhouse inquiry after the police traced her to her south London home. Though she has survived, to the extent of getting a degree and having two well-balanced sons, she is, on her own admission, damaged. She has been in therapy for eight years.

Katrina's story is by no means the worst to have come out of the north Wales scandal. She was never raped ("I was too boyish") and never penetrated with a crowbar or chair leg. But, more typically of the victims, she was habitually beaten, humiliated and, as far as she can recall, denied any human warmth from the moment she was taken into care at the age of 18 months.

"I became frightened of contact with anyone. The only contact I had right through care was punishment," she says. "I didn't ever receive a cuddle - never, ever, ever."

Until she got hold of her file last year, by taking legal action, Katrina had never been sure why she had wound up in care. What awful crime had she committed, she often wondered. What dreadful behavioural problems had she exhibited as a baby?

The file confirms that her mother, struggling to cope on her own and reported to the council by neighbours who monitored gentlemen callers at her Deeside home, agreed to Katrina and her elder sister going into care. The mother vanished for the next 12 years, and the girls disappeared too, into a system seemingly cut off from the rest of the world.

Katrina, now 40, has hazy memories of her early years in residential nurseries and foster homes, culminating in a vast Salvation Army institution in Southport, Lancashire, where she remembers two things clearly: playing the triangle and being punished for bad manners at the table by being made to sit under it.

In 2000, it is difficult to attempt to judge the care of children 30 years and more ago by the standards of the day. But the beatings and lockings-in which Katrina says happened routinely at the next stop, a rambling children's home called Upper Downing at Whitford, near Holywell, in Wales, were unacceptable by any yardstick - even if, as it transpired, they hardened Katrina and her sister for what lay in store.

From Upper Downing, the girls went to a foster home for seven years. A loving family environment it was not. "They had grown-up children and if you misbehaved one of them would come round and just kick the shit out of you, flinging you round the bedroom, saying you'd been rude to their mum. And all the time they were parading you round, as if to say, 'Look what we're doing for society'."

There was worse: although Katrina escaped sexual abuse, she suggests her sister did not. "I used to share her bedroom," she says, "I knew what was going on." The abject failure of the statutory services to detect anything wrong about the placement - "in my file they talk about what a beautiful house it was," says Katrina - was repeated at Llanelwy children's home, in Wrexham.

That she can remember only such flashes of her time as a "Llanelwy girl", even though she was by now a teenager and her mother had reappeared in her life as an occasional visitor, may reflect the fact that Katrina was often sedated. Her medical records, recently obtained, show she was frequently given valium, sleeping pills and other drugs, presumably to curb what was considered her wild behaviour. Eventually, she ran away.

The penalty for absconding was to be sent to a semi-secure unit at the Little Acton assessment centre in Wrexham. There, Katrina says, there was a lot of sex - consenting and forced - between children and staff.

"There was no privacy whatsoever. You couldn't lock the bedroom or bathroom, so the men would watch you in the bath. And there was strip-searching. I heard girls making complaints about staff, but who was going to believe it?"

The last institution Katrina was moved to was a "working girl's hostel" in Flint. After she failed to settle in a job, being sent back by one local farmer because she would not have sex with him, she was referred to a psychiatrist. He diagnosed her behaviour as perfectly normal adolescent rebellion.

Finally, if belatedly, the system worked as it should. A social worker took an interest in Katrina's case and found her lodgings with a caring family. "For the first time, I was treated like a human being. They said, 'You've got brains, you are an attractive young woman.' I just said, 'Huh?'"

Encouraged to develop her talent for art, Katrina started night classes. Although she lacked the full qualifications, she was accepted for a university course in art, gaining a good honours degree. Today, she works as a part-time art therapist with, among others, children in care.

In an attempt to back-fill her life, Katrina has just passed GCSE English. Other gaps are less easily plugged: she has, for instance, no photograph of herself as a child. The legacy of such an abnormal childhood is manifested in other ways, too: she and her sons have always lived in short-life housing and she has, she admits, found it difficult to sustain relationships.

When Katrina turned 18, Clwyd council sent her £8 to set her up in adult life. "I should have said' 'Stuff it'," she says. "I wish I had."
