webTitle: 'I just hope this will protect future generations in care'

fields.headline: 'I just hope this will protect future generations in care'
fields.standfirst:
Reaction: Abuse victims give cautious welcome to report

More about the Wales child abuse scandal
fields.trailText: Victims of abuse and their solicitors cautiously welcomed the report yesterday and hoped it would protect future generations of children in care.
fields.body:
Victims of abuse and their solicitors cautiously welcomed the report yesterday and hoped it would protect future generations of children in care.

Keith Gregory, 42, was at the Bryn Estyn care home in Wrexham - subject of 138 complaints to the tribunal - between 1972-74.

He hoped the care home staff named in the report would never be able to work with children again. "I am glad for the apology - that goes a long way. It's not everything, but it's more than we expected," he said.

"I just hope in time it will help other kids in care. I still think it will be hard for the child to go to the new commissioner [recommended to watch over children in care], to talk to somebody."

He said more people should have been named by the tribunal. "Somebody's got to be accountable for all these suicides and mental problems. It has been a hell of a fight trying to make people believe us. No child should ever go through what we went through. If it stops all this sort of thing then it's worth it. You wouldn't treat animals the way we were treated."

His brother Tony, 37, who was at the home in 1977, said: "I don't know if these recommendations will work - only time will tell. I would like to see the people responsible for this made to account for themselves.

"If they haven't got the guts to apologise, they deserve everything that a criminal prosecution will bring."

Stephen Messham, a former Bryn Estyn resident, said: "Recommendations are not enough. We need prosecutions now. If we don't get them, we will have wasted £13m" on the inquiry.

Kevin Maher, 31, another former resident of Bryn Estyn, called for immediate compensation for all victims.

"If councils have been found guilty, they should be accountable - it's as simple as that," he said. "I want the rhetoric to stop and action to be taken. Every victim should be compensated for lack of education, for lack of trust, the whole lot. Let's have a clean sweep of the care system."

Richard Scorer, a solicitor from the Manchester firm of Pannone and Partners, represented 30 abuse victims. He said: "This report confirms beyond doubt the systematic abuse of children in Clwyd children's homes over a 30-year period. This vindicates the courage of the many hundreds of victims who gave evidence to the tribunal."

He said they were pleased that the report recognised some of the failings of the original investigation by north Wales police, in particular the insensitive interviewing of victims. "The very existence of the tribunal speaks volumes about the failure of the police to uncover this scandal at an earlier stage."

Billhar Uppal, who represented about 130 former residents of North Wales homes, said the report would be broadly acceptable to most abuse victims who gave evidence at the tribunal. He described its recommendations as constructive: "It pays fair justice to the circumstances that gave rise to abuse and neglectful care in North Wales."

Ron Evans, solicitor to the six local councils which succeeded the former Clwyd and Gwynedd councils whose care homes were investigated, said: "We share with everyone else a sense of outrage towards those who have caused the suffering and brought shame on the social services profession."

webTitle: Pinochet brain damaged, says leaked report

fields.headline: Pinochet brain damaged, says leaked report
fields.standfirst: 'Further deterioration is likely' doctors concluded, but felt unable to 'express any useful opinion on the possible effects on his health of undergoing trial' according to confidential report published by ABC in Spain
fields.trailText: Former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet is suffering from brain damage, a Spanish newspaper reported today, breaking the conditions of "strict confidentiality" under which his medical report was released to four countries.
fields.byline: Patrick Barkham, Sean Clarke and Simon Jeffery
fields.body:
Former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet is suffering from brain damage, a Spanish newspaper reported today, breaking the conditions of "strict confidentiality" under which his medical report was released to four countries.

Doctors judged the Pinochet was physically fit enough to stand trial on torture charges, but said the 84-year-old "would not at the present be mentally capable of meaningful participation in a trial," according to a leaked copy of the report published by two Spanish newspapers this morning.

The report, handed over to Spain, Belgium, France and Switzerland by home secretary Jack Straw yesterday, said that Pinochet's two main medical problems were diabetes and "recently progressive cerebrovascular brain damage".

It judged that "further deterioration in both physical and mental condition is likely," particularly with any "situational stress" brought on by a trial on torture charges.

But the four doctors who compiled the report noted that Pinochet has "shown notable personal abilities in managing stress" in the past. Given this, they concluded: "We therefore do not feel able to express any useful opinion on the possible effects on his health of undergoing trial."

The complete text of the medical report's conclusions was published on Spain's ABC newspaper's website, despite the insistence of Lord Justice Simon Brown in the high court yesterday that "fairness demanded" the report should be disclosed only under conditions of "strict confidentiality" to Belgium, France and Switzerland.

The Home Office announced it would ask Spain to investigate the leaking of the report.

"Because the court stressed that the medical report was only to receive limited dissemination, we have asked the Spanish authorities, through the Crown Prosecution Service, their legal representatives, for any information they can supply about how the conclusions of the report came to be disclosed," it said in a statement.

Lord Lamont, a prominent pro-Pinochet campaigner, condemned the publication of the confidential medical details: "What has happened is quite disgusting and entirely predictable from our Spanish friends - it's only happened 24 hours quicker than I expected.

"We are making complete fools of ourselves and we are just being played with by a lot of unscrupulous people," Lord Lamont added.

Pinochet underwent six hours of medical tests at Northwick Park Hospital on 5 January.

The resulting report, which led to Mr Straw saying he was "minded" to let Pinochet return to Chile without trial, was signed by Sir John Grimley Evans, professor of clinical geratology at Oxford University, Dr Michael Denham, a consultant physician in geriatric medicine at Northwick Park Hospital, London, and Andrew Lees, professor of neurology at the National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery in London.

A fourth expert, Dr Maria Wyke, conducted a neuropsychological assessment of Pinochet in Spanish. "He was a person of superior intelligence and at present is functioning within the low average/average range," she said, concluding there was "no evidence that General Pinochet is attempting to fake disability".

The report revealed that the examining doctors believed there were four mental impediments to Pinochet facing torture charges in court:

· Memory deficit for both recent and remote events;

· Limited ability to understand complex sentences and questions owing to memory impairment and consequent inability to process verbal information appropriately;

· Impaired ability to express himself audibly, succinctly and relevantly;

· Easy fatiguability.

The doctors also offered an insight into the life of the ailing former dictator in the fifteen months he has spent under house arrest in Surrey.

"In recent months he has lost interest in former activities," the report said. "He used to read and use the computer but now tends to sit watching television and says he has forgotten how to use the computer."

"Recently he has developed difficulty in shaving without cutting himself," it added.

Media reports at the weekend suggested that Pinochet's medical condition had since deteriorated further and members of his family were poised to fly to Britain from Chile to visit him on the exclusive Wentworth Estate.

Spain, Belgium, France and Switzerland now have until 5pm next Tuesday to make representations to the home secretary in the light of the report.

webTitle: Morgan asks for calm and continuity

fields.headline: Morgan asks for calm and continuity
fields.trailText: February 16 2000: Labour's Rhodri Morgan was yesterday formally elected first secretary of the Welsh assembly, and promptly called for a period of calm and continuity after the events that culminated in last week's resignation of his predecessor, Alun Michael.
fields.body:
Labour's Rhodri Morgan was yesterday formally elected first secretary of the Welsh assembly, and promptly called for a period of calm and continuity after the events that culminated in last week's resignation of his predecessor, Alun Michael.

Mr Morgan, who was elected unopposed, said he felt "tremendous emotion, honour and privilege" at having been appointed to a job he had given much thought to over the past two and a half years.

In a speech that mixed passion with humour, he said he wanted to inspire voters with a vision of devolution and "rebuild the bond of trust" between politicians of all parties and the people of Wales.

He said that if Welsh political giants such as Nye Bevan and Lloyd George could dream their dreams of how to improve society, assembly members could do so too, now that the new institution gave them a vehicle for improving the lives of the people of Wales.

Paying tribute to the hard work and dignity of his predecessor, Mr Morgan said the assembly could not allow the culling of first secretaries to become Wales's annual blood sport. His number one target, he said to laughter from fellow assembly members, was to survive until the half-term recess.

He paid "a huge tribute" to Mr Michael, who sat in the assembly chamber next to former Welsh secretary, Ron Davies, and behind his old seat. Mr Morgan said: "Nobody could have worked harder for Wales and nobody with an ounce of humanity about them could have failed to be moved by the dignity that he showed last week and is still showing now."

The opposition parties then welcomed the fresh start for the assembly. Plaid Cymru president, Dafydd Wigley, referred to Tony Blair's original attempt to block Mr Morgan's bid to become first secretary in favour of Alun Michael.

He said: "It is us here in Wales as parties and as an assembly who decide who are to be our leaders. Let that message go forth in no uncertain terms."

Meanwhile, the row over European funding which toppled Mr Michael spread to Scotland yesterday, with the Scottish National party calling for a full parliamentary inquiry after an independent report appeared to lend weight to claims that the treasury is breaking the additionality rules which require funds from Brussels to be matched by UK funding in Scotland as well as in Wales.

Gillian Bristow, of Cardiff Business School, says the method by which EU funds are dispersed to Wales and Scotland, through the block grant system, means neither country is getting its full entitlement.

"The EC says EU money should be additional to existing public expenditure," said Dr Bristow yesterday. "At present it is very difficult to assess that that is the case. In Wales it is probably not the case and the arguments are that the same thing must be happening in Scotland."

The SNP has estimated that Scotland has lost out on some £730m since 1993 because of the funding system.

The party is sending representatives to Wales today to hold talks with Plaid Cymru on the matter.

A treasury spokesman refuted suggestions that rules were being broken on the issue of additionality, and a spokesman for the Scottish executive said there was no question of Scotland having lost out because of the way structural funds are managed.

fields.headline: Secretary in a state
fields.standfirst: The new man behind the Tories' anti-Europe crusade
fields.trailText:
From John O'Groats to Land's End, there cannot be a man, woman or child who failed to notice Michael
           Portillo's return to the Tory front bench. His fan club, otherwise known as the Portillistas, has made sure
           of that. But who spares a thought for Francis Maude , elevated to shadow foreign secretary in the same
           reshuffle?
fields.body:
From John O'Groats to Land's End, there cannot be a man, woman or child who failed to notice Michael Portillo's return to the Tory front bench. His fan club, otherwise known as the Portillistas, has made sure of that. But who spares a thought for Francis Maude , elevated to shadow foreign secretary in the same reshuffle?

He has no star quality, nor a claque of Maudeites to sing his praises, but his appointment may turn out to be just as significant, since he will now lead the Conservatives' anti- European crusade , which, they hope, will bring the voters flocking back to their party.

So what are Francis Maude 's qualifications for the job? I turn to the Hansard of January 31 1990, when he was minister for Europe in the government of Margaret Thatcher, the well-known federalist. `We are seeing the growth of economic and monetary integration to reduce costs, to help business and to take forward the integration of Europe,' Maude informed the Commons. `In all these important areas, Britain has led the way and we are showing the way forward . . . In economic and monetary union, no country is more advanced than ours.'

Does little Hague know this? And has anyone told him that it was also Francis Maude who signed the hated Maastricht treaty on behalf of the British government? Irony may be delicious as a snack, but can bring on terminal indigestion when eaten with the roast beef of old England.

Talking of which, I wonder if William Hague has read Alan Clark's diaries. In an entry for December 19 1987, Clark describes `a very jolly dinner at the Savoy' with Francis Maude , David Heathcoat Amory and the late Ian Gow, during which Gow suggested that Margaret Thatcher might send Nigel Lawson to the foreign office.

`Maude, supported by David H-A, said Lawson couldn't be foreign sec as a Jew,' Clark records. `This made Ian very indignant. `Do you mean to tell me that today, this very day, in this, the Conservative party , I take it that we are all members of the Conservative party? , you are seriously suggesting, no, asserting . . .' and so on. Ian then switched to `He's not a practising Jew, anyway.' But we couldn't quite swallow it.'

Jewish supporters of the Conservative party , if such people still exist , may wish to ask themselves if they can quite swallow Francis Maude .

webTitle: Morgan asks for calm and continuity

fields.headline: Morgan asks for calm and continuity
fields.body:
Labour's Rhodri Morgan was yesterday formally elected first secretary of the Welsh assembly, and promptly called for a period of calm and continuity after the events that culminated in last week's resignation of his predecessor, Alun Michael.

Mr Morgan, who was elected unopposed, said he felt "tremendous emotion, honour and privilege" at having been appointed to a job he had given much thought to over the past two and a half years.

In a speech that mixed passion with humour, he said he wanted to inspire voters with a vision of devolution and "rebuild the bond of trust" between politicians of all parties and the people of Wales.

He said that if Welsh political giants such as Nye Bevan and Lloyd George could dream their dreams of how to improve society, assembly members could do so too, now that the new institution gave them a vehicle for improving the lives of the people of Wales.

Paying tribute to the hard work and dignity of his predecessor, Mr Morgan said the assembly could not allow the culling of first secretaries to become Wales's annual blood sport. His number one target, he said to laughter from fellow assembly members, was to survive until the half-term recess.

He paid "a huge tribute" to Mr Michael, who sat in the assembly chamber next to former Welsh secretary, Ron Davies, and behind his old seat. Mr Morgan said: "Nobody could have worked harder for Wales and nobody with an ounce of humanity about them could have failed to be moved by the dignity that he showed last week and is still showing now."

The opposition parties then welcomed the fresh start for the assembly. Plaid Cymru president, Dafydd Wigley, referred to Tony Blair's original attempt to block Mr Morgan's bid to become first secretary in favour of Alun Michael.

He said: "It is us here in Wales as parties and as an assembly who decide who are to be our leaders. Let that message go forth in no uncertain terms."

Meanwhile, the row over European funding which toppled Mr Michael spread to Scotland yesterday, with the Scottish National party calling for a full parliamentary inquiry after an independent report appeared to lend weight to claims that the treasury is breaking the additionality rules which require funds from Brussels to be matched by UK funding in Scotland as well as in Wales.

Gillian Bristow, of Cardiff Business School, says the method by which EU funds are dispersed to Wales and Scotland, through the block grant system, means neither country is getting its full entitlement.

"The EC says EU money should be additional to existing public expenditure," said Dr Bristow yesterday. "At present it is very difficult to assess that that is the case. In Wales it is probably not the case and the arguments are that the same thing must be happening in Scotland."

The SNP has estimated that Scotland has lost out on some £730m since 1993 because of the funding system.

The party is sending representatives to Wales today to hold talks with Plaid Cymru on the matter.

A treasury spokesman refuted suggestions that rules were being broken on the issue of additionality, and a spokesman for the Scottish executive said there was no question of Scotland having lost out because of the way structural funds are managed.

webTitle: 'His memory of remote events is impaired'

fields.headline: 'His memory of remote events is impaired'
fields.standfirst: The leaked medical report
fields.trailText: Senator Pinochet has a complex medical history, but the main active medical problems at present are diabetic peripheral neuropathy and recently progressive cerebrovascular brain damage. The diabetic neuropathology is contributing to difficulties in walking and to the observed tendency to postural hypertension. The diabetes will also have predisposed to arterial disease as will a past history of smoking
fields.body:
Senator Pinochet has a complex medical history, but the main active medical problems at present are diabetic peripheral neuropathy and recently progressive cerebrovascular brain damage. The diabetic neuropathology is contributing to difficulties in walking and to the observed tendency to postural hypertension. The diabetes will also have predisposed to arterial disease as will a past history of smoking

The cerebrovascular disease has manifested partly as minor strokes and transient asthmatic attacks but also causes progressive damage without acute symptoms. There is clinical evidence of extensive damage to the brain. This includes bilateral damage to pyramidal tracts to cause spasticity symptoms and to the basal ganglia producing features of parkinsonism.

The presence of "primitive" reflexes indicates damage to the frontal lobes and the memory defecit is comparable with bilateral damage to temporal lobe structures. Difficulties in comprehension are secondary to the memory deficit. While much of the damage is attributable to areas of the brain served by the basilar artery (shown to be calcified, in the CT scans) the frontal lobe impairment indicates more generalised arterial disease.

Fitness for trial

Physically: Senator Pinochet would at present be able to attend a trial but as features of cerebrovascular damage have progressed despite optimal treatment (with good control of diabetes and blood pressure and antiplaseler agents) further deterioration in both physical and mental condition is likely.

Mentally: It is our view that Senator Pinochet would not at the present be mentally capable of meaningful participation in a trial. We base this opinion on:

1. Memory defecit for both recent and remote events.

2. Limited ability to understand complex sentences and questions owing to memory impairment and consequent inability to process verbal information appropriately.

3. Impaired ability to express himself audibly, succinctly and relevantly.

4. Easy fatiguability

With these impediments he would be unable to follow the progress of a trial sufficiently to instruct counsel. He would have difficulty in understanding the content and implications of questions put to him and would have inadequate insight into his difficulty.

His memory of remote events is impaired. He would have difficulty making himself heard and understood in replying to questions.

We are satisfied that the impediments we have identified are due to brain damage, as they are coherent in nature and consistent in manifestation and formal neuropsychological testing showed none of the features of deliberate exaggeration of impairment. In particular those neuropsychological tests indicative of original intelligence and educational levels (such as the vocabulary scale of the WAIS)show superior performance. At present, Senator Pinochet shows no evidence of clinical depression.

Situational stress, as likely to be occasioned by trial, produces physiological responses that could accelerate the progression of vascular disease. We were told, however, that Senator Pinochet has in the past shown notable personal abilities in managing stress. We therefore do not feel able to express any useful opinion on the possible effects on his health of undergoing trial.

The major episodes of damage seem to have occurred in a cluster of thromboembolic events during September and October 1999.

There has been sufficient time for the great majority of any expected spontaneous recovery from these events to have taken place.

Although some day to day fluctuation in functional abilities is characteristic of brain damage due to cerebrovascular disease we consider further sustained functional improvement of a significant degree unlikely.

Background - the rest of the report:

Professor Sir John Grimley Evans, Dr M J Denham, and Professor Andrew Lees undertook a clinical consultation with Senator Pinochet at Norwick Park Hospital on January 25th 2000. The consultation was undertaken in Spanish.

Also present: Dr Henry Olivi (Observer) Prof. D J Thomas (Observer) Nurse Shelley Cape, Manuel Cerda (Senator Pinochet's valet)

Recent Medical History: Following surgical decompression of lumber spine in 1998 Senator Pinochet was troubled for some weeks by severe headache across the brow. This resolved spontaneously. For the last 8 to 9 months he has noted difficulty in walking and now can only cover 200 yards before his legs become too weak to continue. He now walks with a stick. Numbness of the soles of his feet has also progressed over that time.

Over the last ten months he has noticed a gradual progression of problems with memory which have become much more marked recently. He has difficulty in remembering people's names and in recalling dates and events of long ago.

Has been reported as talking as if he had difficulty in turning ideas into speech.

On September 9th 1999 Senator Pinochet was walking in the garden and developed a sudden headache and imbalance. Other episodes suggestive of transient cerebral dysfunction reported to us include once failing to recognise his wife and once failing to register that his son had visited him. He also recalls an episode in which his vision became dim for a short period.

When seen by Dr Thomas on September 14th Senator Pinochet showed nominal dysphasia and circumlocution together with a positive glabellar tab, blank facies, pour reflex and brisk jaw jerk. Gait was small stepped with instability on turning. The Romberg test was positive. Left-sided upper motor neuron weakness worse in leg than arm was noted as was short-term memory defect. The clinical diagnosis was of multiple small bilateral cerebral infarcts.

When reviewed later by Dr Thomas (letter 13.10.99) further deterioration with probable further cerebral ischaemic events on September 20th and October 9th. A definite increase in parkensonian features was noted, with parkensonian speech difficulty, deterioration in handwriting, inability to dress himself, and needing help with rising from chair and with transfers. Since then the senator has had two further falls, one in the garden and one in the bathroom, both due to loss of balance without impairment of consciousness. His voice noted as quiet in October has also deteriorated. There is a history or urinary symptoms - hesitancy, poor stream, urgency and occasional minor incontinence. He can generally stay in bed until early morning but thereafter may have to void 3 or 4 times.

Senator Pinochet was depressed last summer but following a change of therapy... this has ceased to be a problem. He still feels homesick and bored and frustrated by his physical ills. He wakes frequently at night. In recent months he has lost interest in former activities. He used to read and use the computer but now tends to sit watching television and says he has forgotten how to use the computer. Letter writing has become a chore and his handwriting less legible. Recently he has developed difficulty in shaving without cutting himself.

His appetite is unremarkable, weight steady recently following temporary loss during last year.

He has been troubled in recent months with aching pain in both buttocks, and his knees hurt in cold weather.

Postural hypotension has been recorded in the past, but this has improved since reduction in dosage of terazosin and stopping amlodipine (Dr Olivi).

Current Medication: Budesonide 400 ug b.d. Merformin 500 mg t.d.s. Finasteride 5 mg daily Nimodipine 30 mg b.d. Allopurinol 150 mg daily Amiodarone 200 mg daily Thyroxine 75 ug daily Terazosin 2.5 mg daily Citalopram 30 mg daily Clopidogrel 75 mg daily Terbutaline inhalation p.r.n

Examination: Senator Pinochet arrived in a wheelchair and was interviewed in bed. He is severely deaf but able to conduct conversation when his hearing aid in place. He was alert and co-operative but easily tired. His voice was quiet and monotonous in tone and speech was indistinct.

There was no abnormal lymphadenopathy. A well-healed lumbar laminectomy scar was noted Cardiovascular system: Pulse 65 regular (pacemaker in situ). No oedema, normal jugular venous pulse. Cardiac apex not palpable. Heart sounds normal. No carotid or abdominal bruits. Femoral and dorsalis pedis pulses present on both sides, posterior tibial pulses not palpable. Blood pressure 135/70 lying and standing on one occasion. 130/60 lying changing to 110/70 standing on another (associated with some unsteadiness).

Chest: Pacemaker in situ in left upper chest, no other abnormality detected.

Abdomen: Obese. Normal to inspection, no tenderness or guarding. Liver, spleen, kidneys and bladder not palpable. No abnormal masses.

Nervous System:
Cerebration: Showed slowness in comprehension with difficulty in understanding complex instructions. Showed bradyphrenia and circumlocutory speech but no lower level dysphasia. Mini Mental Status Examination score 23/30.

Mood: Good rapport and cooperative. Face immobile but smiled appropriately. Sense of humour intact. No evidence of depression.

Gait: Required help getting out of bed and in steadying when standing. Wide-based short paced gait holding stick in right hand and no swinging of left arm. Tendency to fall backwards. Turning unremarkable. Romberg - some swaying but did not fall.

Handwriting: tendency to micrographia

Primitive reflexes: Pour reflex present. Palmomental positive bilaterally left more than right. Jaw jerk normal. Glabellar tap positive.

Cranial Nerves:
I - Intact, but unable to name scents
II - Fields full to confrontation, discs normal and no retinopathy
III, IV, VI - External eye movement full, no impairment of upward gaze, no nystagmus. Pupils small symmetrical react to light.
V - Motor and sensory function intact all three divisions
VII - Full facial movements
VIII - Perceptive type deafness both ears, left worse than right
IX, X - Palate move normally mid line. Gag not tested
XI - Intact
XII - No fasciculation of tongue. Movements full in extent but reduced rapidity of sideways movements

Upper Limbs: Appearance normal, no tremor, no fasciculation. Tone increased bilaterally with cogwheeling bilaterally but more prominent on right. Some drift of left arm on extension. Power normal. Coordination difficult to interpret owing to patient's difficulty in understanding requirements. Possible subjective dulling of pinprick sensation distally but no impairment of light touch proprioception or vibration sense.

Reflexes normal and symmetrical.

Lower Limbs: Some fasciculation in both calves. Movement poor owing to painful joints. Tone increases bilaterally. Power symmetrical and good. Coordination normal on right, some impairment in left. Loss of light touch and pinprick sensation in stocking distribution to mid-calf level.

Proprioception impaired in toes. Vibration sensation absent from knees downwards, knee jerks present on reinforcement on right, unobtainable on left. Ankle jerks absent. Plantar responses extensor bilaterally.

Investigations: ACG showed consistent pacing at 65 beats per minute; further interpretation not possible owing to pacemaker artefact. Pacemaker electronically checked and found to be fully functional.

CT scan of brain basilar artery calcification, moderate generalized atrophy with evidence of lacunar infarcts. NO significant change from previous scan. (MRI not possible owing to presence of pacemaker).

Haemoglobin and blood picture, urea and electrolytes (including calcium) normal.

Neuropsychological assessment:
Undertaken in Spanish by Dr Maria A. Wyke, Devonshire Hospital, London. Tests included Spanish version of WAIS, Coloured Progressive Matrices, memory tests for designs, short story, pictured objects and Spanish version or paired associates.

Summary Report: "General Pinochet shows a moderate/severe deterioration of intellectual function beyond that due to his age. He was a person of superior intelligence and at present is functioning within the low average/average range. Short term memory, learning ability and delayed recall all show severe deficit. His greatest difficulty is his inability to retain information over time. There is no evidence that General Pinochet is attempting to fake disability. In my opinion he would not be able to cope with the legal complexities of a trial".

Gait was small stepped with instability on turning. The Romberg test was positive. Left-sided upper motor neuron weakness worse in leg than arm was noted as was short-term memory defect. The clinical diagnosis was of multiple small bilateral cerebral infarcts. When reviewed later by Dr Thomas (letter 13.10.99) further deterioration with probable further cerebral ischaemic events on September 20th and October 9th. A definite increase in parkensonian features was noted, with parkensonian speech difficulty, deterioration in handwriting, inability to dress himself, and needing help with rising from chair and with transfers. Since then the senator has had two further falls, one in the garden and one in the bathroom, both due to loss of balance without impairment of consciousness. His voice noted as quiet in October has also deteriorated. There is a history or urinary symptoms - hesitancy, poor stream, urgency and occasional minor incontinence. He can generally stay in bed until early morning but thereafter may have to void 3 or 4 times. Senator Pinochet was depressed last summer but following a change of therapy... this has ceased to be a problem. He still feels homesick and bored and frustrated by his physical ills. He wakes frequently at night. In recent months he has lost interest in former activities. He used to read and use the computer but now tends to sit watching television and says he has forgotten how to use the computer. Letter writing has become a chore and his handwriting less legible. Recently he has developed difficulty in shaving without cutting himself. His appetite is unremarkable, weight steady recently following temporary loss during last year. He has been troubled in recent months with aching pain in both buttocks, and his knees hurt in cold weather. Postural hypotension has been recorded in the past, but this has improved since reduction in dosage of terazosin and stopping amlodipine (Dr Olivi). Current Medication: Budesonide 400 ug b.d. Merformin 500 mg t.d.s. Finasteride 5 mg daily Nimodipine 30 mg b.d. Allopurinol 150 mg daily Amiodarone 200 mg daily Thyroxine 75 ug daily Terazosin 2.5 mg daily Citalopram 30 mg daily Clopidogrel 75 mg daily Terbutaline inhalation p.r.n Examination: Senator Pinochet arrived in a wheelchair and was interviewed in bed. He is severely deaf but able to conduct conversation when his hearing aid in place. He was alert and co-operative but easily tired. His voice was quiet and monotonous in tone and speech was indistinct. There was no abnormal lymphadenopathy. A well-healed lumbar laminectomy scar was noted Cardiovascular system: Pulse 65 regular (pacemaker in situ). No oedema, normal jugular venous pulse. Cardiac apex not palpable. Heart sounds normal. No carotid or abdominal bruits. Femoral and dorsalis pedis pulses present on both sides, posterior tibial pulses not palpable. Blood pressure 135/70 lying and standing on one occasion. 130/60 lying changing to 110/70 standing on another (associated with some unsteadiness). Chest: Pacemaker in situ in left upper chest, no other abnormality detected. Abdomen: Obese. Normal to inspection, no tenderness or guarding. Liver, spleen, kidneys and bladder not palpable. No abnormal masses. Nervous System: Cerebration: Showed slowness in comprehension with difficulty in understanding complex instructions. Showed bradyphrenia and circumlocutory speech but no lower level dysphasia. Mini Mental Status Examination score 23/30. Mood: Good rapport and cooperative. Face immobile but smiled appropriately. Sense of humour intact. No evidence of depression. Gait: Required help getting out of bed and in steadying when standing. Wide-based short paced gait holding stick in right hand and no swinging of left arm. Tendency to fall backwards. Turning unremarkable. Romberg - some swaying but did not fall. Handwriting: tendency to micrographia Primitive reflexes: Pour reflex present. Palmomental positive bilaterally left more than right. Jaw jerk normal. Glabellar tap positive. Cranial Nerves: I - Intact, but unable to name scents II - Fields full to confrontation, discs normal and no retinopathy III, IV, VI - External eye movement full, no impairment of upward gaze, no nystagmus. Pupils small symmetrical react to light. V - Motor and sensory function intact all three divisions VII - Full facial movements VIII - Perceptive type deafness both ears, left worse than right IX, X - Palate move normally mid line. Gag not tested XI - Intact XII - No fasciculation of tongue. Movements full in extent but reduced rapidity of sideways movements Upper Limbs: Appearance normal, no tremor, no fasciculation. Tone increased bilaterally with cogwheeling bilaterally but more prominent on right. Some drift of left arm on extension. Power normal. Coordination difficult to interpret owing to patient's difficulty in understanding requirements. Possible subjective dulling of pinprick sensation distally but no impairment of light touch proprioception or vibration sense. Reflexes normal and symmetrical. Lower Limbs: Some fasciculation in both calves. Movement poor owing to painful joints. Tone increases bilaterally. Power symmetrical and good. Coordination normal on right, some impairment in left. Loss of light touch and pinprick sensation in stocking distribution to mid-calf level. Proprioception impaired in toes. Vibration sensation absent from knees downwards, knee jerks present on reinforcement on right, unobtainable on left. Ankle jerks absent. Plantar responses extensor bilaterally. Investigations: ACG showed consistent pacing at 65 beats per minute; further interpretation not possible owing to pacemaker artefact. Pacemaker electronically checked and found to be fully functional. CT scan of brain basilar artery calcification, moderate generalized atrophy with evidence of lacunar infarcts. NO significant change from previous scan. (MRI not possible owing to presence of pacemaker). Haemoglobin and blood picture, urea and electrolytes (including calcium) normal. Neuropsychological assessment: Undertaken in Spanish by Dr Maria A. Wyke, Devonshire Hospital, London. Tests included Spanish version of WAIS, Coloured Progressive Matrices, memory tests for designs, short story, pictured objects and Spanish version or paired associates. Summary Report: "General Pinochet shows a moderate/severe deterioration of intellectual function beyond that due to his age. He was a person of superior intelligence and at present is functioning within the low average/average range. Short term memory, learning ability and delayed recall all show severe deficit. His greatest difficulty is his inability to retain information over time. There is no evidence that General Pinochet is attempting to fake disability. In my opinion he would not be able to cope with the legal complexities of a trial".

fields.headline: Stitching up Ken
fields.standfirst: Labour's 10 top ruses to stop Ken Livingstone
fields.trailText:
1. Drop one member, one vote
Last spring, the government's then minister for London Nick Raynsford promised parliament that Labour would choose its candidate for the London mayor by one member, one vote. Last summer, the Labour leadership reneged on its plan, creating an electoral college, with the vote split between party members, MPs and unions. It gave everyone of the 75 MPs, MEPs and GLA candidates a vote worth those of about 1,000 party members.
fields.body:
1. Drop one member, one vote
Last spring, the government's then minister for London Nick Raynsford promised parliament that Labour would choose its candidate for the London mayor by one member, one vote. Last summer, the Labour leadership reneged on its plan, creating an electoral college, with the vote split between party members, MPs and unions. It gave everyone of the 75 MPs, MEPs and GLA candidates a vote worth those of about 1,000 party members.

2. Delay the vote
Labour were initially set to decide their candidate in late summer 1999. Summer turned to autumn and finally Frank Dobson was encouraged to join the race. After Mr Dobson threatened to quit the mayoral contest in November, the Labour party's selection committee meeting at its Millbank HQ finally agreed to let Ken Livingstone stand.

With Mr Dobson trailing in the polls, Labour announced it would further delay the ballot until February 2000. This was widely believed to be a calculated attempt to deny Mr Livingstone enough time to mount an independent campaign in the May elections if he failed to win Labour's nomination.

3. Ban a secret ballot
MPs, MEPs and GLA candidates were not allowed to have a secret ballot on the candidates, instead being given numbered ballot papers. Given the current party culture in which loyalty is rewarded above all else, MPs who went against the preference of the Labour leadership and backed Mr Livingstone were likely to be identified and ostracised.

Rudolf Vis, the MP for Finchley and Golders Green, told his local party that he was offered extra help from the Labour party in the next general election if he abandoned his intention to abstain in the ballot.

4. Give Dobson exclusive membership lists
Frank Dobson was given a complete list of Labour's London membership by Euro MP Richard Balfe in October 1999, breaking Millbank rules which decreed that membership lists could only be given to MPs, Euro-MPs or constituency party secretaries, and not to candidates in internal party elections. Mr Dobson promptly spent £20,000 on a mailshot.

Panorama revealed that this was only possible following the intervention of a senior party official, but the party hierarchy refused to release the lists to Mr Livingstone and Ms Jackson until Mr Balfe handed them over in January 1999. He had already given Mr Dobson a three-month campaigning advantage. The data protection registrar was called in to investigate Mr Dobson.

5. Bring back the block vote
The Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union (AEEU) refused to ballot its members. Instead it cast 50,000 votes through 73 union delegates, who decided to back Frank Dobson. It gives Mr Dobson just under 4% of the entire vote in Labour's mayoral electoral college. Ken Livingstone says: "There should be no place for this kind of thing in 2000." The Co-operative party also refused to ballot its members.

6. Misinform the public
Tony Blair claimed that Labour selected its candidate for London mayor "through an electoral college in exactly the same way as it elected me". He was wrong. In the electoral college that elected Mr Blair, all unions had to ballot their members. He also claimed that Ken Livingstone "does not have the support of a single London councillor". Dozens wrote to the Guardian declaring Mr Livingstone had their backing. Downing Street repeatedly briefed against Mr Livingstone.

7. Apply different rules for unions
The Manufacturing Science and Finance union and the train drivers' union Aslef were banned from taking part in the electoral college because they didn't pay their Labour party affiliation fees on time. MSF received a letter from Millbank several days after the MSF London executive was recommended by 28-1 to vote for Ken Livingstone. A secret ballot of Aslef members gave 1,479 votes to Mr Livingstone, compared with 96 for Glenda Jackson and 60 for Frank Dobson. Neither unions' votes will count.

In contrast, Labour party members were given until the ballot papers were sent out in January to ensure lapsed membership fees were fully paid up. MSF's court appeal failed, despite the union being able to participate in past party votes while paying late. In 1997 the MSF London region was allowed to take part in the Greater London Labour conference, even though it didn't pay till 1998.

8. Give retired loyalists a vote
The former MEP and Labour loyalist Pauline Green was allowed to vote in the MPs' section, despite the fact that she retired as an MEP last year and now works for the Co-operative Union in Manchester.

9. Seal it with a letter
A letter from the prime minister - who vigorously campaigned for Frank Dobson and criticised Mr Livingstone and Ms Jackson - was included with members ballot papers when they were sent out in January. Mr Livingstone claimed the letter was, in effect, an endorsement of Mr Dobson.

10. Rig the vote?
The party arranged a minimum three-day gap between the end of the voting on February 15 and announcing the winner, to allow appeals and complaints about the process. Frank Dobson's spokeswoman called it "unprecedented"; Ken Livingstone said it was "an open invitation to fraud".

Millbank has indicated it will not announce the result until all candidates agree the vote was a fair result. It appears one final rule designed to stop Ken Livingstone running as an independent if the Labour party's six-month stitch-up engineers a defeat he is forced to accept as free and fair.

webTitle: Troubled Water may not be filmed in India

fields.headline: Troubled Water may not be filmed in India
fields.trailText: A nationalist Hindu group has said that acclaimed director Deepa Mehta must radically alter the screenplay of her new film Water if she wants to shoot the film in India
fields.body:
A nationalist Hindu group has said that acclaimed directorDeepa Mehta must radically alter the screenplay of her new film Water if she wants to shoot the film in India.

The Vishwa Hindu Parishad (World Hindu Council) believes that the third part in the Canadian-based director's elements trilogy which focuses on the plight of Hindu widows in the holy city of Varanasi during the 1930s, is a denigration of Hinduism, and would only consider changing its position if senior Hindu priests cleared a less controversial script.

The statement came after the Hindu nationalist state government of Uttar Pradesh this week banned Mehta from shooting the film because of demonstrations and an attempted protest suicide by a Hindu nationalist in Varanasi.

The director is now considering an invitation to shoot the film in the opposition Congress party-ruled state of Madhya Pradesh, but has to await official permission from central government.

fields.headline: Hague disputes Blair's good news
fields.trailText: The Conservative leader  William Hague today labelled Tony Blair "all mouth and no delivery" for failing to fulfil promises made last year on police numbers, NHS waiting lists and asylum-seekers.
fields.body:
The Conservative leader William Hague today labelled Tony Blair "all mouth and no delivery" for failing to fulfil promises made last year on police numbers, NHS waiting lists and asylum-seekers.

To loud cheers from his own benches, Mr Hague challenged the prime minister to read out recent official statistics which contradicted his claims that police numbers had fallen, that waiting lists had lengthened and that assessments of asylum applications had speeded up.

Mr Blair dismissed the charges during heated Question Time exchanges in the Commons, and insisted all Labour's pledges would be met, as he has claimed, by the time of the next general election.

Mr Blair also insisted waiting lists were lower than the level inherited from the Tories, a record 5,000 extra police were to be recruited and new measures would speed up handling of asylum cases. He claimed that currently 4,000 applications were being processed every month, with 8,000 a month by the late spring.

He argued that all these measures would cost money, yet the Tories planned to put their "tax guarantee" policy before increases in public spending.

Mr Blair said the Tory tax guarantee was a "boom and bust guarantee" and an "NHS cuts guarantee" as he claimed Labour would put investment in while the Tories would take it out.

In earlier more sombre exchanges the prime minister vowed to bring to justice those named as being involved in the Welsh child abuse scandal.

After Tuesday's publication of the Waterhouse report, Mr Hague called for resources to be made available to track down 28 people pinpointed as being involved but whose whereabouts was currently unknown. He demanded that such cases be investigated and, where appropriate, prosecutions brought to ensure they never worked with children again.

The opposition leader, who commissioned the report when he was Welsh secretary in 1996, added: "We now know that hundreds of the most vulnerable children in our society were cruelly betrayed.

"The inquiry has come up with many sensible recommendations. Can you give a clear timetable for responding to this report and for action particularly with regard to the creation of a children's commissioner for children in care for all parts of the UK?"

Mr Blair said the Care Standards Bill gave an opportunity for the Government to respond to the report's recommendations. He said the children's rights director would be a senior post within the national care standards commission, which would "drive forward raising standards of care in these homes".

The prime minister pledged: "We will implement the measures as soon as we possibly can in respect of all the other recommendations of the report."

In answer to a challenge from the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy, Mr Blair stressed that Britain would join the euro "only in circumstances where it is economically beneficial to the country".

He argued that the decision on when to call a referendum would be based on the economic situation - not anti or pro-European ideology.

"The (economic) tests should surely be British jobs and British investment and British industry - that is a sensible test," he said. "We should not rule out joining the euro for political reasons, which is the position of the Conservative party, but neither should we be in the position where we join regardless of the economic conditions.

"That is surely to the best benefit of the whole of British industry."

However, Mr Kennedy called on Mr Blair "to engage more seriously" in the task of winning public support for euro entry, warning: "Sentiment is slipping away from the sensible pro-euro case."

Mr Blair insisted: "The case of the Government is that we should apply the tests of the economic conditions.

"I believe it is where the vast majority of the British people are, that they want to be in a position where the test is one of Britain's national interest.

"The test is British jobs and British industry and British investment and they believe it is right they should have the ultimate say in a referendum."

fields.headline: The best real estate scene
fields.standfirst: American Beauty
fields.trailText: Suburbia. The ever-spruce Carolyn Burnham (Annette Bening) stands before the curtains of her latest property, a slightly down-at-heel condo. Her eyes brighten; she straightens her back.
fields.body:
Suburbia. The ever-spruce Carolyn Burnham (Annette Bening) stands before the curtains of her latest property, a slightly down-at-heel condo. Her eyes brighten; she straightens her back.

"I will sell this house today."

Cut to Carolyn, on her hands and knees cleaning the kitchen.

"I will sell this house today."

She arranges flowers in the lounge.

"I will sell this house today."

Carolyn shows a pair of sullen, middle-aged women into the house.

"Welcome! I'm Carolyn Burnham. This living room is very dramatic. But wait until you see the native stone fireplace!"

She hovers in the bedroom.

"Cream would really lighten this place up. You could even put in skylights!"

On to the kitchen.

"A dream come true for any cook!"

Outside, Carolyn stands beside the pool with her disgruntled clients.

"We were told this pool was lagoon-like. There's nothing lagoon-like about it."

"Except the bugs."

"There aren't even any plants out here."

Carolyn's smile freezes. She motions toward a bush.

"What do you call this? Is this not a plant? If you have a problem with the plants, I can call my landscape architect."

"I think lagoons, I think tropical. This is a... hole."

Back in the house, alone again, Carolyn weeps. Suddenly she slaps herself around the face.

"Shut up! You're weak! You baby! Shut up! SHUT UP!"

See also: Glengarry Glen Ross, The Two Jakes, Psycho

Don't see also: Indecent Proposal

Pointless trivia: Annette Bening has described Hilary Clinton's bid to become Senator of New York as the work of "an opportunist".

fields.headline: Forced change
fields.standfirst:
Gerard Lemos calls for special police race units in all areas with large ethnic communities
Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Gerard Lemos calls for special police race units in all areas with large ethnic communities.
fields.body:
It will be a year ago on February 24 that Jack Straw put before parliament the report of the inquiry by Sir William Macpherson into the murder of Stephen Lawrence. Straw told MPs that "the central and most important issue for the inquiry was racism and whether and how that affected the handling of the case". Macpherson famously concluded "the [murder] investigation was marred by a combination of professional incompetence, institutional racism and a failure of leadership by senior officers". Soul-searching has ensued - not just in the Metropolitan police, but in many public services. Were they guilty of institutional racism? What should they do about it?

It is too early to tell whether Straw's action plan to implement the recommendations of the inquiry has had a decisive, positive impact. The Police Inspectorate, in their second report on policing London, noted "the effort, energy and leadership commitment to improving service to minority ethnic communities was impressive". They particularly recognised the work of specialist officers in the Met's Racial and Violent Crime Task Force, led by John Grieve, which was set up in response to the Stephen Lawrence case, but before the report of the inquiry was published.

But the wider picture in the Met still troubles the inspectorate. It states: "Whilst those working within the specialist units are beginning to see positive results, there is more to be done in securing the professional hearts and minds of non-specialist police officers. A pervasive feeling exists amongst some staff that what is seen as special treatment for the victims of racist attacks can only be delivered by prejudicing services to the wider community."

The absence of a commitment stretching beyond senior people and specialists may explain the stream of apparently racist murders and inadequate investigations that are belatedly coming to light. Michael Menson, Ricky Reel and Harold and Jason McGowan, the two men found hung in Telford, show that justice is only secured after pressure from strong, articulate families with campaigning legal advisers and lots of media savvy - and even then, not always.

Attempts to change the culture of institutionally racist organisations, even self-confessed ones, is a long game. Meanwhile, practical measures to improve responses to black communities can get lost in the abstract labyrinths of complex systems analysis as applied to racial discrimination.

With funds from the home office, the DTR, the Joseph Rowntree Foundation and the Housing Corporation, Lemos&Crane are researching action to tackle racial harassment in the 70 areas of the country in which 98% of Britain's ethnic minority communities live. The picture beginning to emerge - admittedly, still in the early days - is one of discussion, strategising, planning, report writing and lots of meetings. This is much influenced by the statutory requirement on the police and local authorities to consult local people and devise community safety strategies for their areas. But specific examples of effective action are proving harder to find.

The framework for tackling racial attacks is still, even after Stephen Lawrence, the multi-agency approaches set out in successive reports from the home office and the home affairs select committee since 1981. Nineteen years later, there is little consistently reliable data, huge under-reporting of racial incidents and a frustrating lack of co-operation and communication between local agencies.

In the important fight to understand the workings and consequences of institutional racism the police and other agencies may be in danger of taking their eye off the ball. The most pressing requirement for a successful strategy to tackle racial attacks is not, for example, changing children's attitudes through the national curriculum, as recommended by the Macpherson inquiry, however important this might be. fields.headline: Call that acting, Lightyear?
fields.standfirst: Mr Potato Head has become a stereotype, Rex the dinosaur is a whining kvetch, and poor Buzz Lightyear is, well,  bland .  Annalena McAfee explains why, despite the box-office records they set this weekend, the toys from Toy Story 2 should find a new director - and a better script
fields.trailText: Mr Potato Head has become a stereotype, Rex the dinosaur is a whining kvetch, and poor Buzz Lightyear is, well, bland . Annalena McAfee explains why, despite the box-office records they set this weekend, the toys from Toy Story 2 should find a new director - and a better script.
fields.body:
Dazzling technical virtuosity . . . ingenious wit . . . subtle characterisation . . . superb acting . . . the ground-breaking, cross-generational film of the year. No, make that the decade. For once, it seems, the critics got it right. Only the year was 1995, and the film was Toy Story, the magnificent computer-generated account of the travails of the inhabitants of a suburban American toybox. Now it is Groundhog Day for superlatives as reviewers unanimously welcome the arrival of Toy Story 2. Ingenious characterisation . . . superb technical effects . . . dazzling wit . . . the boundary-breaching film for all ages. This time, however, they're wrong. Whisper it soft - unless you want hate mail from under-13s and film critics - but Toy Story 2 is, in fact, not very good.

The sequel, which made a record-breaking £7.75m in the UK last weekend and has been deemed one of the 20 all-time highest grossing films in the US, is a pale, pixelated phantom of its glorious predecessor.

The visual effects are still remarkable; the startling verisimilitude of the animation, the swooping perspectives, the vivid colours, the pristine planes and rendered textures. But wit, characterisation, dialogue, plot, jokes? No one likes to be identified as a joyless curmudgeon but it has to be said that you'll find more complexity in first generation Space Invaders than you will in this smug sequel. Where the original Toy Story bristled with swift, subversive one-liners, engaging adults and children without patronising either, this pasteurised, homogenised version relies on cheap slapstick and heavy-handed, pointedly-trailed gags: how much more humour can be milked from the near-parodic Star Wars?

While the plot of the original movie was seamlessly structured, contrasting the Eden of life with owner Andy to the Inferno of Sid's post-punk nightmare next door, its sequel offers a hectic, one-note sequence of chase and rescue, and the bad guy's lair is simply a drab museum of 50s artefacts.

And what has happened to the characters? In the first film, the wonderful Wally Shawn's cowardly dinosaur, Rex, suggested a reptile who had spent several years in inconclusive therapy. Now he's simply a whining kvetch. The original acerbic Mr Potato Head, whose misaligned features prompted references to Picasso portraiture, is now locked in a stereotypical henpecked relationship with an over-solicitous wife.

There is one genuinely funny sequence involving a Busby Berkeley routine by grinning Barbie dolls but, overall, the film is a dizzying triumph of form over content. And what of Buzz Lightyear, that relic of the great days of space exploration, when the world was young, the Kennedys were the perfect American family and McDonalds were members of a blameless Scottish clan?

In Toy Story, Buzz's epiphany - when he finally realised that he was a child's plaything rather than a pioneering astronaut - was a transcendent moment of tragedy and cathartic humour. In the new movie, he's blandly reconciled to his role as team leader of the chase-and-rescue mission and an allusion to his earlier identity crisis - he encounters a doppelgänger, who is still convinced that infinity and beyond are in his grasp - is speedily dealt with as the frantic pursuit resumes.

Woody the cowboy - that genial reminder of America's terrestrial pioneering days (James Stewart would have been perfect carbon-based casting) - commands what passes for complexity in this new story when he is stolen by an overweight, halitositic toy collector and meets Jessie, an assertive cowgirl.

There is a promising plot strand when it is Woody's turn to face an identity crisis; like Odysseus's lotus eaters or the Snow Queen's Kai, he is tempted to turn his back on his past and exist, unquestioning, in an undemanding present. But it is at this point that every shred of subtlety is drenched in confectioners' sugar as Jessie, hitherto a thigh-slapping proponent of girl power, sings a song of such ghastly lachrymosity that it might well be covered by Sir Cliff on his next album. The song, devoid of a single redeeming note of the irony that enriched Toy Story, is pure Disney. Strip away the computer-generated images and we're back with the soupy, smoochy torch songs which, for children, have marred every cartoon from Bambi to the Lion King. The cowgirl's song - to quote one eminent film critic who was, alas, commenting on another movie - brought out the child in me, and the child in me wanted to throw up.

What has gone wrong? Conspiracy theorists might find clues in the title sequences of the film - Pixar, the company responsible for the creative genius behind Toy Story, offers a witty animated sequence referring to its own humble grassroots. Disney, the global merchandiser of sentimentality, claims credit with its portentous logo. Was innovative Pixar crushed in Disney's sugar mill?

But the clever creators of Toy Story have to take some blame for this sad falling-off. The self-congratulatory "out-takes" of fluffed lines and corpsing "actors" in the closing credits suggest that, fatally, they had begun to believe their own publicity. This problem has faced many charged with the task of making sequels to unexpected, runaway - and deserved - successes. Those involved can be too close to the project, accentuate the wrong aspects and overlook the real charm of the original.

Perhaps a second sequel, Toy Story 3, will eschew the saccharine and bring back the subversion. Meanwhile, children will, of course, love Toy Story 2, the box office will boom and the entire thesaurus of superlatives will continue to be deployed. The picture is certainly worth seeing, but joyless curmudgeons are urged to wear earplugs. Or rent a video of the peerless Toy Story instead.

fields.headline: Hick charts England's progress
fields.trailText: Three years ago England played their first one-day international in Zimbabwe at this ground. They went down by two wickets and went on to lose the series 3-0. Defeat today and this brittle England side might have gone on to make that whitewash look like a heroic triumph. Forget World Cup 2003. England need to win now. And, for once, they did so under pressure.
fields.body:
Three years ago England played their first one-day international in Zimbabwe at this ground. They went down by two wickets and went on to lose the series 3-0. Defeat today and this brittle England side might have gone on to make that whitewash look like a heroic triumph. Forget World Cup 2003. England need to win now. And, for once, they did so under pressure.

At 109 for 5 with the required rate creeping up to a run a ball, England were in the sort of position from which they tend to implode. But Graeme Hick, reaching double-figures for only the second time in seven innings against his former countrymen, added both a dash of Worcestershire sauce and 90 unbroken runs for the sixth wicket with Mark Ealham (36*) to buck the trend.

OK, so this wasn't a day/night game (when England's run-chases seem doomed before they have begun), but it was the first ODI they have won this winter without having to rely on a century stand for the first wicket between Nasser Hussain and Nick Knight. And - another first - one of England's lower/middle-order, Ealham, finally made a noteworthy contribution.

The others remain a worry. Darren Maddy is compact and eager, but once opposing captains plug his favourite shovel through square-leg, he'll be even more out of his depth than he already is. Vikram Solanki is capable of treading water at least, but he was all at sea today, and could have been dismissed three times before he was bowled going for a lazy cut shot. (His brief international cv now reads 7, 14, 16*, 10 and 11.) Craig White may have fallen to a brilliant catch by Henry Olonga, but a) he shouldn't have made a meal of a slow full-toss, and b) he shouldn't be batting as high as No.6 anyway.

There were two other areas of concern. England shouldn't have allowed Grant Flower to be so dominant at the end of the Zimbabwean innings on a sluggish pitch. And they certainly shouldn't have allowed him to get away with figures of 10-1-27-3, when his previous 118 matches had brought him 44 wickets.

But these are minor carps. England did it in style in the end, and there were even signs that they're beginning to think a bit more as well. With the weather a constant threat, the pressure was atmospheric too, and Hick assiduously kept one eye on a Duckworth/Lewis chart he had in his pocket. Three years ago, England probably wouldn't have managed that either.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: We have contact
fields.standfirst: How can two people who can't even bear to be in the same room share access to their child?  Dave Hill  visits the Accord centre and finds out
fields.trailText: How can two people who can't even bear to be in the same room share access to their child? Dave Hill visits the Accord centre and finds out.
fields.body:
Nina walks in with her smiling children, a boy aged seven and a girl aged six. The girl picks out some notes on a toy piano. The boy takes out some felt pens and draws a picture of me. We are in an upstairs room at the Accord contact centre in north-west London, talking, but mostly waiting. In half an hour's time, the children will say goodbye to Nina, descend to the ground floor and go into another room full of toys. There they will meet their father. These days, they never meet him in any other place. But if they didn't meet him there, they might not even know him.

Nina's children's father is an alcoholic. His drinking fuelled the violence that led to his divorce from Nina, and the courts have ruled that his continuing dependence makes it unsafe for him to exercise his right to contact - what used to be called "access" - with his son and daughter anywhere except under the auspices of the Accord. One of 277 contact centres in the country, the Accord is the biggest. It was set up in 1997 by Welcare Community Projects, and provides specialised services that are beyond the scope of most others. Its core purpose, though, is the same as more modest centres, which may comprise only a handful of volunteers and a church hall: to provide an impartial location where younger children - most are under 10 - may keep alive relationships with estranged parents that otherwise would lapse or even die.

Contact centres contend with some of the rawest emotions and deepest fears that arise from family breakdown. Many of the parents who use their services are unlikely ever to make the kinds of voluntary agreements that might otherwise be achieved with the help of mediators. Most are in the thick of post-separation acrimony and although some troubled families approach centres for help of their own volition - and are welcome to do so - the great majority are referred by the courts or social workers while legal settlements are argued over, sometimes for years. There is often such ill-feeling between the parents that a contact centre is the only place where they can transfer their children to each other's care without quarrelling or worse.

The building has good security arrangements and enough rooms to keep feuding parents separate. It helps that there is no car park - "That's where all the fights start," remarks one of the Accord's staff, who has seen it happen elsewhere.

Movement within the Accord building is managed with great care. When the parent with whom the child still lives - the "carer parent" - arrives at the centre they go to their own special room where they and their children await the arrival of the "contact parent" in the contact room (aka the "bumblebee room"). Nina and her children are well used to the procedure - they are Accord veterans - but for others, especially those new to it, making the move into the bumblebee room can be fraught. Children may be anxious about meeting contact parents, perhaps because they haven't seen them for some time, perhaps because of past bad experiences, perhaps because their other parent has been turning them against the contact parent. Coaxing a reluctant child can be one of the hardest parts of the job for the Accord's staff, especially if the carer parent deepens that reluctance.

Julia Wise-St Leger, Welcare's chief executive of the Accord centre, has no doubt where responsibility lies in such situations: "We will say to the carer parent that it is their responsibility to help the child feel happy to meet their other parent, even if it sometimes means going with them at first."

Mixed feelings, inevitably, are common on all sides. In the bumblebee room, a young man plays mini-snooker with his small son; they are each clearly delighted by the other. Nina's children are happy, too. Dad used to turn up too drunk to stay awake, but not any more. Sober, he seems fragile and almost childlike himself. The three of them look totally at ease. Another father, though, is deeply unhappy. Sunil and his wife are going through a painful divorce and, at least for now, his time with his son, aged just 14 months, is restricted by court order to a short period at a contact centre every Saturday. On this occasion, though, Sunil's wife had failed to turn up with the child: further proof, he believes, that she is intent on stopping him from building a proper relationship with the child.

In such situations a contact centre can only try to persuade defaulters to behave otherwise. Similarly, it cannot always still the fears of those who honour court orders that they are unhappy about. Another user of the centre, Mary, is happy enough for her older son to see his father at the Accord: "I feel the boy needs contact with his father, but I wouldn't want him having it anywhere else. I feel this is a good place, a safe place. He's not capable of looking after the boy anywhere else." However, she would rather keep her younger son away from his father, at least for now. "He never wanted the second boy, and has never shown the slightest concern for him. The child has become asthmatic since he started coming here to see him; I'm sure it's because of anxiety." As for the father, he resents having to use the contact centre at all.

Dealing with parental resistance is part of the centre's work. Just as some carer parents don't want their children to see the estranged parent anywhere, ever, many contact parents feel stigmatised by being reduced to seeing their children in an artificial setting, however child-friendly. The Accord's approach is to stress that children's needs must come first, and that the centre aims to help everyone move forward. That entails providing more than just a physical space. All Accord clients have to make a "pre-visit" so that Wise-St Leger can make her own assessment of each situation and prepare suitably. Contact parents with agreements or court permission may take children off the premises during their contact period, sometimes just to a nearby McDonald's, sometimes further afield. Others have to be kept safely indoors.

Providing "supported contact" can be a delicate business, requiring staff, some of whom are trained volunteers, to facilitate play and interaction between parents and children, but also to be watchful. As one volunteer acknowledges: "You have to make sure nothing is going on, such as the wrong sort of touching. That happens very rarely, but I have sometimes been asked to keep an eye. It's an uncomfortable position to be in." Serious accusations can be made. One former Accord client, Harry, had precisely that experience. His former wife alleged that "interference" was taking place in the main contact room. Though sickened by the accusation, Harry went along with the Accord's suggestion that his contact sessions be supervised in a separate room. This meant the entire session being observed and a report compiled. There was no evidence of abuse, and the Accord's report was used to vindicate Harry in court. He now sees his children on a freer basis, but still comes back to the Accord to work as a volunteer.

The need for more people like Harry is increasing as the demand for contact centres rises. The National Association of Child Contact Centres is aiming to increase the number of centres to 400, and its chief executive, Eunice Halliday, has recently urged the government to release more resources so that this target can be met. It is not hard to sympathise with the cause. At present, some 19,000 children use one to keep in touch with estranged parents at an intensely difficult times in their young lives. Many more would surely cherish the chance to wear smiles as wide as Nina's children's as they play in the safety of the contact centre, laughing with their dad.
