Julia Wise-St Leger, Welcare's chief executive of the Accord centre, has no doubt where responsibility lies in such situations: "We will say to the carer parent that it is their responsibility to help the child feel happy to meet their other parent, even if it sometimes means going with them at first." Mixed feelings, inevitably, are common on all sides. In the bumblebee room, a young man plays mini-snooker with his small son; they are each clearly delighted by the other. Nina's children are happy, too. Dad used to turn up too drunk to stay awake, but not any more. Sober, he seems fragile and almost childlike himself. The three of them look totally at ease. Another father, though, is deeply unhappy. Sunil and his wife are going through a painful divorce and, at least for now, his time with his son, aged just 14 months, is restricted by court order to a short period at a contact centre every Saturday. On this occasion, though, Sunil's wife had failed to turn up with the child: further proof, he believes, that she is intent on stopping him from building a proper relationship with the child. In such situations a contact centre can only try to persuade defaulters to behave otherwise. Similarly, it cannot always still the fears of those who honour court orders that they are unhappy about. Another user of the centre, Mary, is happy enough for her older son to see his father at the Accord: "I feel the boy needs contact with his father, but I wouldn't want him having it anywhere else. I feel this is a good place, a safe place. He's not capable of looking after the boy anywhere else." However, she would rather keep her younger son away from his father, at least for now. "He never wanted the second boy, and has never shown the slightest concern for him. The child has become asthmatic since he started coming here to see him; I'm sure it's because of anxiety." As for the father, he resents having to use the contact centre at all. Dealing with parental resistance is part of the centre's work. Just as some carer parents don't want their children to see the estranged parent anywhere, ever, many contact parents feel stigmatised by being reduced to seeing their children in an artificial setting, however child-friendly. The Accord's approach is to stress that children's needs must come first, and that the centre aims to help everyone move forward. That entails providing more than just a physical space. All Accord clients have to make a "pre-visit" so that Wise-St Leger can make her own assessment of each situation and prepare suitably. Contact parents with agreements or court permission may take children off the premises during their contact period, sometimes just to a nearby McDonald's, sometimes further afield. Others have to be kept safely indoors. Providing "supported contact" can be a delicate business, requiring staff, some of whom are trained volunteers, to facilitate play and interaction between parents and children, but also to be watchful. As one volunteer acknowledges: "You have to make sure nothing is going on, such as the wrong sort of touching. That happens very rarely, but I have sometimes been asked to keep an eye. It's an uncomfortable position to be in." Serious accusations can be made. One former Accord client, Harry, had precisely that experience. His former wife alleged that "interference" was taking place in the main contact room. Though sickened by the accusation, Harry went along with the Accord's suggestion that his contact sessions be supervised in a separate room. This meant the entire session being observed and a report compiled. There was no evidence of abuse, and the Accord's report was used to vindicate Harry in court. He now sees his children on a freer basis, but still comes back to the Accord to work as a volunteer. The need for more people like Harry is increasing as the demand for contact centres rises. The National Association of Child Contact Centres is aiming to increase the number of centres to 400, and its chief executive, Eunice Halliday, has recently urged the government to release more resources so that this target can be met. It is not hard to sympathise with the cause. At present, some 19,000 children use one to keep in touch with estranged parents at an intensely difficult times in their young lives. Many more would surely cherish the chance to wear smiles as wide as Nina's children's as they play in the safety of the contact centre, laughing with their dad.

fields.headline: Can he play football?
fields.trailText: Alex is eight and has cerebral palsy. For eight years, friends, neighbours, passers-by have asked his mother questions. Does he know his name? Does he go to school? Does he keep still when he sleeps? And always lurking in the background is the Big One: what is it like to have a disabled child? In her new fortnightly column, Alex's mother reveals all.
fields.body:
Alex is eight and has cerebral palsy. For eight years, friends, neighbours, passers-by have asked his mother questions. Does he know his name? Does he go to school? Does he keep still when he sleeps? And always lurking in the background is the Big One: what is it like to have a disabled child? In her new fortnightly column, Alex's mother reveals all.

Rosie, seven, an otherwise sweet and intelligent girl, had declined to sit next to my son the last time she met us because he dribbled. Yuk! Indeed, she had avoided coming anywhere near him the whole day. Before our next meeting, I asked her parents to talk to her about cerebral palsy but I had no way of knowing if they had done so.

They had. Rosie ran helter-skelter into the house and made a beeline for Alex. "He's a poor little boy, isn't he? I know about children like him . . ." She stopped, and put on a very devout expression. "If I had one wish, I'd wish that all little boys like you could stop being poorly." I cringed.

Alex, despite not being able to talk at all clearly, has two special friends of his own age at his mainstream school, Simon and Tom.

Simon is a child who has his own difficulties in life. He finds school work hard, and doesn't make friends easily - yet he is possibly the most good-natured little boy I've ever come across. Simon loves playing football, but when he's with Alex they like playing boardgames together, painting, cooking and making a mess.

But I have a sneaking feeling that what they like doing best is cuddling up on the sofa to watch TV. Simon drapes his arm round Alex's shoulders, Alex rests his head trustingly on Simon's chest; their expressions are of dreamy contentment and togetherness.

Tom is the opposite. He's bright, with a massive amount of energy and the gift of the gab. Mostly, he follows Alex around, hanging onto his arm and chattering about just about everything in the world, and Alex listens with a slight smile on his face. Tom is particularly into "inventing things", and has already mentally designed a stairlift and a walking device. When he's not recounting and explaining, he is keen on dancing around Alex, playing the fool to make him laugh or even improvising little puppet shows for his entertainment.

The other day, when Alex took a long time to pick up a dice, Tom said, "It won't keep till tomorrow you know!" Later, while they played on the computer, Tom exclaimed, "Ugh, Alex, stop dribbling on my arm!" Watching them, my heart contracted, and my spirits took a nosedive . . .

But there was no need to worry - they were both smiling, and soon moved on to the next thing.

fields.headline: Dirty war against allergy
fields.standfirst: Lucy Atkins  on why clean living isn't always best for your children
fields.trailText: Last week's issue of the British Medical Journal seems to contain good news for people like me whose cleaning skills aren't all they should be. A team of Italian scientists has found that exposure to some nasty bugs might actually help to prevent children from developing allergies.
fields.body:
These days I seem to spend much of my time chasing my one-year-old through the house, extracting filthy objects from her jaws and yanking her hands from grimy crevices. I do my best to keep her clean, but as I scrape partially digested foodstuffs from floors, carpets and walls, I get the sense that she's only a mouthful away from botulism. Last week's issue of the British Medical Journal, though, seems to contain good news for people like me whose cleaning skills aren't all they should be. A team of Italian scientists has found that exposure to some nasty bugs might actually help to prevent children from developing allergies.

Given that one in three children in Britain today suffers from allergies and that each year asthma kills 2,000 people and soaks up £2bn of our taxes, any scientific breakthrough has got to be good news. The Italian team, led by Dr Paolo Matricardi, studied airforce cadets aged 17-24 years and found that those who had been exposed to microbes transmitted orally - in contaminated food for instance - were less likely to suffer from respiratory allergies than those who had been unaffected.

The theory is simple: if your child's immune system is stimulated, it will get used to coping with foreign invaders. Too much bug-free food and bleaching of surfaces and it will stay weak and vulnerable, and your child will therefore be more likely to develop allergies. It creates a bit of a dilemma, doesn't it? Nobody wants their child to be infected with salmonella, but asthma's no picnic either. Matricardi's advice is double-edged: "We must improve hygiene to reduce the impact of infectious diseases," he says. "But at the same time, we must learn how to safely 'train' our immune system, especially during infancy, in order to prevent allergy."

Dr Matricardi was studying Heliobacter pylori and the hepatitis A virus - not bugs any sane parent would want anywhere near their child. But the team found that it's not the bugs themselves that prevent allergies. It's just that when they cause infection they stimulate the immune response, and therefore help to protect the body from other invaders. The National Asthma Campaign is optimistic. "We hope that the data from this study can be used to develop vaccines against asthma," said a spokesperson.

Martyn Partridge, a consultant chest physician at Whipps Cross Hospital in London, also welcomes the research. "It's a vital step forward in our understanding of allergies," he said. "Children today are exposed to far fewer nasty bugs than they would once have been. This research shows that things children used to be routinely exposed to, such as food poisoning or contaminated drinking water, were probably also priming their immune systems."

Of course, the idea that dirt might not be all bad isn't new. A study last year claimed that regular contact with farm animals makes children less likely to develop allergies. And 10 years ago Professor David Strachan of St George's hospital medical school in London advanced his "dirt hypothesis" after observing that children from large families who are exposed to infections at a young age are less likely to develop allergies than are children from smaller families, raised in a "cleaner" environment.

But what does this new research really mean for parents today? Can we whip off our Marigolds and let our little ones wallow in muck? Absolutely not, say the experts. "Matricardi's study isn't yet of any practical benefit to the way you bring up your children," says Partridge. For a start, susceptibility to allergies can be genetic. Also, many allergies are probably caused by our living conditions generally, not just our relative cleanliness: carpets, double-glazing, draught-proofing and showers all make our homes warm, damp and insulated - the perfect environment for house mites and other allergens. The National Asthma Campaign is also adamant that while Matricardi's study bolsters the "dirt hypothesis", backwards is not the way forwards. "We certainly would not encourage you to let your children eat dirt."

So you can't just turn your house into some kind of Angela's Ashes slum, and hope your child survives to be wheeze-free. A bit of dirt might not do much harm, but virulent filth will. Still, one day I could find myself taking a break from the hoovering to get my child vaccinated with dirt. Some things in life just don't seem fair, do they?

fields.headline: Warehouse man makes Oscar history
fields.standfirst: American Beauty by first-time director Sam Mendes wins eight nominations, as Brits give strong showing in shortlists
fields.trailText: With a stack of Golden Globes already on the mantelpiece, and his trophy cabinet filling fast, Sam Mendes made yet more Hollywood history yesterday when American Beauty was nominated for eight Oscars - the most by a first time foreign director and more than any other film this year.
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell  in Los Angeles and Fiachra Gibbons
fields.body:
With a stack of Golden Globes already on the mantelpiece, and his trophy cabinet filling fast, Sam Mendes made yet more Hollywood history yesterday when American Beauty was nominated for eight Oscars - the most by a first time foreign director and more than any other film this year.

But the wunderkind, who runs the Donmar Warehouse theatre in London, was anything but blasé last night about the success of his dark satire on suburbia. "I know, there's been so many awards ceremonies you almost get inured to them," he said.

"But when you get a load of Oscar nominations, and you look down the list of great directors who have won in the past, it's really humbling. I know it sounds naff, but it's true. I'll wear my lucky suit, the one Prada gave me to wear at the Golden Globes."

Mendes, 34, is in no hurry to do another film and wants to direct a play at the Donmar first. "I feel I need to come back down to earth. I don't know what I'm going to do, and maybe it's a mistake to decide now when I am in a euphoric state."

Although there was disappointment that neither Mike Leigh's much-fancied Topsy-Turvy, Anthony Minghella's The Talented Mr Ripley, nor Neil Jordan's The End of the Affair made it into the frame for best picture, the Brits did well overall. Leigh and Minghella were nominated for best screenplay, with Leigh an early favourite for his story about the comically strained relationship between Gilbert and Sullivan.

Janet McTeer won a nomination for best actress for her role in the low-budget American comedy Tumbleweeds, Nottingham-born Samantha Morton is in the running for best supporting actress, while Jude Law and Michael Caine (The Cider House Rules) both appear on the list for best supporting actor. Though Caine is a previous winner, Law is already thought to be a surefire bet for his performance as a wastrel American shipping heir in The Talented Mr Ripley.

The biggest surprise was the inclusion of the Welsh film, Solomon and Gaenor, in the shortlist for best foreign language film. Directed and written by Paul Morrison, it is the story of a Jewish door-to-door salesman who falls in love with a good chapel girl, and is told in Welsh, Yiddish and English.

Eleven-year-old Haley Joel Osment's nomination for The Sixth Sense showed that the academy's weakness for child actors is alive and kicking, though he is far from the youngest ever. Justin Henry was eight when he was nominated for the 1979 film Kramer vs Kramer, and Anna Paquin won one for The Piano when she too was 11.

Two films received seven nominations: The Insider, the true story of a whistle-blower in the tobacco industry, and The Cider House Rules, an adaptation of the John Irving novel set in a New England orphanage. The Green Mile and The Sixth Sense also made the best film nominations.

The failure of The Hurricane to win a best picture nomination was a surprise. Based on the true story of the wrongful conviction of black boxer Rubin Carter, the film has been criticised for bending the facts, which may have damaged its chances, but its star, Denzel Washington, appears in the best actor category.

Richard Farnsworth, 78, becomes the oldest actor ever to be nominated, for his part in David Lynch's The Straight Story. Even so, the favourites for that category remain Kevin Spacey in American Beauty and Russell Crowe in The Insider. Sean Penn, who plays a jazz guitarist in Woody Allen's Sweet and Lowdown, is also nominated.

Hilary Swank, who has already won a Golden Globe for her role in Boys Don't Cry, is one of the favourites for the best actress Oscar, a category that sees Meryl Streep win a record 12th nomination for Music of the Heart. Annette Bening in American Beauty and Julianne Moore in Neil Jordan's adaptation of Graham Greene's novel The End of the Affair are also nominated.

Samantha Morton, much praised for her performance as the mute lover of Sean Penn in Sweet and Lowdown, was also nominated in the Golden Globes and faces competition from Chloe Sevingy who won the Globe for her part in Boys Don't Cry. Angelina Jolie (Girl, Interrupted) and Catherine Keener (Being John Malkovich) were also nominated.

Pedro Almodovar's All About My Mother is the favourite for best foreign film, having cleaned up on the festival circuit and won a Golden Globe to boot.

The academy dismissed claims that its announcement had been scooped by the Aint-It-Cool-News website which ran an early list of supposed nominees. A spokesperson described as "a fake" the "long list" of nominations. The supposedly leaked list contained the names of Kate Winslet (Holy Smoke) and Gwyneth Paltrow (The Talented Mr Ripley) as nominees but neither appeared in the final lists.

The votes of the 6,000 members of the invitation-only Academy of Motion Pictures have to be in by March 21. The Oscars ceremony is on March 26.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Every newborn should be given £1,000 by the government to invest in stocks and shares, a think tank proposed this week. If you have £1,000 to spare for your child, or if you want to invest a regular sum, what is the best thing to do with it?
fields.trailText: The Question: Every newborn should be given £1,000 by the government to invest in stocks and shares, a think tank proposed this week. If you have £1,000 to spare for your child, or if you want to invest a regular sum, what is the best thing to do with it?
fields.body:
Amanda Davidson Director at Holden Meehan, independent financial advisers

Think ethical investment - by the time this fund matures, your child is going to be very well-informed on environmental and ethical issues, and probably isn't going to thank you for having invested money in something he or she finds distasteful. I'd look at a unit trust, such as the NPI Global Care Fund, which invests in things that have positive effects on the environment. Over the past five years, its growth has averaged 16.9% per annum against an average global growth of 14.2% per annum. It's certainly suitable for your lump sum, though if you want to make regular payments you'd have to invest a minimum of £50 a month.

Mark Bolland Independent financial adviser at Chamberlain de Broe

£1,000 is just about enough to split two or three ways so you can spread risk. Look at an investment trust fund, something solid like Foreign and Colonial. You've got to ask yourself if you want a fund that manages your money globally or domestically. Do you want your investment used all over the world, or just in the UK? If you wanted something riskier, think about what's driving the world economy and speculate on what might be big tomorrow: internet companies, global technology companies, Chinese companies. There are some gimmicky funds directed at children - look beyond that. Check their performance and whether they're right for you.

David Berger Father and chief 'fool' at personal finance website Motley Fool (www.fool.co.uk)

If you'd invested £1,000 18 years ago, based on a long-term historical stock market return, it would be worth around £36,000 today. And there's no doubt the stock market is where you should put this investment for your child: over a short term there might be worries about its performance, but you don't have that worry long term. If you just want to put the money away and forget about it, I'd advise an index-tracking unit trust. You can buy it online or find one in a personal finance supplement. It's a pooled investment of shares which mimics the stock market index - suitable for your lump sum, your regular amounts, or both.

Donna Bradshaw Director, Fiona Price and Partners, female-focused independent financial advisers

If you've got a lump sum to invest, look at the companies which are likely to perform well over the next 20 years, and consider investing in them. Good bets might be Japanese companies and new technology companies; they're not low-risk, but you're looking over such a long term that it's not too much of a risk. For a medium risk, and if you're investing a regular amount each month, I'd say look at an investment trust like Witan's, which is one of the few that allows you to invest as little as £25 a month. Unit trusts are less risky still, and the Royal and Sun Alliance Portfolio Trust has one with a minimum payment of just £25 a month.

Julie Lord Certified financial planner with Cavendish Financial Management

With a long term investment for a child, you'd be crazy to look at anything that wasn't stocks and shares. I tell parents to invest whatever they can - they're always delighted by what they get back. Many people don't depend absolutely on their family allowance to feed and clothe their children, so can invest it. I'd say go to someone for advice - don't begrudge spending £100 for help - and beware of those endowment-type plans that are often suggested for parents. They don't produce such good returns. For my two-year-old, Mary, I put money into an Invesco European Growth Fund. It's performing well, and good for lump sums and regular amounts.

I'd look at a unit trust, such as the NPI Global Care Fund, which invests in things that have positive effects on the environment. Over the past five years, its growth has averaged 16.9% per annum against an average global growth of 14.2% per annum. It's certainly suitable for your lump sum, though if you want to make regular payments you'd have to invest a minimum of £50 a month. Mark Bolland Independent financial adviser at Chamberlain de Broe £1,000 is just about enough to split two or three ways so you can spread risk. Look at an investment trust fund, something solid like Foreign and Colonial. You've got to ask yourself if you want a fund that manages your money globally or domestically. Do you want your investment used all over the world, or just in the UK? If you wanted something riskier, think about what's driving the world economy and speculate on what might be big tomorrow: internet companies, global technology companies, Chinese companies. There are some gimmicky funds directed at children - look beyond that. Check their performance and whether they're right for you. David Berger Father and chief 'fool' at personal finance website Motley Fool (www.fool.co.uk) If you'd invested £1,000 18 years ago, based on a long-term historical stock market return, it would be worth around £36,000 today. And there's no doubt the stock market is where you should put this investment for your child: over a short term there might be worries about its performance, but you don't have that worry long term. If you just want to put the money away and forget about it, I'd advise an index-tracking unit trust. You can buy it online or find one in a personal finance supplement. It's a pooled investment of shares which mimics the stock market index - suitable for your lump sum, your regular amounts, or both. Donna Bradshaw Director, Fiona Price and Partners, female-focused independent financial advisers If you've got a lump sum to invest, look at the companies which are likely to perform well over the next 20 years, and consider investing in them. Good bets might be Japanese companies and new technology companies; they're not low-risk, but you're looking over such a long term that it's not too much of a risk. For a medium risk, and if you're investing a regular amount each month, I'd say look at an investment trust like Witan's, which is one of the few that allows you to invest as little as £25 a month. Unit trusts are less risky still, and the Royal and Sun Alliance Portfolio Trust has one with a minimum payment of just £25 a month. Julie Lord Certified financial planner with Cavendish Financial Management With a long term investment for a child, you'd be crazy to look at anything that wasn't stocks and shares. I tell parents to invest whatever they can - they're always delighted by what they get back. Many people don't depend absolutely on their family allowance to feed and clothe their children, so can invest it. I'd say go to someone for advice - don't begrudge spending £100 for help - and beware of those endowment-type plans that are often suggested for parents. They don't produce such good returns. For my two-year-old, Mary, I put money into an Invesco European Growth Fund. It's performing well, and good for lump sums and regular amounts.

webTitle: Removing the last barrier to net growth

fields.headline: Removing the last barrier to net growth
fields.standfirst:
Brown to push for lower internet charges

David Teather, Guardian media business correspondent, explains how Chancellor Gordon Brown's plans to reduce net costs could work in practice
fields.trailText: David Teather, Guardian media business correspondent, explains how chancellor Gordon Brown's plans to reduce net costs could work in practice.
fields.body:
The official term is bill shock - that numbing feeling when you open a telephone bill after spending a little too long surfing on the internet.

The cost of access to the web has long been identified as arguably the chief barrier to the growth of the internet in Britain and chancellor Gordon Brown will tonight set new targets to halve the amount consumers and businesses are paying by 2002.

The chancellor wants access charges to match those in the US and will suggest that regulatory action will be taken if telecoms companies and internet service providers fail to move prices downwards themselves.

At the end of last year some 18% of people in this country were accessing the internet, ahead of most of Europe but trailing the gadget-loving Scandanavians - led by Sweden where the figure is 41%, and the US at 46%.

Costs of internet access in Britain have fallen dramatically in the past year through the introduction of "free" service providers which began with Freeserve, launched by high street electrical retailer Dixons. Freeserve quickly became the biggest service provider in Britain by dropping the conventional monthly subscription fee, in most cases around £12-15, and prompted a wave of copycat services.

Even though "free" access is something of a misnomer - due to the continued existence of call charges - the new model for internet access underlined a near doubling of people going online across Europe last year. ISP's which offer free access make their money back on a share of call charges and theoretically e-commerce and advertising.

But even with free access, the cost of peak-rate charges in Britain remains roughly 20% higher than Italy, 50% higher than the US and 100% higher than Canada, according to government statistics.

A number of key developments are on the way, however, that should enable Mr Brown to achieve his aims without intervention.

The high level of internet use in the US has largely been driven by the country's longstanding method of not charging for local calls. This "unmetered" access has meant that people are not discouraged from surfing by the fear of high telephone bills.

A number of companies in Britain have started to experiment with versions of unmetered charging including cable company Telewest which launched a new tariff earlier this week charging a flat monthly fee of £10 for unlimited web access.

The major change, however, will come in the spring when British Telecom launches its own unmetered internet access product called Surftime. Not only will BT be offering the service but, because of the way the company is regulated, other internet service providers will also be able to repackage the service and sell it under their own brands. This means unmetered calling is likely to become pervasive. The other significant change approaching is the so called "unbundling of the local loop". Eight months ago, BT was warned that it will be forced to give up its stranglehold on the local network of telephone wires in July 2001 allowing rival suppliers to take over the line to the home at the customer's request.

The effective dismantling of BT is seen as key because despite almost a decade of competition in Britain's telecoms market, around 85% of homes are still connected to the erstwhile monopoly.

Opening up BT's local loop to competition will have two effects. Most simply, the increased competition will put pressure on service providers and telecoms companies to reduce their prices still further.

But by giving other companies access to BT's network, the government and Oftel, also hope to speed the investment needed to upgrade the wires. The "killer" technology which will do that is called ADSL (asymmetric digital subscriber line) which enables existing copper wires to be used for high bandwidth applications such as high speed internet and broadcasting.

The company which runs the line installs its kit at the telephone exchange and a box over the wall socket in the home which means there is no need to dig up the road and put down new cable.

Oftel and Mr Brown are minded to encourage BT to get its network ready earlier than the July 2001 date although given BT's natural reluctance that seems unlikely.

fields.headline: Winning and losing
fields.standfirst: Catholic opposition in Scotland to  Section 28 isn't a local issue for  local people, says Gordon  Urquhart. The campaign is being  led by Rome
fields.trailText: Catholic opposition in Scotland to Section 28 isn't a local issue for local people, says Gordon Urquhart. The campaign is being led by Rome.
fields.body:
Cardinal Thomas Winning, head of the Roman Catholic church in Scotland, is a larger-than-life personality who certainly lives up to his reputation as the "hard man" of British Catholicism. But to evaluate his contributions to the Section 28 debate as though they were his own personal views is to miss entirely their true, far more disturbing significance. He does not speak in his own name - although his personal distaste for homosexuality is not in doubt - but for Rome.

Winning is one of nine Cardinal Presidents of the Pontifical Council for the Family, the department of the Roman Curia which coordinates the Holy See's activities in sexual politics. No British prelate is better acquainted with its international campaign to halt gay rights.

Last year, the Council for the Family, through one of its consultants, Christine Boutin, a member of the French national assembly, put up an unsuccessful fight to stop the recognition of civil unions in France. It is currently girding its loins for the follow-up to the 1995 Beijing UN Women's Conference, Beijing+5, which takes place in New York in June. At a gathering of Vatican-affiliated NG0s in Rome last November, Archbishop Renato Martino, the Holy See's permanent observer to the UN, declared that Beijing+5 "will be a new occasion to confront additional battles . . . on homosexuals' rights". Underlining the importance Rome ascribes to these battles - note the military terminology - John Paul II's first message for the new millennium was an appeal to civil authorities to protect the family against the demands of homosexuals for legal recognition of their relationships.

Early in his reign, the Pope realised that his crusade to re-establish traditional morality was primarily a war of ideas - a "culture war". A secular ideology, not bible-thumping, was required to fuel this struggle, which would be fought principally in the political arena. He duly established numerous think-tanks and academic bodies all over the world, staffed by rightwing "experts" in key areas such as psychology, law, history, sociology and anthropology.

Lately, the efforts of these propagandists have focused on the subject of homosexuality.

In 1988, the Vatican daily newspaper, Osservatore Romano, published a series of 15 papers - later issued in book form by the Vatican Press - in which a group of academics attempted to refute the most up-to-date research in the field of gay and lesbian studies.

According to Gianfranceso Zuarazzi, professor of psychology and psycho-pathology at the John Paul II Institute for Studies on Marriage and the Family, in Rome, male gay relationships are "unstable, unfaithful, strewn with jealousy and bitterness, marked by possessive love and demands that can never be satisfied". Lesbian relationships, he says, are "stormy and agonising". He concludes that abstinence - or, better still, a cure - is the only solution for those suffering from this unnatural tendency.

Cardinal Winning's controversial suggestion last month that there is an international lesbian and gay plot to destroy the family was hardly his own invention; it lies at the heart of the Vatican's sexual ideology. John Paul II, following the announcement of the European parliament's recommendation in February 1994 that gay marriage should be legalised in member states, angrily described homosexuality as "a bad tree that humanity carries within itself which is nurtured with the help of vast funds and the support of powerful mass media".

Last month, the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith (CDF), the doctrinal watchdog once known as the Inquisition, came up with the Vatican's most bizarre anti-gay conspiracy theory yet. Bishop Tarcisio Bertone, secretary of the CDF, announced a summit conference in Rome to decide a course of action against what he described as "human race feminism". This term, he pointed out, refers to the attempt of gays and lesbians to abolish the two sexes of male and female, replacing them with a single neuter gender.

To the fury of the Pope and the Roman Curia, the largest-ever international gay event, Worldpride 2000, is to take place in Rome from June 28 to July 9, with a million gays and lesbians expected to cut a colourful swathe through hordes of devout Catholics attending the church's jubilee celebrations. At the end of last month, semi-official diplomatic representations were made to the Italian govemment by Cardinal Sodano, the Vatican secretary of state, that to allow a homosexual celebration at this time would infringe the Lateran Treaty drawn up between the Holy See and the government under Mussolini. The appeal met with a flat rebuttal from the Italian foreign minister, Lamberto Dini.

The exasperation of Francesco Rutelli, mayor of Rome, and the Italian governent with this latest example of Vatican intolerance was made clear when neither Rutelli nor the designated government representative turned up for an important ceremony with the Pope on January 31. Press reports talked of the Pope's "isolation" and noted the "big freeze" between the Vatican and the Italian civil authorities.

This decisive reaction to Vatican homophobia on its own doorstep surely holds a message for politicians in faraway, protestant Britain.

Cardinal Winning is anxious that Catholics should be fully accepted in Scottish society and that old prejudices and suspicions should be laid to rest. Ironically, however, through his agency the classic protestant nightmare has come true - a foreign potentate is meddling in British politics.

 Gordon Urquhart is the author of The Pope's Armada and The World And The Flesh, the Vatican's international strategy of sexual politics.

fields.headline: Shelter from the storm
fields.standfirst: When cyclones strike the Bangladeshi coast, the death toll is  almost beyond belief. Paul Brown visits people who believe  there is a simple way to avoid such needless carnage
fields.trailText: When cyclones strike the Bangladeshi coast, the death toll is almost beyond belief. Paul Brown visits people who believe there is a simple way to avoid such needless carnage.
fields.body:
Three months after a cyclone killed 20,000 in the Indian state of Orissa, across the Bay | of Bengal, people in the vulnerable coastal areas of Bangladesh are bracing themselves for the new cyclone season. Sadly, many will die needlessly simply because there are not enough shelters for the 7m people at risk.

Golam Rabbani, regional chief of the Red Crescent Cyclone Preparedness Programme (CPP), says the tragedy will happen even though Bangladesh has the most advanced cyclone tracking system in the world and plenty of warning will be given - through a 10-hour "great danger" signal on the radio and by teams with megaphones. "When the warning comes, it is first-come-first-served at the shelters," he says. "Those who cannot get in have nowhere to go and many could drown as a result."

Rabbani says there are 1,841 cyclone shelters in the coastal belt of Bangladesh, capable of taking 1.3 million people. At least another 3,500 shelters are needed.

The Red Crescent is appealing to the prime minister, Sheikh Hasina, for more funds when she visits the seaside resort of Cox's Bazaar on March 2 to talk to 2,500 CPP volunteers and meet team leaders from the region. Currently, government funding for the CPP early warning programme is the equivalent of only about one penny per head per year for those at risk. Funds are so short that there is not enough money to provide torches for all the 32,904 volunteers and half of each team of 12 are not issued with raincoats and boots. Each group is allowed one megaphone for warning purposes.

After the terrible disaster in Chittagong in 1991, when officially 138,000 people died out of an affected population of 3 million, funds were given by foreign governments and aid agencies, but it was still not enough. Some shelters were built in places where they were not needed, while vulnerable offshore islands where many were killed were given little or no protection.

Ten miles south of Chittagong is Patenga, which was flattened by a tidal surge in 1991. A new 30-foot-high "bund" - a bank topped with a road - has been built to replace the one destroyed in the last cyclone, but land donated by the villagers to build a promised cyclone shelter is still just a grassy patch. The bund would not be enough to protect the coast if the cyclone coincided with a high tide, as it did in 1991.

Ismail Hossain, aged 45, a survivor of that disaster, says: "Local political leaders, at the time of the elections, utter sweet words and give false hope of constructing shelters, roads and bringing electricity, but after the elections they do not turn up, nor do their promised improvements."

Rezia Begum, the oldest member of the community, lost seven members of her family in 1991, including six grandchildren. Some were never found. She recalls: "The water gushed over the embankment, sweeping away houses. It was over the roof tops. The surge carried me and I was trapped in a tree." Other survivors brought her down from the tree two days later, when the water receded.

Those who survived did so by luck. Hazrat Ali jumped on the back of his cow, knowing it could swim, and clung on for an hour until it reached dry land. Afterwards, hunger forced him to sell her. "I sold her to a butcher to fill my belly," he says. "Now I think I am the most ungrateful man in the world."

Near the centre of Chittagong is a shelter built with Saudi government money. It is at the base of one of Chittagong's hills, where people could scramble to safety without the need of a shelter. However, Bimal Kanti Barua is grateful. He is headmaster of the primary school which uses the shelter for its classrooms. It also doubles as a local meeting hall.

Rabbani says: "This shelter probably would not have been built there now. We have different rules." He says it would still be used to shield people against the winds, but it would not now be a priority.

He also says that, despite the previous devastation at Patenga beach, he does not think building the bund and a shelter was a priority either, because there are roads and, with the early warning system, people could be bussed to safety. He is more concerned about low lying islands from which there is no escape. They are the most vulnerable to the next cyclone.

One such island, Urirchar on the Meghna river, is a newly-emerged 8 sq km island formed from the washed down silt of the annual floods. In 1985, it was hit by a cyclone and half the 10,000 people on the island died. Nural Islam, aged 70, had moved to the island because his home on another silt island had been washed away in erosion. He lost his wife, three daughters and a son in the 1985 tidal surge.

Two shelters were built subsequently and have room for 2,000 people standing up. But there are 10,000 people living on the island, with the nearest safety two days' journey away in small boats.

One of the newer islands is Sonar Char - or "golden island", because of the quality of rice it produces. It has 1,500 people living on it, and Abbas Ali was the only survivor of the 1991 cyclone. "I could not know what happened," he says. "I just found myself floating in the darkness." He was rescued after swimming for two days.

Now, during the cyclone season, everyone under 18 and over 40 is evacuated from the island to distant safe places.

Rabbani says there are some places which are so dangerous that he believes people should be banned from living there are all. He supports a new "disaster act" proposed by the government to declare some places off limits.

In the past 200 years, 64 major cyclones have struck the coast of Bangladesh and it is inevitable that there will be more.

Samarendra Karmaker, regional director of the meteorological department at Chittagong, says that cyclones - which strike between April and May and from autumn up to November - can be 1,000km (600 miles) across and have winds up to 360kph (220mph).

He believes that the early warning system is probably the best in the world, with the most sophisticated methods of tracking exactly where the storms will make landfall. But he adds: "The most serious problem we have remaining is to educate people to leave their homes and save their lives."

Poorer people, with no way of locking their homes, fear they will be looted, so they are prepared to risk their lives rather than travel to seek safety. There are often no shelters or substantial buildings nearby and those left behind on watch are killed.

In an effort to improve the response of poorer people, the CPP has trained 2,070 imams, the local religious leaders. They will use their microphone systems - normally used for calling the faithful to prayer - to warn local people of impending danger. It is hoped their influence will get people to seek safety.

In the 1991 cyclone, Chittagong port was devastated: 28,000 bodies were found in the area, 35 ships were sunk or badly damaged and thousands of containers were blown away. But now the port is well prepared, with special control rooms and emergency plans which are put into action during cyclone alerts. Larger ships are sent out to weather the storm in deep water, while smaller boats are sent up river for safety. Those that cannot be moved because of tide or breakdown are secured with double cyclone lines.

Concrete buildings, strong enough to withstand the wind and high enough to be safe from a tidal surge, can shelter more than 10,000 workers. The port, at least, is ready for the next onslaught.

 Paul Brown, the Guardian's environment correspondent, was director of a recent training course in Chittagong for the Commonwealth Journalists' Association.

One such island, Urirchar on the Meghna river, is a newly-emerged 8 sq km island formed from the washed down silt of the annual floods. In 1985, it was hit by a cyclone and half the 10,000 people on the island died. Nural Islam, aged 70, had moved to the island because his home on another silt island had been washed away in erosion. He lost his wife, three daughters and a son in the 1985 tidal surge. Two shelters were built subsequently and have room for 2,000 people standing up. But there are 10,000 people living on the island, with the nearest safety two days' journey away in small boats. One of the newer islands is Sonar Char - or "golden island", because of the quality of rice it produces. It has 1,500 people living on it, and Abbas Ali was the only survivor of the 1991 cyclone. "I could not know what happened," he says. "I just found myself floating in the darkness." He was rescued after swimming for two days. Now, during the cyclone season, everyone under 18 and over 40 is evacuated from the island to distant safe places. Rabbani says there are some places which are so dangerous that he believes people should be banned from living there are all. He supports a new "disaster act" proposed by the government to declare some places off limits. In the past 200 years, 64 major cyclones have struck the coast of Bangladesh and it is inevitable that there will be more. Samarendra Karmaker, regional director of the meteorological department at Chittagong, says that cyclones - which strike between April and May and from autumn up to November - can be 1,000km (600 miles) across and have winds up to 360kph (220mph). He believes that the early warning system is probably the best in the world, with the most sophisticated methods of tracking exactly where the storms will make landfall. But he adds: "The most serious problem we have remaining is to educate people to leave their homes and save their lives." Poorer people, with no way of locking their homes, fear they will be looted, so they are prepared to risk their lives rather than travel to seek safety. There are often no shelters or substantial buildings nearby and those left behind on watch are killed. In an effort to improve the response of poorer people, the CPP has trained 2,070 imams, the local religious leaders. They will use their microphone systems - normally used for calling the faithful to prayer - to warn local people of impending danger. It is hoped their influence will get people to seek safety. In the 1991 cyclone, Chittagong port was devastated: 28,000 bodies were found in the area, 35 ships were sunk or badly damaged and thousands of containers were blown away. But now the port is well prepared, with special control rooms and emergency plans which are put into action during cyclone alerts. Larger ships are sent out to weather the storm in deep water, while smaller boats are sent up river for safety. Those that cannot be moved because of tide or breakdown are secured with double cyclone lines. Concrete buildings, strong enough to withstand the wind and high enough to be safe from a tidal surge, can shelter more than 10,000 workers. The port, at least, is ready for the next onslaught.  Paul Brown, the Guardian's environment correspondent, was director of a recent training course in Chittagong for the Commonwealth Journalists' Association.

fields.headline: Mind the gap
fields.standfirst: Yesterday's report on children's homes in north Wales  documented widespread examples of abuse - but that's not  the only aspect of the system in need of urgent reform.  Henrietta Bond on a campaign to get local authorities to  extend their parental duties beyond the age of 18
fields.trailText: Yesterday's report on children's homes in north Wales documented widespread examples of abuse - but that's not the only aspect of the system in need of urgent reform. Henrietta Bond on a campaign to get local authorities to extend their parental duties beyond the age of 18.
fields.body:
You're young, you're bright and you're ambitious. Your teachers say you should go on to higher education. But there is only one snag: because your parents failed to care for you as a child, you've grown up in foster families. And, at 16, the system is ready to pull the rug out from under your feet. The local authority's duties as a corporate parent come to an end. Homeless, unsupported, struggling to get benefits, the nearest you may come to a fulfilling future is being one more statistic in someone's thesis on unemployment.

The current care system is flawed and everybody knows it. The government has recognised this and in 1998 announced the Quality Protects programme - a £375m initiative to transform the quality of care.

It has also introduced the children (leaving care) bill, which is entering its committee stage in the House of Lords. This acknowledges that the current trend for young people to be discharged from local authority care at 16 is an inadequate response to the needs of this very vulnerable group. The bill will impose new and stronger duties upon local authorities to support care leavers until they are at least 18.

But is 18 old enough to allow young people to benefit from the educational and training opportunities that many of them need to survive alone in society?

The Action on Aftercare Consortium, a group of children's charities working with care leavers, feels that the government is missing a valuable opportunity to extend the duties of local authorities to assist these young people until they are 21 - or 24 if they are still in education or training, recognising that previously disadvantaged young people may need longer to catch up.

"The government is talking about giving local authorities the power to assist with education, training and employment up to 24, but a power is very different from a duty," says Amanda Allard, chair of the consortium and public policy officer with NCH Action For Children.

"I know from talking to our after-care projects that local authorities don't exercise their existing discretionary powers with regard to care leavers. If there's a hard-pressed choice between things the local authority has to do and things they would chose to do if funds were only available, the outcome is pretty obvious. I believe the government when they say they'd like to make it a duty but that they're not sure if the money is there. But if they make it a duty then the treasury will have to find the money."

Allard says that promoting the education of young people in care fits well with the Quality Protects objectives for enabling young care leavers to live successful adult lives. However, she argues that what is needed is a system which supports young people rather than forcing them to fight for the help they need. Parents, she says, support their children through the ups and downs of teenage years, providing the safety net when the going gets tough. Young people who have already suffered the disadvantage of being in the care system have a right to expect the same - if not more.

"I came across a young care leaver who was on a training course where it was mandatory to have a particular type of boots with steel caps," Allard says. "He just couldn't afford these himself and the after-care project had to threaten the local authority with going to the media in order to get him these boots. There will be other tools he needs for further parts of the course, but the local authority have said that they won't help him any more."

The Action on Aftercare Consortium has supporters in high places. Sir William Utting, former chief inspector of social services and author of the Safeguards for Children Living Away from Home report in 1997, pays tribute to the government's integrated strategy for improving care, but wants to see it strike while the iron is hot.

"I think the government accepts the case for extending a local authority's duties until young people from care are 21 or 24, but says it's still a question of timing," Utting says. "To me, this is the best and only time in which this can be achieved. At the moment, it would be in the context of the bill going through parliament. This group of young people is currently receiving sustained interests and support from politicians, the media and the public.

"My worry is that if extending the age limit is differed, this small and isolated group of young people may revert to their former low priority. The single measure of extending the local authority duty to 21 may soon be overtaken by other agendas."

Billie Ibbidun, national coordinator for A National Voice, an organisation run by and for young people from the care system, says that young people from care are always making the distinction between what "real" parents give their children and what young people are offered by social services. She says that most young people do not feel cared for, and that feeling loved and cared for is the thing which enables most of us to flourish.

"The care system should help young people to be the best they can," Ibbidun says. "For some, the best will be to find fulfilling work. For others, it will be to go on to higher education. It's different for everyone. But at the moment there's very limited opportunity."

Ibbidun gives the example of Allison (not her real name), who was recently offered a place at university. However, because she had moved between authorities, neither was prepared to support her financially. She had to leave supported housing when she reached 18. She was forced to approach a charity to obtain accommodation.

Her problems were compounded because, having no contact with her parents, she could not provide information about their income, on which her eligibility for a student loan could be assessed. She only managed to complete her first term because another charity made her a cash grant. Her second term has just started, but she has no idea how much longer she will be able to continue.

"Allison just wants to be like her contemporaries - embracing mainstream life," Ibbidun says. "But she's being forced to seek grants from charities and queue up with homeless people. She's being shoved into a category of 'excluded' people. She's a sparkling young woman who deserves the right to make her own future."

"We must redesign the care system so that it doesn't create a heap of wasted talent," says Susanna Cheal, chief executive of the Who Cares? Trust. "Surely all young people are entitled to have aspirations, but the current system is putting roadblocks in the way of those who have already encountered more problems than most of us can imagine. We welcome the government's intention to raise the duty of care to 18 - but we want them to go that further step and ensure that local authorities support young people through those vital times in their lives when new opportunities are opening up for them. Only that way can they look back and say: 'The system helped me to feel cared for and cared about. Now I have left care behind - but only when I was ready.'"

Wanted: time to grow up

Melanie is 18, wants to work with children, and is currently taking a three-year course in health and social care. She loves the work, her tutors are delighted with her progress, but Melanie may be forced to leave college - because she has grown up in foster care.

"Melanie was a very timid girl who was picked on at school," explains Avril McGowan, her former foster carer. "Going on to the FE course was the turning point in her life.

"But she'd just started her second year at college when I had a phone call saying that because she'd reached her 18th birthday she'd have to leave.

"They were talking about moving her to a hostel but I knew she'd be eaten alive there. I found her a flat with a friend, paid the deposit myself and kitted it out. But she doesn't understand the bills, and there have been problems with her benefits. Melanie is a young woman who really needed a little more time for growing up."

When Melanie reaches 19 she must be available for employment in order to receive benefits - which means she may have to give up her college place.

"This course is Melanie's real chance to do something she'll be good at," Avril says. "Instead, she could end up on the dole.

"Children shouldn't be prevented from going into further education because they've been in care. Everything doesn't get sorted when you reach 18."

 The Action on Aftercare Consortium includes Barnardo's, Centrepoint, Childline, Coram Family, First Key, The National Children's Bureau, NCH - Action For Children, National Foster Care Association, The Prince's Trust, Save The Children, The Foyer Federation, The Children's Society, Voice for the Child in Care and the Who Cares? Trust.

fields.headline: Slice of American pie
fields.standfirst: John Quelch believes new tax breaks will allow British universities to  compete with the US to attract the brightest and best academics
fields.trailText: John Quelch believes new tax breaks will allow British universities to compete with the US to attract the brightest and best academics.
fields.body:
Charities, including universities, believe the new incentives for charitable giving, to be included in the next budget, will make a huge difference in their ability to raise funds - especially from wealthy donors.

The new tax breaks are being introduced following the government's two-year review of charity taxation. They will, for the first time, give UK charities many of the fund-raising opportunities that their counterparts in the US have enjoyed for years - and without the limits that apply in the US tax rules. American universities have been able to use the money they raise under these incentives to give chairs to the best and brightest academics in the world.

The Getting Britain Giving package, announced last year, was immediately welcomed. Last week, it was spelled out in more detail by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, at the annual conference of the National Council for Volun tary Organisations. It is only now that the full potential of the package is becoming clear.

However, charities are anxious to learn more of the details from the Inland Revenue as soon as possible amid concerns that the opportunities offered by the new incentives might be tied up in red tape.

The existing tax breaks for cash donations are already quite generous, but as I said in an article back in September, the rules and the paperwork are a nightmare. The inland revenue's own research has identified this as one of the reasons why fewer than 10% of charity donors use the tax breaks. The government has listened to these concerns. Among the measures announced are:

 The removal of all minimum and maximum limits for donations. From this April, the new Gift Aid scheme will apply to all donations, large or small, regular or one-off. So for every pound given to charity, the government will contribute to that charity an extra 28 pence.

 The ending of the old deed of covenant scheme, with tax relief for all future donations now being available under a single scheme.

 Easier payroll giving (with no ceiling on the amount) and a 10% supplement on all payroll donations to charities over the next three years.

 A reduction in paperwork - indeed, an end to paperwork altogether for donors who choose to give over the phone or via the internet.

But charities and universities that rely on wealthy donors are most excited by the new incentives to encourage gifts of shares and bonds.

From next April, people - and companies - who give listed shares or securities to a charity will be able to claim a pound-for-pound tax deduction for the value of those shares - and they won't have to pay capital gains tax either.

Universities will be courting alumni who have made their money in business - the new entrepreneurs, such as internet whizzkids, whose wealth is largely in shares - for whom this new tax break will be very attractive.

Note that the government is not yet permitting gifts of unlisted shares or property to qualify for these tax breaks, on the grounds that they cannot be valued as definitively.

The government's review ducked some of the US tax breaks for planned giving through trusts, like lead trusts and remainder trusts.

The review concluded, debatably, that such incentives would add too much complexity. But the government has recognised that US universities raise a lot of money through such trusts, and has therefore proposed removing one major tax barrier to giving in this way.

In future, trusts in which the settlor has an interest will be able to make donations to charity without attracting a tax charge for the settlor.

The government undoubtedly realises that any changes must be kept simple if it is really to stimulate increased giving.

Charities need to work closely with the inland revenue over the coming months as officials work out the details, to ensure that the new measures are not strangled at birth by red tape. We at London business school are considering volunteering to be a test site for the inland revenue's new scheme to facilitate giving tax effectively through the internet.

In sum, the new legislation will remove many of the obstacles that today discourage both newly wealthy entrepreneurs and older citizens doing estate planning from transferring their assets to charity. As a result, British charities will now be able to participate in the wealth created through stock market appreciation and new company listings just as their American counterparts do.

fields.headline: Tiers of joy
fields.standfirst: As many as one in five elderly people in hospital need not be  there. David Brindle reports on one solution in Southend
fields.trailText: As many as one in five elderly people in hospital need not be there. David Brindle reports on one solution in Southend.
fields.body:
Queenie Bartley had come off her electric scooter and made a real mess of her left leg. At 93, a prolonged stay in hospital followed by transfer to a residential home would be the norm. But not in Southend. At Pantile House, Queenie is completing her recovery and getting her strength back. Although all options remain open, she is starting to think seriously about going back to her own home. "I would be able to do what I want," she says thoughtfully.

Pantile is the kind of facility that Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has in mind when he talks about creating a new "intermediate" tier of care. As the government's national beds inquiry last week reported, two-thirds of general and acute hospital beds are occupied by people aged 65 or more and possibly 20% of them need not be there if other services were available.

In Southend, Pantile is enabling earlier discharge of older hospital patients who are no longer in medical need but are not fit to return home. As a result, possibly 10 more beds are free at any one time. But it is doing far more: by rehabilitating its "clients" through intensive therapy, it is preventing them having to go into residential or nursing care and enabling them to go home, often with lighter support packages than they would otherwise have required.

"We thought we could probably reduce some of the demand for residential care, but expected to end up with a lot of high intensity community care packages," says Jane Held, social services director of Southend council. "To our surprise, the current profile is not like that. We are discharging considerably more people than we expected with lower intensity packages."

The scheme, which started in January last year but got fully into its stride only in July, is a true joint venture between social services and the local NHS. It is housed in a former council residential home and Southend and Essex social services together contribute some £619,000 annually and provide the building, managerial staff and care and domestic workers. The NHS chips in £355,000 and provides therapy and community nursing services. There are 24 rehabilitation beds and 10 respite, with a district nurse on site full time to offer practical support and advice.

This permanent nursing presence is one of several issues which have caused problems over registration of the unit as a non-clinical facility. Another was the teaching of one client to "peg feed" himself, using a tube into his stomach, in order that he might return home.

Perhaps the biggest stumbling block, though, and one that the government will have to address when it gets round to decisions on long-term care, has been that people are allowed a maximum 56 days in such "step down" care environments before charges kick in. Several Pantile clients have overrun this limit and there has been correspondence with ministers. The circle seems to have been squared, for now, by informing the clients concerned that a charge will be added retrospectively to any bill incurred if and when they enter residential care.

Hospital patients are assessed on their suitability for Pantile before being invited to transfer. A projection is made for each client of what the likely outcome, and cost, would otherwise have been - thus enabling close monitoring of the scheme's progress.

With early indications that 70% of clients (average age 87) are returning home, Held reckons net savings are running at about £225,000 a year. Pippa Sage, director of rehabilitation services at Southend Healthcare NHS trust, which runs Southend hospital, is a little more cautious. "We felt, from the hospital's perspective, that the project would be worth 10 beds, enabling us to take more emerg encies and do more elective surgery. and there is evidence beginning to emerge that supports that, "she says.

To achieve these results, the Pantile therapy regime is necessarily rigorous. Clients who arrive expecting an easy time are in for a shock. Adapting from hands-on to "hands in pocket" care, deliberately not intervening to provide automatic assistance or fetch and carry, has equally been a shock for social services staff accustomed to a residential home environment. Some have not been able to make the change.

On the other side of the partnership, meanwhile, joint working and training has forced NHS staff to address their own practice. "Our people couldn't understand what was going on," says Ruth Bull, adult resources manager for social services. "It wasn't just that they were speaking in jargon; it was some of the cryptic signs that they tend to use to write to each other."

Above all, though, the Pantile team has together had to tackle external preconceptions of what a rehabilitation scheme is all about. Bull says: "People come round and ask: 'Where are the exercise machines?' What we are talking about here is a very high dependency level. The difference between going into a residential home and being able to stay in your own home may be being able to work a hoist. That's what we mean by rehabilitation."

But it is doing far more: by rehabilitating its "clients" through intensive therapy, it is preventing them having to go into residential or nursing care and enabling them to go home, often with lighter support packages than they would otherwise have required. "We thought we could probably reduce some of the demand for residential care, but expected to end up with a lot of high intensity community care packages," says Jane Held, social services director of Southend council. "To our surprise, the current profile is not like that. We are discharging considerably more people than we expected with lower intensity packages." The scheme, which started in January last year but got fully into its stride only in July, is a true joint venture between social services and the local NHS. It is housed in a former council residential home and Southend and Essex social services together contribute some £619,000 annually and provide the building, managerial staff and care and domestic workers. The NHS chips in £355,000 and provides therapy and community nursing services. There are 24 rehabilitation beds and 10 respite, with a district nurse on site full time to offer practical support and advice. This permanent nursing presence is one of several issues which have caused problems over registration of the unit as a non-clinical facility. Another was the teaching of one client to "peg feed" himself, using a tube into his stomach, in order that he might return home. Perhaps the biggest stumbling block, though, and one that the government will have to address when it gets round to decisions on long-term care, has been that people are allowed a maximum 56 days in such "step down" care environments before charges kick in. Several Pantile clients have overrun this limit and there has been correspondence with ministers. The circle seems to have been squared, for now, by informing the clients concerned that a charge will be added retrospectively to any bill incurred if and when they enter residential care. Hospital patients are assessed on their suitability for Pantile before being invited to transfer. A projection is made for each client of what the likely outcome, and cost, would otherwise have been - thus enabling close monitoring of the scheme's progress. With early indications that 70% of clients (average age 87) are returning home, Held reckons net savings are running at about £225,000 a year. Pippa Sage, director of rehabilitation services at Southend Healthcare NHS trust, which runs Southend hospital, is a little more cautious. "We felt, from the hospital's perspective, that the project would be worth 10 beds, enabling us to take more emerg encies and do more elective surgery. and there is evidence beginning to emerge that supports that, "she says. To achieve these results, the Pantile therapy regime is necessarily rigorous. Clients who arrive expecting an easy time are in for a shock. Adapting from hands-on to "hands in pocket" care, deliberately not intervening to provide automatic assistance or fetch and carry, has equally been a shock for social services staff accustomed to a residential home environment. Some have not been able to make the change. On the other side of the partnership, meanwhile, joint working and training has forced NHS staff to address their own practice. "Our people couldn't understand what was going on," says Ruth Bull, adult resources manager for social services. "It wasn't just that they were speaking in jargon; it was some of the cryptic signs that they tend to use to write to each other." Above all, though, the Pantile team has together had to tackle external preconceptions of what a rehabilitation scheme is all about. Bull says: "People come round and ask: 'Where are the exercise machines?' What we are talking about here is a very high dependency level. The difference between going into a residential home and being able to stay in your own home may be being able to work a hoist. That's what we mean by rehabilitation."

fields.headline: Enough talking
fields.standfirst: Nigel Sizer believes  forests can be saved  only by communities,  not by treaties
fields.trailText: Nigel Sizer believes forests can be saved only by communities, not by treaties.
fields.body:
Diplomats battled until seven in the morning at the United Nations in New York last Saturday to fend off successfully a Canadian-led push to begin all-out negotiations of a global forest treaty.

This marked the final session of the Intergovernmental Forum on Forests, now due to report its conclusions to the rest of the UN. Instead of embarking on treaty formulation, they agreed that a new UN permanent forum on forests should be formed, with meetings of ministers every two years to review implementation of commitments already made to conserve and carefully manage forests.

Governments have been trying for almost two decades to slow destruction of forests through the UN, the World Bank and other international agencies. The results are disappointing. Rates of tropical forest loss are higher than ever and degradation of the vast northern boreal forests continues apace.

In 1992, environmental awareness peaked with the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro and the largest gathering of heads of state ever seen. Forests featured high on the agenda. Environmentalists hoped that a binding global forests treaty would be signed. But talks collapsed amid rancour over how much the wealthy "north" would "pay" the poor "south" to implement the agreement. A toothless and vague "statement of forest principles" was adopted.

Officials have been jetting to New York and Geneva every six months or so since, trying to get beyond the "north-south" standoff. In recent years, environmentalists and indigenous peoples' representatives turned sharply against efforts to start negotiation of a global forests treaty.

They fear that a binding treaty would be dominated by logging and trade interests. It could create a global greenwash that would do little to combat forest loss. Such suspicions were reinforced in New York. A trade expert headed Canada's delegation, with representation from their environment ministry nowhere in sight. Many were also suspicious of the intentions of countries that allied themselves with Canada in the talks. These included Russia, Malaysia and francophone African countries - not places with sterling conservation track records. Internal divisions dulled the European Union's voice. Key members, including the UK, were opposed to the EU's official pro-treaty line.

With the threat and distraction of a "talk and log" treaty off the table, the emphasis should now shift to local actions and the initiative of civil society. While global trends look bleak, many places have stories to tell about how forests have been saved.

In India, thousands of villages have organised community efforts to manage and protect forests. Mexican communal organisations have done the same, some now even certified according to the toughest international standards as sources of good wood.Around the world, environmentalists, companies, workers and human rights advocates are teaming up to find solutions that get around the mismanagement perpetrated by many governments.

One alliance, the Forest Stewardship Council, has set the standard in forest management and in the eco-labelling of good wood.

Another groundbreaking partnership of forest peoples, corporations, environmentalists and some government agencies is launching Global Forest Watch. This is the first worldwide effort to monitor independently the threats to forests, bringing together satellite data and local information through the internet to anyone who wants it.

The clear lesson for the UN is that forests cannot be cared for through edicts from globetrotting diplomats and experts. Instead, the UN agencies should encourage partnerships with dynamic civil society and community-led initiatives that can protect and manage forests for future generations.

During each minute spent talking, another 100 acres of tropical forest - replete with its teaming wealth of plants and animals - is destroyed.

 Nigel Sizer is director of forest policy with World Resources Institute, an independent policy research centre in Washington DC.

fields.headline: Fog clears the way
fields.standfirst: Kate Sainsbury on a partnership development  fighting poverty and isolation in rural Devon
fields.trailText: Kate Sainsbury on a partnership development fighting poverty and isolation in rural Devon.
fields.body:
Beyond the windows are rolling hills, church towers and the outline of Dartmoor. Inside, James Ravilious's photographs capture rural life, hardship and celebration amid Devon's natural landscape. The Beaford Centre, for a couple of days twice a year, is home to the Torridge Funding Opportunities Group (Fog), a rural partnership in a community whose poverty belies the tranquil exterior.

It is a district where unemployment is above the national average and isolation poses difficulties for the management of its transport and care infrastructure.

Recently, it was given European Objective 2 status, alongside Plymouth and poorer parts of Bristol.

The main aims of Fog are identifying funding opportunities, coordinating efforts, avoiding duplication of applications and securing inward investment. Membership of the group is open and newcomers join on a networking basis.

Partnership development is tackled in two ways: thematically, covering elderly and young people, and housing; and project-based, such as Surestart programmes and healthy living centres. Steve Batt, from the county's European office, sees Fog "integrating policy, funding streams and projects, so that groups can draw down quickly and get on".

The success of the group lies in Torridge's rural location and in the recognition by members of Torridge district council, the joint consultative committee and the partnership committee, of the need for a flexible approach in such an area.

There is a sense of local identity, a well-developed network in place, and the small population allows easy mapping of existing work, key players and opportunities, which can create an atmosphere of trust.

Ian Hobbs, former district manager of social services, who convenes and coordinates the network as the county council's local community development and partnership officer, says: "There is a general sense of energy and personal commitment, a lack of jealousy over boundaries and a focus on doing what works and spending small money well."

Importantly, the group can function with little bureaucracy because its members are already accountable to communities and organisations.

Fog's function is a mix of networking, awareness-raising, training, even empowerment. It recognises that, in sustainable development, people themselves are resources, with spare capacity that can be released by relaxed conditions and action learning.

A ndrew Lightfoot, of the Community Development Trust (CDT), says: "Fog helps shape priorities for Torridge, but just as important is its role of offering mutual support to community workers struggling in isolation."

Annie Brenton, from Capacity through Quality, agrees: "Community groups need encouragement as well as leadership," she says. "They need their real needs met, and Fog is a way of making those needs known."

A user perspective of Fog looks for evidence of organisations taking up communities' own priorities and issues more effectively than before. The test is whether the data from consumers and smaller organisations informs and produces changes in the strategic capacity-building picture so that long-term programmes meet their needs.

Members of the group are mindful of the wider community and discuss issues of bridge-building, representation and constituency.

Fog is providing a speaker for a National Lottery Charities Board seminar for community development workers and others in Dorset next month. John Skrine, regional development officer for the charities board, sees it as a model of good practice.

"Torridge's change in profile from an area of low applications to the board to one of healthy numbers is, I am sure, attributable to Fog," he says.

 Fog can be reached at the website www.devon-cc.gov.uk/fog
