fields.headline: Deadly serious
fields.standfirst:
When an addict hits rock bottom, life becomes cheap. Neil McKeganey and Joanne Neale warn that a rise in drug-related deaths may be the tip of an iceberg
Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: When an addict hits rock bottom, life becomes cheap. Neil McKeganey and Joanne Neale warn that a rise in drug-related deaths may be the tip of an iceberg.
fields.body:
Thousands of drug addicts in Scotland could be approaching a burn-out phase in which they may be taking ever-increasing risks with their own lives. This is a gloomy scenario, but it is one that may account for the marked increase in the number of addict deaths that are now being seen in Strathclyde.

Between 1994 and 1998, there were a total of 465 addict deaths in Strathclyde. In 1999, there were 148 drug-related deaths - a 33% increase on the previous year.

The availability of higher-than-normal quality heroin on the streets of Glasgow and other parts of Strathclyde and the tendency of addicts in the west of Scotland to mix different drugs is part of the explanation for the number of deaths that are now being seen. It has also been shown that addicts recently released from prison are at high risk of overdosing if they resume their previous pattern of drug use.

There is, though, another possible explanation for the marked increase in deaths that may mean we have only seen the tip of a much larger iceberg.

In the mid-1980s, heroin use exploded in Glasgow. There were an estimated 5,000 heroin addicts in the city in 1985; by 1990, it was an estimated 8,500. On the basis of research carried out in the US, we know that after about 12 to 15 years of using illegal drugs many addicts approach the rock bottom phase of their addiction. This is a point of maximum despondency.

In interviews carried out at Glasgow university with ex-addicts, it was clear that experiencing rock bottom could result in some addicts taking the decision to cease their drug use. Sally, an addict for 15 years, described the point when she decided to stop using illegal drugs: "I really decided to clean up when my health was zero. I was covered in abscesses from head to toe. I was only six stone. Nobody would talk to me, nobody liked me and I didn't even like myself, and I thought that if I continued like this I was going to die. It came to the crunch and I said to myself either I'm going to die or I'm going to clean up. And that's when I decided to clean up."

Other addicts hitting rock bottom may decide that their own life is hardly worth living. In interviews with addicts in hospital recovering from a non-fatal drug overdose, many were similarly pessimistic about their life but in their case they had decided to continue with the drug use that they knew could kill them. Many of these people had, it seemed, lost the will to live, and while their overdose was not necessarily a deliberate attempt to end their life, nevertheless, they had reached a point in their drug use where they were not bothered whether they lived or died.

Karl, for example, started using illegal drugs in his early teens and was now aged 32. Homeless and recently released from prison, he said: "A lot of people who are on drugs have got nothing to live for so they don't really care whether they live or die. That's how I go - I don't care if I catch the virus [HIV] or not."

A 34-year-old female addict put it even more succinctly when she said: "I couldn't give a shit if I died now. That's the way I feel."

While the rock bottom experience of some addicts may help them to come off drugs, for others it may lead them to take ever greater risks with the drugs they are using.

Although fatal drug overdoses are not confined to older addicts, those in their later 20s and early 30s are at particularly high risk of dying. The average age of addicts dying in Strathclyde in 1998 was 28. Many of these will have been using heroin and other illegal drugs for at least 10 years and are likely to have been experiencing the real low points of their addiction.

In the interviews with 77 addicts recovering in hospital from an overdose, 49% said they had felt suicidal before taking the drugs that had nearly killed them, 63% had overdosed previously, 40% were currently homeless and 72% were unemployed. Many were at the end of the road of their addiction, at a point where an overdose could seem an all-too-easy way out of a life of unending misery.

The first thing that needs to happen if the number of drug-related deaths is to be reduced is that every drug agency in contact with addicts who are in their late 20s and 30s, and who have been using illegal drugs for more than 10 years, must recognise that these individuals are at high risk of a fatal overdose. Since many of them will have been in contact with drug services for years, agency staff may have become so used to seeing them year after year that they assume they will always be there. In fact, they may be approaching a point where they are at greater risk of dying from their drug use than at any point in the past.

Second, hospital casualty departments need to deal with drug addicts admitted for a non-fatal overdose in a much more intensive way than they do at present. While casualty staff will work valiantly to reverse the immediate effects of the drug overdose in what may be very difficult circumstances, most addicts then leave the hospital only to resume the drug use that had nearly killed them.

There is a need to ensure that all drug users admitted for an overdose are offered the maximum help possible, including the opportunity to talk about their drug use and their risk-taking behaviour, and, if necessary, be referred to specialist psychiatric services.

In many instances, they will also need follow-up support to reduce their risk of a subsequent fatal drug overdose. We need to ensure that, at the point where an addict is recovering from a non-fatal overdose, there is a maximum input of services. This is likely to be important not only in terms of reducing the likelihood of a subsequent fatal drug overdose but because the experience of the non-fatal overdose may help the individuals to realise that they are indeed at the end of the road of their addiction.

There will be those who question whether we should seek to preserve the life of someone so set on his or her own self-destruction. But drug addiction is an illness, not a moral failing. If we hold back from doing our best to preserve the life of an addict, who is to say where such selective treatment may end?

 Prof Neil McKeganey is director and Dr Joanne Neale a research fellow at the centre for drug misuse research, Glasgow university.

fields.headline: Culling fields
fields.standfirst: Paul Evans on a mass  shoot that may have  been more about  politics than pigeons
fields.trailText: Paul Evans on a mass shoot that may have been more about politics than pigeons.
fields.body:
Bang! A shotgun blast shattered the quiet of the woodland dusk. Other guns went off from the woods' edge. Last Saturday was national wood pigeon and corvid day, billed as Britain's biggest ever wild bird shoot. As wood pigeons and rooks straggled back across the sky to roost in the trees, it was time to get the hell out of there.

Organised by the National Gamekeepers Organisation (NGO), 8,000 guns signed up to shoot wood pigeons and corvids - rooks, crows, magpies, jackdaws and jays. According to NGO, the mass shoot aimed to help farmers get rid of the wood pigeons, which damage crops, and corvids, which prey on other birds. It was, they said, about pest control and conservation.

Or was it? Although small-scale roost shoots are a tradition at this time of year, just before the breeding season, there has not been a big national day for it since the 1950s and 1960s. The plan was to have so many guns blasting at the varmints that they would have no safe place to roost.

A National Farmers Union survey carried out in 1992 claimed that wood pigeons did £4m worth of damage annually, principally to oil seed rape and linseed crops during the winter. But this seems like a drop in the ocean compared with the £190m farmers receive in subsidies for these crops. Under the arable areas payment scheme, a farmer can get £427 per hectare of oil seed rape, even if it's poor quality or the wood pigeons ate it all. The emphasis is then on yield, with payments of £120 per ton, over and above the subsidies. So the wood pigeons affect the yield, but not the subsidy.

However, recent research suggests that when crops like oil seed are browsed by wood pigeons it helps to thin out the individual plants, allowing the remaining ones to grow bigger - thus achieving a higher yeild.

Given the level of public money being pumped into farming, you might expect those who want to kill wildlife to engage in some sort of public debate about it. With 40% of farmland birds lost since the mid-1970s, it seems cruelly ironic that those which have benefited from agricultural changes are now being persecuted.

But, no. Gamekeepers and their landowning bosses were intent on firing away, regardless of any conservation concerns.

In Shropshire, I asked the local wildlife trust what they thought of the shoot. Conservation officer John Tucker said: "This will not have much effect on the wood pigeon population, which in winter is swollen by climatic refugees - birds from colder climates of Scandinavia and further east in Europe. A shoot will replicate conditions of a normal winter, when many die anyway. There are no ecological grounds for this shoot. It's just a day for gamekeepers to be united in a rather spurious cause."

The RSPB said it was concerned that the 15-18 million winter population of wood pigeons represented a threat to crops, but was not so sure about the corvids. Crows and magpies may have a local impact on partidge, grouse and pheasants, which gamekeepers are interested in, but the jury is still out on whether they really do that much damage to other nesting birds. An RSPB spokesman says: "We have misgivings that a general license to shoot these birds may be abused for sporting or political purposes."

It seemed clear in the early reporting about national wood pigeon and corvid day that it was being used as a rally in support of the hunting community. The suggestion was that this was the alliance of rightwing countryside groups flexing more political muscle - putting on a show of strength and warning the government and the urban population what a committed and dangerous lobby they can be.

All this was denied by Charles Nodder, acting as spokesman for NGO. "This is not our aim at all," he said. "Our aim is to tell people about the need for pest control, how useful field sports are and why we do what we do. We have been misrepresented. We have a job to do and people can draw their own conclusions."

There are many people who will draw the same conclusions as Andrew Tyler, of Animal Aid. He says: "This is disgusting. Thousand of birds have been killed and even more will have died a slow lingering death from their injuries, just so that the field sports lobby can make a point. fields.bodyText: Bang! A shotgun blast shattered the quiet of the woodland dusk. Other guns went off from the woods' edge. Last Saturday was national wood pigeon and corvid day, billed as Britain's biggest ever wild bird shoot. As wood pigeons and rooks straggled back across the sky to roost in the trees, it was time to get the hell out of there. Organised by the National Gamekeepers Organisation (NGO), 8,000 guns signed up to shoot wood pigeons and corvids - rooks, crows, magpies, jackdaws and jays. According to NGO, the mass shoot aimed to help farmers get rid of the wood pigeons, which damage crops, and corvids, which prey on other birds. It was, they said, about pest control and conservation. Or was it? Although small-scale roost shoots are a tradition at this time of year, just before the breeding season, there has not been a big national day for it since the 1950s and 1960s. The plan was to have so many guns blasting at the varmints that they would have no safe place to roost. A National Farmers Union survey carried out in 1992 claimed that wood pigeons did £4m worth of damage annually, principally to oil seed rape and linseed crops during the winter. But this seems like a drop in the ocean compared with the £190m farmers receive in subsidies for these crops. Under the arable areas payment scheme, a farmer can get £427 per hectare of oil seed rape, even if it's poor quality or the wood pigeons ate it all. The emphasis is then on yield, with payments of £120 per ton, over and above the subsidies. So the wood pigeons affect the yield, but not the subsidy. However, recent research suggests that when crops like oil seed are browsed by wood pigeons it helps to thin out the individual plants, allowing the remaining ones to grow bigger - thus achieving a higher yeild. Given the level of public money being pumped into farming, you might expect those who want to kill wildlife to engage in some sort of public debate about it. With 40% of farmland birds lost since the mid-1970s, it seems cruelly ironic that those which have benefited from agricultural changes are now being persecuted. But, no. Gamekeepers and their landowning bosses were intent on firing away, regardless of any conservation concerns. In Shropshire, I asked the local wildlife trust what they thought of the shoot. Conservation officer John Tucker said: "This will not have much effect on the wood pigeon population, which in winter is swollen by climatic refugees - birds from colder climates of Scandinavia and further east in Europe. A shoot will replicate conditions of a normal winter, when many die anyway. There are no ecological grounds for this shoot. It's just a day for gamekeepers to be united in a rather spurious cause." The RSPB said it was concerned that the 15-18 million winter population of wood pigeons represented a threat to crops, but was not so sure about the corvids. Crows and magpies may have a local impact on partidge, grouse and pheasants, which gamekeepers are interested in, but the jury is still out on whether they really do that much damage to other nesting birds. An RSPB spokesman says: "We have misgivings that a general license to shoot these birds may be abused for sporting or political purposes." It seemed clear in the early reporting about national wood pigeon and corvid day that it was being used as a rally in support of the hunting community. The suggestion was that this was the alliance of rightwing countryside groups flexing more political muscle - putting on a show of strength and warning the government and the urban population what a committed and dangerous lobby they can be. All this was denied by Charles Nodder, acting as spokesman for NGO. "This is not our aim at all," he said. "Our aim is to tell people about the need for pest control, how useful field sports are and why we do what we do. We have been misrepresented. We have a job to do and people can draw their own conclusions." There are many people who will draw the same conclusions as Andrew Tyler, of Animal Aid. He says: "This is disgusting. Thousand of birds have been killed and even more will have died a slow lingering death from their injuries, just so that the field sports lobby can make a point. I don't believe this had anything to do with conservation - as the gamekeepers claim. I believe it was a sick political project."

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
It is more than 20 years since the first publication of Susan Sontag's book Illness As Metaphor, but her account of the mythologies surrounding TB and cancer is still a powerful reminder of our continuing incapacity to talk of any serious disease without relying upon common fantasies about both its causes and eventual outcome.

Sontag's concern was not merely to chronicle these fantasies but to rout them. How could we ever have a proper scientific appreciation of TB and cancer, she argued, when the dying tubercular was so often culturally depicted as made "more beautiful and soulful" by the disease whereas the person dying of cancer was "portrayed as robbed of all capacities of self-transcendence, humiliated by fear and anger"?

But is it possible to scrape away cultural accretions around a disease until we are left with nothing more than a blunt scientific category?

One sceptic is the social historian, Roy Porter, whose widely praised study, Gout: The Patrician Malady, appears in paperback next week. He shows that gout is positively steeped in myth. It was seen as a disease which only affected upper-class males of superior wit, genius and creativity. It was also thought to flow almost inevitably from excess: "To be 'in the gout' was animate proof that one already had been debauched."

Porter's reaction to this elaborate cultural edifice is far more sanguine than Sontag's. People, he points out, have "always given meaning to disease". It is the way in which they talk about the experience of the body itself and about their own individuality. "Why should the language of sickness not be available for staking out claims about the self?" he asks. Might there not be "a therapeutic value and possibly even virtual healthiness in owning one's own disorders", rather than handing them over to the medical profession?

But as the medical sociologist, Michael Bury, has recently argued, it is possible to agree with Porter that "stripping away metaphor and getting people to face pain, suffering and death directly is not possible for many people" and yet still be concerned about the manner in which metaphors can distort reality.

Our persistent belief that coronary heart disease is the moral pay-off reserved for over-stressed businessmen has led us to play down its greater incidence among working class men and virtually to ignore its impact upon women. Can we truly be comfortable with a metaphor which so crudely distorts reality?

 Laurie Taylor discusses illness as metaphor with Roy Porter and Michael Bury in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4 pm today.

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: A hail storm made visibility so bad during an over-40s league football match in Hartlepool that a linesman was still out on the pitch five minutes after the referee had abandoned the game.
fields.body:
House of repute: Phylis Dixie, who in 1940 became Britain's first legal striptease artist, is among the famous local people shortlisted to have plaques erected outside the houses where they lived in Surbiton, Surrey.

Counting the money: A woman from Dewsbury, Yorkshire, who admits to having been obsessed with Dracula and vampires since she was a child, has set up a company importing coffins from Transylvania.

Banged out: The drummer with a jazz-funk band got a shock when his neighbour's cat shot out of the bass drum as he started to play at a gig 60 miles from their home in Cardiff.

A bit fishy . . . Police are hunting for an angler who jumps into the Stroudwater canal in Gloucestershire and asks passing women to help him get out.

Sitting target: Four cars were badly damaged when they crashed into an armchair in the middle of the Malmesbury bypass, Wiltshire.

Stuck for cash: The ceremonial chain of the mayor of Congleton, Cheshire, is to be repaired at a cost of £3,500 after being held together with Blu-Tack for three years.

Mixed reception: A man who used modern materials to build a porch at his 200-year-old cottage near Warminster, Wiltshire, has overcome planning objections by using a mixture of cow dung and yoghurt to age the bricks.

Heavy duty: Operators of a school bus service have been forced to bring in bodyguards to protect drivers from unruly pupils of a comprehensive near Neath, south Wales.

Stolen moments: Women pinching chips from their partner's plate is the most common cause of arguments between couples eating out, according to a poll.

The old one-two: Two muggers got more than they bargained for when a 79-year-old great-grandfather they tried to rob in Doncaster, Yorkshire, turned out to be a former boxer who floored one of them with a right hook.

Copper coffee: Visitors to Alfreton police station, Derbyshire, are being offered free cups of ground coffee to help them feel relaxed if they are kept waiting to see an officer.

Out of touch: A hail storm made visibility so bad during an over-40s league football match in Hartlepool that a linesman was still out on the pitch five minutes after the referee had abandoned the game.

Grab and smash: An armed robber jailed for 10 years in Glasgow was caught because he had forgotten his glasses and managed to drive only 30 yards before crashing into an off-duty prison officer's car.

fields.headline: Other news
fields.trailText: Disney pulls out on Gwyneth Paltrow's Duets, Travolta in snow ploy to attend daughter's birth, Spike Lee signs to direct Kings of Comedy, and Eddie Murphy makes a packet out of Doolittle sequel
fields.body:
 Disney has decided not to distribute Gwyneth Paltrow's new film, Duets, because studio executives object to two violent scenes. The company, which prides itself on its reputation for family entertainment, said that the two scenes - one showing a man being gunned down in a convenience store, and the other showing a man being shot whilst performing karaoke - were not acceptable and has pulled out. "Those two scenes completely take you out of the film," a Disney source told the Hollywood Reporter. "It's just not for us, it may get a better release somewhere else." The company who made the film is now trying desperately to find a new distributor so the film can be released in May, as intended.

 A British company is to deliver £5,000 worth of artificial snow to California so that John Travolta can be present at the birth of his second child. The actor, who is currently filming Numbers said he would not leave his wife Kelly Preston at home in California just as the baby was due, so the makers of the film have asked British company Snowbusiness to deliver enough snow to Sacramento for a mile-long toboggan chase. Travolta says if the baby is a girl he will call her Diana, after his close friend the late Princess of Wales.

Casting couch

 Spike Lee has signed to direct Kings of Comedy, a docudrama based on a popular African-American live comedy act of the same name. The film will feature outtakes from the actual show, including the acts from Steve Harvey, DL Hughley and Bernie Mac, and mix it with backstage drama.

 As reported in yesterday's news, Eddie Murphy is to make a sequel to Dr Doolittle, once he has finalised a deal with production company Fox that will pay him a $20m advance against 20% of the gross earnings. The original grossed over $240m worldwide and opened at $29m. The astute Mr Murphy is expected to start filming after finishing work on another sequel, The Nutty Professor.

webTitle: Alternative Oscars blow a raspberry to the academy

fields.headline: Alternative Oscars blow a raspberry to the academy
fields.trailText: Two of last year's blockbusters, The Phantom Menace and Wild Wild West, are up for Worst Film at this year's Golden Raspberry Foundation Awards - aka the Razzies - a ceremony which satirises the Oscars by awarding top movies with a gold spray-painted plastic raspberry on top of a mangled film reel.
fields.body:
Two of last year's blockbusters, The Phantom Menace and Wild Wild West, are up for Worst Film at this year's Golden Raspberry Foundation Awards - aka the Razzies - a ceremony which satirises the Oscars by awarding top movies with a gold spray-painted plastic raspberry on top of a mangled film reel.

Each film has been nominated in eight categories of criticism by the 457 foundation members - journalists, cinema-goers and industry members in eight different countries - who sent in their postal votes to Golden Raspberry creator, John Wilson.

Their nominations include Worst Director for Star Wars' George Lucas and Worst Supporting Actor for his controversial computer-animated star Jar Jar Binks, whilst Wild Wild West star Kevin Kline was nominated for Worst Actor and Worst Supporting Actor. Other Worst Actor nominees up for the coveted award - retail value £2.50 - also include Kevin Kostner for his leading roles in Message in a Bottle and For the Love of the Game, and Robin Williams for his performance in Bicentennial Man and Jakob The Liar.

In contention for Worst Actress are Catherine Zeta-Jones for both Entrapment and The Haunting, Melanie Griffith for Crazy in Alabama and Heather Donahue for Blair Witch. And among nominees for the Worst Film title are The Blair Witch Project, Big Daddy and The Haunting.

To celebrate the end of the millennium, there will also be a number of Worst of the 20th Century awards. Sylvester Stallone has been nominated in the Worst Actor of the Century category for "99.5% of everything he has ever done", whilst Madonna is a strong contender for Worst Actress of the Century, although she will have to beat off strong competition from perennial favourite Bo Derek.

 The Golden Raspberry Award Foundation will announce its winners (or losers) on March 25 - the eve of the Oscars ceremony.

webTitle: 'He has lost interest in his former activities'

fields.headline: 'He has lost interest in his former activities'
fields.standfirst:
What the medical report says about Pinochet's changing life under police arrest in Surrey
The report's full conclusions
fields.trailText: What the medical report says about Pinochet's changing life under police arrest in Surrey
fields.body:
His feelings

"Senator Pinochet was depressed last summer but following a change of therapy this has ceased to be a problem. He still feels homesick and bored and frustrated by his physical ills. He wakes frequently at night."

His hobbies

"In recent months he has lost interest in former activities. He used to read and use the computer but now tends to sit watching television and says he has forgotten how to use the computer. Letter writing has become a chore and his handwriting less legible."

His daily routine

"Recently he has developed difficulty in shaving without cutting himself. His appetite is unremarkable, weight steady recently following temporary loss during last year. He has been troubled in recent months with aching pain in both buttocks, and his knees hurt in cold weather."

The neuropsychological assessment

"General Pinochet shows a moderate/severe deterioration of intellectual function beyond that due to his age. He was a person of superior intelligence and at present is functioning within the low average/average range. Short-term memory, learning ability and delayed recall all show severe deficit. His greatest difficulty is his inability to retain information over time. There is no evidence that General Pinochet is attempting to fake disability."

fields.headline: Children in care
fields.trailText:
How are children put into care?
Children are 'looked after' under government legislation if they are subject to a care order or if they are provided accommodation on a voluntary basis for more than 24 hours. They can be placed in care in a variety of circumstances: under an interim or full care order made by a court; if they are subject to police protection or an emergency or child protection order; if they are committed or remanded to local authority accommodation or made the subject of a residence requirement of a supervision order in criminal proceedings; if they have been sentenced under section 53 of the Child and Young Persons Act 1933.
fields.body:
How are children put into care?
Children are 'looked after' under government legislation if they are subject to a care order or if they are provided accommodation on a voluntary basis for more than 24 hours. They can be placed in care in a variety of circumstances: under an interim or full care order made by a court; if they are subject to police protection or an emergency or child protection order; if they are committed or remanded to local authority accommodation or made the subject of a residence requirement of a supervision order in criminal proceedings; if they have been sentenced under section 53 of the Child and Young Persons Act 1933.

Social services for children in England and Wales are provided under the provisions of the Children Act 1989 which came into force in October 1991. In Scotland the statute is the Children (Scotland) Act 1995 which was implemented in 1997.

How many are in care?
The latest figures for England show that social services departments looked after 55,300 children in 1999, a 4% increase on 1998. Of these 36,100 were in foster homes, 4,800 in community homes, 1,000 in hostels, 6,200 with their own parents and 2,900 were placed for adoption. 55% were boys.

How old are they?
The largest group - 22,300 children were aged 10 to 15. There were 9,000 over 16, 12,500 aged between 5 and 9 and 11,400 under fives.

What about children at risk?
Each social services department holds a central register which lists all the children in the area who are considered to be suffering from or likely to suffer significant harm. Registration takes place at a child protection conference. In England and Wales last year there were 31,000 children on registers. The peak was in 1991 with 43,300 cases.

What sort of abuse do they suffer?
The main reason for being placed on a register continued to be neglect with 13,900 cases. This is defined as persistent neglect or failure to protect a child from exposure to any kind of danger, including cold or starvation, or a failure to carry out important aspects of care leading to significant impairment of a child's health or development.

The second highest category is physical abuse with 9,100 cases. Sexual abuse accounted for 6,600 cases and emotional abuse 5,400. The number at risk from physical or sexual abuse continued to fall while the numbers at risk from neglect and emotional abuse rose. Under the Family Law Act 1997 a suspected abuser can be removed from the family home, rather than taking the child away as was the case before.

How far does alcohol play a role in child abuse?
An estimated 920,000 children in the UK could be living in a family where a parent has an alcohol problem. Research shows that alcohol is a factor in a third of child abuse cases, while young people in families with a drinking parent are much more liable to suffer from psychiatric disorders. An Alcohol Concern study found that living with a problem drinking parent can take away a young person's childhood, forcing them to shoulder responsibilities for beyond what could be expected.

What's the role of adoption?
About a third of all children adopted have been looked after by a local authority. Two thousand were adopted in 1999, slightly more boys than girls, with an average age of 4 years 11 months.

What is the government doing to prevent any repetition of the scandal in Wales?
After the disclosure of past abuse in children's homes, the previous Conservative government set up an inquiry. The report concluded that abuse on such a scale is now unlikely to happen in children's homes, a view supported yesterday by the Association of Directors of Social Services. It recommended that the government implement a strategy to drive up the standards in children's homes. The response from the former health secretary Frank Dobson in September 1988 was the Quality Protects Programme, which instructed local authorities to draw up an action plan and appoint an official to monitor it.

fields.headline: Don't let peace slip away
fields.standfirst:
It's time for all parties involved to take a final bold step to save the Northern Ireland peace process, says Derek Brown
Plus: The old man and the ABC
fields.trailText: It's time for all parties involved to take a final bold step to save the Northern Ireland peace process, says Derek Brown
fields.body:
The Provisional IRA is in a dangerously fragile condition. Last week, it said it would never give up its weapons. At the weekend, panicked by the suspension of power-sharing devolution, it said it would consider disarmament. Now it has withdrawn in a huff from the decommissioning process.

Goodness knows how many more times it will travel round the revolving door, and who will come out of it on the right side. The republican movement is battered and divided, its Sinn Fein leadership undermined and despairing. A split surely cannot be far off.

The Provisionals, who broke away from the Official Republicans in 1970, are themselves a product of the schismatic tendency which is deeply embedded in the movement. It can be traced back to the Irish civil war of the 20s, and it is living now in the shadowy form of the Real and Continuity versions of the IRA.

But there still is - there must be - hope that the Provisionals can limit the damage to their own movement, and play a part in the peace process which is supported by an overwhelming majority of the people of Northern Ireland.

For that slender hope to be realised, both the republicans and the unionists must now show some generosity of spirit, and stop shovelling all the blame for the current crisis on "the other side". The fact is that both groups have given a spectacular amount of ground. They should be applauding, not rubbishing, each other.

The Sinn Fein/IRA republicans - for it is hard to believe that there is a distinction between the armed and political wings - have not only stopped their grisly campaign of violence; they have undertaken, courageously, to take part in government under the crown. They are, as their own hard men would say, collaborating with the enemy.

The unionists, for their part, have overcome their deeply embedded antipathy to power-sharing, and have sat at the same table with the representatives of a rebel movement. That they should now want that movement to start to disarm is entirely reasonable; but that they should unilaterally set a deadline for disarmament is not.

The British and Irish governments too have given generously; the former with its early release of paramilitary prisoners, and the latter by dropping its constitutional claim to the six northern counties.

The idea that the peace process could now go into reverse gear is ghastly, but it is a very real risk. This is a time not just for coolness, but for boldness. All parties simply must jump together.

Power-sharing, cross-border institutions, RUC reform and disarmament must be bundled into a package for simultaneous implementation. Peace in Northern Ireland no longer depends on grudging, piecemeal concessions, but rather on across-the-board action.

Related documentary
Northern Ireland: special report

The old man and the ABC

So now we know what Jack Straw was so reluctant to share with us: that General Augusto Pinochet is physically fit, but brain-damaged. The old dictator would be able to stand trial, but would have difficulty following the proceedings.

The home secretary wants to send Pinochet home to Chile, but didn't want to tell us why. He was obliged by the high court to release the medical report to those countries hoping to extradite the old rogue to stand trial for damaging lots of other people's brains. The report was handed over, in strict confidence, to Spain, Belgium, France and Switzerland. Hours later, a full text was printed on the website of Spain's ABC newspaper.

Hooray for Spanish journalism, and for the internet. Pity about the general's privacy, but then again he didn't show much respect for other people's rights during his 17-year reign of terror.

fields.headline: Collymore in trouble again
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore has landed himself in trouble barely a week after joining Leicester City. The striker has been accused of being behind a disturbance late last night which forced Leicester to return home from a training break in Spain.
fields.byline: By Football Unlimited staff and agencies
fields.body:
Stan Collymore has landed himself in trouble barely a week after joining Leicester City. The striker has been accused of being behind a disturbance late last night which forced Leicester to return home from a training break in Spain.

Collymore has been named as the man who let off a fire extinguisher in a hotel bar in La Manga at 2.30 this morning. According to Sky Sports News, the 29-year-old has denied the claims but the managing director at La Manga, Tony Coles, said: "When the entertainment finished, Stan Collymore decided to let off a fire extinguisher in the bar.

"The effects of a fire extinguisher going off are very unpleasant. They do enormous damage. Hotel security and resort security arrived, and they resolved the situation.

"The players were sent to bed and this morning, after meetings with John Robertson (assistant manager) and Paul Franklin (coach), and a telephone conversation with Martin O'Neill (manager), I asked them to leave and they have gone.

"Their behaviour was totally and utterly unacceptable. We have major concerns about looking after all our clients and we can't expose them to this sort of behaviour.

"We would not want them to return for the foreseeable future. We have now had over 250 teams visit our soccer centre since it was opened in 1998 and we have never had any problems whatsoever."

Leicester released a statement this afternoon which read: "As part of our preparations for the Worthington Cup final, players and officials travelled to Spain for a scheduled break at the La Manga resort.

"The club will be launching its own internal investigation and will severely reprimand any individual or individuals found to be in breach of club discipline."

fields.headline: Don't stop the music
fields.trailText: The MCC's ban on musical instruments at Lord's this summer is at odds with the ECB's marketing ploy for the World Cup last year: it will affect the very people the board is trying so hard to attract. The Carnival of Cricket featured two black faces on its official brochure, one of them a Rastafarian man. In an attempt to be seen to be taking the game to ethnic minorities, the ECB wheeled in B-list celebs - from the Indian novelist and actress Meera Syal to chef Ainsley Harriot (who had me in stitches with stories about his cousin, the former West Indies wicketkeeper Jeffrey Dujon). The thing had an unmistakably Caribbean flavour, right down to the music. Channel 4 caught the spirit of the times with their snazzy theme song "Mambo Number Five", and pictures of a suitably moody, brooding Alex Tudor.
fields.body:
The MCC's ban on musical instruments at Lord's this summer is at odds with the ECB's marketing ploy for the World Cup last year: it will affect the very people the board is trying so hard to attract. The Carnival of Cricket featured two black faces on its official brochure, one of them a Rastafarian man. In an attempt to be seen to be taking the game to ethnic minorities, the ECB wheeled in B-list celebs - from the Indian novelist and actress Meera Syal to chef Ainsley Harriot (who had me in stitches with stories about his cousin, the former West Indies wicketkeeper Jeffrey Dujon). The thing had an unmistakably Caribbean flavour, right down to the music. Channel 4 caught the spirit of the times with their snazzy theme song "Mambo Number Five", and pictures of a suitably moody, brooding Alex Tudor.

As they used to do with female membership, the MCC are demonstrating how spectacularly out of touch they are. Instead of taking the ECB's strategy a step forward by allowing the drums and trumpets in, they've moved backwards. It's as if they're happy for the dominant image of the Lord's Test to be the age-old one of gin-soaked colonels, steaming in the blazers and ties in the summer heat - or what passes for it in England. West Indies fans will bring their own atmosphere of course, in the same way that Aussies bring their chanting ("Aussie, Aussie, Aussie! Oi, Oi, Oi!") painted faces, wigs and plastic kangaroos.

But Caribbean fans without musical instruments is like Tiger Woods without his irons. Who can forget the din at The Oval in 1976 when they helped pump up Michael Holding to return his best-ever match figures of 14 for 149 and beat England? Or the World Cup finals of '75 and '79, both of which the Windies won? We don't even need to go that far back to be reminded how good it can get. At last year's World Cup, Dublin entertained Bangladesh and the West Indies - Brick Lane meets Brixton. Each side had their own orchestra on the tiny Clontarf ground. The atmosphere sizzled in spite of a very cold day and a dull, one-sided game.

That's the whole point about cricket for Caribbean people. It has always been an occasion, a day out, far more than what's happening on the field of play. To quote the title of CLR James's cricketing classic, it has always extended beyond a boundary. Watching an entire stand at the Antigua Recreation Ground heaving to soca music and a cross-dressing character named Gravy gyrating on his head, is one of the unforgettable experiences of a Caribbean cricket tour.

I can half understand why a musical din at a place like Lord's would not be to everyone's liking. A day's play is different things to different people, depending on whether they come from Trinidad or Tunbridge Wells. But Disgusted would have to concede that the face of cricket is changing, and with it the kind of day out he can expect. He might even come to like the stuff. And despite the carefree image, Caribbean people are generally conformist, something instilled in them by an upbringing that emphasises manners. Ever noticed how in Antigua the band leader waves the music to a stop as the bowler gets into his delivery stride? And how it picks up again once the shot is played? It's about having fun without being disruptive. MCC take note.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for five years and currently works as a broadcast journalist.

webTitle: Hungary to sue over cyanide spill

fields.headline: Hungary to sue over cyanide spill
fields.standfirst: More about the Danube cyanide spill
fields.trailText:
Hungary today confirmed that it will take legal action over the cyanide spill that has destroyed the
ecosystems of two of its rivers in the worst European environmental disaster since Chernobyl.
fields.body:
Hungary today confirmed that it will take legal action over the cyanide spill that has destroyed the ecosystems of two of its rivers in the worst European environmental disaster since Chernobyl.

Prime minister Viktor Orban said his country is planning three lawsuits: against the Rumanian-Australian gold mining joint venture, its Australian parent company and against Rumania in the international courts for compensation.

Mr Orban said the aftermath of the cyanide contamination could spark tensions in bilateral relations, but added that that Hungary had to defend its interests to the fullest possible extent. The cyanide spill has already sparked complaints from Yugoslavia, which issued a protest note to the Rumanian embassy in Belgrade yesterday.

The note cited "serious damage caused by the destruction of fish in the Tisza and the hazard to the riverside". The Geneva-based Green Cross International said the cyanide had killed all living species in its path and threatened to contaminate the Black Sea.

The group blamed the west for its failure to provide enough funds to rebuild the destroyed economies of the region and to upgrade obsolete industrial infrastructure, or to impose the kind of regulations necessary to prevent accidents.

Yugoslav ecologists warned of long-term food poisoning and dangerous metal concentrations that have already killed tons of fish in the contaminated Danube and Tisza rivers.

"Dead fish are covering the rivers, and 400,000 birds that find winter shelter in the Yugoslav part of the Danube River are threatened," said prominent ecologist Radoje Lausevic. He warned there was a great danger that the river pollution - which was dozens of times above normal levels - could contaminate the food chain through groundwater and water used for irrigation.

The cyanide poured into streams from a containment dam at a gold mine near the Rumanian town of Baia Mare on January 30, returning to Rumania after passing through Hungary and Yugoslavia via the Szamos and Tisza rivers. The World Health Organisation earlier expressed concern that heavy metals such as lead and cadmium also might have escaped into the water, posing a potentially far greater health threat.

Esmeralda, the Australian company that co-owns the Baia Mare gold mine, has denied responsibility for the cyanide spill, saying the extent of poisoning had been exaggerated. Rumania has argued that the damage was overstated and that it suffered the most. Hungary and Yugoslavia have demanded compensation from Romania; both have threatened to sue Bucharest if their demands are not met.

fields.headline: Depp comes over all camera-shy
fields.trailText: He didn't mind donning the 70s gear for his role in Donnie Brasco, but according to a story on BBC Online, Johnny Depp is so embarrassed by his 70s get-up in his new film Blow that he's refusing to show his face on set.
fields.body:
He didn't mind donning the 70s gear for his role in Donnie Brasco, but according to a story on BBC Online, Johnny Depp is so embarrassed by his 70s get-up in his new film Blow that he's refusing to show his face on set.

Depp, who plays George Jung, a notorious West Coast cocaine dealer believed to be responsible for bringing 80% of the drug into the country in the 70s, has to wear flares, a tight white top, long dyed hair and enormous sideburns and, according to an extra, refuses to hang around the set for longer than he needs to.

"He has a body-double doing all the set-ups for him. He hates being here for very long and will just be brought here when it is absolutely necessary," the insider said.

fields.headline: AOL Europe swaps travel agent
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
ebookers
fields.trailText: Ebookers.com, the online travel agency, has struck a £15m alliance with AOL Europe to become the group's preferred travel partner on its website, replacing Microsoft's travel outfit Expedia.
fields.body:
Ebookers.com, the online travel agency, has struck a £15m alliance with AOL Europe to become the group's preferred travel partner on its website, replacing Microsoft's travel outfit Expedia.

The two-year agreement will see Ebookers pay £15m to AOL Europe in two tranches. The payment is conditional on an agreed number of page impressions being generated from the advertising and promotion on AOL's site.

Analysts had estimated that Ebookers' sales and marketing spend for 2000 would be $45m (£28m) of the $70m it raised after floating on the Nasdaq at $18 a share in November last year.

The first tranche paid will be drawn from that $45m with the understanding that Ebookers might have to issue more shares later this year to raise funds to pay the second tranche.

Dinesh Dhamija, chief executive of Ebookers, said: "This is unquestionably the most significant alliance we have negotiated to date. To sign an exclusive pan-European deal with a company of the calibre and stature of AOL Europe further strengthens the Ebookers.com brand and allows us to expand our sales and branding efforts across Europe."

The agreement covers Britain, Germany, France, Switzerland, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Austria and Sweden.

Ebookers also expects to announce several acquisitions of online travel agencies in Italy, Spain, Denmark and the Netherlands in the next few months.

AOL Europe - a joint venture between America Online and Bertelsmann - replaced Expedia with Ebookers after looking for an online travel agency that could offer a pan-European service.

Andreas Schmidt, president and chief executive of AOL Europe, said: "This relationship will offer our members the unparalleled breadth and value of fares and services they want, providing them with ease of access to a wealth of travel information and services to meet all their travel needs."

Ebookers handled more than 10,000 passengers last month, which represents an increase of 600%-plus on the 1,466 passengers it served in January last year.

webTitle: Brown to push for lower internet charges

fields.headline: Brown to push for lower internet charges
fields.trailText:
Chancellor Gordon Brown today will announce plans to slash the
cost of internet access by forcing British Telecommunications to
allow rivals the use of its local loop - the wires that run into
homes and businesses.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown today will announce plans to slash the cost of internet access by forcing British Telecommunications to allow rivals the use of its local loop - the wires that run into homes and businesses.

The telecoms regulator, Oftel, had agreed to open the local loop to BT's competitors by July 1, 2001, but Mr Brown wants to bring that date forward. Telecom companies welcomed the initiative. Tony Illsley, chief executive of Telewest, said the regulator's plans to force BT to grant access to its local loop would mean that Telewest could offer national services beyond the boundaries of its own cable network.

"A lot of our research has shown that what's holding a lot of families back from the internet is concern about bill shock," Mr Illsley said.

In an interview with the Financial Times, Mr Brown said he was concerned that high telephone charges meant British companies lagged behind the US in e-commerce. Only one in 10 businesses in Britain sells online with one in four buying online. Fewer than one in five people have internet access in Britain compared to one in two in the US.

Analysts have estimated that flat-fee internet connections with unmetered time online would triple internet usage in Britain, although some think the timescale too slow.

webTitle: Wages and jobs hit new highs

fields.headline: Wages and jobs hit new highs
fields.trailText: The treasury called for pay restraint today as wage growth rose to its highest level for almost 18 months and unemployment fell to a 20-year low.
fields.body:
The treasury called for pay restraint today as wage growth rose to its highest level for almost 18 months and unemployment fell to a 20-year low.

A record 27,580,000 people are now in work, as the numbers claiming benefit fell by 9,800 last month to 1,158,000. However, the figures mask a continuing decline in manufacturing jobs.

The claimant count total represents a 4% jobless rate, the best figure since January 1980. International Labour Organisation unemployment, which includes people not eligible for benefit, also fell, by 4,000 to 1,718,000 between October and December last year.

However, average earnings increased by 5.5% in the year to December, a rise of 0.6% compared to the previous month. The Office for National Statistics said the rise was due mostly to bonus payments in manufacturing and financial services and millennium payments in hotels and catering, as well as continued increases in manufacturing overtime.

Average earnings rose by 5.8% in private firms in the year to December, compared to 3.9% in the public sector.

Although claimant count unemployment has fallen by an average of 15,000 a month in the last quarter and by 12,700 a month in the last six months, the ILO unemployment rate was 5.9% in October to December, unchanged from the previous quarter.

The number of manufacturing jobs continued to fall, down by 126,000 to 4,015,000 in the three months to December, with the biggest cutbacks in textiles and leather.

There were also signs that the fall in unemployment might be about to bottom out. Notifications of new vacancies to jobcentres fell by 7,700 to 228,800 last month.

The treasury issued an immediate call for pay restraint following the unexpectedly big leap in average earnings, while also emphasising that the rise was linked, in part, to millennium bonus payments.

"These figures reinforce the need for all of us to show responsibility on pay," a spokesman said. "We must not pay ourselves more than we can afford now at the cost of higher interest rates, lower growth and fewer jobs tomorrow."

fields.headline: It's a wonderful death
fields.standfirst: It's Oscar shortlist time again. Stuart Jeffries  meets Frank Darabont, director of tear-jerking prison movie The Green Mile
fields.trailText: It's Oscar shortlist time again. Stuart Jeffries meets Frank Darabont, director of tear-jerking prison movie The Green Mile.
fields.body:
Sentimentalism is the working off on yourself of feelings you haven't really got," DH Lawrence once wrote. "Very few people really feel love, or sex passion, or kindliness, or anything else that goes at all deep. So the mass just fake these feelings inside themselves. Faked feelings! The world is all gummy with them."

The Green Mile - which has Oscar nominations for best film, best sound, best screenplay adaptation and best supporting actor (Michael Clarke Duncan) - is sentimental, and not just because it stars Tom Hanks as a prison guard, playing another of his nice American Everyman roles. It's sentimental because it manipulates us into feeling a great deal, then leaves us red-eyed in the foyer, wondering if our emotion has any value.

The Green Mile is set in a death row prison block in Louisiana in 1935. A man mountain of a black prisoner is brought into a cell to await execution for the rape and murder of two white girls. Frank Darabont's film affects to be challenging by confounding our expectations about the milieu in which it is set. The prison guards (all white) are good and non-racist, apart from one crudely drawn baddie. The black inmate, John Coffey (Duncan), is set up as an ogre, but turns out to be an innocent with magical powers. Despite several electric chair executions shown in purportedly upsetting detail, this is not - unlike Dead Man Walking - a film that proselytises against capital punishment.

In fact, for all its cunning confounding of expectations and provoking of emotions, it's not at all clear what, if anything, the film is saying. And it takes a very long time to say it. Adapted from Stephen King's six-part novel published in 1996, it is 188 minutes long. While it's not as rambling as most recent King fiction, it still has more back story and leisurely character development than you could shake a stick at. There's even a subplot about Paul Edgecombe's (Tom Hanks's) urinary infection, which, given that the film is long enough to warrant at least one trip to the loo, is a bold move. Never before has a lead actor been to the toilet so often in a movie; never before, I'll bet, has a double Oscar winner been required to yell "I'm pissing razor blades" from his cubicle.

But really. What's wrong with a good long sentimental film? You know, one of those that often involve Hanks or Meg Ryan or both. There's a huge audience for this kind of blubbathon, for a Titanic, a Schindler's List, a Saving Private Ryan or a Green Mile. Darabont's film has taken $120m in the US and is poised to fill British multiplexes later this month.

Darabont suspects that these audiences want to purge their emotions. And perhaps - contra Lawrence - it doesn't matter too much what those feelings are about; to have them at all in the cinema is enough. "To me the core of film- making is to stir the emotions of the audience," says Darabont.

He has written, produced and worked on many films but directed just two, the other being The Shawshank Redemption. Both are based on King novels, both are set in prison, both have redemptive, humanistic messages that have proved appealing and lucrative. Darabont is becoming a latterday Frank Capra, wallowing in sentiment in an unashamedly Ameri can way that makes snooty critics sniffy. His next film, which he hopes to shoot later this year, he describes as a Capra-esque romantic comedy set during the McCarthyite blacklisting in the 50s. It will, he promises, be sentimental. "There's nothing wrong with honest sentiment," he says. "It's a Wonderful Life is my favourite movie of all time, which should tell you something.

"Both films I have made are very moving," says Darabont. "They both say something very positive about the human heart and I think it's something people crave to hear."

Even when Darabont, 41, was a film student he was trying to make movies of King's books: "I've always been drawn to his voice as an author. To me he's up there with Dickens, who was a great populist storyteller."

Doesn't he think The Green Mile is too long, that the framing devices could have been cut, and that the execution scenes are self-indulgent? "No, and apparently neither does the audience in the US. It's been a huge success," he says, understandably defensive. "I can mention precious few great 90-minute movies, but I can reel off many great films that are three hours plus, starting off with Mr Lean's work, Mr Kubrick's work and Mr Cameron's work.

"If you're gonna go on a rich emotional journey with the storyteller, then you need to get to know the characters. I don't think the boat started sinking until nearly two hours into Titanic. If the boat had started sinking after 30 minutes, I wouldn't have cared as much about those characters."

The Green Mile is, as Darabont recognises, a cunningly manipulative film. "Every frame of every movie is an attempt by the artist to manipulate the perceptions or emotions of the viewer. The point is, do you appreciate the manipulation or resent it? Do you notice it, or do you completely, blindly give yourself over to it?"

The problem is that the film constructs a reassuring moral universe out of what was a cruel prison system, and thus short-circuits our emotions, making them unproblematically uplifting and not worth reflecting upon. This, after all, was the South of Jim Crow, this was the penal system that used the chain gang, the whip and the club. Louisiana state penitentiary was one of the most violent penal institutions in America. Only last year a documentary called The Farm: Angola USA showed that racism was still rife there. Darabont's film is seemingly oblivious to all this. Shouldn't he have made a more substantial film?

Darabont believes he has. "I enjoy the fact that we might give the audience something to think about - the death penalty, race relations, miracles, our relationship with a higher power. But I don't want to make up people's minds for them. I love that we had an earlier era of films in which you would leave the theatre but not leave the movie behind. You'd go out with your friends and talk about it for three hours over coffee. I'm hearing from a lot of people that this is the effect it's having and I think that's wonderful."

But what are they talking about? About racism in the US? Darabont thinks so. "With The Green Mile, King is saying something very compelling about the relationship between the races at that time. Maybe not just at that time, but forever. And the message is: don't judge a book by its cover. There's magic in all of us if you look closely enough."

But that message is sentimental and expresses only a facile truth. And indeed, The Green Mile's simplistic vision of the world is one in which the bad guys have shifty eyes and are sadistic to pet mice. It's one in which black men cannot be allowed to be bad and white men cannot be racist. Consequently, racism is not treated seriously. Instead, Coffey is an instinctive healer who helps Hanks with his waterworks.

The Green Mile inhabits a soothing dreamworld in which audiences can experience strong yet vague feelings and leave the cinema thinking life is beautiful. The sentimentality is akin to that characterised by the philosopher Professor Malcolm Budd in his book Values of Art. Such sentimentality "involves the wilful neglect of various aspects of the target of the emotion that would necessitate a more complex and less rewarding response; a false intensity of experience is gained by ignoring any features that militate against the simple, one-sided response which typically idealises, glamorises or romanticises the target, making it tug at the heartstrings."

And yet there is, and perhaps always has been, a big demand for such heartstring tugging. No wonder Darabont is keen to compare King to Dickens. "Dickens was a bleeding heart for humanism, he had a wide open heart for humanity. Now people are catching on to the fact that King is very much more like that than they thought, largely I think because of the film of Stand By Me and, I suspect, the films I've made."

Darabont has undeniably caught King's gushing humanism. When Coffey walks the Green Mile (the title is a reference to the colour of linoleum on the death row floor) to the electric chair, everyone on screen seems to be crying. Coffey is crying. The guards are carrying on like they're Gwyneth Paltrow at Oscar time. Even Hanks's chin is twitching. It's Dickensian sentimental overload: like the death of Little Nell in The Old Curiosity Shop, it would take a heart of stone not to laugh at the scene. Or maybe I'm cynical.

Maybe not. I tell Darabont that the most affecting execution scene I have seen in film was in Kieslowski's A Short Film About Killing. A young man is hanged for the vile murder of a taxi driver. Has he seen Kieslowski's film? Darabont admits he has not, but perhaps he should. It takes the viewer on an emotional journey at the end of which we question our feelings rather than merely have them and leave them in drenched Kleenexes on the cinema floor. And it makes us sit around over coffee for hours afterwards arguing about substantial things - about whether there is a moral difference between murder and state killings. DH Lawrence might have liked Kieslowski's film but not, surely, Darabont's.

The Green Mile is released on February 25.

fields.headline: Cinderella Minghella
fields.trailText: Anthony Minghella talks to Xan Brooks about the transformation of The Talented Mr Ripley from a snappy pulp thriller into a sweeping examination of class envy
fields.body:
The titular hero of The Talented Mr. Ripley is a man with his nose pressed up against the glass. Through the sun-dappled resort-land of the Italian Riviera he goes; a star-struck interloper from the wrong side of the tracks. He hungers for a new lifestyle, a change of identity. Cool, easy-living Dickie Greenleaf - bumming around Europe on his daddy's allowance - embodies everything that Ripley desires. The pauper looks at the playboy and wants to possess him.

On reading Patricia Highsmith's source novel twenty years ago, writer-director Anthony Minghella felt an immediate affinity with this gauche, questing anti-hero. Certainly the man's own upbringing on the Isle of Wight reads like a peculiarly anglicised take on the Ripley tale. The son of working-class Italian parents, Cinderella Minghella's weekends were spent working inside the family ice-cream van, serving cones and ices to the island bourgeousie. "For me," he remembers, "every English person was a Dickie Greenleaf."

In a sense, then, Minghella's career history has been an uphill struggle from humble origins. The gloss and polish on show in The Talented Mr. Ripley is the result of years of careful honing. As an aspiring writer, he cut his teeth in local theatre and the TV treadmill. He wrote scripts for Inspector Morse and toiled through a regular gig on Grange Hill. During the Nineties, he began picking up speed. His debut feature --1991's Highgate-set romantic fable Truly, Madly, Deeply - was a successful calling-card, while film number-two - 1993's Mr. Wonderful - broke him into the American film industry. In 1997 he took an oblique, complicated, darn-near unfilmable novel called The English Patient and converted it into a critics' favourite, a box-office hit and Oscar-winner for Best Picture and Best Director.

Released in the UK next week, The Talented Mr. Ripley follows The English Patient's tried-and-tested tack of translating a book to the screen. Indeed, such is Minghella's success in this area that he's even planning on doing it again - his next project will be an adaptation of Charles Frazier's Civil War novel Cold Mountain. "I think the problem with being a playwright from an early age is that you start patrolling the same ground," he tells me. "You start telling the same story, making the same film. Adapting a book stops you falling into a pattern of repetition. Also there's an attraction of almost having an argument or a discourse with the novel. It takes you to places you wouldn't normally go. I mean, Cold Mountain is about the American Civil War and the romance of nature, and none of that feels comfortable to me. In the same way, Patricia Highsmith and I are not natural bedfellows. But it's fun to have that argument with the material. It stretches you in new directions."

In the case of The Talented Mr. Ripley, then, he somehow conspires to remould Highsmith's snappy pulp thriller into a sweeping, well-toned examination of class envy and identity. Minghella initially came to the project three years ago, in the fraught months when funding for The English Patient kept falling through. It was intially conceived as a smaller scale picture, until the runaway success of The English Patient beefed it into a bona-fide Hollywood spectacular. "It wasn't so much that The English Patient inflated Ripley as the fact that I began to sense the story's possibilities," Minghella argues. "I realised how what was essentially a suspense story, a thriller, could become the vehicle to enable the film to talk about more profound things than the book did. In a sense, I realised what Ripley could be, and that it couldn't be a little chamber piece any longer."

Such a transformation brought its own set of problems. Because, love it or not, Ripley is an uncharacteristically dark and edgy Hollywood product. Its lead character (ably played by Matt Damon) is at once pathetic and horribly pro-active; a serial-killer with homosexual leanings. There have been rumours in the press of studio concern over aspects of the picture, and script rewrites undertaken on the insistence of co-star Gwyneth Paltrow. "Let's just say there were appropriate anxieties about the film," Minghella says. "But film-making is a long process and attitudes don't change in a day. It's much more organic than that. So yes, there was resistance to Ripley over a period of many months. Oddly enough, the more interested that Miramax were in the film the more nervous they became. It had big stars and a bigger budget, so there was much more to lose and inevitably the story's subject comes under more scrutiny. Luckily for me, The English Patient had been a big hit so my judgement was more trusted than it otherwise might have been."

This is not to say that Ripley is some wild guerrilla missive in the style of Todd Solondz's Happiness or Lars Von Trier's The Idiots. Minghella doesn't make movies like that. His story's dark interiors come covered with a pristine surface (all sumptuous locations and pretty star faces). You might even feel that The Talented Mr. Ripley is just too darn refined. Reviewing the film in the online magazine Salon, Charles Taylor likened the picture to "an expensive desert cart propelled by a discreet waiter. After a while you get the message - Anthony Minghella doesn't want to get his hands dirty."

Minghella admits it - up to a point. "The more I understand about film-making the more meticulous I want to be. And yes, there's a great deal to be said for throwing all that away. I recently made a three-minute film for Comic Relief in Nairobi where we were just shooting and moving, hanging the camera out of the back of the car, and it was wonderful. But to a certain extent you have to make peace with yourself. There is a scale of film that I naturally gravitate to - films that are larger and more formal and have this careful finish to every frame. That is the style of film-making that I find myself drawn to and I have grown to respect my own voice."

On current evidence, Hollywood does too. The Talented Mr. Ripley has already eclipsed The English Patient in terms of American box-office takings, and if its sum total of five Oscar nominations is a shade down on The English Patient's tally of nine, the failure is only relative. "Exactly," says the director. "There's nothing like having such an incandescent success as The English Patient to make everything else look dim."

Minghella claims to treat both monetary and Academy success with a hefty pinch of salt. The fact remains, though, that the director has carved a career making the sort of classy star-vehicles that appear tailor-made for both. If the young Minghella craved a place at Hollywood's top tabel, he's now got it, with bells on. The English Patient made his reputation. Ripley has secured it. "I know that the commentators were looking to label me as a one-hit wonder, so I'm very comforted to have avoided that," he admits. "I don't feel I've got anything to prove as a film-maker now. Having said that, Oscars and box-office don't actually have any effect on the content of a film. Certainly The English Patient wasn't any better the day after the Oscars than it was before. I can't imagine that Ripley will be either."

There have been rumours in the press of studio concern over aspects of the picture, and script rewrites undertaken on the insistence of co-star Gwyneth Paltrow. "Let's just say there were appropriate anxieties about the film," Minghella says. "But film-making is a long process and attitudes don't change in a day. It's much more organic than that. So yes, there was resistance to Ripley over a period of many months. Oddly enough, the more interested that Miramax were in the film the more nervous they became. It had big stars and a bigger budget, so there was much more to lose and inevitably the story's subject comes under more scrutiny. Luckily for me, The English Patient had been a big hit so my judgement was more trusted than it otherwise might have been." This is not to say that Ripley is some wild guerrilla missive in the style of Todd Solondz's Happiness or Lars Von Trier's The Idiots. Minghella doesn't make movies like that. His story's dark interiors come covered with a pristine surface (all sumptuous locations and pretty star faces). You might even feel that The Talented Mr. Ripley is just too darn refined. Reviewing the film in the online magazine Salon, Charles Taylor likened the picture to "an expensive desert cart propelled by a discreet waiter. After a while you get the message - Anthony Minghella doesn't want to get his hands dirty." Minghella admits it - up to a point. "The more I understand about film-making the more meticulous I want to be. And yes, there's a great deal to be said for throwing all that away. I recently made a three-minute film for Comic Relief in Nairobi where we were just shooting and moving, hanging the camera out of the back of the car, and it was wonderful. But to a certain extent you have to make peace with yourself. There is a scale of film that I naturally gravitate to - films that are larger and more formal and have this careful finish to every frame. That is the style of film-making that I find myself drawn to and I have grown to respect my own voice." On current evidence, Hollywood does too. The Talented Mr. Ripley has already eclipsed The English Patient in terms of American box-office takings, and if its sum total of five Oscar nominations is a shade down on The English Patient's tally of nine, the failure is only relative. "Exactly," says the director. "There's nothing like having such an incandescent success as The English Patient to make everything else look dim." Minghella claims to treat both monetary and Academy success with a hefty pinch of salt. The fact remains, though, that the director has carved a career making the sort of classy star-vehicles that appear tailor-made for both. If the young Minghella craved a place at Hollywood's top tabel, he's now got it, with bells on. The English Patient made his reputation. Ripley has secured it. "I know that the commentators were looking to label me as a one-hit wonder, so I'm very comforted to have avoided that," he admits. "I don't feel I've got anything to prove as a film-maker now. Having said that, Oscars and box-office don't actually have any effect on the content of a film. Certainly The English Patient wasn't any better the day after the Oscars than it was before. I can't imagine that Ripley will be either."

webTitle: Diary of an international family planner

fields.headline: Harmony rules
fields.standfirst: In China, a land where one child is the norm,  Anna McDermott finds a sexual revolution
fields.trailText: In China, a land where one child is the norm, Anna McDermott finds a sexual revolution.
fields.body:
The docks through which I departed Shanghai 15 years ago were Dickensian. A mural of the "ideal" one-child family was painted storeys high on the side of a building.

Now, I was back in a China, where many educated and prosperous couples in urban areas are choosing to have one child or even none at all. On behalf of the International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF), I visited family planning associations (FPAs) and attended a "sexwise" workshop on potential joint sex education projects with the BBC World Service radio in China, Vietnam and Indonesia.

One participant, Ye Huan, from China FPA, said such a project would be as welcome as "charcoal in snowy weather". Another, Dr Chen, a celebrity sexologist with a local radio phone-in programme, told of the 50-year-old woman who wept as she wrote of her recent first experience of orgasm following his advice. In a rapidly changing China, the desire for sexual satisfaction, or "harmony", has created a growing market for advice and counselling.

The task of meeting this need in China is too enormous to adequately quantify. There are 1 million FPAs in China, with 83 million volunteer members. The smallest FPA is in a hotel. Some have suggestive names, such as Ship of Love or Home of Love. Most run "population schools", which ensure family planning is taught and understood. "Whisper" mailboxes for confidential inquiries are a popular feature in FPAs. Some have condom machines near grocery shops or on housing estates.

Services provided by some rural FPAs include "happiness projects", where poor families with one daughter are helped to buy land or livestock and become self-sufficient. Pensions are arranged by other FPAs for families with a daughter who will marry and not be able to support their old age. Ye Huan confided: "It hurts our feelings when we see how it's reported in the west that we don't look after our girl children."

At a rural community centre, where local women ran an FPA, some retired men gave me their opinion. "Before liberation, more births meant more happiness, but we were poor and miserable," one said. Another joined in: "This area was wild with dogs and wolves, and dead bodies were left here. We support the family policy. Our children never knew the hardship we knew."

No one condoned coercion, but it was explained that the one-child policy had applied only in urban areas, where less then 20% of the population lived. Over 100 million people living as "floating populations", who work as migrant labour on the outskirts of cities, were also excluded. It is more likely to be peer rather than governmental pressure that influences a couple's decision about children.

Having only one child carries a cost. Overweight young Chinese boys balancing precariously on the back of their doting parent's bikes as they travel to school are a common sight. In Qingdao, an industrial coastal town, the FPA runs a popular "little lunch table" project to help "only children" eat properly and to improve their behaviour.

In a Shanghai secondary school with a sex education programme to make our government envious, one teenager, Liu Song, said: "Since reform in China and with more western things, we have become more open." On display was a student's painting depicting menstruation as waves of graceful swimmers.

The need for "population control" has all but passed; now the emphasis is on planning to improve the quality of life - "informed choice". At a final presentation, by peer educators, young men and women acted out assertiveness skills to increase self-esteem and illustrate more equal relationships. "Family planning", as a term, barely touches the breadth and diversity of activity undertaken by Chinese FPAs. As the need for sex as procreation diminishes, so the emphasis on sexual "harmony" in marriage has grown.

Leaving China with memories of older men and women in the park, gracefully waltzing or performing Tai Chi in the early morning mists, and shy young couples holding hands in public, I wish them well in their search for "harmony".

 Anna McDermott is communications manager for IPPF, the world's largest voluntary organisation in sexual and reproductive health.

webTitle: Hopkins may have third Hannibal helping

fields.headline: Hopkins may have third Hannibal helping
fields.trailText: Anthony Hopkins has been offered £15m to star as the flesh-eating psychiatrist, Hannibal Lecter, for a third time. The actor, who won an Oscar for the role in Silence of the Lambs, has already agreed to star in the sequel Hannibal, and now Hollywood producers are keen for him to star in a prequel called Red Dragon, which they hope to make immediately after Hannibal has finished shooting.
fields.body:
Anthony Hopkins has been offered £15m to star as the flesh-eating psychiatrist, Hannibal Lecter, for a third time. The actor, who won an Oscar for the role in Silence of the Lambs, has already agreed to star in the sequel Hannibal, and now Hollywood producers are keen for him to star in a prequel called Red Dragon, which they hope to make immediately after Hannibal has finished shooting.

Julianne Moore, meanwhile, officially confirmed on American TV last night that she was in negotiations for the role of FBI agent Clarice Starling, and "completely enthralled" with the idea of being involved in the project after reading the script; what's more, she already has the part, according to inside sources. Since Jodie Foster turned it down, a number of major actresses have been wary of taking on such a high-profile role, but Moore has reportedly been chasing it very hard.

Red Dragon, the first in Thomas Harris's best-selling trilogy, has been made into a film before - in 1986 under the title of Manhunter - but producers want to make a big-budget version. John Gilstrap, who has just finished writing the script, confidently predicts: "I believe Red Dragon will be a much better film than Manhunter."

Meanwhile, MGM and Universal are negotiating to "swap" distribution rights for the film so that MGM will release it domestically in the US while Universal will promote it overseas. Shooting is expected to start in April as planned.
