fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the latest transfer news, even if it is a bit Ruud
fields.trailText: Opta Soccer PSV Eindhoven will invite bids for £28m Ruud van Nistelrooy this week. Arsenal, Chelsea, Manchester United and Leeds are all said to be interested in the Premiership-bound scoring sensation, but it is understood that Arsene Wenger is the only manager to have made a concrete bid.
fields.body:
Opta Soccer PSV Eindhoven will invite bids for £28m Ruud van Nistelrooy this week. Arsenal, Chelsea, Manchester United and Leeds are all said to be interested in the Premiership-bound scoring sensation, but it is understood that Arsene Wenger is the only manager to have made a concrete bid.

The Mirror Marc Overmars will quit Arsenal if the Highbury club fail to reach the Champions League - and could move to Chelsea or Manchester United. "I may not be an Arsenal player next season. That will be decided by what happens on the pitch," said the 26-year-old winger.

Teamtalk Wim Jansen will consider a second spell as Celtic manager, but only if Kenny Dalglish is removed from his post as Director of Football. "If I am going to go down as a coach, I will do it with my own ideas and my own mistakes - not through other people," said the man who led the Bhoys to the 1997-8 Scottish title. "I'm in a position now where if that is not an offer, then no problem."

Daily Star Arsenal, Chelsea and Sunderland have all made bids for Liverpool's teenage defender Djimi Traore. But Anfield boss Gerard Houllier has insisted that the French U-21 international is not for sale at any price.

fields.headline: Prize fools
fields.trailText: Everyone has a different reason for tuning into the Oscars, and it's nothing to do with the state of cinema.
fields.body:
Everyone has a different reason for tuning into the Oscars, and it's nothing to do with the state of cinema. This year we'll be keen to gauge the current height of Sean Penn's pompadour; to see how the singin', dancin' kids in the chorus cope with nominated best song Blame Canada, from the South Park movie; and to find out whether the customary spoofs will include Being Billy Crystal. Personally, I'll be waiting to see whether best short film (live action) goes to My Mother Dreams the Satan's Disciples in New York, described on the oscar.com website as "a mother/daughter/biker comedy". Far too few of those these days.

No one really expects the Academy Awards to provide a definitive picture of today's cinema. They don't even provide a reliable impression of American cinema.

This year's nominations are passably rum: some films are genuinely oddball, some solid but overrated, and some unimaginably stodgy. In the best-picture category, alongside the predictably board-sweeping American Beauty, there's Michael Mann's old-fashioned torn-from-today's-headlines drama The Insider; The Cider House Rules, a cosy, handsome John Irving adaptation; and The Green Mile, a three-hour-plus prison drama. I'd like to see The Sixth Sense win, because it's small but smart and doesn't stand on ceremony, and it would strike a rare Oscar blow for the genre pic. I suspect it won't win, because Oscar loves a consensus.

That would make the winner American Beauty - also nominated for cinematography, direction, editing, score and original script, with acting nominations for Kevin Spacey and Annette Bening (but no supporting actor for Chris Cooper, who, for me, was the real star turn). This is an Oscar consensus movie par excellence: superbly acted and directed, clever and amusing, yet so much less of a big deal than it appears. The Academy can't handle messy, sprawling movies that blaze away under their own febrile inspiration - that's why it has traditionally given short shrift to directors like Altman and Scorsese, and why there are a few notable omissions this year.

David Fincher's audacious, wildly misunderstood Fight Club gets only a derisory sound-effects-editing nomination. Paul Thomas Anderson's bustling Magnolia should have been a possible best film (it gets a screenplay mention, and one for Tom Cruise as supporting actor). Mike Leigh's Topsy-Turvy also gets short-changed, with a few technical nominations and best screenplay, but no show for the great Jim Broadbent.

It's worth noting that one triumph doesn't guarantee you a sinecure: after The English Patient, there's a scant showing for Anthony Minghella with the far better The Talented Mr Ripley, and a rotten one for Scott Hicks's follow-up to Shine, the dreary Snow Falling on Cedars (Paint Drying on Cedars, more like). It's reassuring too that apparent Oscar certs don't always register - The End of the Affair gets only a best-actress nomination for Julianne Moore.

Most interesting are those best actor/actress surprise nominations that are almost programmed into the event. There's the obligatory Meryl Streep showing for a heart-warming but inconsequential film (Music of the Heart). There's the congratulations-on-still-being-alive best actor for Richard Farnsworth, from The Straight Story. And there's the wild-card nomination for someone in a film no one has seen: Janet McTeer in single-mom drama Tumbleweeds.

The most interesting nominations are among the supporting-actress nominees, for newish names with indie records - Toni Collette, Angelina Jolie, Catherine Keener, Chloë Sevigny and Samantha Morton. I'd favour Keener, from Being John Malkovich: her supervamp role is so wildly at odds with her usual ingenue parts that it reveals her to be more versatile than anyone dreamed.

Among the best-actress names is Hilary Swank, who plays the gender-troubled Teena Brandon/ Brandon Teena in Boys Don't Cry. Her vibrant performance is more complex and unnerving than the Oscars usually reward. But the awards aren't in tune with what matters to the public - and I don't mean box office, but zeitgeist.

The two most epoch-defining films in the whole list are utterly sidelined. The Matrix is mentioned for sound, visual effects and editing - things that make great cinema just as much as words and acting. And the sublime Toy Story 2 only gets a mention for a jolly Randy Newman song. As long as the Academy gives something to Being John Malkovich, for Spike Jonze's direction or Charlie Kaufman's script, at least it'll show some commitment to the newer, wilder possibilities in American cinema. But no one really wins on Oscar night, except the couturiers and Billy Crystal's gag writers.

fields.headline: Frank Dobson (or possibly not)
fields.trailText: • You could have knocked me down with a feather when that Matthew Wotsisface rang and asked me to be guest diarist. "Oooh, you amaze me!" I said (that's my "catchphrase", see); "What with the Guardian being a paper written by Trots for liberals." Let bygones be bygones, he said, and do the column on the day the mayoral ballot closes. Put your side of the story to those nasty liberals.
fields.body:
 You could have knocked me down with a feather when that Matthew Wotsisface rang and asked me to be guest diarist. "Oooh, you amaze me!" I said (that's my "catchphrase", see); "What with the Guardian being a paper written by Trots for liberals." Let bygones be bygones, he said, and do the column on the day the mayoral ballot closes. Put your side of the story to those nasty liberals.

Well, I was all of a twitter - and you all know what happens downstairs when that happens (loose as a goose I was, if you'll pardon my anatomicals!). "Frank, think very carefully about this," my chief adviser said, "and then make your mind up." "You're right, Margaret," I replied, "You'd best get Number 10 on the phone at once." Well, Alastair said Tony thought it was a good idea, which is exactly what I thought, so here I am, large as life and twice as ugly.

 It was on October 12, oooh, a full three weeks after I vowed on my life never to run for mayor, that I kept a lifelong pledge to myself and announced my candidacy. It was brave of me, I reckon, when everyone thought it would be one member, one vote and Ken was so far ahead - but 10 minutes after I'd declared, His Nibs announces the electoral college. "Oooh," I screamed, "you amaze me!" Well, how was I to know he was planning that? I hadn't spoken to Tony since I went to resign from cabinet two hours before.

 Now I've had some smashing fellas with me. Adrian McMenamin, my first spokesman, lasted, oooh, weeks before going to the Welsh office. And that nice Conor Ryan, he got appendicitis and never came back. Grand lads. And they loved working for me.

 For legal reasons, I can't say owt about the investigation into the membership lists. But the first I knew was on October 28, when that Mervyn Wotsisname wrote how people were complaining. I don't care what anyone says, I know I posted my application to the Data Protection people. Now I remember this because it was a cold Tuesday morning, and I was leaving the flat when Mrs Dobson shouted: "Put on your anorak, Frank, you daft ha'p'orth, the maroon one I fetched you for your 60th, or you'll catch your death." Anyway, I went to the post box on the corner of St Pancras Way, the one by the chippie. Now hang on, was it the one by the Chinese on Tavistock Place? I can't say, but I do know this. I definitely posted it.

 The thing is, it's Millbank that's caused all the problems. I'll tell you what amazed me . . . when them London MPs sent out the identical letter asking folk to support me. I told that Ann Keen. "Annie," I said, "what the fiddling ferret are you up to? Did you not get the pager message from Lance Price at Number 10, telling you to change the blinking first paragraph?"

 What upset me most was when that Malcolm Whodyamaflick came round with them jugglers and fire throwers, saying I wanted cheering up, while Trevor and I were visiting a sick little boy in Great Ormond Street. It was a strictly private, non-political visit, which is why I went with my mayoral running mate, and it was wrong of him to write about it, especially when we'd sent a letter about the visit to the Guardian, marked "for publication".

 Now that I've set the record straight, please wish me luck. But even if Ken wins it, don't count old Dobbo out yet. The whole thing's been so rigged against me, well, I may just amaze you all. I may, that's all I'm saying; I may, and I may not; but I may - by standing as an independent! TTFN!

But the first I knew was on October 28, when that Mervyn Wotsisname wrote how people were complaining. I don't care what anyone says, I know I posted my application to the Data Protection people. Now I remember this because it was a cold Tuesday morning, and I was leaving the flat when Mrs Dobson shouted: "Put on your anorak, Frank, you daft ha'p'orth, the maroon one I fetched you for your 60th, or you'll catch your death." Anyway, I went to the post box on the corner of St Pancras Way, the one by the chippie. Now hang on, was it the one by the Chinese on Tavistock Place? I can't say, but I do know this. I definitely posted it.  The thing is, it's Millbank that's caused all the problems. I'll tell you what amazed me . . . when them London MPs sent out the identical letter asking folk to support me. I told that Ann Keen. "Annie," I said, "what the fiddling ferret are you up to? Did you not get the pager message from Lance Price at Number 10, telling you to change the blinking first paragraph?"  What upset me most was when that Malcolm Whodyamaflick came round with them jugglers and fire throwers, saying I wanted cheering up, while Trevor and I were visiting a sick little boy in Great Ormond Street. It was a strictly private, non-political visit, which is why I went with my mayoral running mate, and it was wrong of him to write about it, especially when we'd sent a letter about the visit to the Guardian, marked "for publication".  Now that I've set the record straight, please wish me luck. But even if Ken wins it, don't count old Dobbo out yet. The whole thing's been so rigged against me, well, I may just amaze you all. I may, that's all I'm saying; I may, and I may not; but I may - by standing as an independent! TTFN!

webTitle: Kafka would hate to be a square, say Prague officials

fields.headline: Kafka would hate to be a square, say Prague officials
fields.trailText: "Prague won't let you go, the little mother has claws," Franz Kafka once wrote about his uneasy relationship with the city of his birth. But now scholars of the late author are having trouble winning recognition for him after authorities turned down a proposal for a Franz Kafka Square, saying that it would have "terrified" their famous son.
fields.body:
"Prague won't let you go, the little mother has claws," Franz Kafka once wrote about his uneasy relationship with the city of his birth. But now scholars of the late author are having trouble winning recognition for him after authorities turned down a proposal for a Franz Kafka Square, saying that it would have "terrified" their famous son.

Prague officials last year suggested renaming a small rectangular area close to the site of his house after the German-speaking writer. But yesterday city council officials, headed by the mayor of Prague's first district, Jan Buergermeister, rejected what would have been the first official monument to him, saying that Kafka would turn in his grave at the very thought.

"Franz Kafka would be terrified by the idea that streets or squares should be named after him," said Mr Buergermeister.

Kafka enthusiasts scorned the decision, questioning whether the mayor had a "hotline" to the spirit of Kafka, who died in 1924. "How does he know what Kafka wouldn't have liked?" asked Eduard Goldstücker, a Kafka scholar. "[Kafka] was a very modest man but that doesn't mean he wouldn't like to have had his name attached to something."

Mr Goldstücker has been campaigning since 1963 for recognition of arguably the most famous Czech. "It's a unique phenomenon in the world that the most famous son in the city is not being acknowledged by having something named after him," said Prof Goldstücker. "Trying to imagine Prague without Kafka is rather like trying to imagine Salzburg without Mozart."

Mr Goldstücker said the reason efforts to rename the street have failed is a strong revival of nationalist tradition in the Czech lands. The fact that Kafka wrote in German and was a Jew does not help, he said.

webTitle: Blunkett backtracks over top-up tuition fees

fields.headline: Blunkett backtracks over top-up tuition fees
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government's cast iron promise that undergraduates at Britain's best universities will not be charged a "top-up" tuition fee may not survive long after the next election, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The government's cast iron promise that undergraduates at Britain's best universities will not be charged a "top-up" tuition fee may not survive long after the next election, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said yesterday.

Signalling the possibility of a u-turn in higher education policy, he said there would be another strategic review of the purpose and funding of higher education in 2002, five years after Lord Dearing's inquiry. The question of charging differential fees could not be ruled out.

He was still personally against letting prestige universities such as Oxford and Cambridge charge tuition fees higher than the standard £1,025 payable by full-time undergraduates this year. "But I will not be secretary of state for ever."

His warning delighted vice-chancellors in the elite Russell group of universities who think higher fees can provide the income needed to maintain standards in the face of cut-throat international competition for the best students and researchers.

But it caused fury among student leaders and the academic unions. Andrew Pakes, president of the National Union of Students, said: "Unless ministers stick to their promise that top-up fees are not on the agenda, there will be great anger among students and academics. The idea of a two tier education system is abhorrent."

Students are planning a lobby of parliament on March 7 to demand fee concessions in England and Wales similar to those being introduced in Scotland. Bill Rammell, Labour MP for Harlow, is in the process of tabling a motion which condemns top-up fees and claims they would damage access to higher education.

Tom Wilson, head of universities at the National Association of Teachers in Further and Higher Education, said lecturers would fight against top-up fees that would deter poorer students from going to more expensive universities or studying more expensive courses. He interpreted Mr Blunkett's remarks as a warning to opponents of top-up fees that they had better start fighting their corner, rather than a signal that he was resigned to demands from Downing Street that more income must be found for the elite universities.

The government's original promise not to introduce top-up fees helped to head off Labour backbench concern about abandoning the principle of free tuition for undergraduates. Mr Blunkett legislated to claw back any top-up fees charged by rogue universities.

Yesterday a spokesman for Mr Blunkett insisted the government's position had not changed, "but he recognises that there is a need for an intellectually rigorous debate on the subject".

Howard Newby, vice-chancellor of Southampton university and president of the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals, said: "We know there's not going to be any change in fees until after the general election. Afterwards, the question is how to bring more resources into higher education. Fees have be part of the equation."

Sir Colin Campbell, vice-chancellor of Nottingham university, said the top British universities needed extra income if they were to compete with the best in the US. "In every country planning for the knowledge economy, they know they cannot turn to the poor down-trodden taxpayers to subsidise students who are going to earn a lot more than they are going to earn."

Mr Blunkett also defended the government's plans to introduce a two-year "foundation degree" in 2002, following criticism that the new qualifications would create a two tier system of higher education, devaluing traditional degrees and confusing employers. He said he could see no reason why elite universities would not want to offer the degrees, which would allow students to move on to honours degrees involving an extra one-and-a-third years of study.

fields.headline: Sex for the teenagers
fields.trailText: Can we trust this government with the sex education of our children?
fields.body:
Can we trust this government with the sex education of our children? I ask because they have swung between libertarian pressure groups and pro-family moralists without a single thought about what contemporary teenagers themselves might need or want.

The government, which has done so many recent U-turns, has so far been strangely firm on repealing section 28. Campaigners are delighted at this commitment to ending discrimination and contemptuous of suggestions in the rightwing press that this unexpected firmness results from a cabinet driven by sexual sympathies. If the cabinet is a sexually motley crew, they say, so is the rest of the world. This would explain their desire to enshrine "the live and let live" principle in sex education.

Forgive my cynicism, but this is not a live and let live government. Its natural instinct is to interfere, and moralise: ask any single mother if the last two years have increased or reduced tolerance of her situation. So it's safe to assume there is some deep commitment to the guiding principles of the repeal section 28 campaign: a belief that there is no such thing as "normal" sexuality; that no one should feel bad about their preferences; and that gay relationships should not be presented as "pretend" or less valuable.

Now the government has realised the extent of Middle England's resistance to repealing section 28, they are desperately trying to pacify the traditionalists who think the precise opposite; that children should be taught the boundaries of what is normal and abnormal, desirable and undesirable. Blunkett is proposing children should be taught that marriage is the "proper" relationship, thus discriminating against the millions of children, like mine, whose parents are happily unmarried. Perhaps they will manage a compromise; sex comes in all shapes and sizes, all sex is good, but when it comes to children, marriage is best. But this can only ever be a face-saving formula and will spectacularly fail to address what contemporary children need.

Over the past few weeks, endless bleeding-heart accounts of growing up gay in a homophobic society have implied nothing has changed around sex. This is nonsense. But the changes are seismic and children need different guidance in this sexually very literate society. Contemporary children are saturated with sexual imagery and information. The major soap operas regularly tackle homosexuality. It's also widely discussed in teenage magazines, along with how to do a blow job, premature ejaculation and so on. On Channel 5, there's all-night porn. With a couple of clicks they can (and do) download anything they like from the internet. Homosexual buggery is the least of it. If they prefer they can have bestiality, coprophilia, sex with tiny children.

In such a context it is frankly absurd to be struggling over these Janet-and-John versus John-and-Jim versions of sexuality. The terrain is infinitely more difficult and all adolescents - regardless of gay or heterosexual identity - are struggling with much more complex issues. How can they avoid damaging sexual diseases? What is safe sexual behaviour? What should they agree to do or ask someone else to do in sex? Most critically, how does the experimental, transgressive sex with which they are bombarded ever become the "normal" family life most of them see around them?

It is not gay adolescents who are at sea; it is all of them. None of them knows where to draw boundaries or how to understand what they really want, as opposed to what is being fed to them by outside interests. Girls remain particularly vulnerable to the flood of endorsing and inciting material. To find their way through all this, children have no need at all of these old-fashioned political ideologies, whether libertarian or conservative. They need basic facts of life, and information about health and contraception. More importantly, they need help developing self-esteem and confidence so they can chart their way through the sexual landscape, making choices which do not hurt others or damage themselves.

Last year I visited a drug education project in Norway. There they start teaching the children at 11. It is not the sort of muddled stuff we do here: "Now children, if you must inject, always use a clean needle." In fact they don't talk about drugs directly at all. Instead they help children develop confidence and self-esteem, encouraging them to speak about what matters to them and how to communicate this to others. There are important lessons for sex education. The real issues are emotional literacy, self-awareness and confidence to protect yourself. This is what the government should be addressing, not how to satisfy the outmoded ideologies of the sexual campaigners.

webTitle: Now we are six - and 'beyond genius'

fields.headline: Now we are six - and 'beyond genius'
fields.trailText: By the age of two Justin Chapman was reading; six months later he was crying all the time because he was bored in pre-school classes; but now, at six, everything is much better and the boy has just scored a B for a university paper on the Iliad in a course on ancient world history.
fields.body:
By the age of two Justin Chapman was reading; six months later he was crying all the time because he was bored in pre-school classes; but now, at six, everything is much better and the boy has just scored a B for a university paper on the Iliad in a course on ancient world history.

None of this means, though, that childhood is a breeze for Justin, from Penfold, in New York state. "I have faced age discrimination all my life," says the child who cites Albert Einstein as his hero. "It is very frustrating not to be able to benefit from schooling or activities because of being too young. I love learning, it just occurs at a faster pace for me."

Linda Silverman, a psychologist and director of the Gifted Development Centre in Denver, who keeps in touch with him by email, said: "He's way beyond genius. He's probably unique in the world."

Elizabeth Chapman, a 27-year-old single mother, said she had been teaching her son at home because she could not find a school for older children that would take him. "I've tried every school in a 60-mile radius trying to find one that would accept him.

"He' s far too advanced academically and they say socially he needs to be with six-year-olds."

In the meantime, Justin runs a campaign on the internet to have above-average children placed in schools according to their academic level rather than their age.

The history course at the university of Rochester will earn Justin credits towards a degree and he is also studying physics and computer science in an online programme for gifted children run by Stanford university, California.

Ms Chapman says that in many ways her son is a typical six-year-old with an untidy bedroom, who enjoys fencing, fishing, camping, swimming and tae kwan do. But Brent Rushall, a professor of exercise and nutritional sciences in San Diego, said: "The first time I saw his email I checked to see it wasn't a hoax because he writes like a college professor."

Carole Lieberman, a psychiatrist, said that Justin would be better off in a school with children of his own age. "His brain or his IQ may be at a college level but his social and psychological development is still at first-grade level."

fields.headline: Zimbabwe says no
fields.standfirst:
Mr Mugabe deserved his defeat

Zimbabwe special report
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe's referendum on Zimbabwe's new draft constitution turned out to be a referendum on Mr Mugabe himself. Having personally campaigned for a "yes" vote, the president has suffered an unprecedented personal defeat. His doctoring of the draft before the vote was a bad mistake.
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe's referendum on Zimbabwe's new draft constitution turned out to be a referendum on Mr Mugabe himself. Having personally campaigned for a "yes" vote, the president has suffered an unprecedented personal defeat. His doctoring of the draft before the vote was a bad mistake. His portrayal of his opponents as stooges of Zimbabwe's whites, rather than advocates of democratic reform, was divisive and crass. But his worst miscalculation was to take for granted the support, unswerving over the past 20 years, of the 70% of Zimbabweans who live beyond the main cities. To his surprise, his pledge to redistribute white farmland and his claim that the constitution meant a final break with the colonial past did not enthuse. Three in four voters abstained. Less than 12% of the total electorate backed Mr Mugabe.

Many other factors contributed to this defeat, not least Zimbabwe's economic crisis and the unpopular Congo war. The labour-backed Movement for Democratic Change, led by Morgan Tsvangirai, proved an effective opposition despite arrests, intimidation, and ballot irregularities. Many voters reportedly could not follow the constitution's legalistic English terminology. The weather was wet. There are other possible excuses, but none which can save Mr Mugabe's face. With all the state's powers at his disposal, including government-controlled media, he has only himself to blame. The poll became a test of popular confidence in the way he is running the country. He should draw the obvious conclusion, and consider very carefully what he does next.

This proof that Zanu-PF's dominance can be successfully challenged will greatly encourage opposition groups as April's parliamentary elections approach. In a continent in which gunfire too often drowns out reasoned argument, the referendum reminded that democracy can work wonders. There is a long way still to go but, all in all, it was a good day for the people.

webTitle: Poll 'slap in the face' for Mugabe

fields.headline: Poll 'slap in the face' for Mugabe
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabweans signal anger over economy and Congo war

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabweans yesterday delivered a damning verdict on Robert Mugabe's authoritarian rule and the rapid decline of their country by rejecting a constitution aimed at increasing the president's powers.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in Harare  and  Chris McGreal
fields.body:
Zimbabweans yesterday delivered a damning verdict on Robert Mugabe's authoritarian rule and the rapid decline of their country by rejecting a constitution aimed at increasing the president's powers.

The opposition called for his resignation without expecting to get it. But Mr Mugabe's only poll defeat in 21 years in power lays the ground for them to mount a strong attack on his ruling Zanu-PF party in parliamentary elections in April.

The new constitution was rejected by 55% of those taking part in the referendum, which was seen as a test of Mr Mugabe's popularity amid a failing economy, increasing oppression and deep discontent at the country's leading role in the civil war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

The low turnout, at just 20%, provided more evidence of the government's unpopularity after its expensive campaign to get supporters to the polls.

The new constitution would have permitted Mr Mugabe to serve two more terms, redistributed white-owned farmland without compensation and allowed press censorship.

Lovemore Madhuku, deputy chairman of the opposition National Constitutional Assembly, described the vote as a slap in the face to Mr Mugabe.

"We said don't think you can mess with the economy and get away with it. Don't involve us in the Congo war and think we won't protest," he said.

The cities delivered the heaviest vote against the new constitution but the most significant shift was in rural areas, usually a Zanu-PF stronghold, where support fell amid anger at petrol shortages and power cuts, largely attributed to the cost of the Congo war.

Even Mr Mugabe's attempt to guarantee peasant votes, by including a clause in the constitution to redistribute white-owned farms without compensation, failed. Many Zimbabweans did not trust him to give the land to the poor. In the past, seized farms have been passed to party officials.

A constitutional review was launched last year. Opposition campaigners wanted to rewrite the document drawn up with the British at independence and diminish the president's powers.

Mr Mugabe hijacked the process and came up with a draft which would have consolidated his control.

The draft was rejected in the referendum but Mr Mugabe still retains the powers he has exercised for 21 years, including draconian emergency laws enabling him to crush dissent.

Whether the vote will be seen as the beginning of the end for Mr Mugabe depends on whether his opponents can capitalise on the result in the April elections. Zanu-PF holds all but one seat in parliament.

If he hopes to avoid further embarrassment Mr Mugabe may be forced to rethink his policies, particularly Zimbabwe's involvement in Congo.

Zimbabwe spends £1m a day keeping 11,000 troops in Congo to prop up Laurent Kabila's government. Many Zimbabweans believe their army is there to protect the interests of leading politicians in mining projects.

The new constitution was rejected by 55% of those taking part in the referendum, which was seen as a test of Mr Mugabe's popularity amid a failing economy, increasing oppression and deep discontent at the country's leading role in the civil war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The low turnout, at just 20%, provided more evidence of the government's unpopularity after its expensive campaign to get supporters to the polls. The new constitution would have permitted Mr Mugabe to serve two more terms, redistributed white-owned farmland without compensation and allowed press censorship. Lovemore Madhuku, deputy chairman of the opposition National Constitutional Assembly, described the vote as a slap in the face to Mr Mugabe. "We said don't think you can mess with the economy and get away with it. Don't involve us in the Congo war and think we won't protest," he said. The cities delivered the heaviest vote against the new constitution but the most significant shift was in rural areas, usually a Zanu-PF stronghold, where support fell amid anger at petrol shortages and power cuts, largely attributed to the cost of the Congo war. Even Mr Mugabe's attempt to guarantee peasant votes, by including a clause in the constitution to redistribute white-owned farms without compensation, failed. Many Zimbabweans did not trust him to give the land to the poor. In the past, seized farms have been passed to party officials. A constitutional review was launched last year. Opposition campaigners wanted to rewrite the document drawn up with the British at independence and diminish the president's powers. Mr Mugabe hijacked the process and came up with a draft which would have consolidated his control. The draft was rejected in the referendum but Mr Mugabe still retains the powers he has exercised for 21 years, including draconian emergency laws enabling him to crush dissent. Whether the vote will be seen as the beginning of the end for Mr Mugabe depends on whether his opponents can capitalise on the result in the April elections. Zanu-PF holds all but one seat in parliament. If he hopes to avoid further embarrassment Mr Mugabe may be forced to rethink his policies, particularly Zimbabwe's involvement in Congo. Zimbabwe spends £1m a day keeping 11,000 troops in Congo to prop up Laurent Kabila's government. Many Zimbabweans believe their army is there to protect the interests of leading politicians in mining projects.

webTitle: Anti-fur protesters return to pique fashion's cognoscenti

fields.headline: Anti-fur protesters return to pique fashion's cognoscenti
fields.standfirst: London fashion week: special report
fields.trailText: Fur protesters yesterday jostled their way back on to the fashion agenda with an attempt to sabotage Alexander McQueen's catwalk show.
fields.body:
Fur protesters yesterday jostled their way back on to the fashion agenda with an attempt to sabotage Alexander McQueen's catwalk show.

They broke into a film studio in Islington, north London, the venue for last night's show, and daubed anti-fur slogans on the specially designed backdrops.

They were also reported to have tried to booby-trap the stage. This is the first sabotage attempt to take place during London Fashion Week, but follows three recent attempts by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals during the recent New York shows. Last week protesters tried to halt Oscar de la Renta's show, jumping on to the catwalk waving banners. Fur has been largely absent from the London catwalks so far although another possible target could be Julien Macdonald's show, to be held at the Millennium Dome tomorrow which is sponsored by Saga Furs.

But a spokesperson for the company last night said that Macdonald would only be using fake fur in his collection, although leather and shearling would feature.

Earlier Betty Jackson went back to the 1980s for her collection, which featured red leather calf-length boots and wide red leather belts of the sort not seen since the heady days of Spandau Ballet.

Halterneck tops in shocking pink or floral seqins were worn with tight pencil skirts. The sweater dress made a comeback, as did that other 80s staple, the waistcoat. There were also voluminous nappa leather blouson jackets with dolman sleeves and neat little pussy bows.

webTitle: Home secretaries always lose the plot in the end

fields.headline: Home secretaries always lose the plot in the end
fields.standfirst:
Straw's treatment of asylum-seekers appals even the Wall Street Journal.

Refugees in Britain: special report

Stansted hijack: special report
fields.trailText: Straw's treatment of asylum-seekers appals even the Wall Street Journal.
fields.body:
We members of that much misunderstood body, the parliamentary lobby, used to have a variety of silly games with which to while away the tedious hours of late-night sittings, like composing ribald versions of the Red Flag and the Eton Boating Song.

One of the funnier games -invented, I think, by Gerald Kaufman in his Daily Mirror days - involved reversing the initial letters of the names of MPs' in the hope of creating felicitous Spoonerisms. My favourites were Head Teeth and Sir Dalek Hugless Doom.

Another entailed defining the various government departments in Westminster in term of regiments of the British army. Thus the foreign office was, and clearly still is, the Household Cavalry, while the treasury is equally clearly the Foot Guards. At the opposite end of the scale, the min of ag and fish must be the Pioneer Corps, while social security, with its headquarters at the unfashionable Elephant and Castle, can only be the Pay Corps.

But there is one great department which defies this sort of definition. In some of its aspects, the home office is frightfully grand - the equivalent, shall we say, of some fancy infantry regiment like the Green Jackets. In others - for instance, its rather unpleasant duties relating to immigration and prisons - it is much more like the Red Caps.

This is probably because the home office is really a sort of rag-bag department, many of whose functions stay under its roof because they don't obviously belong anywhere else. As a result it is a jack-in-the-box stuffed with unpleasant surprises, always ready to spring open just when the home secretary of the day is settling down to his cinnamon toast and Earl Grey tea.

That is certainly how most recent home secretaries have seen the job. They mostly like it, because it is definitely very grand indeed, and therefore makes them grand, too. But they have all been acutely conscious that somewhere in the building there is a file on someone's desk, which will eventually explode on to the front page of the Sun. Or, worse, that some prisoner is even now digging his way through the wall of his jail, leading to that home secretaries' nightmare, "questions in the House".

This atmosphere of menace has a curious effect on otherwise balanced and stable ministers.

Even Roy Jenkins, the man the Tories blame for destroying the fabric of decent society with his liberal policies on abortion, buggery and the like, was panicked by a spate of prison escapes (he said he feared to walk down Whitehall lest he bump into an escaped jailbird), imposing a security regime in our jails which would have alarmed all his Tory confrères save Michael Howard.

Then there was Willie Whitelaw, who spent most of his time in the department trying to hold back the hangers and floggers in his party, but was nagged into trying out boot camps offering "short, sharp shocks" to unruly teenagers. They failed, but that won't stop them being tried again.

Kenneth Baker followed with his barmy Dangerous Dogs Act, which was triggered by a spate of tabloid stories about rottweilers biting babies. And even Uncle Jim Callaghan, the ultimate "keep calm" politician, was scared by some spectacularly newsworthy crime to say in the Commons that he was pleased to be able to tell MPs that the perpetrator had been apprehended - a dreadful contempt of court.

So I suppose we shouldn't have been too surprised when Jack Straw quickly began to show signs of singing along to the Wagnerian background music of his department. It had happened to all the others, so why not to him? What has been surprising, however, is just how far this ex-student activist, CND marcher and Tribune group member has been prepared to go to demonstrate his adherence to the principles that guide Daily Mail leader writers.

Even his one glaring inconsistency - his decision to detain General Pinochet to enable Spain's extradition claim to be tested in the courts - has turned out to be a frost. His announcement delighted but also astonished his old lefty friends, many of whom had already written him off as a deserter from the liberal cause. "Good old Jack," was the jubilant reaction, "perhaps he's Labour after all."

But if he wasn't prepared to go through with it, why did he do it in the first place? Had he allowed the old torturer to go home at once, the affair would have lasted a matter of days. The Labour left, already disillusioned to the point of apathy, would have filed it away as just another example of Jack's transformation.

The course he did adopt has kept the case of the general on the front pages for months: and led to Straw's discomfort yesterday as the appeal court unanimously rejected his attempts to keep the medical reports on Pinochet secret.

However, for me the last straw (no, honestly, no pun intended) was his sickening remark in the Commons last week, when he told MPs that he wanted to see all - yes, all - the people on the hijacked Afghan jet removed from Britain "as soon as reasonably practicable".

It isn't just that this declaration, no matter what he says now, makes nonsense of his quasi-judicial role in deciding the fate of the applicants. Far worse is the insight it gives into his mind-set on the whole asylum issue.

Needless to say, the Daily Mail loves it. But even the Daily Telegraph has its doubts. And yesterday Mr Straw achieved the almost unimaginable feat of attracting the condemnation (which we reprint below) of the Wall Street Journal, a US newspaper so rightwing that it sometimes makes Conrad Black's Telegraph look like a reincarnation of the Cadbury-owned News Chronicle.

After praising Britain's record as one of the world's hitherto most civilised countries, the Journal characterises today's UK as an uglier sort of place: and it roundly takes Jack Straw to task for it. So a Labour home secretary is considered too illiberal for the Wall Street Journal. What a fate!

fields.headline: The ugly Britons
fields.standfirst:
The view from Wall Street

Refugees in Britain: special report

Stansted hijack: special report
fields.trailText: Britain is one of the world's more civilized countries. So it came as no surprise that it allowed a hijacked Afghan airliner to land at Stansted last week, or that its security officials were able to resolve the standoff with no loss of life. But reaction to the news that more than 70 of these accidental tourists now want to stay has cast the country in a uglier light.
fields.body:
Britain is one of the world's more civilized countries. So it came as no surprise that it allowed a hijacked Afghan airliner to land at Stansted last week, or that its security officials were able to resolve the standoff with no loss of life.

But reaction to the news that more than 70 of these accidental tourists now want to stay has cast the country in a uglier light. Britain's tabloid press has played on popular fears that immigrants want to take people's jobs or dole money.

"We'll wager that most 'victims' of the Stansted hijack are still enjoying life on benefits in Britain, five years hence," said the Daily Mail. Even British home secretary, Jack Straw, has said he wants the remaining passengers to leave the country "as soon as is practicably possible".

Mr Straw has of course pledged to consider each of the asylum applications on an individual basis, as he is bound to do by a United Nations convention on refugees.

But his reaction is far from what one might expect from the chief legal officer of such a rich and historically tolerant nation. With Afghanistan's fundamentalist Taliban regime recognised by only three other countries (Britain is not among them), it would seem that the case for asylum might have merit.

The fact that the Taliban have already said that the hijackers themselves could face the death penalty, a seemingly disproportionate punishment, suggests that they too should be dealt with under British law.

But so far Mr Straw seems to be echoing the Taliban party line. In words that could easily have sprung from the mouth of virtually any government minister, Taliban foreign minister, Wakil Ahmed Muttawakil, said: "We have to differentiate between political and economic asylum seekers."

That kind of distinction between "political" and "economic" freedom certainly sits well even with New Labour, who would have us believe that people are free so long as consenting adults are left alone in the bedroom, no matter how crushing the burden of government is on the pursuit of happiness generally.

But if such a distinction is spurious at best, it is almost impossible to make in the case of the Taliban regime. Are women who are not allowed to work or be educated in Taliban Afghanistan political or economic asylum seekers? The same question could be asked of everyone suffering from an economy doomed by a misinterpretation of Islamic law to forbid the payment of interest.

To be sure, Britain has never explicitly asked the world for its "huddled masses". But how can this Labour government not recognise the potential public relations coup it could have if only it were willing to show a bit of leadership?

For what the remaining Afghans are effectively saying is this: we respect your country so much that we are willing to leave our families and all our possessions behind if only you'll give us a chance to stay.

And they respect it for good reason. Britain's tradition of democracy and the rule of law is second to none. Every year Britain does indeed open its doors to more asylum seekers than any European country but Germany.

It is a pity that Mr Straw seems bent on passing up this high-profile opportunity to lead by example. Britain should show the likes of Austria's Jörg Haider how civilised countries treat the dispossessed, not present him with an opportunity for accusations, however unwarranted, of hypocrisy.

 This editorial appeared in the Wall Street Journal yesterday.

fields.headline: Home office attacked on hostages
fields.standfirst: Stansted hijack: special report
fields.trailText: The home office came under fire last night for allowing former hostages on the hijacked Afghan Boeing 727 to be interviewed about their asylum claims without legal representation.
fields.body:
The home office came under fire last night for allowing former hostages on the hijacked Afghan Boeing 727 to be interviewed about their asylum claims without legal representation.

Alison Stanley, an immigration specialist at the law firm of Bindman and Partners, said the action was legal but was neither fair nor good practice for former hostages still stressed and bewildered by the hijacking, which ended at Stansted airport last Thursday.

The home office said 76 passengers were seeking asylum, including two previously arrested on suspicion of involvement in the hijacking but since released. Of those, 37 are "principal" applicants and the remainder wives and children.

Ms Stanley said: "All the others are being interviewed and their lawyers aren't being allowed to speak to them before they are interviewed about their full asylum claim."

Her criticisms are believed to be shared by officials at the Refugee Legal Centre, which is now organising representation for the asylum-seekers at Moreton-in-Marsh, Gloucestershire, but no one from the organisation could comment yesterday.

The centre is farming out some legal help to agencies and lawyers, including Ms Stanley. After the first interview, the asylum-seekers have five days to amass further information in support of their claim.

The home office said legal advice would have been provided before interview to anyone who had requested it.

Ms Stanley said: "These people are particularly vulnerable and they should have had proper legal advice before they made a legal decision about whether to seek asylum in the first place, and then subsequently having made that decision, before they were interviewed about their asylum claims."

The criticism adds to that voiced by David Fazel, an interpreter for the hostages, who said he was "quite disgusted" by their treatment. He said immigration officials had warned applicants that if they were re fused asylum, "they would be sent straight back to Afghanistan whether they were happy or not".

The asylum-seekers will be dispersed to other centres at the end of this week to await a decision by home secretary, Jack Straw, who has promised to look at each case quickly. Those turned down then have seven days to appeal.

It costs £1,300 a week to house and secure each asylum-seeker, a home office spokesman said.

The 73 hostages who chose to return to Afghanistan on Monday were given advice on leaving the country from representatives of the International Office of Migration, an independent body supported by governments.

Diane Grammer, head of the IOM office in London, said each of those who left was given the option of staying in interviews. Three changed their minds and decided to seek asylum.

Though the decision to return home was voluntary, she conceded that it may not always have been properly informed. "People were very tired and were quite confused. We tried to give everyone the option to say yes, I want to go, or no, I want to stay. Their lives had been turned upside down ... some just wanted that to be over and for life to get back to normal."

Some of the 10 crew members who returned home complained of being beaten by the hijackers and were checked by a doctor, Ms Grammer said.

Yesterday, one of those returned to Afghanistan said the hijackers were all related. Describing the hijackers as "one big family", Mohammed Shamsullah, 50, said: "Everyone was afraid, but their women and children were laughing ... the women were very relaxed."

One man was still being questioned last night by Essex police. Thirteen men appeared before magistrates on Monday. Only one of the 13 names given in court was found on the passenger list at the Ariana Airlines office in Kabul, suggesting they gave false names when buying their tickets.

fields.headline: Amazon prepares European expansion
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Amazon, the world's largest online retailer, is poised for a big European expansion after annual sales in Britain passed £100m for the first time.
fields.body:
Amazon, the world's largest online retailer, is poised for a big European expansion after annual sales in Britain passed £100m for the first time.

The company indicated yesterday that it plans to expand beyond the UK and German markets it operates in and widen the range of goods it offers for sale in Europe.

President and chief operating officer Joe Galli said: "E-commerce is about to erupt throughout Europe and we want to be in a position to lead that." Analysts believe Amazon is likely to be looking at expansion into France, Italy, Spain and Scandinavia.

Mr Galli, revealing the breakdown of European trading and customer numbers for the first time, said that more than 1m customers had used Amazon.co.uk to buy books and CDs worth more than £100m during 1999. Sales in the final quarter of the year rose 430% to £26m.

"These figures reinforce Amazon.co.uk's position as Europe's biggest e-commerce site," he said, pointing to a recent report from independent researcher Media Matrix which rated it Europe's leader in terms of unique visitor numbers and the length of time they spent on site.

Almost all of Amazon.co.uk's customer base has been built up in 1999 as users became more willing to hand over credit card and email details to online retailers, Mr Galli said. "Internet over mobile phones will bring another exciting dimension," he added.

Shobhit Kakkar, an analyst at Fletcher Research, said: "These are impressive figures and illustrate the multi-stage process internet users go through.

"It takes around 12 months for users to build familiarity with the medium and find the confidence to buy online. The fourth quarter of the year before was when leading internet service providers like Freeserve really started to put on customers and these numbers show that the way consumers in the UK are using the internet is becoming more sophisticated."

Further Amazon expansion into Europe is thought to be imminent. It announced yesterday that it is hiring 125 people for a new customer service centre in the Hague and plans to expand its distribution centres in England and Germany. A new 50,000m distribution centre is being built in Milton Keynes and a new headquarters in Slough.

The new staff are likely to be given the task of distributing a number of new products. Amazon.com in the US offers a far broader range of products, from DIY equipment and machine tools to computer software and toys.

"We will broaden our offering away from books and CDs until we achieve universal selection," Mr Galli said. "Amazon's stated goal is to offer the Earth's broadest selection of goods online. There's no category that we felt we shouldn't get into eventually in relation to e-commerce."

Despite rapid growth the company announced 150 redundancies in the US, spread across all operations.

Seattle-based Amazon has 17m registered users globally, of which 3.8m were added in the fourth quarter of last year. However, heavy investment in marketing and distribution has prevented the company making a profit.

Asked when Amazon might turn a profit Mr Galli said: "The company has a plan to achieve profitability worldwide but we never discuss details."

The company indicated yesterday that it plans to expand beyond the UK and German markets it operates in and widen the range of goods it offers for sale in Europe. President and chief operating officer Joe Galli said: "E-commerce is about to erupt throughout Europe and we want to be in a position to lead that." Analysts believe Amazon is likely to be looking at expansion into France, Italy, Spain and Scandinavia. Mr Galli, revealing the breakdown of European trading and customer numbers for the first time, said that more than 1m customers had used Amazon.co.uk to buy books and CDs worth more than £100m during 1999. Sales in the final quarter of the year rose 430% to £26m. "These figures reinforce Amazon.co.uk's position as Europe's biggest e-commerce site," he said, pointing to a recent report from independent researcher Media Matrix which rated it Europe's leader in terms of unique visitor numbers and the length of time they spent on site. Almost all of Amazon.co.uk's customer base has been built up in 1999 as users became more willing to hand over credit card and email details to online retailers, Mr Galli said. "Internet over mobile phones will bring another exciting dimension," he added. Shobhit Kakkar, an analyst at Fletcher Research, said: "These are impressive figures and illustrate the multi-stage process internet users go through. "It takes around 12 months for users to build familiarity with the medium and find the confidence to buy online. fields.headline: Joe Bloggs founder gets e-friendly
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Fashion entrepreneur Shami Ahmed is to pass control of his Joe Bloggs jeans empire to his 25-year-old brother and devote his time to a new e-commerce investment vehicle which he plans to float later this month.
fields.body:
Fashion entrepreneur Shami Ahmed is to pass control of his Joe Bloggs jeans empire to his 25-year-old brother and devote his time to a new e-commerce investment vehicle which he plans to float later this month.

Mr Ahmed, 37, set up Joe Bloggs when he was in his teens but will experience life as chief executive of a public company for the first by bringing Legendary Investments to the Alternative Investment Market. Broker Seymour Pierce is expected to release details of a private placing of £3m-5m next week.

Kashif Ahmed will take over as managing director of Joe Bloggs, which turned over about £50m last year. He has worked for his brother since he was 15. Mr Ahmed also plans to hand over control of his £60m property portfolio although ownership will not change.

"I will be devoting my time and efforts to Legendary," Mr Ahmed said last night. "I want to act as a strategic partner not just an investor."

Legendary plans to invest in a number of technology companies that have strong products and cash flows and are likely to float within a year. Mr Ahmed is examining the British, American and Indian software markets.

He will be joined on the board by Michael Fry, a former director of Thorn EMI, and Smit Berry, owner of Equity Link. Two other directors are expected to be appointed.

Mr Ahmed will be the majority shareholder, owning around 50% of the equity. The three directors will control collectively around 80%.

Mr Ahmed came to Britain at the age of two and left school at 16 to work on his parents' market stall. Joe Bloggs is the only domestic company to figure in the British top 10 for jeans.

Two years ago he rescued haute couture designer Elizabeth Emmanuel from bankruptcy but their relationship ended in acrimony and threats of litigation a year later.

Since then Mr Ahmed has made a series of investments in stock market listed companies, typically taking stakes of less than 3%.

webTitle: SEC puts Maxwell telecom plan on hold

fields.headline: SEC puts Maxwell telecom plan on hold
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Another week, another financial hairpin bend, but Kevin Maxwell's Telemonde company is still on the road. America's securities and exchange commission (SEC) threatens, however, to force the company into the abyss next month unless certain documentation is tidied up.
fields.body:
Another week, another financial hairpin bend, but Kevin Maxwell's Telemonde company is still on the road. America's securities and exchange commission (SEC) threatens, however, to force the company into the abyss next month unless certain documentation is tidied up.

That, says Mr Maxwell, is not a problem, and the paperwork will be straight by the deadline. As for the £76m of supply credit that Telemonde is unable to service, that was being renegotiated yesterday and a successful outcome expected.

All Telemonde will have to do then is cable up the world. Its aim is to allow developing countries to participate fully in the communications revolution with high-quality, low-cost telecom links. Oman is signed up, Bangladesh and Yemen are being wooed.

If all goes to plan, Mr Maxwell will be teaching the world to communicate with itself. It will be a remarkable turn of events after 10 years in which Mr Maxwell has lost his father, briefly assumed directorship of one of the world's largest publishers (Maxwell Communication Corporation), been bankrupted, discharged from bankruptcy, tried on fraud charges and cleared.

Oh, and last year he won a court case which effectively rewrote the rules on interviews conducted by department of trade and industry inspectors.

But, before the world's poor can reach for their Max-phones, Telemonde has those bends to negotiate.

At the bottom of the company's troubles are supply contracts signed with two suppliers, US groups MCI Worldwide and Global Crossing under which Telemonde is required to "draw down" a certain quantity of telecoms materials at set periods.

In November, Mr Maxwell wrote to the SEC, as required under US law, to warn that Telemonde had been unable to generate sufficient cash flow to meet these requirements and was in danger of default.

He added that there was no guarantee the contracts could be successfully renegotiated.

According to Mr Maxwell, the SEC's main concern was not the fact of Telemonde's debt service difficulties but the language in which it was expressed. "It's not the content it's the presentation."

The SEC told Telemonde to remove jargon and make the so-called Form 10 filing more comprehensible to ordinary investors by March 8.

The exchange on which Telemonde is quoted, America's Nasdaq market, on February 11 added its probationary signage, in the form of an "e", to Telemonde's ticker-tape identity, TLMD. This told investors that, should all not be well by March 8, Telemonde would cease to be quoted on the "over the counter bulletin board" (OTC BB), Nasdaq's smallest market. The shares tumbled.

Telemonde pointed out the "e" symbol is standard when ever the SEC adds "comments" to the Form 10 filing of a quoted company. Mr Maxwell said that, come March, Telemonde would be "home and dry" and TLMDE would once again be plain old TLMD.

Adam Bishop, Telemonde's cofounder and a former manager with BT, said: "We are confident that we will meet the conditions set out by the Nasdaq OTC BB compliance group."

This is of interest to telephone subscribers in Britain, even if they are not in the habit of sending emails to Oman. Along with its mission in the developing world, Telemonde is keen to exploit tactical opportunities in Europe and America, and in December announced it had been awarded a full UK telephone operator's licence by the department of trade and industry.

fields.headline: Hospital queues rise by 36,000
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The government lost almost half the ground it had gained on hospital waiting lists when queues soared more than 36,000 last December, official figures yesterday showed.
fields.body:
The government lost almost half the ground it had gained on hospital waiting lists when queues soared more than 36,000 last December, official figures yesterday showed.

The increase in hospital queues in December means that Labour is now again 60,000 short of its general election promise to cut the total for England by 100,000.

Ministers remain confident of regaining the ground over the next 12 months, in time for a possible spring 2001 election. But critics are accusing them of being the victims of their own rhetoric.

Liam Fox, Conservative shadow health secretary, said: "We warned the government that their obsession with the waiting list initiative and running the system with no slack for common and predictable occurrences, such as winter flu, would have major ramifications for the health service."

The figures for December 31 showed that the total list grew 36,600 that month to 1,108,000. The number of people waiting more than a year grew even more to 51,000.

As many as 101 patients had been waiting more than 18 months for treatment in breach of the guarantee in the patient's charter, compared to 69 at the end of November.

The department of health said the increase was to be expected. Many hospitals started to cancel routine surgery in the second half of December in preparation for possible problems over the millennium holiday period.

The government's difficulty was that plans to resume surgery sessions in January were knocked off course by the flu outbreak that filled wards with emergency admissions.

There was better news for ministers in quarterly figures for out-patient waits, the main indicator of which fell in the three months to December 31 for the first time in three years. People waiting more than 13 weeks to see a specialist dropped 16,000 to 496,000.

However, people waiting more than 26 weeks rose 10,000 in the quarter to 159,000.

fields.headline: Clinton likely to visit Pakistan
fields.standfirst: The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton is likely to pay an official visit to Pakistan next month, senior US administration sources now say.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton is likely to pay an official visit to Pakistan next month, senior US administration sources now say.

The move is set to aggravate US relations with India and anger human rights campaigners who claim a visit will legitimise last October's Pakistani military coup.

Officially, the White House is still considering whether to add a Pakistan visit to Mr Clinton's India and Bangladesh trip, due to start on March 20.

However, a senior Clinton administration official said privately this week that a visit to Pakistan is now "likely to take place" as part of the first US presidential tour of the subcontinent since Jimmy Carter's 1978 visit.

A Clinton decision to visit Pakistan would deal a blow to New Delhi, which wants Washington to declare Pakistan a rogue state over its alleged role in December's hijacking of an Indian Airlines jet to Afghanistan.

The Pentagon has taken the lead in pressing Mr Clinton to talk with Pakistan's new military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, but the state department, initially cautious, is now believed to accept that a visit would be in the best interests of the US in the region.

Pakistan's eagerness for the visit was underlined yesterday, when General Ghulam Ahmed, head of the intelligence service (ISI), repeatedly accused by India of masterminding the long-running conflict over Kashmir and the aircraft hijacking, gave a rare interview to the Washington Post.

Gen Ahmed said the ISI is focussing on internal not external issues and he shared US fears about regional terrorism.

Mr Clinton originally hoped to make a keynote tour to India and Pakistan in 1998 and 1999. Those plans collapsed, partly because of the Monica Lewinsky affair and Mr Clinton's impeachment, but also because India and Pakistan began nuclear testing.

fields.headline: Secretary in a state
fields.standfirst: The Tories' links with neo-fascism | John Major, thigh fondler
fields.trailText: From John O'Groats to Land's End, there cannot be a man, woman or child who failed to notice Michael Portillo's return to the Tory front bench. His fan club, otherwise known as the Portillistas, has made sure of that. But who spares a thought for Francis Maude, elevated to shadow foreign secretary in the same reshuffle?
fields.body:
From John O'Groats to Land's End, there cannot be a man, woman or child who failed to notice Michael Portillo's return to the Tory front bench. His fan club, otherwise known as the Portillistas, has made sure of that. But who spares a thought for Francis Maude, elevated to shadow foreign secretary in the same reshuffle?

He has no star quality, nor a claque of Maudeites to sing his praises, but his appointment may turn out to be just as significant, since he will now lead the Conservatives' anti-European crusade - which, they hope, will bring the voters flocking back to their party.

So what are Francis Maude's qualifications for the job? I turn to the Hansard of January 31 1990, when he was minister for Europe in the government of Margaret Thatcher, the well-known federalist. "We are seeing the growth of economic and monetary integration to reduce costs, to help business and to take forward the integration of Europe," Maude informed the Commons. "In all these important areas, Britain has led the way and we are showing the way forward . . . In economic and monetary union, no country is more advanced than ours."

Does little Hague know this? And has anyone told him that it was also Francis Maude who signed the hated Maastricht treaty on behalf of the British government? Irony may be delicious as a snack, but can bring on terminal indigestion when eaten with the roast beef of old England.

Talking of which, I wonder if William Hague has read Alan Clark's diaries. In an entry for December 19 1987, Clark describes "a very jolly dinner at the Savoy" with Francis Maude, David Heathcoat Amory and the late Ian Gow, during which Gow suggested that Margaret Thatcher might send Nigel Lawson to the foreign office.

"Maude, supported by David H-A, said Lawson couldn't be foreign sec as a Jew," Clark records. "This made Ian very indignant. 'Do you mean to tell me that today, this very day, in this, the Conservative party - I take it that we are all members of the Conservative party? - you are seriously suggesting, no, asserting . . .' and so on. Ian then switched to 'He's not a practising Jew, anyway.' But we couldn't quite swallow it."

Jewish supporters of the Conservative party - if such people still exist - may wish to ask themselves if they can quite swallow Francis Maude.

John's double whammy

At a Westminster lunch last week I sat next to John Major, who was disarmingly friendly. Shortly after our second bottle of wine arrived, I noticed that his hand was on my thigh - something of a first for me, at least with former Tory prime ministers.

Since his defeat in 1997 Major has developed a nice line in self-mockery; even if he stood unopposed in an election, he said, he'd still come second. When I replied that he was bound to win the award for which we'd both been shortlisted - political author of the year, chosen by customers of Politico's bookshop - he laughed incredulously.

But win it he did, by three votes. Could it be that luckless John had at last banished the jinx that made him destroy everything he touched, including the Conservative party?

Er, perhaps not. A day later, noticing that a blistery rash had suddenly erupted down one side of my face, I went to the doctor. "Shingles," he pronounced briskly. "Probably brought on by stress."

I cannot say for sure that it was the thigh-fondler's fault. But what could be more stress-inducing than the realisation that I'm one of the few people in Britain incapable of beating John Major in a secret ballot?

The Monster Raving Loony Party which has managed to crack the intellectual code and establish a branch at Oxford University. Its membership is already 50-strong. fields.standfirst:
Peter Mandelson's move to appease unionists means the mechanism of a subtle process remains jammed

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: This was the moment everyone had feared. From its first faltering steps more than five years ago, the quest for peace in Northern Ireland has hinged on a single fact: the Irish Republican Army's ceasefire.
fields.body:
This was the moment everyone had feared. From its first faltering steps more than five years ago, the quest for peace in Northern Ireland has hinged on a single fact: the Irish Republican Army's ceasefire.

Without that, there would have been nothing - no Good Friday agreement, no overwhelming majorities in referendums north and south, no assembly and, above all, none of that exhilarating sense of possibility, that hint of imminent normality, which has filled the province since the bombs stopped.

When the first ceasefire was broken, with the 1996 blast at Canary Wharf, all that hope drained away in an instant. Last night brought a similar moment of dread: the IRA announced its withdrawal from the disarmament talks on which the entire peace process now hangs. The heart began to sink. Could it be that Northern Ireland, having come so close to a peaceful future, was about to return to the bloody past of bombs, shootings and death?

No, thankfully, it seemed not. The interpreters who routinely fan out to decode statements from the IRA provided rapid reassurance - in time for the Six O'Clock News: there was, they said, no threat to the ceasefire. The provisionals were not returning to war; instead they were pulling out in disgust from the process that is meant to secure peace. As one senior republican put it, the IRA's latest action is a "controlled upping of the ante". They want the Ulster Unionists and the British government to realise how bad things have got.

What explains this crisis? After all, little more than two months have passed since we all witnessed the once-unimaginable: Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Bruin taking their seats as Sinn Fein ministers in a new Northern Ireland executive - sharing a cabinet table with their blood-enemies in Unionism. Just a few days ago John de Chastelain, the Canadian former general charged with overseeing the disarmament process, stepped forward to deliver his first truly upbeat report - anticipating, at last, a process of IRA decommissioning. So what went wrong?

The answer, sad to say, may lie with one man: Peter Mandelson. The republican movement is in a state of cold fury with the secretary of state, accusing him of dishonesty and unforgiveable bias - acting not as an honest broker but as an agent for unionism. Relations have not broken down. Nor have they reached the nadir plumbed by Mr Mandelson's predecessor, Mo Mowlam, in her relationship with the unionists. The distrust is not yet that bad. But, says one Sinn Fein activist, "It's getting there."

At the heart of the problem are the events of last Friday. On that day Mandelson announced the suspension of the fledgling Northern Ireland executive. From now on the province would be governed by him alone: a return to the direct rule of the last quarter century. He had no alternative, he said. If he had allowed the executive to survive, the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble would have faced his party's ruling council the next day and been forced to resign. After all, Trimble had only persuaded the UUP's hardliners to allow the executive on a promise that, if the IRA did not hand over their guns by February 12, he would quit as first minister and bring the whole body tumbling down. In the absence of any movement from the IRA, Mandelson says the only way he could save Trimble - and therefore the executive itself - was to suspend it.

It is that decision which has so enraged Sinn Fein. For they believe the IRA had indeed moved - and moved an enormous distance. Admittedly it was at the last minute, late on Friday afternoon, but there is nothing unusual in that - not in a process which saw the Good Friday agreement negotiated at five o'clock in the morning. The IRA's shift was certainly significant enough to put a rare spring in General de Chastelain's step, after hours of intensive work. Dublin and Washington regarded it as a huge breakthrough, too. For what was in the pipeline was a statement declaring an end to the war, a promise for a symbolic yielding of arms before the May deadline agreed on Good Friday and even a possible timetable for decommissioning, dependent on an equivalent move toward demilitarisation by the British government. The critical element for the provos was a national day of reconciliation, one in which they could be seen not as a defeated force but as an army "standing down" along with the British.

With all that in the air, it's easy to understand republican fury. Why on earth would Peter Mandelson have passed up this chance, just to stick to a deadline laid down by the Ulster Unionist Council? For Sinn Fein's president, Gerry Adams, it made life particularly difficult. At the end of last year he faced a grilling from republican hardliners who doubted Mandelson's bona fides. They feared the secretary of state had issued wavering unionists with a personal assurance that he would collapse the executive if the IRA gave up no guns, no matter what the Good Friday text said. When they heard Mandelson on the radio, explaining why unionist patience had finally snapped, they felt their worst fears had been confirmed - that they were dealing not with a British cabinet minister but a spokesman for the UUP.

Their fury was stoked yet further by their belief that Mandelson is massaging the truth. He insists that he had no idea what was in the IRA statement when he ordered the suspension on Friday night. Sinn Fein say that is absolutely untrue. As secretary of state, he is kept informed of every step of these ultra-delicate negotiations. They are convinced that he sacrificed a real chance for peace last week - in order to stick to his bargain with David Trimble.

That may be a conspiracy theory too far, but Peter Mandelson does indeed seem to have snatched defeat from the jaws of victory. His error has been to give the distinct impression - so fatal in a Northern Ireland secretary - that the ultimate veto remains in unionist hands: if events don't run on their timetable, they don't run at all. He has not paused to imagine what his actions on Friday night looked like to nationalist and republican eyes. For they seemed to confirm the hardliners' constant complaint: that no matter how much you bend over backwards, no matter how much you negotiate, it will never be good enough. Adams and McGuinness have spent years arguing with their fellow republicans that politics is worthwhile, that gaining a power-sharing executive was worth trading, say, articles 2 and 3 of the Irish constitution, which maintained a claim on the north and which have now been dropped. Then, on Friday, a British minister removes the executive with a stroke of a pen just because the unionists insist he must.

No wonder the hardliners are walking away. Peter Mandelson has succeeded in making the moderates in republicanism look like saps and the extremists like sages. He needs to move quickly to turn that around - for a peace process that remains deadlocked for too long can fast become a war.

fields.headline: 'Foolish' Gorman hits back at inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Life in Parliament: special report
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The maverick Tory MP, Teresa Gorman, yesterday launched a pre-emptive strike against a report which is expected tomorrow to recommend her suspension from the Commons for repeatedly misleading parliament over her business interests.
fields.body:
The maverick Tory MP, Teresa Gorman, yesterday launched a pre-emptive strike against a report which is expected tomorrow to recommend her suspension from the Commons for repeatedly misleading parliament over her business interests.

The MP for Billericay, furious about two Guardian articles disclosing that she had failed to declare property interests held in offshore trusts, accused the Commons standards and privileges committee of acting like "the Spanish inquisition and the Star Chamber". MPs decided this week to complete their inquiry despite a decision by Mrs Gorman no longer to cooperate with their deliberations.

Mrs Gorman admitted she had got in a muddle over her business and said she had inadvertently misled Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner.

She was forced to apologise to the Commons last year for failing to register a directorship and shareholdings in a business providing scientific teaching aids. The present inquiry, prompted by the Independent newspaper, is into her failure to disclose three properties in south London which she had rented out to tenants. She also failed to disclose that she had interests in a villa in Portugal registered in an offshore trust.

Mrs Gorman said: "I may have been foolish and said the wrong thing at the wrong time. But what was I obliged to put in the register? Not my holiday home, not my private residence, only things in which I had a beneficial and pecuniary interest in my own right and not because it was my husband's." She said she and her husband had decided to split their assets in 1986 and she inadvertently left her name on the land register of the properties.

Mrs Gorman called for reform of the system of policing of MPs' conduct. She wants a right of appeal against tomorrow's expected judgment.
