webTitle: No truck with the lorry for the badger-gassing man

fields.headline: No truck with the lorry for the badger-gassing man
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report
Life in Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Ashley Stewart, dark, jut-jawed freelance van driver, steered William Hague's Keep The Pound battle lorry into the main street of St Albans, displacing the Dinky Donuts van, which was moved out of camera range. The juxtaposition of Dinky Donuts and Mr Hague's head might have set up resonances in the viewers' minds.
fields.body:
Ashley Stewart, dark, jut-jawed freelance van driver, steered William Hague's Keep The Pound battle lorry into the main street of St Albans, displacing the Dinky Donuts van, which was moved out of camera range. The juxtaposition of Dinky Donuts and Mr Hague's head might have set up resonances in the viewers' minds.

On the left was another van selling French pancakes. It's not the first time Mr Hague has found himself in competition with a load of crepes.

Just why the battle lorry was there at all was unclear. Except for a few balloons, the back was empty. Mr Hague was coming in a car, and when he arrived he chose to stand on a platform instead, having no truck with the lorry, which seems to be little more than a mobile backdrop for the great leader's tour.

Quite a large crowd had gathered, though most seemed to be local Tories, a few puzzled tourists, and a lot of media people. Mr Hague had promised to get outside the M25, that perimeter fence which rings all the inbred, metropolitan chattering classes, in order to meet the real people - and St Albans does lie almost a mile from that highway of hypocrisy.

There was a sudden loud screeching noise, so we assumed Ann Widdecombe had arrived, but it turned out to be feedback from the mikes.

Michael Ancram, the Conservative party chairman, made a noisy speech telling us that the leader was on his way. "I am assured that he will be with us shortly! Yes, he is coming! We want to keep the pound: we are proud of our country!"

"Plonker," remarked one of the real people outside Boots.

"Yes, he is on his way!" yelled Mr Ancram. "The man who is driving this campaign!" But not, for some reason, driving the lorry.

Finally he was among us, wearing a brown rustic sort of jacket, suitable for a night gassing badgers.

"You're going to see a very rare thing for a politician to do, put his hand in his pocket," he said, pulling out a coin. "This is the pound!" He waved it at us, as if we were a particularly thick primary school class.

"Put yer hands up if yer have a job or run a business!" he shouted. No one did. "Yes!" he went on, undeterred by the almost total absence of hands, "hundreds of you have a job or own a business!

"Hands up everyone who pays taxes!" About six hands rose. "Yes, almost everyone pays taxes, and under Labour you pay more taxes!" Nothing would stop him. "How many of you have a pension fund?" Seven arms went up. "Hundreds of people!" he raved.

Faced with a city in which everyone appeared to be an unemployed, tax dodging indigent, he simply pretended it wasn't so. (The last time I was in St Albans was in April 1997, when Michael Heseltine told me: "Look, people are flooding back to us!" even while they were fleeing like shoals of fish from a shark. Tricking Tory politicians seems to be a local hobby.)

Question time next. This consisted largely of Mr Hague repeating the question then adding: "So vote Conservative". Michael Portillo joined his leader, alternately smiling adoringly at him and jutting a determined jaw, like a man looking forward to having his teeth extracted. Another real person shouted: "Do you wear dresses?"

Mr Portillo spoke grimly of the day we crashed from the European exchange rate mechanism in 1992. "Some people may have short memories, but William and I have long memories." As do we all, of those dark days when the treasury chief secretary was, er, Michael Portillo.

fields.headline: So who watches soaps?
fields.trailText: I was intrigued, and irritated, by your report on the findings of the Royal Television Society (BBC fails to make the top 10, February 12).
fields.body:
I was intrigued, and irritated, by your report on the findings of the Royal Television Society (BBC fails to make the top 10, February 12).

None of my family have ever been asked about their viewing habits, nor have any of our friends. Between us, my husband and I have never managed to find anyone who was involved in these researches, yet we are regularly told how many millions of us are watching soap operas and quiz programmes - programmes which my own large family and most of our friends never think of looking at.

Perhaps it is time the society did a bit of research into its range of respondents.
Mavis D Colvin
Southend, Essex
The compiler of the survey, William Philip, says: "Take away EastEnders, a handful of specials, and little remains in the top 50 to justify the corporation's pretensions as a convenor of the whole nation for shared amusement." A statement of Murdochian inaccuracy. He could equally have said: "Take away Coronation Street and Who Wants To Be A Millionaire and little remains to justify ITV taking £3bn spent annually on television advertising from the shopping public."
Rodney Giesler
Nr Calne, Wilts


The Church of England complains that the BBC's religious output is "boring, trite drivel" (Synod rails at BBC religious output, February 15). Could this be anything to do with the subject matter?
Terry Sanderson
London

fields.headline: Raising the alarm
fields.trailText: Allan Horsfall (Letters, February 15) says "the really alarming thing" about me is my membership of the home office working party on sex offences. Although I was invited to serve on this body, I am not and have never been a member.
fields.body:
Allan Horsfall (Letters, February 15) says "the really alarming thing" about me is my membership of the home office working party on sex offences. Although I was invited to serve on this body, I am not and have never been a member. The really alarming thing is that somebody appears to have told Mr Horsfall that this invitation was made, but not that it was declined; but then, credulity and disinformation are always linked in dishonourable causes.
Melanie Phillips
London
Edward Hardy (Letters, February 12) described hamsters as "nasty mouse-like things". Has it occurred to him that the feeling was mutual.
Sarah Platt (aged 12)
Stockport, Cheshire


A more satisfactory word for "shambles" in Welsh (Letters, February 14) would be blerwch. It derives from bler, which means "untidy, messy" and is pronounced "Blair".
Eric Owen Stephens
Pembroke Dock

fields.headline: Help with the helpline
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel's naming and shaming of the corporate phonies (February 15) is long overdue.
fields.body:
Matthew Engel's naming and shaming of the corporate phonies (February 15) is long overdue. The switch on my electric shower recently failed and I was informed that there was only one national distributor for spares. After being kept on hold for 41 minutes it then only took me five minutes to place my order. Cost of switch including post and packing, £4.88; cost of telephone call, 46 minutes at national daytime rate of 7.19 pence per minute, £3.30. Perhaps the cost of phoning helplines and call centres should be included in calculating the retail price index.
Brian P Moss
Tamworth, Staffs
Dell Computers' technical help line may be slow, but what gripes me more is a national call rate number for it, bearing in mind that Dell is one of the most successful computer makers in the world. Even worse is Microsoft. Bill Gates, the richest man in the world, allows a local-rate sales number and a national-rate technical help number.
C Pygott
Buildwas, Shropshire
clive@g-f-h.demon.co.uk


If you can't get though on the support (complaint) line then ring the sales number. This is frequently the same place and sometimes a free phone number. When you get through ask to be put through to the support, explain that you have been waiting and that nothing is happening. If they say they can't put you through or that you will have to ring the other number, ask to speak to the supervisor. If they refuse, insist on speaking to the supervisor.

Do not hang up. They are not allowed to hang up on you (though the occasional line drop does happen). Remember, you are paying no more for this call than you would be waiting to hear their "we value you custom" message. You will eventually be put through to someone else. Tell them your problems.

Always get the name of everyone you talk to. If the line drops then phone back and ask to speak direct to the person you were talking too. In some cases you will need a second name and potentially a call centre name. Remember if you go through on the sales line you are costing them more in lost sales than the cost of the call. They want you off the line as soon as posible. Be calm, be patient, but also be persistent. Do not get annoyed at the initial person you are talking to, they have no authority to deal with the problem and are paid very little for what they do. They get lots of people shouting at them during a day so stand out by being pleasant but firm. It works.
Eamon Hughes
Wallingford, Oxon
eamon@enemy.org.uk

Always get the name of everyone you talk to. If the line drops then phone back and ask to speak direct to the person you were talking too. In some cases you will need a second name and potentially a call centre name. Remember if you go through on the sales line you are costing them more in lost sales than the cost of the call. They want you off the line as soon as posible. Be calm, be patient, but also be persistent. Do not get annoyed at the initial person you are talking to, they have no authority to deal with the problem and are paid very little for what they do. They get lots of people shouting at them during a day so stand out by being pleasant but firm. It works. Eamon Hughes Wallingford, Oxon eamon@enemy.org.uk

fields.headline: It's a crime
fields.trailText: My eyes lit up when I read that the government had set a 30% target reduction in vehicle crime over the next five years (Crime targets cannot be met, say police, February 15).
fields.body:
My eyes lit up when I read that the government had set a 30% target reduction in vehicle crime over the next five years (Crime targets cannot be met, say police, February 15). At last, the drivers who treat speed limits and red lights with contempt, make illegal turns with impunity and generally behave as if the laws controlling motoring offences were non-existent, are going to get their comeuppance.

But then I read on and realised that crime against cars was being targeted, not crime by drivers, and that property is seen as more important than the safety of more vulnerable road users like pedestrians and cyclists.
Dr RF Carter
London

fields.headline: Going to war over words
fields.trailText: Gary Younge's discussion of political correctness doesn't go far enough (The badness of words, February 14). Some forms of speech and manners dubbed as "politically correct" are, as he says, expressions of politeness and respect, others are politically loaded and reflect social attitudes of a bygone age, such as a belief in the inferiority of women.
fields.body:
Gary Younge's discussion of political correctness doesn't go far enough (The badness of words, February 14). Some forms of speech and manners dubbed as "politically correct" are, as he says, expressions of politeness and respect, others are politically loaded and reflect social attitudes of a bygone age, such as a belief in the inferiority of women.

Political correctness is used as a term of abuse in order to disparage styles of speech, address and manners introduced to reflect more modern egalitarian attitudes. But political correctness (though it wasn't called that) was invented long before more egalitarian attitudes became common. All of us were once expected to stand in silence as the national anthem was played at the end of performances in theatres and cinemas. And, even today, if you address the Queen as "Mrs Windsor", the fury in the tabloids would show that they have their own standards of political correctness.
Grenville Wall
Vantaa, Finland
gren.wall@kolumbus.fi


The term political correctness has been used by sexists, racists and homophobes to batter their critics for far too long and it's high time that an embargo was put on its use in a quality newspaper.

Please also ban the following terms which are routinely trotted out by those too lazy to justify their reactionary views and policies: "do-gooders", used to denigrate compassionate people; "Hampstead liberals", the categorisation as a hypocrite of anyone (rarely from Hampstead) opposed to the adoption of Tory policies by the Labour government; "joined-up thinking", spin-doctor-speak which attempts to portray the betrayal of pre-election promises as mature.
Christopher Connolly
Chesterfield
consperanza@yahoo.co.uk


I sympathise with Gary Younge's frustration at the use of political correctness as a catch-all phrase. The politically correct are not true liberals but pseudo-liberals. Such persons, who are usually white and heterosexual, do not see individuals, only members of arbitrarily defined groups. The politically correct, who include politicians and journalists, expect gratitude from homosexuals and black people for their "support". Criticism angers them, often revealing their true intolerance. It is this syndrome that I have named political correctness. In future, I shall call it by its real name: patronising bigotry in reverse.
Aidan Rankin
London
A.Rankin@lse.ac.uk


Gary Younge would have us believe that the label political correctness serves to silence people and suppress true liberalism (whatever that may be). The reality is that PC is a virulent ideological censorship which dominates the "free" world's pseudo-educational and political systems. The label had to be invented because PC always pretends to be simply the truth. Effective political policies and social harmony can only be achieved through the honest discussion of evidence which PC censorship prevents.
Robin P Clarke
Birmingham
r.clarke@zazz.org.uk


The fact that political correctness is used as a derogatory term reminds us that equality battles are constantly acted out on the terrain of language. I personally do not apologise if accused of being politically correct. It is important to meet these debates face on. If we don't then we end up apologising for being feminists, anti-racists, multi-culturalists, and so on. At that point liberals are on the retreat. The political, as feminists have long argued, is personal as well.
Dr Stephen Whitehead
Department of Education, Keele University
flashgreen@clara.co.uk

fields.headline: Lesson in power sharing
fields.trailText: Teaching citizenship is an uphill struggle, says John Crace (The new citizens, February 15). It is not a struggle if it entails children running their own schools in a democratic way. Most schools are dictatorships - benevolent ones maybe, but dictatorships nevertheless.
fields.body:
Teaching citizenship is an uphill struggle, says John Crace (The new citizens, February 15). It is not a struggle if it entails children running their own schools in a democratic way. Most schools are dictatorships - benevolent ones maybe, but dictatorships nevertheless. To teach children about our political system while refusing them the right to question these dictatorships is sheer hypocrisy. No wonder they are bored.

Issues of social justice are of passionate interest to children. If schools were organised in a way that accepted the expression of this interest, and then allowed children to take action to correct what they saw as wrong, you wouldn't have to teach citizenship at all. Children would learn it for themselves.
David Gribble
South Brent, Devon
Thank you Barry Cole, (Letters, February 12). I have been waiting more than 20 years for a simple, clear description of the role of the teacher and the extent of his/her responsibilities. And, at last, we have it, in brilliant detail from someone who really does know. It reminded me so much of the school in which I taught some 40 years ago, when local authorities ran the schools in close, continuous co-operation with the teachers, and when heads were teachers first and administrators second.
Arthur Fright
East Wittering, West Sussex

fields.headline: The IRA pulls the plug
fields.standfirst:
Mr Mandelson has some explaining to do

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: We need to be told what it was that inspired the notably upbeat second report which General de Chastelain published on Friday night after the IRA's last minute initiative on decommissioning. "How on earth," asked the Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams later, "could anyone work with a commission that, when it makes a report that the British government and Unionists don't like, they simply bin it?"
fields.body:
We need to be told what it was that inspired the notably upbeat second report which General de Chastelain published on Friday night after the IRA's last minute initiative on decommissioning. "How on earth," asked the Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams later, "could anyone work with a commission that, when it makes a report that the British government and Unionists don't like, they simply bin it?" And last night, on the same calculation, and to mark its contempt for the Northern Ireland secretary's downbeat response, the IRA washed its hands of the decommissioning process.

On the basis of what has been published so far - the mere summary of the general's conclusions - that action might seem precipitate and hard to defend. It appeared from the evidence on Friday that the IRA had still failed to answer the two essential questions put by the SDLP deputy leader, Seamus Mallon: Will you decommission? And if so, when? While those questions remained unanswered, progress was blocked. But it now begins to appear that the IRA may have answered them in a way which met Mr Mallon's terms - which is no doubt why he mysteriously hinted at the weekend that the basis for a deal might be there after all. And if that is true, the crucial question becomes why London did not join Dublin in recognising a breakthrough. On this reading, what should have become a basis to build on has instead brought breakdown. Mr Mandelson was also adamant on Friday that at the point when he made his decision to suspend the assembly and the executive, he knew nothing of the IRA's change of heart: that too is disputed.

The peace process is not beyond rescue. The ceasefire survives. But the story which began to emerge yesterday suggests that both may have been unnecessarily endangered by London's reluctance to move. Mr Blair and Mr Ahern have urgent repair work to do when they meet in London today.

fields.headline: A network of betrayal
fields.standfirst:
Few escape the censure of Waterhouse
More about the Wales child abuse scandal
fields.trailText: There was a familiar pattern to the start of the scandal: a whistleblower who was not only not believed, but suspended and later sacked. Neither internal nor police inquiries were able to stand up her allegations.
fields.body:
There was a familiar pattern to the start of the scandal: a whistleblower who was not only not believed, but suspended and later sacked. Neither internal nor police inquiries were able to stand up her allegations.

It ended yesterday, 14 years later, after a four-year long judicial inquiry, the longest and most expensive investigation into childcare in Britain. The 500,000-word Waterhouse report paints a chilling picture of life in North Wales's children's homes over 25 years. The initial complaint involved physical abuse in a single Gwynedd home. That expanded into an investigation into more than 40 homes - public, private and voluntary - in Clwyd and Gwynedd which found not only blatant physical bullying but gross sexual, emotional and mental abuse too.

Yet again, a system designed to protect children from abusive parents or relatives stands indicted for inflicting abuse as bad or worse on the children under its protection. Most cases go back to the 1970s or early 1980s, but a few stretch into the 1990s. In far too many homes in North Wales there was an absence of compassion, care or concern for children and "a conspiracy of silence" among the staff. As Paul Murphy, Welsh secretary, told the Commons, there were "appalling misdeeds, wickedness and total abuse of trust". The system was devoid of leadership, management or planning. No part of it escapes censure - social services, councillors, police, or the Welsh office.

There has been a succession of internal, external and independent investigations into North Wales homes. High-profile criminal trials of key abusers have kept the scandal in the news. Yet there was much we still did not know - and a lot of rumour which needed scotching.

Of the 12 internal inquiries into Clwyd, only two were relayed to councillors in comprehensive form. In Waterhouse's words, some accounts were "positively misleading". Yet it seems that no official has been disciplined. Then there was the 254-page Jillings report, an independent investigation which was withheld from publication by Clwyd partly because of the demands of its insurers.

Waterhouse is exceptionally weak in defending this decision. He's no champion of the public right to know. But his is the first comprehensive review of the scandal to be published. Without him, the faults of the Welsh office and social service leaders would have remained obscure. He lays to rest the idea that a paedophile ring of prominent people was operating in North Wales and finds no evidence of freemasons interfering with police inquiries. In terms of organised abuse, he restricts his findings to a paedophile ring in the Wrexham and Chester areas ("in the sense that there were a number of male persons, many of them known to each other, who were engaged in paedophile activities") but uncovers no evidence that they were solely or mainly interested in persons in care.

Waterhouse has cleared the air. But compare the £13.5m bill for this exercise with the miserable £5m set aside for "Children First", the new childcare strategy for the principality. England has no cause to be too smug. A survey of 27 English children's departments 16 months ago failed to find one where all the safeguards protecting the welfare of children were being applied.

But much progress has been made even since then. A succession of initiatives in the wake of the 1997 review of safeguards has introduced stricter inspection, tougher monitoring and more systematic complaints systems. Independent visitors, children's rights officers and helplines have added to children's security. So have better police checks and the spending of an extra £375m over three years to ensure local action plans are introduced. Wales is following suit, but slightly behind.

We are not there yet. Some 40% of social work places in the new scheme have still to be filled. England should follow Wales and appoint a children's commissioner. But, above all, the words of Alison Taylor, the original whistleblower, need to be heeded. "Child abuse," she said yesterday, "is part of the spectrum of human behaviour that has occurred throughout history. It is not going to disappear."

fields.headline: The minimum increase
fields.trailText: The government's spin about its uprating of the minimum wage is that 10p is generous because it is "above the rate of inflation" (Labour to raise minimum wage, February 15).
fields.body:
The government's spin about its uprating of the minimum wage is that 10p is generous because it is "above the rate of inflation" (Labour to raise minimum wage, February 15). Inflation is running at over 2% and the extra on the minimum wage is not due until October. An increase of just under 2.8% after a year and a half means the annual increase is, er... below the rate of inflation, which is over 3% in 18 months. Perhaps Mr Byers needs to be sent on one of Mr Blunkett's new McDegree courses?
Alex Wilcock
London
alex@tisl.co.uk


Your report states that "government sources said there had been no question of the government bowing to outside pressure". Whew! That's alright then. For one terrible moment, I thought the government might be becoming democratic.
Brian Clark
Brighton, East Sussex


The government's acknowledgement that £3.50 an hour (approximately £130 a week) is inadequate to live on is welcome. An extra 10 pence per hour (£3.60 a week), though niggardly, is a step in the right direction. Having entered this train of thought, will the government now also acknowledge that a state pension of £66.75 a week, with a proposed increase of 75 pence a week in April, is not only inadequate but an absolute disgrace?
Clifford Fuller
Gloucester

webTitle: Second official quits UN Iraq team

fields.headline: Second official quits UN Iraq team
fields.standfirst:
HM Customs and Excise
Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: The United Nations sanctions against Iraq suffered a new setback yesterday after another high-ranking official was reported to have resigned in protest at the suffering of the civilian population.
fields.body:
The United Nations sanctions against Iraq suffered a new setback yesterday after another high-ranking official was reported to have resigned in protest at the suffering of the civilian population.

European diplomats in Baghdad said the head of the UN World Food Programme in Iraq, Jutta Purghart, of Germany, had quit her post.

Her move came 24 hours after the UN accepted the resignation of the humanitarian coordinator, Hans von Sponeck, who protested at the impact of the sanctions on the civilian population.

The sanctions policy has been criticised by other international humanitarian organisations operating in Iraq. Mr von Sponeck's predecessor, Denis Halliday, resigned in 1998, also over the sanctions.

Sanctions were imposed after the invasion of Kuwait in 1990. Six years later, amid public pressure, the UN softened its stance and allowed Iraq to export some oil in return for food and medicines.

Ms Purghart had administered the distribution of food supplies in Iraq under the oil-for-food deal since taking up her post in January 1999.

A European diplomat said Ms Purghart had written to the World Food Programme headquarters in Rome to say she could not continue in her job because she believed that sanctions were a failure and caused suffering. She was said to be critical of the recent British-inspired UN resolution that offered to ease sanctions in return for Iraq allowing in weapons inspectors.

A World Food Programme spokesman in Rome, Francis Mwanza, confirmed that the agency had received a letter of resignation from Ms Purghart. But he said hers was a personal decision to return to work for the German government and that the move was not a protest over sanctions.

Doubts about the effectiveness of the sanctions have increased because they have failed to persuade President Saddam Hussein to allow in weapons inspectors to check whether he is developing weapons of mass destruction, and the policy is hurting the civilian population.

Russia applauded the resignation of Mr von Sponeck and called for the lifting of sanctions. A Russian ship, intercepted by the US in the Gulf because of alleged sanction-breaking, is in Amman, awaiting results of tests to confirm whether it was carrying Iraqi oil.

The French government said it could understand the motives behind Mr von Sponeck's resignation. Speaking before Ms Purghart quit, a foreign ministry spokeswoman, Anne Gazeau-Secret, said of Mr von Sponeck: "His evaluation of the humanitarian situation in Iraq corresponds to reality. Without question, it reflects the views of all observers of the situation on the ground."

Meanwhile, the US and Britain have insisted that President Saddam could end the suffering by allowing entry to weapons inspectors. A British foreign office spokeswoman said: "We would focus on the the programme, not the individuals. We trust the [UN] secretary general to appoint worthy successors."

The Iraqi ambassador to the UN, Saeed Hasan, said: "People are resigning because they could no more be silent on the genocide which is taking place in Iraq."

fields.headline: Cresson to face inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Former European commissioner stripped of immunity to open the way for investigations into allegations of corruption

The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: The former French prime minister, Edith Cresson, will face questioning from Belgian police about allegations of corruption after the European Commission announced last night that it was lifting her immunity.
fields.body:
The former French prime minister, Edith Cresson, will face questioning from Belgian police about allegations of corruption after the European Commission announced last night that it was lifting her immunity.

Ms Cresson, at the centre of the controversy over the collapse of Jacques Santer's discredited commission last year, has said she wants to cooperate with police, and has repeatedly protested her innocence.

She is wanted for questioning about the "Berthelot affair", involving the hiring of a dentist friend who stayed in her Brussels home when she was the EU's research commissioner.

"Naturally, the commission makes no judgement on the substance of the allegations under investigation," a commission statement said last night. She is the first EU commissioner to come under investigation for criminal offences.

Ms Cresson, the French prime minister for 10 months in 1991-92 and commissioner from 1995 to 1999, once famously insisted that one in every four Englishmen was gay and that the Japanese lived "like ants".

Commission sources said last night that Romano Prodi, Mr Santer's Italian successor, wanted to move quickly on the immunity issue to show that he and his colleagues represent a different culture and will not tolerate cronyism or corruption.

Neil Kinnock, Mr Prodi's vice-president for reform, said in a statement: "The commission has taken the proper decision firmly and without delay. The whole issue is now a matter for judicial reference."

Police will be able to enter commission premises - including its in-house anti-fraud office - to search for files and question six employees, although Belgium has not asked for their immunity to be lifted. However, Ms Cresson's old friend, René Berthelot, does not enjoy immunity.

In the squeaky clean atmosphere of the Prodi commission, the alleged offences are seen as an embarrassing hangover from a different era. webTitle: Aspirants vow to obey EU code

fields.headline: Aspirants vow to obey EU code
fields.standfirst: The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Six countries from the Baltic to the Mediterranean pledged to abide by the rules and values of the European Union yesterday at the launch of talks that will almost double its membership within a decade.
fields.body:
Six countries from the Baltic to the Mediterranean pledged to abide by the rules and values of the European Union yesterday at the launch of talks that will almost double its membership within a decade.

Ministers from Romania, Bulgaria, Slovakia, Latvia, Lithuania and Malta all hailed the "historic" nature of their engagement with the 15-member club, now in the throes of the biggest expansion in its history.

This second wave of enlargement follows talks under way with fast-track candidates Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Slovenia and Cyprus.

If all join, plus Turkey, the EU would one day comprise 28 countries with more than 500m citizens, which would make it the largest trading and investment bloc in the world.

The EU says the first newcomers can be admitted after 2003 though entry will be staggered, according to how quickly the candidates meet the many criteria they have to fulfil.

The scale of the expansion is acting as a spur to urgent institutional reforms by the existing members - launched in Brussels on Monday - that are needed to avoid paralysis when the club grows.

"After being for almost half a century on the bad side of history ... this historic moment means that Romania is now on the right side," the Romanian foreign minister, Petre Roman, said.

In Bucharest, an EU flag was symbolically placed on a pedestal where a bronze replica of Lenin stood until a decade ago.

Joseph Borg, the Maltese foreign minister, compared the significance of the occasion with the island's independence from Britain in 1964.

There have been six waves of enlargement since the European Economic Community was founded in 1957. The last step involved the accession of Austria, Finland and Sweden in 1995.

But the entry of the former communist countries of eastern Europe poses far bigger challenges.

The current crisis over Austria also poses awkward questions, as the country's far-right Freedom party exploits fears of an influx of immigrants and a loss of jobs as investors move to its low-wage neighbours.

All 12 candidates face the huge task of adapting their legislation to EU rules, and respecting the union's basic principles of human rights, democracy and market economics.

Negotiations must tackle complex technical issues, including agricultural and industrial subsidies, anti-trust law and environmental standards - an issue highlighted by the cyanide spill that has devastated fishing in Hungary in recent days.

Turkey was also recognised as a candidate at last December's Helsinki summit, while Croatia, Macedonia, Albania and Bosnia have expressed long-term hopes of joining.

Wide support exists for enlargement, though there are fears - expressed recently by the former commission president, Jacques Delors - that if the process moves too fast the EU's original values will be diluted or lost.

New wave of wannabes

Bulgaria

Population: 8.2m

Poor economic situation, but EU more worried about tightening border controls. Being rewarded for backing Nato during the Kosovo crisis

Latvia

Population: 2.4m

Tried hard to meet EU concerns about treatment of some 650,000 Russians who settled in Latvia during Soviet rule. Praised by Brussels for economic reforms

Lithuania

Population: 3.7m

Biggest obstacle to membership is its Chernobyl-style Ignalina nuclear plant, which the EU wants closed

Malta

Population: 400,000

Missed 1998 round of membership talks after a previous government froze its bid. Expects to join union and euro zone by 2003.

Romania

Population: 22m

Behind in economic and agricultural reform. Concern about children's homes

Slovakia

Population: 5.3m

Economy up to scratch, but left out of 1998 round because of political record of its former hardline prime minister, Vladimir Meciar. Wealthiest of new wave with GDP 46% of EU average

webTitle: Right rallies for attack on McCain

fields.headline: Right rallies for attack on McCain
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: George W Bush intensified his attacks on John McCain in the bitter Republican presidential battle yesterday, mobilising conservative groups to bombard voters with messages accusing the Arizona senator of being soft on abortion and taxation and not to be trusted on causes dear to rightwing hearts.
fields.body:
George W Bush intensified his attacks on John McCain in the bitter Republican presidential battle yesterday, mobilising conservative groups to bombard voters with messages accusing the Arizona senator of being soft on abortion and taxation and not to be trusted on causes dear to rightwing hearts.

The anti-McCain onslaught is rising to a peak as the two men slug it out in the South Carolina Republican primary, where voters vote on Saturday in a contest that both candidates have to win.

Mr Bush's lurch to the right in a state where white religious conservatives hold political sway seems to be paying dividends, according to the opinion polls. A new Gallup poll taken between Friday and Sunday shows Mr Bush with a 49%-42% lead over Mr McCain. This is Mr Bush's best poll showing since Mr McCain trounced the Texas governor in the New Hampshire primary two weeks ago.

Mr Bush has a 59%-34% lead among registered Republicans, while Mr McCain has a 54%-36% advantage among independents, who are allowed to vote on Saturday.

Mr Bush's tactics included the launch of 100,000 taped telephone calls to Republican voters from the iconic conservative Republican Congressman Henry Hyde, who led the impeachment drive against President Bill Clinton and is best known as a militant opponent of abortion rights.

Mr Hyde praises Mr Bush's "strong pro-life record in Texas" and criticises suggestions "that changes be made to the party platform on the life issue". Though Mr Hyde does not name Mr McCain, his comment refers to the senator's view that Republican policy should be modified to allow abortion for victims of rape or incest, or where the mother's life was endangered.

"There's not going to be a lot of ambiguity about this by the time it's all over," a Bush aide was quoted as saying in the Washington Post yesterday.

Mr Bush's mobilisation of the conservative right includes a mass mailing by the National Right to Life Committee which claims that Mr McCain "voted repeatedly to use tax dollars for experiments that use body parts from aborted babies". The mailing carries the picture of a baby with the message: "This little guy wants you to vote for George Bush."

The National Smokers Alliance (NSA) - founded by the tobacco giant Philip Morris - will today launch a series of radio adverts in South Carolina accusing Mr McCain of campaigning to raise cigarette prices and ending: "If straight talk is the issue, John McCain isn't the answer."

The NSA has already spent at least $250,000 (£156,000) on anti-McCain television advertising in South Carolina.

The final days of the campaign have been marked by the intervention of influential rightwing public figures such as the broadcaster Rush Limbaugh and the religious conservative Pat Robertson.

Mr Limbaugh said on his radio show this week that Mr Bush should launch a commercial in which "people with Clinton-Gore buttons and T-shirts with liberal slogans on them" would talk to one another saying "That McCain sounds like one of us". Then, Mr Limbaugh said, the people in the ad would take off their Clinton-Gore buttons, replace them with McCain buttons, and head to a polling station marked "Republican Primary".

Mr Robertson told an interviewer that if Mr McCain wins the Republican nomination "I think there'll be a defection of the Christian conservatives in major waves. I'm talking about a large portion of the Republican base walking away."

Conservative campaigners and lobby groups claim that they are working independently to stay within the loose bounds of US campaign spending laws, but there is not much doubt that Mr Bush and the Republican right are allies in a rearguard action to see off Mr McCain, a candidate who they fear cannot be controlled.

webTitle: How Private Eye shook Whitehall by naming C

fields.headline: How Private Eye shook Whitehall by naming C
fields.trailText: The magazine Private Eye provoked panic in Whitehall when it identified C, the letter used to denote the head of MI6, hitherto secret papers released at the public record office yesterday reveal.
fields.body:
The magazine Private Eye provoked panic in Whitehall when it identified C, the letter used to denote the head of MI6, hitherto secret papers released at the public record office yesterday reveal.

The magazine broke existing media conventions by naming Sir Dick White as C, standing for Chief, in a column by Claud Cockburn, in August 1963. In a small paragraph headed "Note to foreign agents" he named Sir Dick as the "head of what you so romantically term the British Secret Service".

A hastily-summoned meeting chaired by the cabinet secretary, Sir Burke Trend, concluded no action could be taken. Since Cockburn's source was not known and Sir Dick's name was widely known in Fleet Street, he could not be prosecuted under the official secrets act.

Sanity, the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament magazine, picked up the story and published a picture of Sir Dick's house in West Sussex. Colonel 'Sammy' Lohan, secretary of the D notice committee which operates a volountary censorship system, was apoplectic.

He told the cabinet office: "I invited David Boulton [editor of Sanity] to lunch on a battlefield of my own choosing - the Savoy."

Col Lohan said Boulton refused to acknowledge the D notice system, but did promise to let Col Lohan know before committing further breaches.

Officials dragged Harold Macmillan, the prime minister, into the affair after proposing a series of discreet meetings between C and the head of MI5, Sir Roger Hollis, with "responsible editors".

Sir Burke discussed what the media should be allowed to publish. "It is a matter not so much of concealing as of withholding and what is withheld is not so much the truth as the facts."

The identity of C was not revealed until 1994, when the incumbent was Sir Colin McColl.

fields.headline: What the IRA said
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The full IRA statement:
fields.body:
The full IRA statement:

On November 17 the leadership of the IRA agreed to appoint a representative to enter into discussions with the IICD [Independent international commission on decommissioning].

This was on the basis that it would be part of a series of events including, and in particular, the establishment of the political institutions set out in the Good Friday agreement. This was designed to move the situation out of an 18-month impasse. This impasse was created and maintained by unionist intransigence and a failure by the British government to advance the implementation of the Good Friday agreement.

The British secretary of state has reintroduced the unionist veto by suspending the political institutions. This has changed the context in which we appointed a representative to meet with the IICD and has created a deeper crisis.

Both the British government and the leadership of the Ulster Unionist party have rejected the propositions put to the IICD by our representative. They obviously have no desire to deal with the issue of arms except on their own terms.

Those who seek a military victory in this way need to understand that this cannot and will not happen.

Those who have made the political process conditional on the decommissioning or silenced IRA guns are responsible for the current crisis in the peace process.

In the light of these changed circumstances the leadership of the IRA have decided to end our engagement with the IICD. We are also withdrawing all propositions put to the IICD by our representative since November.

fields.headline: UK roundup
fields.trailText: Drive-in movies for shoppers
fields.body:
Drive-in movies for shoppers

The Asda supermarket chain yesterday announced plans to screen drive-in movies at the car parks of its stores.

The American-style shows are to be launched in York next month, with plans to screen films at 25 stores in April and May and a further 25 by September.

Asda, recently bought out by American retail giant Wal-Mart, believes the idea will prove a huge hit with customers, with refreshments provided by an Asda "snack-shack".

An Asda spokeswoman said: "We will show family films, broadcast on a large screen.

"Customers can either listen to the movies on their car radios, or sit in the tiered seating area which will be assembled in each car park.

"The films will be shown in the early evening, so customers could either make a special journey to see a film, or combine it with a visit to do with the shopping."

Family may sue over blood error

The family of a woman who died when she was given the wrong type of blood during brain surgery threatened yesterday to take legal action against the hospital.

Hilary Pearce, 62, died minutes after being given a blood transfusion by operating theatre staff at Addenbrooke's hospital in Cambridge during surgery for a burst blood vessel in her brain last November.

She received half a litre of A positive blood, instead of O positive, which caused irreversible blood clotting. The grandmother from Wisbech, Cambridgeshire, died of a heart attack.

The hospital, which could face a huge payout to Mrs Pearce's family, will be investigated by the health and safety executive. Police are awaiting the outcome of an inquest before considering any criminal charges.

Three staff were suspended during a hospital inquiry, the results of which have been passed to the woman's husband and two children. Two of the staff have returned to work and the third has since returned to the Norfolk and Norwich hospital.

The inquiry revealed that an operating theatre orderly was sent to fetch blood, a duty for which he was not qualified, but picked up the wrong bag and handed it to a theatre assistant. Although normal hospital procedure requires the patient's identity tags to be checked, this was not done before the transfusion.

Mrs Pearce's husband, John, said: "We are taking legal advice from our solicitors and once the inquest is over we will go from there with legal proceedings. We are not interested in the money. We're hoping it will prevent anyone else undergoing this sort of mistake and other families suffering."

Keith Day, administrative director of Addenbrooke's NHS trust, said: "What happened was the result of a dreadful mistake. All the staff involved are very upset by the incident.

"We are not in the business of crucifying people who have been guilty of making a mistake."
Julia Hartley-Brewer

Germany tackled on beef ban

The European commission last night opened up a new front in Britain's beef wars, launching legal action against Germany just as similar action against France has barely begun.

"I must ensure that EU law is respected, particularly given the long delay in Germany's response to lifting the ban on British beef," said the consumer protection commissioner, David Byrne.

Commission officials said that though they were confident the German ban would eventually be lifted, they wanted to hasten a decision.

Infringement proceedings began with a formal letter to Berlin, a pre-emptive strike that it is hoped will produce a speedy decision.

The EU lifted a worldwide ban on British beef exports last August, but Germany and France had held out

Germany approved lifting its ban earlier this month after adopting stringent new EU rules for British beef. The upper house of parliament will now vote on March 17 on whether to endorse the move. The case against France, launched last year, now rests with the European court of justice in Luxembourg, the last stage in the legal procedure, though a final judgment is months away. Ian Black

MPs want corporate killing law

The government was under growing pressure last night to create a new offence of corporate killing after a court of appeal ruling confirmed that the law made it virtually impossible to bring large companies to book for mass disasters.

Three judges yesterday upheld a ruling by the high court last July that Great Western Trains, the company at the centre of the Southall train crash, could not be prosecuted for manslaughter because a conviction would be impossible.

The ruling came as MPs urged the government to reform the law. The parliamentary select committee on environment, transport and regional affairs said in a report yesterday: "We recommend that the government brings forward legislation to introduce a crime of corporate killing as soon as possible."
Clare Dyer

Quids in Lighthouse going for a pound

Unique lighthouse, cast iron, stunning setting on rocky outcrop off south Wales coast, approachable only for few hours every day - yours for £1.

But the new owners of Whitford Point, one mile off the north Gower coast near Llanelli, will be expected to undertake a £100,000 restoration programme on what is believed to be Britain's only cast iron offshore lighthouse.

The 130ft lighthouse was built in 1865 under the direction of Trinity House from a kit of cast iron sections to replace an earlier wooden structure that was destroyed in stormy seas. It ceased operating in 1926. A listed ancient monument, Whitford Point is owned by the Millennium Coastal Park which is carrying out a £27.5m regeneration project on a 22km stretch of industrialised coastal plain along the Burry estuary overlooking the Gower peninsula.

The project, funded by the millennium commission and Carmarthenshire county council, does not have the money needed to restore the lighthouse and is considering selling it for £1 to a charitable organisation that would carry out repairs.

The Gower Preservation Society is already said to have expressed an interest in acquiring the Victorian structure.

Gerry Phillips, coastal park project director, said the proposed sale was the only hope of saving the building and restoring it.

"The lighthouse is an impressive and unique landmark but it has suffered from a lot of erosion," said Naomi Snelling, a park spokeswoman. "It does need a bit of work but it has got great potential."

The lighthouse, which cost £1,133 to build, is approachable at low tide for only a few hours a day. Geoffrey Gibbs

"I must ensure that EU law is respected, particularly given the long delay in Germany's response to lifting the ban on British beef," said the consumer protection commissioner, David Byrne. Commission officials said that though they were confident the German ban would eventually be lifted, they wanted to hasten a decision. Infringement proceedings began with a formal letter to Berlin, a pre-emptive strike that it is hoped will produce a speedy decision. The EU lifted a worldwide ban on British beef exports last August, but Germany and France had held out Germany approved lifting its ban earlier this month after adopting stringent new EU rules for British beef. The upper house of parliament will now vote on March 17 on whether to endorse the move. The case against France, launched last year, now rests with the European court of justice in Luxembourg, the last stage in the legal procedure, though a final judgment is months away. Three judges yesterday upheld a ruling by the high court last July that Great Western Trains, the company at the centre of the Southall train crash, could not be prosecuted for manslaughter because a conviction would be impossible. The ruling came as MPs urged the government to reform the law. The parliamentary select committee on environment, transport and regional affairs said in a report yesterday: "We recommend that the government brings forward legislation to introduce a crime of corporate killing as soon as possible." But the new owners of Whitford Point, one mile off the north Gower coast near Llanelli, will be expected to undertake a £100,000 restoration programme on what is believed to be Britain's only cast iron offshore lighthouse. webTitle: The catch 22 that has snared Ulster

fields.headline: The catch 22 that has snared Ulster
fields.standfirst:
Mandelson surprised by republican backlash as peace process slides into worst crisis since terrorists restored ceasefire in 1997

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president, had predicted the IRA's likely approach if Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, suspended the assembly and its power-sharing executive. Eighteen days ago he said the IRA would break off all contact with John de Chastelain's international commission on decommissioning.
fields.body:
Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president, had predicted the IRA's likely approach if Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, suspended the assembly and its power-sharing executive. Eighteen days ago he said the IRA would break off all contact with John de Chastelain's international commission on decommissioning.

But last night's IRA announcement still sent the fragile peace process into the most serious crisis since the terror group restored its ceasefire in July 1997. Now the Good Friday agreement is locked in a catch-22 situation.

Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble is refusing to return to government with Sinn Fein until the IRA says when and how it will decommission its arsenal. The IRA will only consider decommissioning if the executive is in place.

It is withdrawing all propositions made to General de Chastelain since November. As well as Friday's initiative, it has conceded the arms issue has to be dealt with satisfactorily.

Its move five days ago prompted General de Chastelain to issue an upbeat assessment, 90 minutes after Mr Mandelson had signed the papers restoring direct rule. He said commitments from the IRA held out the real prospect of agreement on decommissioning.

Mr Mandelson claims he only learned of the substance of the fresh initiative after suspending the institutions, while Sinn Fein claims he knew of it for up to 12 hours before.

Sinn Fein believes Mr Mandelson was too set on suspension ahead of last Saturday's reconvened meeting of the Ulster Unionist council. Mr Trimble had promised to quit as first minister if the IRA had failed by then to begin decommissioning.

The IRA's announcement last night came less than two hours before Mr Trimble was to meet General de Chastelain to elicit details left out of his report.

A senior unionist said: "We were about to try and find out what was behind the latest decommissioning report, and the IRA pulls it off the table. That hardly seems to be the best way of convincing us it is serious about settling this issue." Mr Mandelson appears to have underestimated the backlash from republicans at his decision. He is also likely to have been surprised by the united anger of the SDLP and the Dublin government.

He argues that he had no option, that Mr Trimble's resignation would effectively have killed the agreement.

The IRA's move may yet prove to be a tactical withdrawal. It also gives Sinn Fein an important bargaining chip for the forthcoming review.

But there are dangerous splits within republicanism over decommissioning now. That appears to be one of the reasons why Brian Keenan, the IRA interlocutor, insisted General de Chastelain published on Friday only the barest outline of the IRA initiative.

Sir Ronnie Flanagan, RUC chief constable, blamed dissident republicans in Lurgan for a series of hi-jacking and bomb hoaxes this week.

Since Sinn Fein issued a tough statement opposing punishment beatings at the conclusion of ex-US senator George Mitchell's review of the agreement in November, there are no reports of the IRA committing any such attacks. Sir Ronnie also believes the elevation of decommissioning is wrong. He thinks it is more important to have a united IRA, rather than struggle with hardline splinter groups.

The IRA spoke on Friday of putting arms beyond use. It is a phrase which suggests the terror group would consider only a "dump arms" order to its volunteers, as when it ended other campaigns.

If it came with a timetable and evidence that punishment beatings had ended, the pressure would swing heavily onto Mr Trimble to shift. But one pundit said last night: "We have gone back 18 months."

fields.headline: Pope's new man at Westminster
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Vatican yesterday named the Rt Rev Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, veteran bishop of Arundel and Brighton, to lead the 4.1m Catholics in England and Wales as Archbishop of Westminster in succession to Cardinal Basil Hume who died last year.
fields.body:
The Vatican yesterday named the Rt Rev Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, veteran bishop of Arundel and Brighton, to lead the 4.1m Catholics in England and Wales as Archbishop of Westminster in succession to Cardinal Basil Hume who died last year.

The bishop, who at 67 had thought his time for promotion had gone, will be seen as a stop-gap appointment, since he will have to tender his resignation on reaching the age of 75. Cardinal Hume, appointed in his early 50s, was archbishop for 23 years until his death last June.

In a second appointment yesterday, the Vatican appointed the Most Rev Vincent Nichols, regarded as the most up and coming figure in the church in England, as Archbishop of Birmingham.

Bishop Murphy-O'Connor, a former rugby player popular with clergy and parishioners throughout his 22-year tenure at Brighton - described by the Catholic weekly The Tablet recently as "everyone's favourite bishop, human, genial, collaborative, imposing" - yesterday attempted to deflect attempts to label him as liberal or conservative.

He told journalists at Archbishop's House: "If by a liberal you mean someone who is open to all new things that come along then I am not. I am a Catholic bishop who respects the traditions of the church. If by a conservative you mean someone who is a rigid fundamentalist then I am not that either. I am a man of the church."

The archbishop-elect has long experience working in the ecumenical movement and is a friend of the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey. He promised to work closely with other churches.

He distanced himself from his Scottish colleague Cardinal Winning, who has led a vigorous crusade against the repeal of section 28 - the "promotion of homosexuality" clause in local government legislation - by indicating he would not be campaigning against abolition.

Bishop Murphy-O'Connor said: "I am not sure I want to say whether I am for or against clause 28 ... if it does go I would be asking the government to ensure they kept the promise they made to teach the primacy of family life."

His appointment was welcomed by Dr Carey and other church leaders. Dr Carey said: "I look forward greatly to deepening our friendship and cooperation in future."

webTitle: Glue-sniffer who murdered priest gets life

fields.headline: Glue-sniffer who murdered priest gets life
fields.trailText: A homeless solvent abuser was yesterday jailed for life at Stafford crown court after pleading guilty to the murder of a Catholic priest who befriended him and offered him shelter.
fields.body:
A homeless solvent abuser was yesterday jailed for life at Stafford crown court after pleading guilty to the murder of a Catholic priest who befriended him and offered him shelter.

Father Paul Orchard, 80, was stabbed to death on the steps of the presbytery of the Church of Our Lady and St Hubert in Brandhall, near Birmingham, by Mark Massey, 33, who had a history of violent crime related to his use of solvents, which began when he was 14.

Massey had sniffed glue on the day he stabbed Fr Orchard in September, 1998. In mitigation, Michael Birnbaum QC, said that at the time Massey had been suffering "psychotic delusions, thinking he was the devil".

"All he remembers of the offence was a flash of lightning and a pool of blood. One can only speculate what was in his mind but it must have been irrational."

Fr Orchard, a former Benedictine monk, operated an open-door policy at the church and was known for his work with the homeless. He first came into contact with Massey in 1995, and over three years provided him with help and support.

Mr Birnbaum said it was a tragic irony that Massey had killed the person who "perhaps, above all others, had on many occasions helped him and given him food and shelter".

On the day of the murder Massey was found sheltering in the church by a group of women preparing for the the harvest festival. The women called Fr Orchard, who reassured them that Massey did not present a danger as he had not been drinking.

Fr Orchard took him into his study, and after making him sandwiches and tea rang two Catholic shelters for the homeless, both of which were full. Sometime later, after sniffing glue in the toilet and telephoning his grandmother from the presbytery, Massey stabbed Fr Orchard repeatedly in the neck and heart. The body was found the following morning by parishioners.

After killing Fr Orchard Massey went to hospital to have a cut on his hand treated, and told a policeman: "I think I have done a terrible thing. I am a glue sniffer and I have killed a priest. I keep having flashbacks."

Mr Birnbaum said: "There is no rational motive. It happened, in a nutshell, because of the glue addiction. Massey started glue sniffing when he was 14. Most people get over this after adolescence but he continued to sniff glue into his adult life as an escape from his problems."

Mr Justice Kay said: "Leslie Paul Orchard was by all accounts a thoroughly good man who devoted his life to the service of others.

"He spent many years as a Roman Catholic priest. At 80 he didn't seek the retirement he should have had but went on with his life's work. One of those he sought to look after was you," he told Massey.

"He must have known there was an element of danger in this. But he shirked this. You rewarded him for several years of assisting and helping you by taking his life in a brutal and savage fashion."

A spokesman for the Roman Catholic archdiocese of Birmingham said: "Fr Orchard was a much loved pastor to the people of St Hubert's. In a spirit of Christian hospitality he made himself available to anyone and everyone who called at his door.

"It is a sad reflection of inner city life that such generosity was the occasion of his violent death."

webTitle: Scouts criticised for 'cavalier' attitude to safety

fields.headline: Scouts criticised for 'cavalier' attitude to safety
fields.trailText: Scout leaders have an old-fashioned "cavalier attitude" towards adventure and risk that is unacceptable to modern society, according to an internal inquiry into a series of fatal mountain accidents last year.
fields.body:
Scout leaders have an old-fashioned "cavalier attitude" towards adventure and risk that is unacceptable to modern society, according to an internal inquiry into a series of fatal mountain accidents last year.

The Scout Association has ordered tough new procedures to improve safety for the estimated 500,000 scouts in the UK, after its investigation concluded that it needed a shake-up in its approach to adventurous activities.

The inquiry team, which included Ian Peter, chief executive of the National Mountain Centre at Plas y Brenin in Snowdonia, found a "a cavalier attitude to rules by leaders and others within the movement". It said scout leaders were steeped in a "1960s-1970s attitude to adventure and risk that is not acceptable to society in 2000".

A letter sent this week to scout leaders all over Britain outlines the new rules and makes clear that those who fail to follow them will not be supported by the association. John Bezan, chairman of the committee, told leaders: "If we do not take immediate action to change the attitude and culture of some of our leaders, the committee of the council believes that we are in grave risk of an outside body imposing regulatory restrictions upon us".

Worries highlighted included a culture "geared to leader-wants rather than young persons' needs, and leaders who went out to climb the highest peak regardless of party ability." Expeditions were said to lack educational purpose and parties were too often poorly managed.

The inquiry was set up after three deaths on scout-led ex peditions in October last year. Last week an inquest in Wales heard how 35-year-old scout leader Chris Oliver from Devizes in Wiltshire died after falling 150ft from a steep gully on Cader Idris.

Accompanied by a 14-year-old scout, he had left a larger, well-organised party to attempt a "scramble" up the 3000ft mountain. The scout, Gareth Cole, was just feet away from the leader when he fell, and was stranded on the rock face for more than two hours before rescue teams were able to help him.

The coroner, Dewi Pritchard Jones, said the pair were "simply following their noses" when Mr Oliver fell, leaving the 14-year-old stranded on the rock face. Mr Oliver had no climbing qualifications and no equipment.

"I couldn't possibly imagine anyone with any relevant experience choosing to do that route," a local climbing instructor, Andy Hall, said. "I wouldn't go anywhere near it."

A total of 13 recommendations include strict new adult-scout ratios and changes to the rules on authorising expeditions.

Tomorrow a second inquest will examine the death of 10- year-old Jonathan Attwell who plunged 600ft to his death in October after becoming separated on the summit of Snowdon.

Scout leaders on that trip were criticised for choosing the east ridge route. "That is not a footpath", Snowdonia national park warden Sam Roberts told reporters, "it is a scramble."

Ian Peter welcomed the inquiry findings. "The challenge that the scouts face", he said, "is that it's not just about having rigorous and robust rules - it's in making people stick to them."

fields.headline: Court releases Pinochet medical report
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw last night handed over the medical report on General Augusto Pinochet to the four countries seeking to extradite the former Chilean dictator after the high court ruled in London that the home secretary had been wrong to keep it secret.
fields.body:
Jack Straw last night handed over the medical report on General Augusto Pinochet to the four countries seeking to extradite the former Chilean dictator after the high court ruled in London that the home secretary had been wrong to keep it secret.

Lord Justice Simon Brown said "fairness demanded" that the report should be disclosed under conditions of "strict confidentiality" to Belgium, Spain, France and Switzerland, which want to put Pinochet on trial, so they can assess if there is any medical evidence to challenge Mr Straw's conclusion that the former dictator is too ill to face torture charges.

Human rights campaigners welcomed the ruling as a significant step on the road to justice for the thousands who were murdered and tortured during the Pinochet regime.

The four countries have seven days to examine the detailed medical report and make any further representations before Mr Straw makes a final decision on whether Pinochet is sent back to Chile. Baltasar Garzon, the Spanish judge who initiated the extradition request to Britain, will be among those who will be able to decide whether the medical evidence justifies Mr Straw's provisional decision that Pinochet is unfit to stand trial and should be sent home.

With a deadline of 5pm next Tuesday for their comments it means it is possible, in theory, that Mr Straw could make his final decision next week. But last night nobody was prepared to rule out the possibility of further legal challenges.

The landmark ruling in favour of disclosure by Lord Justice Simon Brown, sitting with Mr Justice Latham and Mr Justice Dyson, was won by Belgium in an action backed by six human rights groups including Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch, the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture, Redress Trust, the Association of Relatives of the Disappeared and Justicia.

Lord Justice Brown said yesterday: "If ever there was a case in which the integrity of the international justice system needed to be demonstrated, a case calling for the highest standards of transparency and fairness, this is it." The judges said Pinochet's privacy would not be further compromised as the "gist of the report" was already in the public domain and his right to confidentiality had already been compromised by its disclosure to the chief medical officer of health and by the home secretary's statement that he was "minded" to send the former president home.

Lord Lamont, a Pinochet supporter, condemned the court ruling and added: "One would have thought they have got enough problems with their own legal system without interfering in ours."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Father on murder charge
fields.body:
Father on murder charge

A man appeared before Blackpool magistrates yesterday charged with the murder of his 10-week-old daughter. Sarah-Louise Doran was pronounced dead at Blackpool Victoria hospital on Monday.

Gary Harper, 26, of Blackpool, was remanded in custody until February 22.

Tumour risk from treated cells

Cells left after treatment to remove non-threatening growths in the breast may cause cancer tumours to erupt years later, researchers said yesterday.

Scientists found a strong genetic link between the early stage abnormalities, called ductal carcinoma in situ, and tumours breaking out after between 16 months and nine years.

The finding provides evidence that second tumours are caused by residual cells not removed by surgery or radiotherapy, and are not new, separate lesions.

Lottery cash to wildlife schemes

Grassland, wetland and woods in England and Wales are to benefit from grants of £1.7m from the heritage lottery fund. The move announced yesterday adds to £255.7m already awarded to more than 670 nature, conservation and countryside projects.

Woman jailed for killing thief

A woman was jailed yesterday for the murder of a 16-year-old boy who had snatched a gold chain from her lover's neck. Luisa Bolivar, 37, from Belgravia, cen tral London, hired Hernando Guevara-Jaramillo, 22, from Clapham, and Hector Cedeno, 28, from Stockwell, both south London, to kill Jorge Castillo.

All three were jailed for life at the Old Bailey.

Police yesterday reopened an investigation into the murder of an elderly couple who died after being blasted with a 12-bore shotgun.

Harry Tooze, 64, and his wife ,Megan, 67, were killed at their farmhouse in Llanharry, South Wales, in 1993.

Jonathan Jones, the boyfriend of their daughter Cheryl was jailed for life in 1995 for the murders.

But the 39-year-old was released by the court of appeal in 1996 after Cheryl launched a campaign protesting his innocence. South Wales police yesterday set up a new investigation into the murders as part of a review into unsolved killings in the force's area.

webTitle: British climbers die in Russian avalanche

fields.headline: British climbers die in Russian avalanche
fields.standfirst: Attempts resume today to recover bodies of mountaineers who were warned of peril on plateau, but were too exhausted to reach safety
fields.trailText: Three Britons were among seven climbers killed in an avalanche on a notoriously difficult Russian mountain, it emerged yesterday.
fields.byline: Sarah Hall  and  Amelia Gentleman  in Moscow
fields.body:
Three Britons were among seven climbers killed in an avalanche on a notoriously difficult Russian mountain, it emerged yesterday.

The three men - together with four Russians - were 700 metres from the peak of the 4,700 metre Ushba mountain in the Elbrus range, when an ice fall triggered the snowslide which killed all seven.

The tragedy - early last Thursday - occurred as they rested on a plateau which they had been warned was dangerous but from which they were too exhausted to move.

Last night, a team of 70 rescuers, assisted by helicopters, was forced to call off the search, due to worsening weather .

The threat of a second potentially lethal ice fall, together with heavy snow and strong wind, has already hampered the rescue operation - but the Russian emergency services hope to continue trying to recover the bodies today.

Until that time, the families of three Britons who are believed to be missing in the area will have to wait for confirmation of the deaths. The only clue to the Britons' identities came from a metal tag on a rucksack, which bore the name of a man from London. But the foreign office refused to confirm any names. It emerged that the climbers, who set off in fine conditions, had completed their first arduous day of the climb when they decided to stop on the plateau. A second group of climbers who had made it to the summit tried to deter them from doing so because of the risk of avalanches.

But, according to the second group, the three Britons - none of whom had registered with the emergency authorities as required - were too exhausted to scale one of two ice-covered peaks to safety.

During the night, the second group heard an avalanche. The following morning they saw the plateau had been covered with ice and began the descent to inform the rescue services, arriving back at their base on Friday morning.

The Russians were members of a climbing club in Pyatigorsk, southern Russia, and mountaineering experts suggested the Britons would also have been highly experienced.

The arduous route they had chosen - the most difficult by Russian standards - and their decision to climb in February instead of the summer, suggested they were experts. "We're talking about a serious mountain expedition. It's not straightforward like Everest. Even the easier routes on it are demanding - and it's certainly not something Britons would normally attempt in the winter," said the climber and editor of Alpine Journal, Ed Douglas.

"It's a world class mountain and it's not one that list-tickers on an ego trip would go for: it's too difficult," said John Temple, a mountaineer who nearly died as he scaled its southern peak four years ago.

"It's like two Matterhorns stuck back to back - but unlike the Matterhorn, where you can walk up to the face, you have to climb up even the easier approaches."

"It's long and high and there simply isn't an easy way up. People are regularly killed on it - and in winter, with the wind coming from Siberia and temperatures of minus 20, I would think it must be hell on earth."

But Russian mountaineers - notorious for their macho refusal to stop climbing throughout the winter - insisted that climbing in the Caucasus, in the Kabardino-Balkaria region of Russia on the Georgian border, held great appeal for experienced climbers. "In this part of the Caucasus you're unlikely to come across other climbers," said Gennady Starikov, of the Russian Federation of Mountain Climbers.

"When you set out in the morning there are no footprints but your own - no trace of anyone else; it's an incredible sensation." Gia Ksnelanshvili, of the geographic bureau in St Petersburg, who organises climbs in the region added: "The Caucasus doesn't have the infrastructure of the alps - there aren't the same comfortable hotels and lifts - but for genuine mountaineering enthusiasts this is precisely the attraction. People come here when they want to find out about real mountains."

webTitle: Peace crisis deepens after IRA pulls out

fields.headline: Peace crisis deepens after IRA pulls out
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The IRA last night threw the Northern Ireland peace process into dangerous turmoil after it withdrew its interlocutor to General John de Chastelain's decommissioning body following Peter Mandelson's decision to re-impose direct rule from London five days ago.
fields.body:
The IRA last night threw the Northern Ireland peace process into dangerous turmoil after it withdrew its interlocutor to General John de Chastelain's decommissioning body following Peter Mandelson's decision to re-impose direct rule from London five days ago.

In an uncompromising statement, the IRA said it was withdrawing all the commitments it had given to the independent international commission on decommissioning since appointing its linkman in November.

That included its late initiative on Friday which Gen de Chastelain believed had offered the prospect of a deal.

The IRA said it had agreed to put its go-between in place on the basis of the establishment of all the institutions set out in the Good Friday agreement.

The move by Mr Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, to put the assembly and power-sharing executive on ice after 72 days to avert the resignation of Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble as first minister had altered that.

The IRA said Mr Mandelson had "re-introduced the unionist veto by suspending the political institutions. This has changed the context in which we appointed a representative to meet with the IICD and has created a deeper crisis.

"The British government and the leadership of the Ulster Unionist party obviously have no desire to deal with the issue of arms except on their own terms. Those who seek a military victory in this way need to understand that it cannot happen."

It emerged that Gen de Chastelain had told Mr Mandelson and Brian Cowen, the Irish foreign affairs minister, of the IRA's planned move two days ago. It had been predicted, but still signalled the worst crisis since all-party talks began almost three years ago.

However, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, the RUC chief constable, believed there was no imminent threat to the IRA ceasefire announced in July 1997.

Mr Mandelson said: "I am disappointed at the IRA's decision. I believe this is a time when all channels need to be kept open. What was on the table had real potential and people will be sad that it could not be worked on."

His handling of the crisis has been criticised. The Irish government believes he should have forced Mr Trimble to postpone the critical meeting of the Ulster Unionist Council on Saturday pending clarification of the IRA's initiative on Friday.

Mr Trimble said: "It is very disappointing. This is an action which can only support those who view the so-called IRA offer as simply a publicity stunt, an attempt to divide the governments from each other or from ourselves. We gave them the opportunity by jumping first and now they appear to have thrown it back in our faces."

The SDLP deputy leader Seamus Mallon, the former Nor thern Ireland deputy first minister, savaged the announcement. He accused the IRA of toying with the agreement.

He said: "I was shocked when I heard, but not surprised. We must know whether the IRA is going to be part of the new future or whether it is going to thwart the will of the two governments, of the Irish people, and of world opinion."

Amid an increasing sense of panic in London and Dublin last night, the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, indicated that his party had no intention of taking part in a new review of the 22-month-old agreement. He said he had had "a very poor, a very bad meeting" with Mr Mandelson.

Mr Adams, who also met Mr Trimble, said: "As far as we are concerned, we have moved be yond our obligations. We have been morally and politically bound to do all of that and this Sinn Fein leadership has now no further room to move."

The British and Irish governments seem more divided than ever on a common approach. They are unable even to agree on a formal review.

Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister, will meet today in an attempt to a thrash out a strategy. Mr Blair will then hold talks with the UUP, the SDLP and Sinn Fein.
