webTitle: Blair keeps cabinet members' pay on the saintly side of £100,000

fields.headline: Blair keeps cabinet members' pay on the saintly side of £100,000
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair bounced his senior colleagues into another year of relative pay restraint last night when he accepted recommended increases of 2.9% on ministerial pay without allowing the issue to be debated in cabinet.
fields.body:
Tony Blair bounced his senior colleagues into another year of relative pay restraint last night when he accepted recommended increases of 2.9% on ministerial pay without allowing the issue to be debated in cabinet.

Rises of up to 3.3% go to senior judges and senior military officers, while ranks up to captain will get 3.8%. The awards from the senior salaries review body (SSRB) are above the 2.1% rate of inflation, but all the groups involved complain bitterly about falling behind the private sector where pay deals are running at 4.9%.

The increases will take the prime minister from £109,768 to £112,951 from April 1 and most of his cabinet colleagues from £94,157 to £96,887. But that still leaves them all at least £17,656 behind the formula agreed when the pay of MPs and ministers was tied to that of senior civil servants in 1996.

Ministers will now have to wait until after next year's election to get the full catch-up which Mr Blair and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, insisted on curbing to set a good example in wage restraint.

This postponement will have cost the cabinet a collective £1,080,000 by April 1, £48,282 each, Downing Street announced last night, as unions noted that 2.9% is still a fraction more than the extra 10p an hour just announced on the national minimum wage of £3.60 an hour. They promised to campaign for more.

Downing Street officials said that there had been no cabinet discussion of the pay issue and "no pressure" to do so. The prime minister, who is entitled to draw £158,658 under the 1996 formula, has forgone a total of £124,992, but colleagues point to his high-earning barrister wife.

John Prescott is reported to have said privately that Mr Blair had behaved "like Jesus Christ" over increases in ministerial pay.

Such resentments rankle, the more so since yesterday's salaries review saw William Hague's combined pay as an MP and opposition Conservative leader go from £105,957 to £109,030, a rise he took in full.

That puts him above every minister except Mr Blair, and the Lord Chancellor, Lord Irvine, a wealthy barrister who by law is paid £2,500 more than the Lord Chief Justice. He gets a £7,000 rise to £167,760.

The SSRB also awarded 2.9% to MPs: they get £48,371, similar to the sums for members of the devolved assemblies, and for 2,963 top civil servants who also get performance related awards.

Ministers of state pay will rise to £82,697 (from £80,367), while parliamentary under-secretaries, the lowest form of payroll life in the upper political echelons, will get £74,424 (up from £72,327).

Far more people, around 1.8m, will be affected by the government's decision to raise the national minimum wage in October - six months ahead of predictions. Women in low-paid work are most likely to benefit, ministers said. It did not stop unions, who met Mr Blair in private on Monday before the news was leaked, complaining that the system, introduced after long consultation last April, is already being used as "a political football".

They renewed earlier demands for annual increases, claims denied by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, who said: "The reason why we believe that up-rating annually is wrong is that this is not a benefit, it is a pay increase which will take place when the economic conditions allow."

fields.headline: Town grouse and country grouse
fields.standfirst:
How do you protect the countryside, build 1.1m new homes, revitalise cities and reverse the decline in the north? Answers to John Prescott

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott is gearing up for the most important decision he might have to make as secretary of state for environment, transport and the regions. Rarely has an issue covered almost every aspect of his unwieldy empire: country towns bursting at the seams, roads permanently clogged up and builders threatening to carpet more greenfields with concrete and brick.
fields.body:
John Prescott is gearing up for the most important decision he might have to make as secretary of state for environment, transport and the regions. Rarely has an issue covered almost every aspect of his unwieldy empire: country towns bursting at the seams, roads permanently clogged up and builders threatening to carpet more greenfields with concrete and brick.

While tackling the country's crumbling railway infrastructure might have been foremost in his mind until Lord Macdonald began shouldering much of the transport brief, the deputy prime minister knows development of the south-east - marginal middle-England, no less - could have far graver political consequences.

That's why No 10, and a key cabinet committee, has been mulling over housing projections and population forecasts for the ever-prospering region - England's wealthiest - as countryside campaigners and amenity groups flood local papers with protest letters, or take to the streets. The home counties, it seems, are in revolt - partly because the issue has been so misrepresented.

Prescott's dilemma is how to balance rising demand for new homes, often from key workers such as nurses and teachers - and, increasingly, single people - with protecting the countryside and, crucially, meeting a target of putting up to 60% of new homes on recycled, or "brownfield" land. The issue came to a head at a new style of planning inquiry in London last year. Two government inspectors "tested" proposals from a planning consortium of local councils, known as Serplan, for a maximum of 914,000 homes in the 12 counties outside London up to 2016. Even this number, the planners conceded, would probably require a string of new townships and certainly a big expansion of Milton Keynes, in Buckinghamshire, to contain further greenfield building. Any more would require "difficult environmental choices", warned Chris Williams, chairman of Serplan's strategy group.

Yet that's what the inspectors recommended to John Prescott last October: 1.1m homes, with new developments of 80,000-100,000 homes around Crawley in Sussex, Ashford in Kent, Stansted in Essex and Milton Keynes. Because they suggested building over a shorter timescale, the Council for the Protection of Rural England (CPRE) calculated this represented a 64% increase on Serplan's proposals, or 430,000 homes. It provoked a storm of protest, which has rarely subsided, and a string of lurid headlines - and cheap political gestures from the opposition - bearing little relation to reality.

Largely because of this uproar, the 1.1m figure became written in stone. It was portrayed as Prescott's plan, not as a recommendation which he could either accept, or reject. In fact, after intense discussions between Downing Street and his super-ministry, the deputy prime minister will steer a sensible, middle course, rejecting the old-fashioned, rigid "predict and provide" approach to house building over long time frames in favour of a more flexible system looking no more than five years ahead - with regular, five-yearly reviews afterwards. He will opt for a big expansion of the Thames Gateway area, from Greenwich east to Dartford and Medway - where there is considerable "brownfield" land - and earmark Ashford as a major growth point, conveniently sited for the Channel tunnel.

Nick Raynsford, his housing minister, has already signalled much tougher planning guidelines for local councils. Under these, developers will be subject to a series of rigorous, sequential tests. They will have to prove there is no brownfield land available in a particular area before being allowed to eye greenfield sites. Crucially, they will also have to radically improve the design and standards of new houses - generally regarded by the minister as "tacky little boxes" - and cram many more on to building sites. Raynsford says far too much land is wasted, further extending the urban sprawl.

But Prescott has another problem, often conveniently forgotten by the countryside lobby. While tens of thousands annually leave the sluggish north for work in the booming south-east, much of the housing demand is generated from within the region. Consequently, over the next 25 years, around 850,000 additional households are expected - and not all of them will be in a position to buy. This raises a further dilemma: the desperate shortage of lower cost, rented accommodation for people on average incomes, including young professionals. With house prices already five times average earnings in the region, even senior Tory councillors privately recognise that many more "social" homes will be needed - perhaps 40% of planned provision - to cope with demand.

As he prepares for a final decision, the deputy prime minister is also facing criticism from another quarter - the old planning lobby, which strongly backs the case for 1.1m new homes. It accuses Prescott of bowing to pressure from the countryside campaigners. David Lock, vice chairman of the Town and Country Planning Association, accuses them of a "campaign of deliberate misrepresentation and personal vilification [against Prescott's planning inspectors], which unleashed the bigotry of ignorant bullies..." He fears that Prescott will be forced into a policy of "town cramming" because of impossibly high brownfield targets.

At the other extreme, Prescott has to try to satisfy the architect Lord Rogers of Riverside, whose (government appointed) urban task force last year called for tough measures - a tax on greenfield building and tax brakes for urban development - to curb the rural drift and help the repopulation of cities.

The normally mild-mannered architect, a friend of Mr Prescott, is becoming frustrated. This week he wrote that the government's reaction to his report had been "disappointingly negative". Unless England faced reality and placed more emphasis on reviving conurbations, he warned that the south-east would become even more congested, while northern cities would continue to suffer migration "and the blight of decline".

Yet that's what the inspectors recommended to John Prescott last October: 1.1m homes, with new developments of 80,000-100,000 homes around Crawley in Sussex, Ashford in Kent, Stansted in Essex and Milton Keynes. Because they suggested building over a shorter timescale, the Council for the Protection of Rural England (CPRE) calculated this represented a 64% increase on Serplan's proposals, or 430,000 homes. It provoked a storm of protest, which has rarely subsided, and a string of lurid headlines - and cheap political gestures from the opposition - bearing little relation to reality. Largely because of this uproar, the 1.1m figure became written in stone. It was portrayed as Prescott's plan, not as a recommendation which he could either accept, or reject. In fact, after intense discussions between Downing Street and his super-ministry, the deputy prime minister will steer a sensible, middle course, rejecting the old-fashioned, rigid "predict and provide" approach to house building over long time frames in favour of a more flexible system looking no more than five years ahead - with regular, five-yearly reviews afterwards. He will opt for a big expansion of the Thames Gateway area, from Greenwich east to Dartford and Medway - where there is considerable "brownfield" land - and earmark Ashford as a major growth point, conveniently sited for the Channel tunnel. Nick Raynsford, his housing minister, has already signalled much tougher planning guidelines for local councils. Under these, developers will be subject to a series of rigorous, sequential tests. They will have to prove there is no brownfield land available in a particular area before being allowed to eye greenfield sites. Crucially, they will also have to radically improve the design and standards of new houses - generally regarded by the minister as "tacky little boxes" - and cram many more on to building sites. Raynsford says far too much land is wasted, further extending the urban sprawl. But Prescott has another problem, often conveniently forgotten by the countryside lobby. While tens of thousands annually leave the sluggish north for work in the booming south-east, much of the housing demand is generated from within the region. Consequently, over the next 25 years, around 850,000 additional households are expected - and not all of them will be in a position to buy. This raises a further dilemma: the desperate shortage of lower cost, rented accommodation for people on average incomes, including young professionals. With house prices already five times average earnings in the region, even senior Tory councillors privately recognise that many more "social" homes will be needed - perhaps 40% of planned provision - to cope with demand. As he prepares for a final decision, the deputy prime minister is also facing criticism from another quarter - the old planning lobby, which strongly backs the case for 1.1m new homes. It accuses Prescott of bowing to pressure from the countryside campaigners. David Lock, vice chairman of the Town and Country Planning Association, accuses them of a "campaign of deliberate misrepresentation and personal vilification [against Prescott's planning inspectors], which unleashed the bigotry of ignorant bullies..." He fears that Prescott will be forced into a policy of "town cramming" because of impossibly high brownfield targets. At the other extreme, Prescott has to try to satisfy the architect Lord Rogers of Riverside, whose (government appointed) urban task force last year called for tough measures - a tax on greenfield building and tax brakes for urban development - to curb the rural drift and help the repopulation of cities. The normally mild-mannered architect, a friend of Mr Prescott, is becoming frustrated. This week he wrote that the government's reaction to his report had been "disappointingly negative". Unless England faced reality and placed more emphasis on reviving conurbations, he warned that the south-east would become even more congested, while northern cities would continue to suffer migration "and the blight of decline".

webTitle: Hague's anti-euro leaflet echoes warning from the far right warning

fields.headline: Hague's anti-euro leaflet echoes warning from the far right warning
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague was accused yesterday of "making common cause" with rightwing extremists when it emerged that a new Tory anti-European leaflet mirrors publicity produced by the National Democrats - the successors to the National Front.
fields.body:
William Hague was accused yesterday of "making common cause" with rightwing extremists when it emerged that a new Tory anti-European leaflet mirrors publicity produced by the National Democrats - the successors to the National Front.

The Tories' leaflet, launched by Mr Hague yesterday at the start of his anti-euro campaign, outlines "five reasons to keep the pound". These bear a striking similarity to the "five reasons why Britain should not adopt the euro" outlined in the far right leaflet. There is no suggestion that Tory central office is working in tandem with the National Democrats, which became the successor party to the National Front in 1995.

However, Mr Hague's opponents last night seized on the similarities between the two leaflets to accuse the Tory leader of allowing himself to be linked with "extremist fellow travellers".

John Edmonds, leader of the GMB union, which unearthed the National Democrats' leaflet, said: "It is incredible that the official opposition is making common cause with such an extreme group. Instead of cavorting around on the back of a lorry William Hague should be back in central office rooting out the extremists who are linking the Conservative party to this group."

The two leaflets outline in similar terms the dangers posed by the euro. The Tories warn of a "great danger" that the euro will lead to Europe-wide tax rates, while the New Democrats warn that "Britain's taxation levels will be set by Brussels". Both warn of the huge costs that will be incurred by businesses in preparing for the euro.

The two parties also warn of the threat to Britain's independence. "If we keep the pound, Britain can keep its independence," the Tories say. The National Democrats warn that joining the euro would take away the "democratic freedom of the British people to determine their own future". Tories last night reacted angrily to suggestions that they were acting in league with the National Democrats.

A party spokesman said: "It is complete idiocy to say that we would make common cause with a party whose name I do not even recognise. This is a cheap slur by people who should know better."

Mr Hague made clear at the launch of his Keep the Pound campaign yesterday that he has all but embraced the "never" camp which believes that Britain should remain outside the euro whatever the circumstances.

"A single currency and a single interest rate could mean economic disaster for our country," the Tory leader said, underlining the hardening of his position which still officially holds out the prospect of joining EMU in the parliament after next.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Frontiers | The Promised Land
fields.body:
Peter Evans opens the new season of Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4) by delving into the strange world of autistic savants. Professor Allan Snyder, an Australian expert, believes that the savants' extraordinary musical, artistic, or mathematical ability exists in all of us, if only we knew how to tap it. Brain researchers have found that when they are given an appropriate challenge savants undergo a surge of rapid brain activity, enabling them to absorb and replicate far more detailed information than the rest of us.

Andy Kershaw thinks the famous Route 66 is a thoroughly tedious way of crossing America. So he is retracing the route outlined by Chuck Berry in his 1963 hit The Promised Land (10.0pm, Radio 2). Berry never made the journey himself, being in gaol when he wrote the song. Kershaw begins his trek from Norfolk, Virginia, so impenetrably segregated in the 1960s that black shoppers were not even allowed to try on a jacket.

fields.headline: Men behaving madly
fields.trailText: When a TV show attains classic status as quickly as Queer As Folk, it's easy to forget all the things that made it so remarkable in the first place. Any suspicion that this two-part coda might be a disappointment were quickly dispelled last night, however.
fields.body:
When a TV show attains classic status as quickly as Queer As Folk, it's easy to forget all the things that made it so remarkable in the first place. Any suspicion that this two-part coda might be a disappointment were quickly dispelled last night, however, when Queer As Folk 2 (C4) kicked off with an abortive threesome in Stuart's Canal Street shag-palace before introducing audiences to the steamy delights of Nero's Sauna, where Stuart was at the centre of a knotty mass of pale Mancunians.

The joy of Queer As Folk lies in the gleeful energy that propels its characters from one disaster to another, heedless of whether they come across as good role models, pausing occasionally to survey the emotional devastation before plunging onwards. Viewed from a distance, Stuart, Vince, Nathan and co are a pretty feckless bunch, hopelessly caught up in the claustrophobic world of the Village - but that's not the point. Embarking with them on another evening out is the closest that TV drama has ever come to the real nightlife experience, the mixture of euphoria and anxiety: weird things are said and done, opportunities missed, mistakes made, and then you go and do it all over again.

Queer As Folk 2 was light on plot: Vince still loves Stuart, but can't have sex with him, Nathan's back from London and playing the field, camp Adrian's father is dying. It was, however, rich in detail and dialogue, much of which whizzed by and was lost in the hubbub. Stuart went on the prowl at a family wedding ("Please don't shag the bridegroom", begged Vince), while Adrian, in Buffalo trainers and a nasty suit, danced to Steps records with all the lit tle nieces. Vince's mum Hazel (Denise Black) stole every scene she was in, handing out sage advice to fellow mothers over tea and cigarettes ("Try not to think about the arse thing and you'll be fine").

Russell T Davies, the Jacqueline Susann of gay Manchester, is clearly having a ball, transforming a world that he knows intimately into torrid popular drama. But beneath the fun and games, a purpose lurks. Davies's main concern in Queer As Folk 2 is the relationship between generations, between adults and children - a timely concern, with Section 28 unbelievably back on the agenda. No pussyfooting for Davies: in a scene guaranteed to cause nightmares in the shires, Stuart's nephew surfed into uncle's favourite porn website ("I like Big Cock City") then attempted a bit of blackmail before getting his head flushed down the toilet. "I'll tell them you touched me!" he screamed, prompting Stuart to come out to his parents in a speech so ridiculous that it actually rang true. "I lift those shirts!" he announced. "I'm an uphill gardener! I dine at the downstairs restaurant!" Nephew retired to play in the garden, defeated.

Underage sexuality has always been Queer As Folk's trump card, and Davies went in with all guns blazing. The blackmailing nephew was ten - only five years younger than Stuart's erstwhile trick, Nathan. Hazel announced that she'd conceived Vince at the age of 15. It's extraordinary that so much fuss has been made about a Jill Dando joke in an early scene; there's much more contentious stuff on offer here, if you care to look for it.

Channel 5 provided an appropriate epilogue in Black, Bent And Beautiful, a straightforward account of homophobia in the black community. Josie is a post-op male-to-female transsexual, now living with a woman, who faces constant abuse at home in Hackney. Chris is a gorgeous, savvy drag queen who left Jamaica in fear for his life. Shola is a Nigerian rap artist, whose family wanted to take her to the village herbalist to cast out "the evil spirit of lesbianism". The coming out stories of all these characters were familiar - teenage sexual awareness, living in the closet, problems with family - but the stakes were high. Chris recounted the routine beatings he endured in Jamaica, and revealed how fellow "battymen" were doused with petrol and burned to death. Shola faced daily abuse from her brothers; Josie became so disillusioned with her black peers that she now socialises almost exclusively with whites.

Black, Bent And Beautiful painted a bleak picture of ostracism and loss of identity. All of its subjects have found relative peace and safety in London, but remain wary. "My shoes are by Fredericks of Hollywood", said Chris, embarking from his Hackney flat for a night out as "Celeste D'Or". "They weren't only made for walking. They're fierce weapons. And I'll use them."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Cold Comfort Farm | Steve Rose | Kiss The Girls | The White Balloon
fields.body:
Cold Comfort Farm

(John Schlesinger, 1995)

6pm Sky Cinema

Originally made for British TV, Malcolm Bradbury's adaptation of Stella Gibbons' satirical novel found a warm reception in the US, partly because it panders to romanticised notions of 30s country life and English eccentricity, but also because it's performed with vigour by a quality cast (Ian McKellen, Stephen Fry, Rufus Sewell, Joanna Lumley). Kate Beckinsale is the orphaned daughter, sent to live with her strange farming relatives in their bucolic cloud of gloom.

Steve Rose

New York, New York

(Martin Scorsese, 1977)

10pm, FilmFour

Scorsese goes on the town with a fine updating of MGM musical myths. So instead of debonair Gene Kelly you get Robert De Niro's charming, angsty saxophonist in harrowing love with singer Liza Minnelli (adding resonances of her Star Is Born mum Judy Garland). It looks and sounds great, with jazzy George Auld dubbing for De Niro.

Kiss The Girls

(Gary Fleder, 1997)

10pm, Sky Premier

Strong echoes of Seven in this adaptation of a James Patterson novel: heavy atmosphere, a killer on the loose and Morgan Freeman the forensic scientist fearing the worst. Assisting Freeman is Ashley Judd as a kickboxing doctor who becomes one of the captives of the pervert called Casanova; and although the film finally settles for routine fight 'n' flight action, it's a deviously nasty thriller.

The White Balloon

(Jafa Panahi, 1995)

4.30am, FilmFour

A journey of discovery for seven-year-old Razieh (Aida Mohammadkani), venturing for the first time alone on to the streets of Tehran. She's hoping to buy a goldfish, but losing her mum's money makes this a difficult task and time is running out: the shop will close for a religious holiday in 90 minutes. Told in real time, there is more suspense here than in many a thriller, while an exotic and dangerous world unfolds, seen through the eyes of the child.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What undertakers are watching
fields.trailText: What undertakers are watching
fields.body:
Cyril Chesterton: "I'm a big fan of the old comedies, myself. I'm enjoying the repeats of Rising Damp enormously, takes me back years, they do. Open All Hours is on as well, love that. Porridge has just seen a run, hasn't it? You can call me a has-been, but old ones are definitely the best. I'm not the greatest fan of the shows where they just seem to shout at each other. I watched one the other day - well, I switched it off - heheheh. What was it? Two flatmates, one's gay? Yeah, Gimme Gimme Gimme. I thought it was a right mess."

David Chesterton: "Holby City just keeps me gripped, I love it, I really do, but I wouldn't say it was realistic. Very sanitised version of a hospital - we should know, you don't always see a beautiful corpse coming through the doors to be cleaned up and laid to rest. ER is a bit more gritty, but it's playground stuff. All the doctors and nurses falling in love with each other, it's for schoolgirls, isn't it? That's what most television is. In the real world you don't have time to fall in love with everyone you meet or you just wouldn't get the job done."

Matthew Formley: "I don't allow the television on for longer than a couple of hours per evening in my house. I work long hours and the last thing I want to come back to is doom and gloom on the box. EastEnders, it's all car crashes and abortions. What do I do? I get a book and read, bit of British history, bit of world history, or I go down the pub. That's where you get real television. The stories, the people."

Josh Formley: "I've been away for a while, not been back in England till a fortnight ago, and getting used to the place is quite something! Where was I? All over. Sort of a holiday. Since coming back, I happened to switch on the TV some weeknight and I saw an episode of "the gardening programme" Ground Force, yes. The woman, Charlie Dimmick, is a dead ringer for a lady I met in the Canaries, gorgeous lady. So now I'm going to have to watch it all the time."

Sian Pattenden spoke to undertakers from Shepperton

webTitle: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: No jokes about being born to rock, thank you very much, as recently departed Smashing Pumpkins bassist D'Arcy Wretzky was dispatched to a drugs education programme this week having been found guilty of crack possession.
fields.body:
No jokes about being born to rock, thank you very much, as recently departed Smashing Pumpkins bassist D'Arcy Wretzky was dispatched to a drugs education programme this week having been found guilty of crack possession. Wretzky - who quit the stentorian prog-rockers last year in search of a career in Hollywood - originally found herself on the wrong side of the law back in January, when she was pulled over in Chicago's West Town district after executing two illegal U-turns in the middle of the road at 3 o'clock in the morning. Predictably inquisitive officers then found three rocks of the cheap'n'nasty stuff on the ex-Pumpkin's companion, one Tony Young, a discovery which prompted Wretzky to confess that the "gear" was, in fact, hers. And, as day follows night, she wound up in Cook County Criminal Court on Monday, to be ordered onto a non-custodial rehab programme until April; the successful completion of same will erase her nascent criminal record (the lucky thing).

Meanwhile, talk show maven Oprah Winfrey is celebrating last week's affirmation of her not-guilty verdict over charges she slandered the US beef industry during a 1996 show on the perils of meat-eating. After outraged claims from the cattlemen of America that Winfrey's histrionic approach to mad cow disease precipitated the late 90s "beef crash" (honestly, that's what it was called), the big O was subsequently let off the hook two years later; or at least she was until her bovine-fixated nemeses filed an appeal at the New Orleans 5th Circuit Court. Yet Oprah, as usual, proved triumphant: while describing her as "melodramatic", the new judgment also restated her innocence of defamation. The fat lady hasn't quite let rip, however; the cow-mongers are now reported to be mulling over another appeal, this time to the US Supreme Court. Yee-hah!

fields.standfirst: Rock bands may be famed for their lax attitude to authority but only one has ever helped overthrow a government.  Richard Vine uncovers the bizarre story of the Czechoslovakian group, Plastic People Of The Universe
fields.trailText: Rock bands may be famed for their lax attitude to authority but only one has ever helped overthrow a government. Richard Vine uncovers the bizarre story of the Czechoslovakian group, Plastic People Of The Universe.
fields.body:
Frankie Goes To Hollywood were banned by the BBC. The Sex Pistols shocked the tabloids on a weekly basis. John Lennon made it onto the FBI's subversive list. But few bands rarely manage to smash more than their hotel rooms.

But, as tomorrow's radio programme Document - Happy Hearts Club Banned (8pm, Radio 4) reveals, there was a band who actually did have a hand in smashing the system: Czechoslovakia's Plastic People Of The Universe.

Hounded by the secret police, jailed, their albums were bootlegged overseas through a network of Czech dissidents living abroad, and then deemed illegal to own once they made their way back into the country. Their gigs were infrequent, organised by word of mouth, with the location secret until the last possible moment. And then, they were often surrounded by the police and beaten up. Even the audience were arrested and interrogated from time to time.

A caustic slagging off from a disgruntled hack in the NME is probably the worst most bands have to worry about when they release a new album. The Plastic People received such resounding endorsements from the Czech Ministry of Culture as, "The lyrics of the Plastic People include rude expressions and nonsense whose artistic and formal value is absolutely insignificant. The words expose anarchy, decadence, clericalism, nihilism and cause negative influence on the lifestyle of our young generation."

They were formed after the brief explosion of pop culture that came in the 1968 Prague Spring with Alexander Dubcek's liberalisation of communism. Mirroring their Western long-haired contemporaries, for a while the much abused peace, love and freedom ethos of the hippy culture actually meant something more than annoying people with short hair. Once the Soviet cold war machine got wind of what was going on, of course, the tanks rolled in, trampling flower power before it had a chance to blossom.

Fed on a diet of The Velvet Underground, The Fugs, Captain Beefheart and Frank Zappa's Mothers Of Invention (from whose song Plastic People they took their name) they blended the sound of late 60s underground rock with the traditions of Czech jazz and folk, coming up with a sound that would have happily freaked-out the freaks at Max's Kansas City, let alone the paranoid cultural dictatorship of the Warsaw Pact.

They struggled on after their official licence (which gave them access to fairly crucial elements of being in a band, like instruments and amps) was revoked in 1970, playing with home-made equipment at weddings, private parties and at cultural events organised by their manager Ivan Jirous, who, as a member of the Union Of Artists, had access to convention halls. There he would organise lectures on Andy Warhol, talk for a few minutes, and then get the Plastic People to "demonstrate" the songs of Warhol's cohorts, The Velvet Underground, for an hour or two.

The authorities soon worked out what was going on, and stamped out this loophole. A later festival, in 1976, produced the most dramatic response of the authorities, when they arrested 27 musicians, confiscated equipment and recordings, and expelled the group's Canadian singer Paul Wilson. All but four were later released, following an international outcry, but Ivan Jirous and Vratislav Brabenec, the band's saxophonist, stood trial, alongside two members of another band, DG 307.

It was this trial that drew the attention of the intellectual dissident movement that was to crystalise around the playwright, Vaclav Havel, who was inspired by the treatment of these rock musicians to form Charter 77, which led to the later , successful Velvet Revolution. Havel later befriended the band, allowing them to write and record in his house. After Jirous and Brabenec were released, the band continued to play a leading role in the Czech music scene, and Havel went on to become probably the only state leader ever to consult Frank Zappa on his country's development.

It's easy to romanticise the power of rock music, to delve into the murky territory of worshipping its excessive and transformative power, venerating the teenage kicks and that elusive, defining moment when a generation declares independence from the last; to want to believe that an album or a great single can be released and can actually change things. But maybe, once in while it can happen. As Paul Wilson says, "The kind of music the Plastic People wrote was very different from the prevailing music around it, and one of the songs from the Fugs that we used to sing made a reference to that. The words were, I guess from Plato, 'When the mode of the music changes, the walls of the city shake.' There's a great satisfaction in knowing that in some small way, the music of the Plastic People really did shake the walls and the walls eventually did come down."

Rock and politicians probably shouldn't mix, as Tony Blair and Oasis have shown, and writing political songs is a tricky act to pull off without sounding like Chumbawumba. But as tomorrow's documentary proves, there is a time and a place for everything. In Communist Czechoslovakia, the mere act of writing songs that weren't sanctioned by the state was enough to kick start the beginning of the end.

webTitle: MPs urge more staff to tackle smuggling surge

fields.headline: MPs urge more staff to tackle smuggling surge
fields.trailText: MPs yesterday demanded a substantial rise in the number of customs staff to fight a "rapidly worsening" increase in alcohol and tobacco smuggling.
fields.body:
MPs yesterday demanded a substantial rise in the number of customs staff to fight a "rapidly worsening" increase in alcohol and tobacco smuggling.

A report by the all-party Commons treasury committee warned that legitimate businesses were going bust because violent criminals were moving into the trade.

The report said that in Britain more than £1.2bn worth of tax revenue was lost through tobacco and alcohol smuggling last year via the Channel ports alone.

The committee warned that government revenues were being "significantly undermined" by smuggling and there were a range of wider effects on society.

The report was published on the eve of the summoning of former Tory chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, now deputy chairman of cigarette giant British American Tobacco, to answer charges that the company exploited smuggling and turned a blind eye to black marketing.

He will be accompanied today by his boss, Martin Broughton, who is being recalled for the third time to answer questions by the Commons health committee. The committee's decision follows the Guardian's revelations of how London-based BAT sold billions of packets a year expecting them to be smuggled.

Mr Clarke, attempting to defend the world's second largest international tobacco firm, wrote in the Guardian: "Where any government is unwilling to act or their efforts are unsuccessful, we act, completely within the law, on the basis that our brands will be available alongside those of our competitors in the smuggled as well as the legitimate market."

MPs believe his statement contradicts assurances given at an earlier hearing by Mr Broughton, BAT's chairman, that it always cooperated with customs authorities to combat unlawful sales.

It was suggested that these led to small firms such as newsagents, pubs and off-licences being put out of business, and to violent and organised crime becoming involved in smuggling, especially in the vicinity of the Channel ports.

The problem was made worse, it was said, by children being encouraged to smoke and drink because of lower prices and easy availability.

In the report published yesterday, the committee dismissed calls for duty rates on alcohol and tobacco to be cut to undermine the profit margins of smugglers. Attacking proposals that are now before Gordon Brown, the chancellor, from Martin Taylor, the Barclays Bank adviser and unofficial "smuggling tsar", the MPs rule out any budget changes to cut duty as a means of solving the problems. They said: "Although it is not disputed that reducing excise duty rates would stop the notorious 'white van trade' in smuggled alcohol and tobacco, it is less clear that this course would affect large-scale smuggling, which appears to be the major problem."

The MPs attack recent cuts in front-line customs staff and say the time has come for a big increase in funds to fight smuggling."We believe that far more should be done to keep smuggled goods out of the UK," they said.

"This will require significantly more resources for customs and excise, both for front-line staff at ports, and for inland and investigative staff."

They call for more than another £35m to be diverted to fight the smuggling rise, saying it is bound to be cost-effective. A new national network of X-ray machines should be installed to stop smuggling without delay, they say.

The MPs attack the treasury for covering up a six-year-old report on the need for departmental reorganisation.

MPs accuse customs of not being able to stand up the case against merger to public scrutiny.

Dawn Primarolo, paymaster general, commented on the findings: "This is a very thorough report and the government will respond in detail when we have carefully considered the committee's recommendations."

webTitle: Waiting game at end of bitter mayor battle

fields.headline: Waiting game at end of bitter mayor battle
fields.standfirst:
Voting ends today, with the result not due until Saturday. But Downing Street is expected to have a good idea of the winner by tonight

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: When voting ends in the ballot for Labour's candidate for London mayor at 5pm today, it will herald the climax of what has become the most closely and bitterly fought internal election battle since Denis Healey beat Tony Benn for the deputy leadership in 1981.
fields.body:
When voting ends in the ballot for Labour's candidate for London mayor at 5pm today, it will herald the climax of what has become the most closely and bitterly fought internal election battle since Denis Healey beat Tony Benn for the deputy leadership in 1981.

Whatever the outcome, the contest has already changed the political landscape, exposing the limits of the changes Tony Blair has wrought to Labour and highlighting the tensions between the party system and the mayoral model the prime minister has championed.

According to Labour's Millbank headquarters, the result cannot be declared until 5pm on Saturday at the earliest - and is more likely to come on Sunday or Monday - because a three-day breathing space was agreed to allow time for appeals and complaints from members and candidates.

Ken Livingstone has called the gap "an open invitation to fraud" and Frank Dobson's spokeswoman describes the decision to invite appeals before the result is announced as "unprecedented". But Millbank is adamant there will be no outcome until all the candidates agree the process has been free and fair.

That might take somewhat longer than three days, as Glenda Jackson has threatened to go to court at "any hint of impropriety" - the former transport minister is holding a "moral victory" party tonight - and Mr Livingstone is demanding a police guard on the ballot boxes at Unity Security Balloting, Labour's scrutineers.

Whenever the official announcement, most Labour insiders assume that the winner, if not the precise result, will begin to leak out beforehand and that Downing Street will have a pretty clear idea of who it is by tonight.

Even if Millbank's three-day delay holds, the results of most of the ballots in the union and other affiliates' third of the electoral college - important pointers to the wider voting pattern - are expected to be announced over the next couple of days, though they do not have to be in until Friday.

The latest union ballot to be declared -though it will not count in the final tally because of late affiliation payment - was of Aslef tube train drivers, who it was announced yesterday had given Mr Livingstone 1,479 votes, Ms Jackson 96 and Mr Dobson just 60.

Crucial

But the crucial, and more imponderable, result will be in the individual members' ballot, where Mr Livingstone needs to score well over 60% to offset the overwhelming Dobson majority in the MPs', MEPs' and Greater London assembly candidates' section. The likelihood is that neither will win an outright majority and the outcome will depend on the transfers from Ms Jackson's supporters.

If the former Greater London council leader does, after all, triumph over a selection system designed to see him off, Mr Blair is on record as insisting he will back an official Labour Livingstone campaign.

Despite the obloquy he and other Labour leaders have heaped on Mr Livingstone - and which would be enthusiastically recycled by Tories and Liberal Democrats during the mayoral election campaign - the prime minister has always left himself the alibi that if the Labour party picks the Brent East MP, that would show he has indeed changed.

A Livingstone victory this week would immediately trigger an intense round of negotiations over his choice of deputy and mayoral manifesto, with the future of the government's plans for partial tube privatisation in the balance and Mr Livingstone playing a strong hand.

Secret talks began last month with Lord Whitty, transport minister and former Labour general secretary, acting as go-between. Labour's leadership is particularly anxious to avoid a humiliating climbdown over the tube and strongly opposed to Mr Livingstone's proposal to parachute Ms Jackson into Labour's assembly top-up list and appoint her as his deputy.

But if Mr Dobson wins, the problems for the Labour high command could be even greater, particularly if the former health secretary scrapes through an electoral college widely regarded as having been rigged in his favour. One Blair adviser describes a narrow Dobson victory as a potential disaster, particularly in the wake of the ousting of Alun Michael in Wales.

If the former health secretary were selected but, as expected, Mr Livingstone won a clear majority wherever ballots of party or union members had been held, pressures on him to stand as an independent would be bound to build up. If there are continuing rows, legal threats and challenges over this week's count, those demands would be intensified.

But Mr Livingstone would himself be in a quandary, since he has given unequivocal assurances that he would do no such thing, stating in the Guardian recently: "I will not stand against the party I have spent my whole life serving."

An independent Livingstone London mayoral campaign would be a huge personal gamble and would lead to automatic expulsion from the Labour party. He would have less than three months to attract funds and supporters and, if the government gets its way, he would have to do without free postal delivery.

Mandate

But whether his commitment not to stand alone would survive a discredited selection process and opinion polls predicting a Livingstone independent landslide remains to be seen. If Mr Dobson's victory depended - as it almost certainly would - on the votes of organisations like the engineering union and south London Co-operative party, which both refused to ballot their members, Mr Livingstone might credibly be able to claim a moral victory and democratic mandate.

If Mr Dobson does emerge the winner, but Mr Livingstone has been shown to be the clear choice of Labour's membership, the prime minister might still have to decide whether to seek political accomodation with the Brent East MP or face a potential split in Labour's vote.

webTitle: Morgan asks for calm and continuity

fields.headline: Morgan asks for calm and continuity
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's Rhodri Morgan was yesterday formally elected first secretary of the Welsh assembly, and promptly called for a period of calm and continuity after the events that culminated in last week's resignation of his predecessor, Alun Michael.
fields.body:
Labour's Rhodri Morgan was yesterday formally elected first secretary of the Welsh assembly, and promptly called for a period of calm and continuity after the events that culminated in last week's resignation of his predecessor, Alun Michael.

Mr Morgan, who was elected unopposed, said he felt "tremendous emotion, honour and privilege" at having been appointed to a job he had given much thought to over the past two and a half years.

In a speech that mixed passion with humour, he said he wanted to inspire voters with a vision of devolution and "rebuild the bond of trust" between politicians of all parties and the people of Wales.

He said that if Welsh political giants such as Nye Bevan and Lloyd George could dream their dreams of how to improve society, assembly members could do so too, now that the new institution gave them a vehicle for improving the lives of the people of Wales.

Paying tribute to the hard work and dignity of his predecessor, Mr Morgan said the assembly could not allow the culling of first secretaries to become Wales's annual blood sport. His number one target, he said to laughter from fellow assembly members, was to survive until the half-term recess.

He paid "a huge tribute" to Mr Michael, who sat in the assembly chamber next to former Welsh secretary, Ron Davies, and behind his old seat. Mr Morgan said: "Nobody could have worked harder for Wales and nobody with an ounce of humanity about them could have failed to be moved by the dignity that he showed last week and is still showing now."

The opposition parties then welcomed the fresh start for the assembly. Plaid Cymru president, Dafydd Wigley, referred to Tony Blair's original attempt to block Mr Morgan's bid to become first secretary in favour of Alun Michael.

He said: "It is us here in Wales as parties and as an assembly who decide who are to be our leaders. Let that message go forth in no uncertain terms."

Meanwhile, the row over European funding which toppled Mr Michael spread to Scotland yesterday, with the Scottish National party calling for a full parliamentary inquiry after an independent report appeared to lend weight to claims that the treasury is breaking the additionality rules which require funds from Brussels to be matched by UK funding in Scotland as well as in Wales.

Gillian Bristow, of Cardiff Business School, says the method by which EU funds are dispersed to Wales and Scotland, through the block grant system, means neither country is getting its full entitlement.

"The EC says EU money should be additional to existing public expenditure," said Dr Bristow yesterday. "At present it is very difficult to assess that that is the case. In Wales it is probably not the case and the arguments are that the same thing must be happening in Scotland."

The SNP has estimated that Scotland has lost out on some £730m since 1993 because of the funding system.

The party is sending representatives to Wales today to hold talks with Plaid Cymru on the matter.

A treasury spokesman refuted suggestions that rules were being broken on the issue of additionality, and a spokesman for the Scottish executive said there was no question of Scotland having lost out because of the way structural funds are managed.

Gillian Bristow, of Cardiff Business School, says the method by which EU funds are dispersed to Wales and Scotland, through the block grant system, means neither country is getting its full entitlement. "The EC says EU money should be additional to existing public expenditure," said Dr Bristow yesterday. "At present it is very difficult to assess that that is the case. In Wales it is probably not the case and the arguments are that the same thing must be happening in Scotland." The SNP has estimated that Scotland has lost out on some £730m since 1993 because of the funding system. The party is sending representatives to Wales today to hold talks with Plaid Cymru on the matter. A treasury spokesman refuted suggestions that rules were being broken on the issue of additionality, and a spokesman for the Scottish executive said there was no question of Scotland having lost out because of the way structural funds are managed.

fields.headline: Betty Archdale
fields.trailText: In the conservative Australia of the 1950s, Betty Archdale, who has died aged 92, was a radical voice, and - just as she loved Australia - Australians loved her.
fields.body:
In the conservative Australia of the 1950s, Betty Archdale, who has died aged 92, was a radical voice, and - just as she loved Australia - Australians loved her.

In 1946, she had become principal of Sydney university's womens' college. Describing her role there as "an administrator with an academic bias", she encouraged students who came from all sorts of backgrounds - and from Europe and the United States.

She played a similar role as headmistress of Abbotsleigh, the exclusive Sydney school for girls. The pupils, unusually for the time, were given sex education. She reformed the curriculum, introducing physics and cutting back on British, in favour of Australian, history.

Born in London, Archdale was the daughter of a suffragette and a Irish soldier in the British army. Her godmother was Emmeline Pankhurst. The memory of visiting her own mother, imprisoned in Holloway after a demonstration, was a lifelong inspiration.

Archdale was educated at Bedales school, Hampshire, St Leonard's school, St Andrews, McGill university in Montreal - where she graduated in economics and political science - and London university, where she read law. Specialising in international law, she studied in the Soviet Union but was, she said, a socialist, not a communist. She was called to the bar in 1938.

As well as a feminist, Archdale was also a cricketer, and captained the England women's first - and victorious - tour of Australia.

She served as a WRNS officer in the far east, Africa, Australia and the Pacific during the second world war. Then, in 1946, she was back in Sydney. Later, at Abbotsleigh, she won the support of hitherto conservative parents and daughters and was loved by both generations.

Archdale retired in 1970 and lived with her brother Alexander in a house they built themselves outside Sydney. She adored appearing on television and radio, and two years before her death was voted a "living national treasure".

Philip Jones

fields.headline: Frederick Vanderbilt Field
fields.standfirst: American patrician son harassed for supporting radical causes at home and abroad
fields.trailText: Frederick Vanderbilt Field, who has died age 94, was one of those curious patrician figures from the American left's past.
fields.body:
Frederick Vanderbilt Field, who has died age 94, was one of those curious patrician figures from the American left's past.

Often mistakenly described as a "millionaire communist", he made his mark supporting the Asian left, and was assailed by federal investigators as a spy and a subversive partner of the Chinese communists.

Field described in his autobiography, From Right To Left (1983), the background of luxury which befell him as the great-great-grandson of railroad "robber baron" Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt.

After attending Hotchkiss academy and Harvard, he went to the London School of Economics, where he first heard radical ideas. On his return, he joined the US Socialist party, causing a minor press sensation and prompting his namesake to cut him off from an anticipated $70m inheritance. In 1929, he travelled to Russia, met Lenin's widow, Nadezhda Krupskaya, and was overwhelmed by Russian accomplishments.

Drawn to communism - like Sidney and Beatrice Webb in England, or the handful of Yankee Christian socialists who embraced anti-colonialism - Field joined the American staff of the Institute of Pacific Relations. The IPR provided research materials on the far east, but Field and his colleagues drifted steadily, if quietly, toward Soviet positions. Contributing to the American Communist party publication China Today, which publicised the effects of the 1932 Japanese invasion of China and urged readers' sympathy for the communist cause under the banner of national liberation, he launched the prestigious scholarly journal, Amerasia, in 1937.

Hardly a central issue for most Americans, the plight of the Chinese began to enjoy the growing support of assorted travellers and novelists. From Edgar Snow (author of Red Star Over China) and Pearl Buck, to the left-leaning screenwriters and film directors who delivered vivid portraits of anti-Japanese resistance in such films as Dragon Seed (1944) with a slant-eyed, heroic guerrilla fighter (Katharine Hepburn), they described what few American leaders had been prepared to accept - that the near-collapse of the corrupt Jiang government, and the failure of the US to actively defend China against the Japanese, had opened the path to Mao's victory.

Amerasia magazine, with a patrician founder and a respectful readership in the US diplomatic corps, provided a natural target for congressional conservatives seeking to expose "treason" within the Roosevelt administration. Field had made such charges easier to hurl when he became executive secretary of the communist-led American Peace Mobilisation during the Hitler-Stalin pact period of 1939-41. (He was disappointed that the "red dean" of Canterbury, Hewlitt Johnson, declined his offer to speak for the APM and against the war.)

After the Nazi invasion of the Soviet Union, Field unsucessfully sought military appointment, but served on the Council for Pan-American Democracy, and the Committee for a Democratic Far East Policy organised immediately after the war.

The new, cold-war, atmosphere did not immediately prove deadly. Many returning GIs, veteran missionaries, diplomats and high government officials - including former Vice-President Henry Wallace - shared Fields's dim view of the Jiang regime and of most current US policies in Asia.

Determined to nip such well-placed dissent in the bud, FBI agents arrested Field and four others in June 1945, seizing thousands of pages of documents and accusing him of seeking to pass government secrets to a foreign power. The overwhelming majority of documents seized from the Amerasia office had, however, never been classified. Worse for the prosecutors, the materials in them embarrassed congressional hawks with previously undisclosed revelations about the Chinese nationalist regime.

At this early date, new dealers still in power vigorously fended off the conservative attack, a defence that later withered under cold-war pressures. In a remarkable legal compromise, a fine was agreed upon, and all other charges against Amerasia staffers dropped.

Decades later, scholarly efforts to revive the charges of subversion stumbled across the original difficulties. Field, unquestionably a supporter of the Soviet regime and of the Chinese communists, had acted consistently upon views widely popular in new deal and Democratic party circles until the death of Franklin Roosevelt.

Freed but out of a profession, Field drew closer to the most respectable of remaining communist causes, civil rights and civil liberties. He triumphed once more on his own behalf when congressional hearings of 1950-51 failed to demonstrate any convincing evidence of his spying for the Soviet Union. But he fell victim when, along with mystery writer Dashiel Hammett, he agreed to serve as secretary of the bail fund of the Civil Rights Congress. After refusing to provide congressional investigators with certain names of contributors, he served an 18-month sentence - and walked out free to his awaiting black Jaguar.

In December 1953, Field drove to Mexico, where he spent nearly 30 years as an unsuccessful businessman, an avid amateur archaeologist and musician. After he and his third wife separated, he married Nieves Orozco, reputed to have been muralist Diego Rivera's favourite model. He also became friends with Marilyn Monroe, whom he described as a clear-minded, if taciturn, Marxist. Long since a non-communist but still radical and individualistic, he retired to Minneapolis, wrote his memoirs and continued to be involved in such social movements as environmentalism.

He is survived by his wife Nieves, four daughters, 12 grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren.

Paul Buhle

fields.headline: Elisabeth Collins
fields.trailText: For many people, Elisabeth Collins, who has died aged 95, was best known as the wife and muse of the visionary artist Cecil Collins, and - like many women of her generation - her talent took second place to that of her husband.
fields.body:
For many people, Elisabeth Collins, who has died aged 95, was best known as the wife and muse of the visionary artist Cecil Collins, and - like many women of her generation - her talent took second place to that of her husband.

Yet it was an image in one of her own early drawings that inspired him to explore the subject of the Fool, which became the essence and signature of his work, and a year ago Elisabeth had four paintings from her 1996 London exhibition bought by the Tate Gallery. She was active and creative way beyond her age.

Alongside the Fool, there often stood an Angel. While Cecil painted his magnificent images, Elisabeth was more interested in talking about her Angel: it was, for her, a matter of fact.

Splendidly attired, Elisabeth was a regular visitor at the Chelsea Arts Club. It was round the corner from the house which she and her husband shared for 30 years with the writer and poet Kathleen Raine.

Elisabeth was born in Halifax, the child of a prosperous family. She met Cecil, a Cornishman, at the Royal College of Art in 1927 and they married in 1931. They shared a lifelong conviction that "there are more things in heaven and earth than are dreamt of ..."

In the 1930s, they lived in Totnes, Devon. Through the American artist Mark Toby, they joined Dartington, the idealistic community founded by Leonard and Dorothy Elmhirst to foster rural regeneration and the arts. It was a happy and productive time for both of them.

In 1943 they moved to Cambridge, and in 1970 to London. As the reputation of Cecil Collins grew over the years, culminating in a major retrospective at the Tate just before he died in 1989, his wife continued to create, working on the corner of their dining table or in her bedroom on small drawings and colourful and dreamlike gouaches. After Cecil's death she moved into a corner of his studio, and it was here that she produced most of the works for that last 1996 exhibition.

Her funeral was held at a Russian Orthodox church in Knightsbridge. It was the right place to celebrate a courageous, inspiring life.

Jonathan Stedall

fields.headline: Screamin' Jay Hawkins
fields.standfirst: Wild man of shock 'n' roll weaving spells with ghoulish props
fields.trailText: Screamin' Jay Hawkins, who has died of an aneurism aged 70, may have been the wildest of rock 'n' wild men. Not even Little Richard or James Brown would open a performance by emerging from a coffin or leaping on stage in the costume of an African warrior.
fields.body:
Screamin' Jay Hawkins, who has died of an aneurism aged 70, may have been the wildest of rock 'n' wild men. Not even Little Richard or James Brown would open a performance by emerging from a coffin or leaping on stage in the costume of an African warrior.

Such antics, and a taste for macabre accessories like skulls and shrunken heads, made Hawkins a formative influence on mock-satanic versifiers like Arthur Brown, Alice Cooper and his closest imitator, Screamin' Lord Sutch.

Born in Cleveland, Ohio, Hawkins began playing piano as a child and later learned tenor saxophone, but his first career choice was boxing. In 1949, he became Alaska's middleweight champion, but took so much punishment winning the title that he decided to exchange the ring for the bandstand. Leaving the US army in 1951 after being wounded in Korea, he joined the guitarist Tiny Grimes's Rockin' Highlanders, a rhythm & blues group that performed in kilts and tam o'shanters.

After 18 months as the band's singer, driver and general factotum, he left to develop a solo career. In 1955, he recorded for OKeh, Columbia Records' black music label, a devastating version of his composition I Put A Spell On You. The grunts, groans and screams with which Hawkins decorated what was essentially a pop ballad in waltz time were judged so disturbing that the record was banned from airplay. Nevertheless, it sold more than 1m copies, guaranteeing him the opportunity to commit further outrages on records such as Alligator Wine, The Whammy, Feast Of The Mau Mau and the (confessedly autobiographical) Constipation Blues.

Despite that title, Hawkins was not primarily a bluesman. "My first idol," he said, "was Paul Robeson" - and he might have made a creditable operatic baritone, but after I Put A Spell On You he dedicated himself to contorting his voice in the service of what has been called horror rock or shock 'n' roll. The 1957 album, At Home With Screamin' Jay Hawkins, where he sang easy-listening standards like I Love Paris, was a rare diversion.

Hawkins was primarily a performance artist, and most of his discs were less memorable than his zebra-striped capes, polka-dot suits and pink tuxedos, or his screaming, smoke-shrouded resurrection from a satin-lined coffin. Such ghoulish props - including a smoking skull named Henry - were suggested by the disc jockey and promoter Alan Freed, who booked him on his package shows. Nonetheless, Paramount Pictures cut Hawkins out of the Freed biopic, Mister Rock And Roll (1957), afraid that his appearance might offend black Americans. "I didn't care," said Hawkins. "I'm not a crusader. I'm out to make a dollar."

He made a well-received visit to Britain in 1965, but by the end of the decade was working as a comedian in a Honolulu strip club. Various recording projects in the 1970s came to nothing, and his contribution to the movie, American Hot Wax (1978), was cut to a few scenes. The Rolling Stones guitarist Keith Richards played on a 1979 recording of I Put A Spell On You, one of many revisions Hawkins attempted over the years, culminating in a 1991 dance version.

Hawkins continued to work during the 1980s and 1990s, albeit at a lower temperature. He had cameo roles in the films Mystery Train (1989) and A Rage In Harlem (1991), and in 1998 received a Pioneer Award from the Rhythm & Blues Foundation. Always popular in France, he had moved to the Paris suburb of Neuilly-sur-Seine, where he died.

Tony Russell

fields.headline: Hilde Behrend
fields.standfirst: Economist who probed our motivation to work
fields.trailText: Hilde Behrend, who has died aged 82, was an economist and teacher who won an international reputation for distinguished research into industrial relations.
fields.body:
Hilde Behrend, who has died aged 82, was an economist and teacher who won an international reputation for distinguished research into industrial relations.

Her large-scale surveys and detailed insights informed policy both in Britain (notably through the National Economic Development Office) and the Irish Republic.

She was born in Berlin, and in the 1920s her father, as headmaster of the Kaiser Wilhelm-Realgymnasium and president of the association of German secondary school headmasters and teachers, was one of German education's leading figures. When the Nazis took power, he was ousted because his parents, although Christians by religion, were Jewish by race.

Behrend left Germany in 1936 and arrived in Britain practically penniless. After a succession of jobs, she became a shorthand typist at the London School of Economics (located at the time in Cambridge due to wartime evacuation) before gaining admission as a student, winning the University of London's Metcalfe scholarship for women and graduating with honours in economics in 1944. She then taught French and German in Middlesex and Birmingham grammar schools.

In 1949, Behrend met Professor Sargant Florence, of Birmingham university, who offered her a research assistant's job. It was the beginning of her academic career. Her PhD, Absence Under Full Employment, brought her to the notice of scholars, such as Professor Phelps Brown, who remained a close friend.

In 1954, Behrend took up a research lectureship at Edinburgh university, working in the new social sciences research centre. Led by the philosopher, Professor John Macmurray, the centre brought together scholars from commerce, economics, psychology, sociology, geography and history, exploring social research untrammelled by academic boundaries.

Virtually all Behrend's subsequent work was the richer for the centre's interdisciplinary nature. In 1973, she was appointed to a personal chair in industrial relations. Throughout her career she was an assiduous and dedicated teacher, but found her greatest satisfaction in research. Drawing upon west midlands material, she analysed rich absence-from-work data, revealing - among other things - a peak at the beginning of the week: the "blue Monday index".

Her second area of research was that of incentive payment systems, and their use by employers: the "effort bargain" explained the way in which workers related their effort to the pay which they received. Her longest lasting research was focused on people's perceptions of the forces which contribute to inflation in pay and prices.

In 1982, the year of her retirement, she played a large part in organising the seventh international conference on economic psychology. She wrote 17 books, monographs and reports, and numerous academic papers. She was much loved by her students, perhaps most of all by her many research students, who suffered under, but greatly benefited from, her refusal to accept anything less than the highest standards of scientific inquiry.

Behrend continued to live in Edinburgh for several years, moving closer to her family in Buckinghamshire in the mid-1990s, but fell victim to Alzheimer's disease. She never married.

Phil White

fields.headline: Suicide bomber shatters Beijing calm
fields.trailText: Tiananmen Square was sealed off yesterday after a bomb explosion which police blamed upon an aggrieved "mental patient".
fields.body:
Tiananmen Square was sealed off yesterday after a bomb explosion which police blamed upon an aggrieved "mental patient".

Officials, apparently keen to dampen speculation sparked by such a high-profile explosion, quickly issued a statement naming the bomber as Li Xiangshan from central Hubei province. Police said Li had made four previous trips to the capital to air a grievance with Chinese leaders.

Li, who killed himself in the blast and also wounded a South Korean tourist, chose the most politically sensitive spot in China. The apparent suicide comes as police tighten security ahead of next month's National People's Congress.

The bomb blast at about 4pm shattered street lamps but caused no wider damage. The square is normally crowded with tourists.

Police on the scene stopped vehicles driving around the square, and checked pedestrians' identity papers.

The Chinese prime minister, Zhu Rongji, recently called for greater efforts to be made to deal with popular complaints. At congress time, many peaceful complainants head for Beijing hoping to hand in personal petitions to special offices of the government state council or Communist party.

Yesterday's bomb went off between the mausoleum of Mao Zedong and the revolutionary martyrs' memorial, which was occupied by pro-democracy students in 1989 before the Beijing massacre.

The congress - China's annual parliament - meets in the Great Hall of the People on the western side of the square opposite yesterday's blast. Last year's high security presence around the building is now likely to be intensified.

Suggestions that the blast is connected with the banned Falun Gong cult, after arrests 10 days ago in Tiananmen Square, seem far-fetched. Sect members practise non-violence and protests have been peaceful.

Some previous bomb blasts elsewhere in China have been blamed on Muslim separatists from the north-west region of Xinjiang. Others have been staged by peasants or workers protesting against unemployment and other local scandals.

At least 33 people are thought to have been killed and more than 100 wounded last year in 10 separate bomb incidents across the country.

Two local officials were executed for planting a bomb on a railway line in Hebei province to "get back at society". Another bomb in Ningxia, northern China, which killed three police officers, was planted by a criminal gang fleeing arrest. Other incidents have been blamed on blackmailers and on defrauded investors seeking revenge.

fields.headline: Basilica beauty
fields.standfirst: 15-year restoration completed on Piero masterpiece
fields.trailText: Fifteen years of agonising about colours, shades, details and angles have returned a renaissance masterpiece to its previous magnificence, which was feared destroyed by five centuries of damp, earthquakes, lightning and wars.
fields.body:
Fifteen years of agonising about colours, shades, details and angles have returned a renaissance masterpiece to its previous magnificence, which was feared destroyed by five centuries of damp, earthquakes, lightning and wars.

The Legend of the True Cross, a fresco by Piero della Francesca that adorns three walls of a Tuscan basilica, has emerged from restoration with its revolutionary use of geometry and perspective reclaimed.

Computer experts collaborated with artists and historians to recreate what the art critic Kenneth Clark called "the most perfect morning light in all renaissance painting".

Spread across 300 square metres (3,200 sq ft) in Arezzo's San Francesco basilica, generations have marvelled at the painting's perspective, and despaired as it peeled and faded away.

The £3.5m restoration was scheduled to finish in 1992 for the the 500th anniversary of Piero's death. But the complexity of his shading, symmetries and mirror arrangements forced restorers to stay in the basilica as long as he did - 15 years.

The restoration was completed yesterday and will be open to the public on April 7; those willing to climb scaffolding will be afforded previews.

Colour analysis has inflected the work with a new meaning, said Carlo Bertelli, an art critic. The once starry sky over emperor Constantine's tent has lightened to suggest a coming dawn.

Art critics have hailed Piero as a genius for creating a sense of each incident as part of a greater plan, using perspective and the natural light passing through the window. But even before the work had been finished, the basilica's walls began to crack. Lightning struck in 1785 and, in 1799, Napoleon's troops delighted in using the figures for target practice.

An early 20th century attempt to strengthen the walls backfired when the cement released a saline humidity.

Restorers, led by Anna Maria Maetzke, Arezzo's state cultural commissioner, were guided in their efforts by Piero's published research. It was also discovered that a public bath building that once dominated the view of Jerusalem was superimposed after Piero's death.

webTitle: Bomb trial may call Bush Sr

fields.headline: Bomb trial may call Bush Sr
fields.trailText: The former United States president George Bush may be called to give evidence at a terrorism trial that begins in Milan today, amid persistent claims from the prosecution that the CIA knew of a rightwing bombing campaign in Italy 30 years ago.
fields.body:
The former United States president George Bush may be called to give evidence at a terrorism trial that begins in Milan today, amid persistent claims from the prosecution that the CIA knew of a rightwing bombing campaign in Italy 30 years ago.

Mr Bush was director of the central intelligence agency in 1976 and defence lawyers are expected to ask the court to summons all CIA heads from 1960 to the present.

Four neo-fascist suspects are accused of planting a bomb in the Piazza Fontana branch of the Banca Nazionale dell'Agricoltura on December 12 1969. The blast killed 16 people and started what became known as the "strategy of tension" - a series of indiscriminate bomb attacks against the public to destabilise the country and reduce electoral support for the Communist party.

The rightwingers accused of organising the bomb attack are Carlo Maria Maggi, a doctor and leader of the neo-fascist Ordine Nuovo (New Order) group in Venice, his associate Delfo Zorzi, Giancarlo Rognoni, the leader of the Fenice (Phoenix) extremist group in Milan, and Carlo Digilio, allegedly a CIA informant.

The prosecution case relies heavily on evidence from Mr Digilio, an arms expert who has admitted contacts with Italian and US intelligence officers. A carabiniere report says of him: "He began his activity in 1967, when he took the place of his father as an informant of the CIA in Venice."

Mr Digilio has alleged that Mr Zorzi confided to him that he had been personally involved in the Milan bombing.

"Zorzi told me with pride that he had participated in the Milan action and that despite all those deaths, which were the result of an error, it had been important because it had strengthened the right and struck a blow against the the left," Mr Digilio told an investigating judge, Guido Salvini.

Mr Zorzi denies responsibility for the bombing.

Another witness, Martino Siciliano, has testified on the political background to the bombing. "We rightwingers were widely manipulated by the interior ministry and used how and when they liked," he said in a radio interview last year. "The bombs I planted in Trieste and Gorizia served to prevent President [Giuseppe] Saragat from making a visit to Tito. It's obvious that the order came from someone on high."

The court is expected to examine the role played by two US naval intelligence officers who operated out of a Nato base in Verona. Captains Teddy Richards and David Carrett were allegedly in close contact with the extremists implicated in the massacre.

A key issue for the court will be to decide whether US agents were aware of preparations for the bombing and did nothing, or whether they promoted it.

Mr Salvini believes it was the latter. "American agents were responsible for promoting the strategy of tension, even though they did not intervene directly but through organisations whose actions could not be traced to them," he said.
