webTitle: More editors told to answer racism claim

fields.headline: More editors told to answer racism claim
fields.standfirst: South African government suspected of trying to silence its critics
fields.trailText: South Africa's human rights commission has issued another set of subpoenas requiring media editors to submit to public interrogation over allegations of racism or face prison sentences.
fields.body:
South Africa's human rights commission has issued another set of subpoenas requiring media editors to submit to public interrogation over allegations of racism or face prison sentences.

The commission has ordered nine journalists to appear at hearings next month at which they will be confronted with charges of overt and "subliminal" racism in their coverage of corruption, politics and wars. Several other editors have been invited to attend but are not legally bound to do so.

Although the summonsed journalists have not said outright that they will defy the commission's order, most have consulted lawyers about the legal implications. Some constitutional lawyers argue that the commission's subpoenas conflict with the press freedom clause of the constitution.

The Cape Times editor, John Scott, said that his newspaper was committed to opposing racism, but that was not the immediate issue. "We are also committed to upholding press freedom, and obviously we must consider whether the subpoenas threaten this," he said.

The commission argues that the hearings are part of a necessary process to purge racism from newspapers, some of which had a history of either openly supporting apartheid or tacit collaboration with the white regime.

The ruling African National Congress has backed the subpoenas, reinforcing suspicions that the hearings are politically motivated against critics of the government.

The new summonses went to two newspapers in Durban, a small Cape Town radio station and the only Afrikaans paper on the list, Die Burger. They came on the heels of subpoenas to four other newspapers, including the anti-apartheid Mail and Guardian, owned by the Guardian Media Group. The commission has also summonsed a journalist who writes a business column.

Radio 786, a Muslim community station in the western Cape, is among the few to be told the specific accusation it faces. Its station manager has been ordered to account for a single headline in a news bulletin in July last year - "Angolans find 90 dead bodies" - introducing a report about the civil war in Angola. The commission said that the headline "depersonalises black people's deaths; the report focuses on numbers rather than individual deaths".

"It's ridiculous that we've got to respond to an allegation of this nature," the station's manager, Amin Ahmed, said. "Do you take one news item as the basis for alleging racism? We've handed the matter to our attorneys, but we don't have the finances to engage the commission in these kind of actions."

Mr Ahmed alleged that the commission had obtained the original material under false pretences. "We were told we were part of a study as part of an educational project. We gave them six weeks of material. We were very cooperative. It raises questions about how they go about this," he said.

The official opposition Democratic party joined in the criticism of the commission's handling of the hearings. Other organisations, such as the Freedom of Expression Institute, are reconsidering their cooperation with the commission.

Business Day, a stablemate of the Johannesburg Sunday Times which was also summonsed, derided the commission's handling of the investigation into racism.

"It would be richly ironic if the most decisive initiative in the [human rights] commission's rather lacklustre five-year existence was to have several newspaper editors imprisoned for refusing to answer its subpoenas. What a profound contribution that would be to the building of a human rights culture in South Africa," it said.

fields.headline: Kohl party fined £14m over scandal
fields.standfirst: German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Germany's scandal-battered Christian Democrats were last night planning a legal battle against what is thought to be the biggest financial penalty ever to have been inflicted on a European political party.
fields.body:
Germany's scandal-battered Christian Democrats were last night planning a legal battle against what is thought to be the biggest financial penalty ever to have been inflicted on a European political party.

As things stand, they will have to give up some DM41m (£14m) - roughly as much as they spent on their last general election campaign.

The fine announced yesterday by the speaker of the lower house of parliament, Wolfgang Thierse, is unlikely to be the last for systematic violations of party financing laws during more than 10 years. The scandal has shaken the country's politics to the foundations.

The Christian Democrat Union (CDU) has already lost many of its voters. If it remains financially hamstrung, it may not regain its status as one of the pillars of Germany's two-party democracy.

The CDU's general secretary, Angela Merkel, said: "The financial problems this will cause will be very hard to cope with." The party's treasurer, Matthias Wissmann, added: "Our ability to compete with the other parties would be severely compromised."

But Rezzo Schlauch, the Greens' parliamentary leader, said: "The CDU has admitted breaking the party financing law. They should accept Thierse's decision. They are not in a position to pull legalistic stunts. If they do, they will lose more of their credibility".

Last night, in a new twist, the CDU's parliamentary leaders announced that they were putting themselves up for re-election next week. The move set the stage for a head-on clash between supporters of the party's leader, Wolfgang Schäuble, and its former treasurer, Brigitte Baumeister, whose versions of events is at odds with Mr Schäuble's.

The speaker of the lower house has the power to punish a party for accepting undeclared contributions and filing inaccurate annual reports. Parties in Germany receive financial assistance from the state, and for each mark they conceal, the speaker can claim back up to three marks of state support. The sanction Mr Thierse imposed yesterday is solely for money concealed by the Christian Democrats in the Hesse region - about a third of the total alleged to have been amassed secretly by the conservatives after 1989. It did not cover payments of some £670,000 which the former chancellor, Helmut Kohl, has has admitted accepting.

Less than £2m of the fine will come from future receipts. The rest will have to be returned by the party from money it received last year. It may also have to pay a fine for accepting donations which the party did not record.

Early indications are that the CDU will base its legal appeal in part on the claimed injustice of penalising the entire party for infractions committed by only one region.

fields.headline: Kidnap damages
fields.standfirst: Ex-Beirut captive files £63m lawsuit
fields.trailText: Former Beirut hostage Terry Anderson went to court yesterday, filing a $100m (£63m) federal lawsuit against Iran for its alleged collusion in his seven-year kidnap ordeal.
fields.body:
Former Beirut hostage Terry Anderson went to court yesterday, filing a $100m (£63m) federal lawsuit against Iran for its alleged collusion in his seven-year kidnap ordeal.

US District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson started gathering evidence in the case, heard as an effort builds in Congress to help victims of state-sponsored terrorism collect damages.

Anderson's lawyers claim his captors were members of Hizbullah, or Party of God, "a politico-paramilitary terrorist organisation operating in Lebanon" sponsored and directed by Iran.

The lawsuit was filed last March under a 1996 law allowing claims by US citizens and their families against assets of foreign countries that sponsor terrorism - if the actions resulted in personal injury or death.

So far, no money has been collected under that act because the Clinton administration, while initially supporting the law, has declined to help successful US plaintiffs collect.

Anderson hopes that may soon change. "The Clinton administration is supposed to assist in finding Iranian assets," he said. "In general, they've said they're willing to do this. But there's still a way to go."

Anderson, now 52, was taken captive in Beirut on March 16 1985 and freed 2,454 days later, on December 4 1991.

fields.headline: I feel the madness more
fields.standfirst: For a decade  Maggie O'Kane  has reported on the world's bloodiest conflicts. But she didn't understand the full horror of war until she became a mother - and felt the terrible fear of someone harming her child
fields.trailText: For a decade  Maggie O'Kane  has reported on the world's bloodiest conflicts. But she didn't understand the full horror of war until she became a mother - and felt the terrible fear of someone harming her child.
fields.body:
About a month after my son, Billy, was born I took a walk on London's Hampstead Heath. It was January three years ago. We were alone. Me, an ecstatic mother in my new camel hair Christmas coat and a small boy in an old-fashioned green bouncy pram his grandmother had sent from Glasgow.

I took the path through the trees far from the tweedy dog walkers and sniffed the sweet smell of wet rotting leaves. Then, through the wood, came a man with his shoulders rounded up towards his ears. He had a black V-neck pullover. No shirt. He wasn't wearing a coat. Although we seemed to be the only souls on that charcoal day, he walked past us. He never looked up.

In all my years of foreign reporting - feeling the pop of a bullet beside my ear in Timor or lying under a tree trunk in Chechnya looking up at the iron belly of a Russian gunship - nothing compares to the terror of feeling someone is going to hurt your baby.

When I met Vjolica (pronounced Volitsa) Berisha in a sunny garden in Kosovo on June 15 last year, she brought me back to that day in the Hampstead trees. Our circumstances are a million miles apart. I feel uncomfortable even writing about them on the same page. But until that wet day in the woods, I don't think I had begun to understand the real pain of war. Then I understood that war was not just about blood, bullets or bones, but about the pure, terrible fear of being unable to protect your child.

I went into Kosovo a few hours behind the German Nato troops. It was mid-June. We moved in with a family in the town of Prizren who fed us meatballs in spicy tomato sauce and fresh mango - as though we had personally liberated Kosovo.

Suva Reka, about 20 miles from our base, was a small town on the road to somewhere else. But for Vjolica Berisha it was the place where she was born, grew up, married and became the mother of three children. In the burned-out shopping precinct past the Beni Tours travel shop, there is a coffee shop with blue barstools. Here she saw her children murdered. In my mind I still have a picture of a woman trying to hide her toddler son between her legs, then feeling the bullet thud into his body.

The morning I walked into the coffee house, the white pillars were still splattered in blood. There was blood on the radiators; blood from whoever was hiding behind the cappuccino machine. The lilac tablecloths were still strewn across the floor where they had been pulled on to the ground. On the coffee bar, the breadbaskets had been filled for a lunch that had never happened; in the fridge, there were a dozen eggs and tub of Belgrade yoghurt.

More than 50 people were in here, mainly women and children. I looked across the blackened floor and imagined them lying here - mothers trying to cover the bodies of their children. A local man wandered up. There were two survivors, he said. One of them, Vjolica Berisha, was still around somewhere.

It took a while to find her. Wounded in the attack, she had hidden from the muslim hunters. Her two daughters died that morning. When the international troops arrived she crawled out of hiding, a bullet still in her hip from two months earlier - she had been too frightened to look for a doctor. She told the story without emotion."It is so hard to explain the sound a child makes when they are dying," she said. "You can't imagine it - it's not a scream exactly . . ."

She described how the group of mothers and children had hidden in the coffee shop after being chased by two armed men. "I saw my daughter, Dalphina. We were looking at each other across the bodies and she was moving her lips as though she was saying something to me. I heard Majoinda [her niece] calling out to her mother, 'Mummy what are we going to do?' Then someone threw a hand grenade in on top of her. I saw Alton, my sister's boy, looking across the room for her then he made a noise like 'oouf' and he died."

Fifty-three people, most of them women and children and most of them from the Berisha family, died in the coffee shop that morning, the day after Nato planes began their war against Serbia.

I knew that if he touched my child, I would rip his head off with my teeth. For the first time in my life, I understood real terror at being unable to protect my child.

Suddenly the creeping man stopped. He was about 10ft from our tree. He turned around again and walked away. I waited and then ran, the big round wheels of Billy's pram crashing along the muddy path. On the other side of the wood, where the heath stretches back towards the city, I paused to stop shaking.

There was Sharifa from Afghanistan, who came to live with us when the Taliban made it impossible for her to stay at home, and a husband who can spoon Branflakes and talk into a mobile phone at the same time.

Besides, most of the time I was happy to go. My thumb pressing on the reclining seat on the plane, head back - gin and tonic in front of me. Freedom. The old life, the old adventures, the old friends. Depending on how busy I was, the yearning for him did not start for a week or so. In the last three years, I've stopped carrying his photos to shove in patient people's faces, and I've learned to slice out all thoughts of him the second they sneaked up on me.

For much of the time now I'm a 37-year-old mother concerned with the usual things: staying under 11 stone, loving a three-year-old boy. I swim a bit, gym a bit, smoke a bit. Then for half of the year, I go to places where people are killing each other - and where they often hate foreign journlists.

The year 1999 was busy: Kosovo, East Timor, then Chechnya. In time I had found ways to forget my life as a mother when on assignment. But on my first trip, just six months after Billy was born, I understood that motherhood had changed the way I would look at war forever. In Cambodia's S21 Prison, where the Pol Pot regime executed the higher cadres and their children, the condemned were photographed before execution. Staring out from the wall of the prison museum that still smelt of their blood was a young woman with her six-month-old baby stretched out on the metal bed beside her. She had the number 320 pinned to her collar and she looked into the camera with what seemed like powerless acceptance of what was going to happen to her and her baby.

Upstairs, somewhere in the dusty archives, were the folders of the condemned. I spent four days searching for something about her. It was an obsession. I was driven through file after dusty file, maddened by the look on her face and by her naked child beside her on the iron frame of the prison bed. I was trying to imagine her mind - knowing that, in a day or two, someone would take her baby from her and smash his head open on the trees of the Killing Field outside Phnom Penh. They never wasted bullets on children.

In the leukemia ward of the Saddam Hussein's Children's Ward in Baghdad, I felt the same madness. The figures of two parents stooped over their 13-year-old son who would die tomorrow. The drugs he needed were forbidden under sanctions. Imagine watching your child die because some politicians in France, Britain and the US can't think of a better way of getting rid of Saddam. I had sometimes felt anger in my previous trips to Baghdad, but after Billy it was different.

Back in Europe meanwhile, the ugly pens of the revisionists have already begun their work on Kosovo. A man called Laughland, a former lecturer at the Sorbonne, wrote an article in the Spectator under the headline: The Massacres That Never Were. He wrote that there hadn't been a single body found in Suva Reka. I contacted him. He said he'd made a couple of mistakes in that article, which he corrected later, and bodies had been found in Suva Reka. But he maintained his thesis was correct: that the numbers of dead were exaggerated to justify the war and that, since the numbers of dead were probably not as high as 10,000, no international force should have been sent in.

In those first weeks after the international troops arrived, the people of Kosovo buried those they loved. Maybe they buried 10,000, perhaps only 5,000. Does it really matter? What happened in Kosovo in the months leading up to the war and in the awful backlash following Nato bombs - which undoubtedly made things worse - was evil. Stopping it was important.

Does the fact that there were 53 women and children murdered in the coffee shop, and not 530, mean that mass graves don't exist in Kosovo and the war wasn't justified? I'd like to see Laughland sitting opposite Shyreta and listening to her talk about those last seconds holding the warm body of her baby, of jumping from the truck and leaving behind her four children.

Some time during those last days in Kosovo, my second child died in my womb. It was a month later, on holiday in Italy, before I knew that the foetus was dead and had waited to miscarry. In the wonderful hospital near Florence, a fat cheerful gynaecologist scanned my then flabby belly: "It's gone - all gone," she said congratulating me on the thorough job my body had done getting rid of the foetus.

My husband, standing in the corner of her surgery with Billy in his arms, had tears in his eyes; I felt very little. I can't remember if it was at that moment, or during the long night that my body was rejecting the foetus, that I thought of Shyreta and her four dead children, of those final seconds when she held the body of her smallest one. The joy of being alive on an icy Belfast day by the River Lagan and still having a child to hold.

fields.headline: Warehouse man makes Oscar history
fields.standfirst: American Beauty by first-time director Sam Mendes wins eight nominations, as Brits give strong showing in shortlists
fields.trailText: With a stack of Golden Globes already on the mantelpiece, and his trophy cabinet filling fast, Sam Mendes made yet more Hollywood history yesterday when American Beauty was nominated for eight Oscars - the most by a first time foreign director and more than any other film this year.
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell  in Los Angeles and Fiachra Gibbons
fields.body:
With a stack of Golden Globes already on the mantelpiece, and his trophy cabinet filling fast, Sam Mendes made yet more Hollywood history yesterday when American Beauty was nominated for eight Oscars - the most by a first time foreign director and more than any other film this year.

But the wunderkind, who runs the Donmar Warehouse theatre in London, was anything but blasé last night about the success of his dark satire on suburbia. "I know, there's been so many awards ceremonies you almost get inured to them," he said.

"But when you get a load of Oscar nominations, and you look down the list of great directors who have won in the past, it's really humbling. I know it sounds naff, but it's true. I'll wear my lucky suit, the one Prada gave me to wear at the Golden Globes."

Mendes, 34, is in no hurry to do another film and wants to direct a play at the Donmar first. "I feel I need to come back down to earth. I don't know what I'm going to do, and maybe it's a mistake to decide now when I am in a euphoric state."

Although there was disappointment that neither Mike Leigh's much-fancied Topsy-Turvy, Anthony Minghella's The Talented Mr Ripley, nor Neil Jordan's The End of the Affair made it into the frame for best picture, the Brits did well overall. Leigh and Minghella were nominated for best screenplay, with Leigh an early favourite for his story about the comically strained relationship between Gilbert and Sullivan.

Janet McTeer won a nomination for best actress for her role in the low-budget American comedy Tumbleweeds, Nottingham-born Samantha Morton is in the running for best supporting actress, while Jude Law and Michael Caine (The Cider House Rules) both appear on the list for best supporting actor. Though Caine is a previous winner, Law is already thought to be a surefire bet for his performance as a wastrel American shipping heir in The Talented Mr Ripley.

The biggest surprise was the inclusion of the Welsh film, Solomon and Gaenor, in the shortlist for best foreign language film. Directed and written by Paul Morrison, it is the story of a Jewish door-to-door salesman who falls in love with a good chapel girl, and is told in Welsh, Yiddish and English.

Eleven-year-old Haley Joel Osment's nomination for The Sixth Sense showed that the academy's weakness for child actors is alive and kicking, though he is far from the youngest ever. Justin Henry was eight when he was nominated for the 1979 film Kramer vs Kramer, and Anna Paquin won one for The Piano when she too was 11.

Two films received seven nominations: The Insider, the true story of a whistle-blower in the tobacco industry, and The Cider House Rules, an adaptation of the John Irving novel set in a New England orphanage. The Green Mile and The Sixth Sense also made the best film nominations.

The failure of The Hurricane to win a best picture nomination was a surprise. Based on the true story of the wrongful conviction of black boxer Rubin Carter, the film has been criticised for bending the facts, which may have damaged its chances, but its star, Denzel Washington, appears in the best actor category.

Richard Farnsworth, 78, becomes the oldest actor ever to be nominated, for his part in David Lynch's The Straight Story. Even so, the favourites for that category remain Kevin Spacey in American Beauty and Russell Crowe in The Insider. Sean Penn, who plays a jazz guitarist in Woody Allen's Sweet and Lowdown, is also nominated.

Hilary Swank, who has already won a Golden Globe for her role in Boys Don't Cry, is one of the favourites for the best actress Oscar, a category that sees Meryl Streep win a record 12th nomination for Music of the Heart. Annette Bening in American Beauty and Julianne Moore in Neil Jordan's adaptation of Graham Greene's novel The End of the Affair are also nominated.

Samantha Morton, much praised for her performance as the mute lover of Sean Penn in Sweet and Lowdown, was also nominated in the Golden Globes and faces competition from Chloe Sevingy who won the Globe for her part in Boys Don't Cry. Angelina Jolie (Girl, Interrupted) and Catherine Keener (Being John Malkovich) were also nominated.

Pedro Almodovar's All About My Mother is the favourite for best foreign film, having cleaned up on the festival circuit and won a Golden Globe to boot.

The academy dismissed claims that its announcement had been scooped by the Aint-It-Cool-News website which ran an early list of supposed nominees. A spokesperson described as "a fake" the "long list" of nominations. The supposedly leaked list contained the names of Kate Winslet (Holy Smoke) and Gwyneth Paltrow (The Talented Mr Ripley) as nominees but neither appeared in the final lists.

The votes of the 6,000 members of the invitation-only Academy of Motion Pictures have to be in by March 21. The Oscars ceremony is on March 26.

American Beauty, The Cider House Rules, The Green Mile, The Insider, The Sixth Sense

Best Director

Sam Mendes American Beauty, Spike Jonze Being John Malkovich, Lasse Hallstrom The Cider House Rules, Michael Mann The Insider, M Night Shyamalan The Sixth Sense

Best Supporting Actor

Best Supporting Actress

Best Original Score

American Beauty Thomas Newman, Angela's Ashes John Williams, The Cider House Rules Rachel Portman, The Red Violin John Corigliano, The Talented Mr Ripley Gabriel Yared

Best Original Song

Blame Canada from South Park Bigger, Longer and Uncut, Trey Parker and Marc Shaiman Music of My Heart from Music of the Heart, Diane Warren Save Me from Magnolia, Aimee Mann When She Loved Me from Toy Story 2, Randy Newman You'll be in My Heart from Tarzan, Phil Collins

Best Costume

Anna and the King, Sleepy Hollow, The Talented Mr Ripley, Titus, Topsy-Turvy

Best Documentary Feature

Buena Vista Social Club, Genghis Blues, On the Ropes, One Day in September, Speaking in Strings

Best Documentary Short

Best Live Action Short Film

Best Visual Effects

fields.headline: No: 1578
fields.standfirst: Courtaulds
fields.trailText: Courtaulds
fields.body:
Age: 184.

Status: Clothing and textiles manufacturer. Underwear a speciality.

Origins: Founded in England in 1816 by silk weaver Samuel Courtauld III, descendant of a Huguenot refugee. The firm soon became one of the country's leading suppliers of black mourning crepe, and later bought the British rights to the process for manufacturing rayon.

Best known for: The curve- enhancing Gossard Ultrabra, as modelled by Sophie Anderton. But not for much longer, perhaps, if a takeover bid by the US baking group Sara Lee, reported yesterday, proves successful.

So we can look forward to oven-ready lingerie? Or underwired apple pies, perhaps? Chicago-based Sara Lee may be best known for its wide selection of pre-baked cakes, but also manufactures numerous other products: Douwe Egberts coffee, Radox bubble bath, Pretty Polly tights and - worryingly for Courtaulds - the Playtex Wonderbra, Gossard's longtime arch-enemy in the clash of the cleavages.

Can the British firm resist the Wonderbra's allure? It seems unlikely. All the while it has been encouraging the wearing of plunging necklines, Courtaulds has been suffering from a plunging bottom line, cutting 812 jobs and closing 10 UK plants in 1999 and reporting half-year losses of £3.6m last September. And the takeover bid values the company's shares at 60% higher than the London stock market. So, in a very real sense, it's Sara Lee or, um, bust.

So Courtaulds said 'Hello boys!' and jumped into bed with Sara? Certainly not: they say the offer is far too low. Sara Lee insists the firm will be allowed to keep its individual identity, but industry insiders reckon the Ultrabra might find itself on the losing side in a battle of the bras.

All this is nothing to do with those highbrow art scholars at the Courtauld Institute in London, I presume. You presume wrongly. The Courtauld family demonstrated a far greater diversity in their business interests than in naming their sons: Samuel Courtauld's descendant, Samuel Courtauld, not only chaired his ancestor's firm but, in 1916, founded the art history school.

One more mind-bogglingly cliched phrase we didn't have room for in this column: Storm in a D-cup.

fields.trailText: In a report headed Teenage culture harming pupils, says Woodhead, page 14, February 12, we reminded readers that Mr Woodhead had "triggered a row by claiming that affairs between pupils could be 'educative'..." We should have said between pupils and teachers.
fields.body:
In a report headed Teenage culture harming pupils, says Woodhead, page 14, February 12, we reminded readers that Mr Woodhead had "triggered a row by claiming that affairs between pupils could be 'educative'..." We should have said between pupils and teachers.

Peter Tatchell, the subject of our profile, pages 6 and 7, Saturday Review, February 12, has asked us to point out that his attempted citizen's arrest of President Robert Mugabe last October was in protest at all human rights abuses in Zimbabwe - not just anti-gay abuses. The two Zimbabwean journalists whose treatment Tatchell highlighted were not, as we reported, "homosexual". There were a couple of mis takes in the panel that accompanied the profile. Peter Tatchell was born on January 25, 1952 (not January 21). He did his A-levels at night school at West London College (not in Melbourne).

John Willett has asked us to make it clear that he does not wish to be identified as the author of the obituary of Alan Pryce-Jones, page 22, February 9, on which his byline appeared. The material which he provided was subsumed, with some alterations, in the much longer piece that appeared and he was not consulted about the changes.

Contrary to what we said in Pass Notes yesterday, Angela Rippon was not the BBC's first female television news caster. The first was Nan Winton, who made her debut on June 20 1960.

The choir that sang at the Dome, mentioned in an article, page 18, yesterday, is the London Gay Men's Chorus, not the London Gay Male Voice Choir.

fields.headline: Focus: Thomson Travel
fields.trailText: Having been eased out of British Airways after a bloodletting there, Charles Gurassa has picked up the knife by the handle and carried out his own cull at Thomson Travel.
fields.body:
Having been eased out of British Airways after a bloodletting there, Charles Gurassa has picked up the knife by the handle and carried out his own cull at Thomson Travel.

In less than three months the new chief executive has changed chairman and finance director. Yesterday three more senior heads rolled but there were few shareholders mourning as the share price made a limited recovery, up 3p to 72p. As an investment, Thomson has been worse than a wet two weeks on the Costa Brava. Planeloads of private investors piled in at the 170p float price in May 1998 in order to win "Founders' Club" holiday discounts. But travel sector overcapacity plus a few self-inflicted wounds have produced profit warnings and a soggy stock price.

Gurassa is determined to change this. He has shown the door to chief operating officer Roger Burnell, company secretary Mark Knight and the chairman of the Crystal International subsidiary, Ian Smith. Gurassa has already brought in Charles Sankey from what was Reckitt & Colman to become chairman and appointed David Moloney from Avis Europe as finance director with effect from March 3.

A new human resources director has been appointed and headhunters are looking for a chief information technology officer and a group marketing director. Those in the new positions will all report direct to the former British Airways chief operating officer.

The removal of Gurassa and others did not make BA fly, and the new team at Thomson still has plenty to prove as the annual results to be published next month will show.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Peugeot leaps on takeover talk
fields.body:
Peugeot leaps on takeover talk

Shares in Peugeot jumped by more than 6% yesterday on reports that DaimlerChrysler was planning a bid for the French car maker. Peugeot said no discussions were currently under way, however, and DaimlerChrysler declined to comment on reports that it was in talks with members of the Peugeot family.

The support of the family, which owns 37% of Peugeot's voting shares and 25% of its non-voting shares, is seen as essential if any bid is to succeed.

Industry analysts said the market might have misinterpreted recent talks between the two companies on the possible use of a Peugeot platform for a new DaimlerChrysler small car.

EC blocks cash for Fiat

The European Commission yesterday blocked almost £15m worth of Italian government aid to car maker Fiat.

In a ruling which could have implications for British government aid for the Rover plant at Longbridge, the EC said neither the Italian government nor Fiat had been able to demonstrate that the state support had been necessary to ensure Fiat went ahead with investment in its Rivalta plant. "Italy has also failed to give sufficient evidence of the mobility of the project."

The question of mobility is central to the commission's inquiry into British government support for Longbridge.

The commission has expressed doubts about whether BMW, Rover's parent, seriously considered investing in a greenfield site in Hungary as an alternative to the Midlands plant.

BMW has, however, confirmed that it is to invest £470m in producing a new series of engines in Munich.

Ryanair opens new routes

Ryanair yesterday announced eight new routes to France, Italy, Germany, Sweden for this summer on the back of record passenger numbers last year.

The company said it would take delivery of a further five Boeing 737-800 series aircraft in May and June - bringing its fleet to 31 jet aircraft - which will launch the new European routes.

Chief executive, Michael O'Leary said: "Competition will ensure that the cost of air travel to and from the UK continues to fall, and Ryanair will continue to be the leader of the fast growth low fares market to and from the UK."

Call centre boost for Wales

One2One, part of Deutsche Telekom, is to create 1,000 jobs in Merthyr Tydfil, one of the Welsh valley towns most badly hit by the decline in traditional industries.

Details of a new call centre will be disclosed this morning by first secretary of Wales Rhodri Morgan. The centre is being built on a site at Rhyd-y-Car, where a large area of once derelict colliery land has been reclaimed.

webTitle: Britain gives up the fight against European art sale tax

fields.headline: Britain gives up the fight against European art sale tax
fields.trailText: Britain is expected today to give up the fight against a new Euro-tax on the London art market. The tax could wipe out more than 5,000 jobs and end Bond Street's international supremacy.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and Dan Atkinson
fields.body:
Britain is expected today to give up the fight against a new Euro-tax on the London art market. The tax could wipe out more than 5,000 jobs and end Bond Street's international supremacy.

"We have argued tenaciously for the British art market and British artists, but we have moved to a point where an agreement is not far off," one official in Brussels said.

The retreat brings to an end a battle stretching back to the early 1990s to shield Britain's world-beating auction houses and dealers from VAT and the droit de suite tax, which passes a slice of resale prices to an artist or heirs. Britain is to accept a compromise tabled in the autumn, although it will try throughout today to win some improvements to that package.

London art dealers claim that droit de suite will drive sellers away from the European Union altogether to rival centres such as New York, Tokyo and Switzerland, which do not levy the tax. But the government is unable to fight off the tax, which is a single-market measure and subject to majority voting.

It has lost the argument that London, as the EU's premier international art market, ought to be protected.

Later today, it is expected that the British official at the Brussels committee of permanent representatives to the EU will signal the end of resistance and acceptance of a harmonised droit de suite across the union. Although British sources denied any connection with the battle against a Europe-wide withholding tax, there were suspicions that Bond Street was being sacrificed to keep Britain's powder dry for the big battle to protect the City of London's lucrative Eurobond market.

In June last year, Britain gave way on VAT on imported works of art, which the EU insisted be harmonised at 5%, compared to Britain's special rate of 2.5%. But the government vowed to fight on against droit de suite, which the London market said was by far the more damaging tax.

Under droit de suite, any resale of an artist's work is taxed throughout the artist's lifetime and for 70 years after, and the money passed to the artist or his or her estate. France and Germany claim the tax provides income to impoverished "starving in the garret" painters, whereas Britain alleges that it benefits mostly a handful of wealthy artists who do not need the money.

The deal Britain is signing exempts art works sold for less than €2,500 (£1,750) and, more importantly, more than €10,000, which will protect the more expensive works of art in which Bond Street specialises.

But Anthony Browne, chairman of the British Art Market Federation, said any level of tax would damage London, given that none of its competitors charged at all. Furthermore, big sellers would be unwilling to split up lots for sale between London and non-EU centres.

webTitle: M&S glasnost may not pay off

fields.headline: M&S glasnost may not pay off
fields.standfirst: Julia Finch
fields.trailText: Since Philip Green withdrew his potential bid for Marks & Spencer last week the shares have been in yo-yo mode, and investors and analysts are split.
fields.body:
Since Philip Green withdrew his potential bid for Marks & Spencer last week the shares have been in yo-yo mode, and investors and analysts are split.

There are those - admittedly now a minority - who still believe a heavyweight bidder might emerge. Then there are others who think the shares have nowhere to go but further south.

Yesterday they closed down 8p at 229p. It is a miserable price - the lowest level in 10 years and barely a third of its October 1997 peak. At the current share price M&S is valued at just £6.6bn.

Take away the book value of the chain's property - £2.9bn in last year's report - along with the £1bn value of the financial services division, the £600m the group's overseas businesses might fetch, £60m of joint venture property and £100m of cash, and the UK retail business is valued at around £1.9bn.

There are analysts who still think that is too much. On a pan-European basis it is still highly rated for a retailer in distress. Salomons, for instance, reckons 200p is a fair value for the shares, which would value the group at £5.7bn and the UK retail business at about £1bn.

Yet there is also a growing number of analysts and investors that believes the new M&S formula will ultimately pay dividends and that it is now a classic long-term turnaround stock.

They are impressed with Belgian chairman Luc Vandevelde. They like the supply chain savings being driven through and M&S's new spirit of glasnost. It announced yesterday, for instance, that it would provide a trading update next month to fill the information vacuum which would otherwise have meant no news until the final results in May.

These investors should not hold their breath. As yet there is no proof that M&S's new strategy is paying off - no evidence that the designer ranges will win back shoppers or that the "lifestyles" approach to merchandising will win it any new friends.

The brand has lost much of its reputation and the smartest recent operators will not let M&S stride back in without a fight. A few years ago M&S was seen as a defensive stock. Now it is not one for widows and orphans.

webTitle: Strong pound puts Dyson in a spin

fields.headline: Strong pound puts Dyson in a spin
fields.standfirst: News Analysis: Entrepreneur threatens to take production abroad
fields.trailText: James Dyson, inventor of the bag-less vacuum cleaner, yesterday became the latest UK-based manufacturer to warn that the strong pound could force him to shift planned production overseas.
fields.body:
James Dyson, inventor of the bag-less vacuum cleaner, yesterday became the latest UK-based manufacturer to warn that the strong pound could force him to shift planned production overseas: from the Cotswolds town of Malmesbury to somewhere in the Far East.

His remarks, in a BBC Radio Five Live interview, come hot on the heels of evidence that Corus (the former British Steel and Dutch group Hoogovens) is considering plans to shut down all or part of its Llanwern strip-mill in south Wales and build up output in Ijmuiden, in the heart of the euro zone.

Sony, Toyota, Nissan, Ford and Vauxhall have all voiced concerns, very loudly in private and not so sotto voce in public, that sterling's strength and continuing uncertainty over Britain's entry to the euro could soon see the merits of investing here wiped out by the greater advantages of production in euroland. Like Mr Dyson, they will keep current sites open but put future investment abroad.

Last night, at the Engineering Employers Federation (EEF) biennial dinner, Bruce Ralph, president, told Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary: "The narrow remit of the MPC [Bank of England monetary policy committee] unsupported by other fiscal measures must inevitably reinforce the view of much of our membership that house price inflation in the south-east, perhaps in part driven by City bonuses ... is a case of the tail wagging the dog."

He added: "We understand the issues and the pressures but, with the pound at a 14-year high, large sections of our industry are now hurting - and hurting badly - and something needs to be done."

Sir Brian Moffat, Corus chairman, who calculates that the old British Steel operations have lost £1bn in profits over the past three years through an over-valued pound, went further last week and said manufacturing in Britain was fighting for its existence.

Sterling, partly because it is a petro currency and oil prices have been at a nine-year high, nudging $30 (£18) a barrel or three times the level of 15 months ago, is already worth in excess of 8% more than it was last year when its average value was DM2.97.

And that, said Mr Dyson, is a 30% overvaluation, implying that a pound is now worth around DM2.40. In his designer slacks and T-shirt, Mr Dyson is an unconventional business executive who has stored up a series of pet hates, most notably Eddie George, the Bank's governor, whom he accuses of caring not a jot about manufacturing.

"Well, he's completely wrong about that. It's extremely important, it's a vital part of the economy," Mr Dyson told Five Live. Elsewhere he has said manufacturing is the engine-room of the whole economy.

But, as ever, there is more to this than a campaign against the MPC and its so-called fine-tuning of monetary policy to meet an alleged medium-term inflationary threat. Mr Dyson, who employs 1,800 workers in Malmesbury, Wiltshire, including those at his £20m hush-hush design centre, faces an outbreak of nimbyism against his plans for expansion.

The inventor, who has long promised to come up with a brand-new idea beyond variations on a bag-less cleaner theme and has yet to do so, may want to move to the Far East to be closer to his overseas markets - he exports up to £60m of output each year, including to Japan, and claims not to make a penny. He may well be seeking cheaper, more skilled labour.

But the real targets of his ire are restrictive planning regulations, uncertain economic policy and the nimbyism which, he claims, are putting at risk Britain's technology and industrial competitiveness. Equally, however, his cleaners, which commanded some 70% of the British market, are facing stiffer competition from domestic (and foreign) rivals who used to scoff at his appliances. "If we do not become a global player within five years we will be swallowed up."

He sees the euro zone as the marketplace in which he succeeds or fails in his ambitions and is an enthusiast for early British entry. His remarks found a strong echo in Sir Ken Jackson of the AEEU, the labour movement's most active euro supporter. "It does not mean that the jobs will go tomorrow but will drift abroad over a period and the longer-term future of Britain as a manufacturing nation will be blighted," he said. "Ministers had better understand that if we delay entry too long there may be nothing left to save."

But the evidence is that ministers are convinced UK industry can live with a strong pound and, indeed, cut costs further and close the productivity gap with our euro zone neighbours. Digby Jones, the new CBI director general, has suggested manufacturing can cope with a DM2.80 exchange rate - above the DM2.60 once thought propitious for Britain's entry to the euro but well short of current levels.

Even the EEF, which identified a 6% productivity growth in its latest quarterly survey, has begun to talk of living with a strong pound and to desist from calling for instant devaluation or cuts in borrowing costs as the panacea for all manufacturing's ills.

Last night Mr Bruce, its president, joined forces with Mr Dyson in pointing out that even services depend on industry. Manufacturing, he said, may represent just 22% of GDP -and falling - "but you can add 15% or so for support services and businesses and it punches way above its weight in accounting for 60% of exports."

At a time when investors are shunning heavyweight sectors, forcing their shares down disproportionately, Mr Bruce and Mr Dyson are putting themselves at the head of an informal campaign to save British manufacturing. It is an open question, though, whether Messrs Byers, George and their colleagues are listening.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The FTSE 100 share index clung on to close above the 6,000 level yesterday, but it was a close call. The index has not closed below 6,000 since October, but yesterday it came within six points of losing that record.
fields.body:
The FTSE 100 share index clung on to close above the 6,000 level yesterday, but it was a close call. The index has not closed below 6,000 since October, but yesterday it came within six points of losing that record.

As usual these days Vodafone was a key influence on the market as the shares shed almost 6% to 310p in hefty volume. Dealers said overseas investors getting Vodafone through the merger with Mannesmann are running up against restrictions on the amount of UK stocks they can hold.

Barclays was in the spotlight after excellent figures and a trenchant statement from new chief executive Matthew Barrett which caught the City's eye although the shares closed only a modest 5p higher at £14.38.

Elsewhere in the banking sector, however, Lloyds TSB shares were down 37p at 561p, while Royal Bank of Scotland shares were down 20p at 787p.

Traders reckon both suffered from investors switching into Barclays and RBS is seen as having plenty on its plate in integrating National Westminster , up 4p at £11.37.

Another heavyweight reporting figures yesterday was BP Amoco , down 8p at 475p. The group's fourth quarter figures were seen as slightly disappointing and the absence of news on either the share buy-back programme or the ongoing dispute with the US authorities over the proposed acquisition of Atlantic Richfield was seen as a drag, too.

Utilities, often overshadowed by hi-tech stocks, were back in favour with investors attracted by what are being perceived in some quarters as undemanding ratings.

BG was up 8p at 267p, Scottish Power climbed 11p to 425p and Centrica was up 11p on the day at 184p.

Housebuilders found themselves in the doldrums, hit by what was seen as a fairly hefty hint from the governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, on Monday night that interest rates are likely to rise again, while reports that the government was looking at the possibility of taxing housebuilding added to the sense of depression.

Beazer Group was down 5p to 103p while Bryant fell 6p to 96p.

Hi-tech stockbroker Durlacher continued its recent strong run as the shares powered 182p to £39.50 which puts them up by more than £5 so far this week.

Another stock firmly in favour yesterday was Psion , climbing 634p to 4,360p as its Symbian consortium announced a link-up with IBM.

webTitle: BA share price dives to eight-year low

fields.headline: BA share price dives to eight-year low
fields.standfirst: Airline's market plunge breaks hostage to fortune pledge made by Ayling
fields.trailText: British Airways share price plunged yesterday to an eight-year low and closed below the level chief executive Bob Ayling pledged would never be breached. Some analysts speculated that the airline may be vulnerable to takeover.
fields.body:
British Airways share price plunged yesterday to an eight-year low and closed below the level chief executive Bob Ayling pledged would never be breached. Some analysts speculated that the airline may be vulnerable to takeover.

Mr Ayling made himself a hostage to fortune when he promised staff in November that shares in the world's favourite airline would "never" fall below 275p.

But after flirting with that crucial level for several days they slid to 261p by the market's close yesterday, 15p or 5% down on the day, placing a question mark over the high-profile chief executive.

City sources who have been watching the gradual fall were anticipating last night that a bid would be made for BA if the shares fell much further.

One source said: "The institutions have been rapidly moving out of BA. It is a quality company and the share price is ridiculously low, but it is the perception people have about BA that it is not being properly managed." There has been speculation that Granada might move in on the company.

While the BA share slide is part of a general market movement away from such "traditional" companies to the new dot.com shares, senior institutional investors criticised Mr Ayling for making the 275p pledge in the first place.

Mr Ayling made the promise last November, when he wrote to employees concerned about the plunging value of their BA shares at a time when they were trading at around 275p. "We are never going back to that price again," Mr Ayling said in a staff newsletter.

That attracted the attention of Sir Richard Branson, the owner of Virgin Altantic, BA's bitter rival, who said that he would start buying shares in BA if the share price sank below 275p.

But last night Virgin stressed that it was no longer interested in building up a stake since its deal with Singapore Airlines, which has bought a 49% share in Virgin Atlantic.

A senior fund manager admitted that he was "conscious of the share price move". In fact, he said, "many investors are conscious of it".

In spite of Mr Ayling's pledge on his share price - described by one investor as "daft" - shareholders were not calling for his head last night, giving him the benefit of the doubt because of the overall weakness in the market.

But he was facing questions about his high-profile image as a friend of the prime minister, Tony Blair, as director of the Millennium Dome and chief sponsor of the London Eye wheel on the Thames.

This is said by some to be potentially damaging to his status in the City and a potential distraction from his £550,000 job of running BA, one of the country's biggest companies with 63,000 staff.

"It's the curse of the Dome, although at least the [London] Eye is spinning," a top fund manager said.

Even a fund manager who is very supportive of BA said: "You should never set yourself up with targets like [the 275p share price]."

Shareholders said they were giving Mr Ayling a few weeks of breathing space while they established whether the share price move was of his own making or a general problem related to market sentiment.

Last night investors were still giving Mr Ayling credit for his strategy of cutting costs by £1bn in the past five years with a further £225m in cuts due by the end of March.

They also welcomed the decision to reduce staff by 1,000 by March and by a further 6,500 over the next three years through voluntary means.

BA last night agreed that Mr Ayling had made a pledge but said the company had felt the effects of shareholder interest in e-commerce firms. "We are not alone," a spokesman said.

BA said top managers in the past few days had shown their confidence in the airline by putting their own money into the business - including the chief financial officer, who had bought 30,000 shares.

fields.headline: Business failures up 44% in Japan
fields.trailText: Japan yesterday suffered its second high-profile bankruptcy in three days, overshadowing government claims that the economy is picking up.
fields.body:
Japan yesterday suffered its second high-profile bankruptcy in three days, overshadowing government claims that the economy is picking up.

The collapse of property developer L Kakuei, with debts of 135bn yen (£760m) came as figures revealed that corporate failures increased in January by 44% year on year - the third monthly rise.

Three days ago Japan's retail sector suffered its biggest bankruptcy when the supermarket chain Nagasakiya, which has 95 outlets, sought court protection from creditors with liabilities of ¥380bn.

Although the failures are seen as a necessary part of the pain of restructuring they are likely to dampen consumer confidence and add to an unemployment rate that stands close to a record high.

The news comes at a politically sensitive time, with parliament in the middle of a debate on a record ¥85 trillion budget and a general election due before October.

It also comes just weeks before the announcement of data which are expected to show that Japan tipped back into recession at the end of last year.

Despite huge infusions of public money and a 0% lending rate, the economy has contracted for seven of the past nine quarters.

In a new report, however, the government reiterated its view that the economy was "improving mildly", thanks to an upturn in industrial output and capital investment.

fields.headline: Profits leap at BP Amoco
fields.trailText: BP Amoco cut 18,000 jobs last year - three times more than originally expected - as part of a massive restructuring which helped secure a 40% increase in 1999 profits.
fields.body:
BP Amoco cut 18,000 jobs last year - three times more than originally expected - as part of a massive restructuring which helped secure a 40% increase in 1999 profits.

Further staff reductions are on the way but chairman Sir John Browne said yesterday they would be small compared to the clear-out that immediately resulted from BP's £30bn takeover of Amoco.

Meanwhile, the oil group tried to reassure the City that it had a vibrant growth policy, should court action allow its planned £16.8bn takeover of Atlantic Richfield (Arco) to be blocked by the US regulator.

But the share price of the world's second largest oil group fell 7.5p to 474p as investors remained disappointed by the low-key presentation at a time when oil prices hit a nine-year high.

Sir John said Arco was "only one strand in our strategy" and the group would bring forward a range of exciting development projects from the US gulf to Angola as part of a $26bn (£16.25bn) internal investment programme by 2001. He hinted that substantial acquisitions could not be ruled out in the event of the Arco deal going down.

But the company unveiled a major share buyback programme worth up to £9bn. Sir John will apply for permission to acquire up to 10% of BP Amoco's shares at the next annual meeting, in April.

The cost-cutting drive would continue as part of a march towards $4bn worth of savings by 2001. The vast bulk of the 18,000 job losses came from the United States through voluntary redundancy.

Sir John said BP Amoco remained well on track to meet the targets laid out in July last year, with more than half the targeted performance improvements achieved in a third of the time. "This gives me great confidence that we are positioned to take advantage of the growth opportunities which we have for the new century," he added.

BP Amoco shares last week hit an 11-month low despite expectations of record fourth quarter earnings which were realised yesterday. Adjusted replacement cost profits before exceptionals grew by 145% to $2.123bn in the same period the year before. For the full year, headline profits increased by 40% to $6.21bn.

The exploration and development arm also saw fourth quarter profits rise, from $442m to $2.63bn.

webTitle: Inspector warns of dirty water in pipeline

fields.headline: Inspector warns of dirty water in pipeline
fields.trailText: Water companies were warned yesterday that they faced prosecution if they delivered poor drinking water - even if it was the fault of a new supplier using their network.
fields.body:
Water companies were warned yesterday that they faced prosecution if they delivered poor drinking water - even if it was the fault of a new supplier using their network.

Michael Rouse, the chief in spector of the drinking water inspectorate, said the quality of drinking water must not be compromised as a result of the competition act which comes into effect on March 1.

The act opens the way for common carriage, under which a new supplier can deliver water to its customers using the distribution networks of the established water companies.

Mr Rouse warned companies to be careful about accepting water from new sources. "Some new water sources will be wholly incompatible with water suppliers' present sources," he said.

He added that the owners of distribution pipelines must retain full control of the flow and pressure of any inputs by new suppliers and must include the detailed arrangements in any contract with the supplier.

webTitle: Retailers count cost of pricing restraint

fields.headline: Retailers count cost of pricing restraint
fields.trailText: The delicacy of the Bank of England's task in setting interest rates was starkly highlighted yesterday when the office for national statistics unveiled its latest snapshot of price pressures in the economy.
fields.body:
The delicacy of the Bank of England's task in setting interest rates was starkly highlighted yesterday when the office for national statistics unveiled its latest snapshot of price pressures in the economy.

On the face of it, the data were good. Consumers are sniffing out bargains in the shops, inflation excluding mortgages remains doggedly below the government's target and Britain is Europe's standard-bearer for price stability. Of the 2.1% increase in underlying inflation over the past 12 months, the most important single factor has been the surge in oil prices. Production curbs by the Opec cartel and stronger world demand have meant that the price of a barrel of crude has soared since this time last year, pushing up the cost of petrol by almost a fifth.

On an admittedly rough and ready basis, the 19% increase in the cost of petrol and oil has contributed 0.7 percentage points to the 2.1% annual inflation rate. Without the increase, underlying inflation would stand at around 1.4%, below the level at which the governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, would have to write to the chancellor in explaining why inflation was so low.

Most analysts believe that the latest inflation figures will give the Bank pause for thought, and they are probably right. Base rates have gone up four times in the past six months, and it will be hard for the monetary policy committee to justify further increases unless there is strong evidence that the government's target would be breached without further tightening.

However, while the Bank might be prepared to suck it and see for the next few months, it is likely to be concerned by the UK's reliance on a strong pound for keeping the cost of living low. At present, the high exchange rate is making imports cheaper, keeping the lid on the prices of goods. But if sterling were to fall - as the Bank has been predicting for some time - the price of goods in the shops would rise unless retailers were prepared to reduce profit margins.

Sellers of domestic services have had life far easier than clothing and footwear stores or shops selling videos and mobile phones. Prices of insurance and holidays have risen as the economy has entered its ninth year of expansion, and show little sign of responding to higher interest rates.

While it is normal for inflation in services to be higher than that for goods, the extent of the divergence is unusual. According to Michael Saunders of Salomon Smith Barney Citibank, core services inflation stands at 5.6% and has been nearly 2% above overall inflation on average since 1988. If normal service were restored, inflation excluding mortgages would be 3.6%, well above the government's target.

Some economists argue that this sort of analysis has been made redundant by the new-paradigm economy. But Mr Saunders said that if services inflation remains strong the only way for the government to hit its 2.5% target would be if there were a sharp drop in the cost of retail goods or food.

On the face of it, the data were good. Consumers are sniffing out bargains in the shops, inflation excluding mortgages remains doggedly below the government's target and Britain is Europe's standard-bearer for price stability. Of the 2.1% increase in underlying inflation over the past 12 months, the most important single factor has been the surge in oil prices. Production curbs by the Opec cartel and stronger world demand have meant that the price of a barrel of crude has soared since this time last year, pushing up the cost of petrol by almost a fifth. On an admittedly rough and ready basis, the 19% increase in the cost of petrol and oil has contributed 0.7 percentage points to the 2.1% annual inflation rate. Without the increase, underlying inflation would stand at around 1.4%, below the level at which the governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, would have to write to the chancellor in explaining why inflation was so low. Most analysts believe that the latest inflation figures will give the Bank pause for thought, and they are probably right. Base rates have gone up four times in the past six months, and it will be hard for the monetary policy committee to justify further increases unless there is strong evidence that the government's target would be breached without further tightening. However, while the Bank might be prepared to suck it and see for the next few months, it is likely to be concerned by the UK's reliance on a strong pound for keeping the cost of living low. At present, the high exchange rate is making imports cheaper, keeping the lid on the prices of goods. But if sterling were to fall - as the Bank has been predicting for some time - the price of goods in the shops would rise unless retailers were prepared to reduce profit margins. Sellers of domestic services have had life far easier than clothing and footwear stores or shops selling videos and mobile phones. Prices of insurance and holidays have risen as the economy has entered its ninth year of expansion, and show little sign of responding to higher interest rates. While it is normal for inflation in services to be higher than that for goods, the extent of the divergence is unusual. According to Michael Saunders of Salomon Smith Barney Citibank, core services inflation stands at 5.6% and has been nearly 2% above overall inflation on average since 1988. If normal service were restored, inflation excluding mortgages would be 3.6%, well above the government's target. Some economists argue that this sort of analysis has been made redundant by the new-paradigm economy. But Mr Saunders said that if services inflation remains strong the only way for the government to hit its 2.5% target would be if there were a sharp drop in the cost of retail goods or food.

fields.headline: Channel 5 hits £1bn big time
fields.standfirst: Founders buy out American shareholder
fields.trailText: Channel 5, a month shy of its third birthday, was yesterday valued at £1bn when three of the station's founding shareholders agreed to increase their stakes in the business by buying out US venture capital fund Warburg Pincus.
fields.body:
Channel 5, a month shy of its third birthday, was yesterday valued at £1bn when three of the station's founding shareholders agreed to increase their stakes in the business by buying out US venture capital fund Warburg Pincus.

United News & Media and Luxembourg-based broadcaster CLT-Ufa each paid £61m to take their shareholdings in Channel 5 from 29% to 35%. Pearson, which has assets ranging from Penguin Books to the Financial Times, spent £51m to raise its stake from 24% to 29.25%.

The implied valuation is the first since the channel went on air and underlines its progress after a launch which drew criticism for the quality of its programming and its transmission signals.

In its first 33 months on air, up to the end of last year, Channel 5 recorded advertising sales of £413m and the business is expected to make an operating profit of up to £16m this year.

The changing ownership structure at the channel, however, also has a less palatable side for the two British shareholders.

United News has just 20% of the voting rights in Channel 5 and consequently does not have to include its stake when calculating its share of the national TV audience.

But by increasing its stake, United News will be forced to account for half the audience of Channel 5. That means its combined share with putative merger partner Carlton Communications would be 17.5%, breaching the 15% barrier imposed by legislation and leading to likely disposals if the deal goes through.

For Pearson, the greater stake means the company, which makes The Bill and This is Your Life, will potentially lose its status as an "independent" producer. Since 1991, at least 25% of all programming broadcast has to be produced by independents, which gives the tag a valuable status.

Pearson Television chief executive Richard Eyre, who will be joining the Channel 5 board, said: "By increasing our investment in Channel 5 we are demonstrating both our satisfaction in its performance so far and our confidence in its future."

Warburg Pincus's decision to sell was prompted by an approach from programme maker Flextech but the existing shareholders were given the opportunity to match the bid.

Mathew Horsman, media analyst at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite, described the valuation of Channel 5 as a little "racy" but said the business enjoyed strong prospects. "A lot of people were quite gloomy about Channel 5 when it launched but this company will make a lot of money for its shareholders. For the best part it has delivered on what it promised."

One week last September was the channel's biggest to date when it featured the science fiction film Independence Day and the England versus Poland football Euro 2000 qualifier, and its share of total British viewing reached 8.2%.

Channel 5 now reaches 19.6m British homes, about 81% of the population.

webTitle: Poorer nations urged to press for WTO talks

fields.headline: Poorer nations urged to press for WTO talks
fields.trailText: Developing countries should use their new-found muscle within the world trading system to kickstart global trading talks which broke down in Seattle last November
fields.body:
Developing countries should use their new-found muscle within the world trading system to kickstart global trading talks which broke down in Seattle last November, international development secretary Clare Short said yesterday.

It was clear that a new round could not start until the developing world was confident of big gains in access to western markets, she told the Guardian. She believed developing countries could dominate a revived negotiating round.

They make up three-quarters of WTO membership and, frustrated at being locked out of important sessions in Seattle, pulled the plug as the US and the European Union were inching towards an agreement. "People have woken up to the fact that we can't have trade rounds any more without the developing world taking part."

Officials admit a full-scale WTO round is unlikely because the Americans will be unable to negotiate a potentially explosive trade agreement in the run-up to the November presidential election.

The Unctad conference in Bangkok this week was billed as a chance for rich and poor countries to bridge some of the gaps which opened in Seattle. Ms Short said she hoped the 170-nation gathering would dispel some of the "sourness" of the collapsed talks.

In a sign that some Seattle wounds are healing, the conference endorsed Britain's call for tariff- and quota-free access to western markets for the 48 poorest countries. However, Unctad is not a negotiating body so the endorsement is simply an aspiration with no timescale.

In a speech to the conference today, Ms Short will warn developing countries that they risk exclusion if they resist opening their markets to foreign goods and investment. She fears many will be marginalised from the gains globalisation could bring them.

webTitle: Barrett's talk of targets woos the City

fields.headline: Barrett's talk of targets woos the City
fields.standfirst: Barclays chief has much to prove
fields.trailText: This is culture shock for Barclays' old guard. The suave, smooth-talking chief executive pushed out management theories, set targets and pledged cost cuts. And all the time, addressing his audience at yesterday's final figures presentation, the new boss of Barclays was sitting on a white box, legs crossed, skin tanned.
fields.body:
This is culture shock for Barclays' old guard. The suave, smooth-talking chief executive pushed out management theories, set targets and pledged cost cuts. And all the time, addressing his audience at yesterday's final figures presentation, the new boss of Barclays was sitting on a white box, legs crossed, skin tanned.

If nothing else, Matthew - "call me Matt" - Barrett talked and looked a good story. Indeed, the Irish-Canadian, with his ageing matinee idol looks, tried his hardest to charm the City. Breaking his silence since his October arrival at Barclays - just days after Bank of Scotland launched its (failed) bid for NatWest - Matt talked "shareholder value".

He set targets - for costs, profits and market share - so loved by the City, and produced the kind of management speak usually only tolerated from Sir Brian Pitman of Lloyds TSB, the godfather of the banking sector.

Matt highlighted the fact that Barclays has just a 4% share of mortgages but a 20% slice of current accounts. He will take personal control of Barclaycard, the credit card business, and allow the fund managers at Barclays Global Investors the chance to take shares in their own business.

Matt promised to "slice and dice" his customer data base to sell his customers more products. Bravely, he predicted the end of the dot.com start-up hype within five years, asserting that today's established brands will reinvent themselves, and at the same time promised to woo the City with his internet bank at a presentation next month.

Through adoption of "value based management" - a favourite of Sir Brian at Lloyds TSB - he will decide which of his businesses are delivering "shareholder value". Those which are not, will be sold off, with out any sentimentality or excuses. Barclays Capital, the rump investment bank, received some reassurance about its much-doubted future. With risky positions closed out, Barclays Capital turned 1998's Russian debacle and £270m of losses to £316m of profits last year.

Matt said it was spurious to ask whether a business should be diversified or focused. More important is that all the bits of the business are churning out value for shareholders.

And, while predicting more consolidation in the financial sector, Matt showed his sensitivity to the City's current apathy towards deals and refused to make pledges about the role Barclays would play on the merger stage.

In true North American style, Matt is changing the incentives for his top managers. The new remuneration deal will link options and bonuses to the share performance against 11 of their banking peers. It is a tiered structure, which means that bonuses go unpaid if the shares and profits do not make the mark. If they do, however, the rewards will be bigger than before - and if they don't there will not be any award whatsoever.

But while he promised to "walk the talk", and avoid the falls of, in Texan speak, being "all hat and no cattle", he takes the helm when the sector backdrop is looking as shaky as it has looked years. Hats, cattle, talk and all, Matt will surely have to run rather walk if he is going to prove to the City's old guard that he can beat these "anorexic little virtual banks".

Price of a punt

Yesterday as Britain was laying claim to having the lowest inflation in the European Union Irish inflation was hitting its highest level for 10 years.

The snag is that there is nothing the Irish central bank can do. Interest rates are set in Frankfurt and with the policy needs of the big euro zone economies rather than the smaller ones more in mind. As a result, Ireland has standard euro zone interest rates of 3.25% but far from standard growth rates - maybe 8% again this year - and a harmonised inflation rate that could hit 4.5%.

Ireland is in serious risk of breaching the inflation criterion laid down in the Maastricht treaty on monetary union although, as one Irish economist noted yesterday, that was then, this is now.

It is possible to argue that worries about Irish inflation are overstated. Energy costs and a big increase in tobacco duties have had a significant influence. So has the low exchange rate. If the oil price stabilises, the government holds back on further increases on cigarettes and the exchange rate recovers then inflation will start to fall back. In other words, Irish inflation is being driven by external factors rather than domestic overheating.

That sounds just a little too comfortable. The government is about to give the economy a near £1bn shot in the arm through tax concessions and higher spending. Breathtaking growth rates must have an impact, too.

Certainly there can be few in Dublin who would deny that if monetary policy were being set by the Bank of Ireland, not the ECB, Irish interest rates would be around double their present level.

fields.headline: The drugs bard
fields.standfirst: All-black musicals are rare enough. But all-black, Shakespeare-inspired musicals about crack dealers...  Anita Chaudhuri on the story of Poison
fields.trailText: All-black musicals are rare enough. But all-black, Shakespeare-inspired musicals about crack dealers... Anita Chaudhuri on the story of Poison.
fields.body:
Backstage at the Tricycle Theatre, London, six actors are rehearsing a musical version of Othello. A dude in jeans and a T-shirt marked "Posh Boy" urges them on. "In Gangland, it's getting dark. It's getting late, your heart begins to palpitate, in Gangland," they chant, crouching on the floor.

When South African author and director David Kramer calls this all-black production a "loose reworking" of Shakespeare's tragedy he isn't joking. Poison is set in a club on a north London housing estate and concerns Michael, a corrupt club owner, Lyric, a singer addicted to crack, Poison, his dealer, and Pam, an anti-drugs campaigner. The story tackles racism, the music business and gangsterism. The production was originally staged in Cape Town, and has been reworked for Britain by playwright Jenny McLeod.

Before McLeod flew to Cape Town to meet Kramer, she had never seen a musical. "Why would I bother? A West End musical seems so alien to my own experience."

Kramer and his musical director Taliep Petersen challenge this by marrying politics with the optimism of musical theatre. "In Cape Town we've worked at getting people from the mixed race and black community to go to the theatre. It's seen as a bourgeois activity; that's true for British audiences as well," explains Kramer. "We create musicals because that's what we do best, but I think it's useful for black audiences to have characters they can identify with.

"We did a show called District Six, which is a red light area of our city, and it featured drug dealers, hookers and pimps. People in the area loved it because they saw themselves being represented on stage." At the peak of its run, tickets for District Six were changing hands for thousands of rands on the black market, an unheard of occurrence in local theatre.

In 1998 the pair won two Olivier Awards for their musical Kat and the Kings, based on the Cavalla Kings, a 50s South African pop group who struggled for recognition in Cape Town, where both Kramer and Petersen grew up. But Kat and the Kings was set in the past. Like other compilation music shows, such as Five Guys Named Moe and Ain't Misbehavin', it was in the main good fun. Black Theatre Co-op's 1998 hit Up Against the Wall was set in the present day but even they harked back to the 70s disco era.

Musicals tend to reflect a skewed version of reality, but there have been few attempts to introduce contemporary black and Asian storylines through song and dance - despite the fact that music and dance are the dominant forms of creative expression for those cultures. Dropping the happy ending and addressing politics within the conventions of a musical is a big risk. The multi-racial musical Rent was a hit in the US, but audiences here found its saccharine take on Aids and addiction harder to stomach.

By highlighting the negative aspects of black culture there could be a backlash. "I was worried about that at first," admits McLeod. "But I think these are valid issues that our community does have to address."

She claims that she found it difficult conveying complex issues in the gaps between 23 songs. "In the original version the female characters were doormats. I had to make them stronger because I knew British women wouldn't accept them."

Back in the theatre, an addiction counsellor has visited the cast to talk about the effects of crack on social and emotional development. "I'm supposed to feel numb, right? So would I be bothering to chase this woman?" asks Koffi Missah, who plays Lyric. Missah has been working in West End musicals since he got a part in the original Starlight Express in 1984. He claims that for a black actor, musicals are a tough career option because casting directors are reluctant to offer them parts which are not defined by race. "I've been lucky because I have always had work but that is not true of everyone. There simply aren't enough parts being written for us."

Mykal Rand, who plays Michael, "the Othello character", has had similar experiences. "Things are getting better - the Lion King and Jesus Christ Superstar have both been great. But for years I wanted to do Les Miserables and they wouldn't cast a black actor. I was attracted to Poison because I think people will relate it to what is happening in London now. That's not something you can say about many musicals."

Rand admits that he too feared that the show was presenting a negative image of black culture. "But there is a positive message, that it is possible to kick the habit. These issues shouldn't be swept under the carpet. For too long, musicals have only been selling a fantasy life and here is something real."

With such enthusiasm surrounding his project, Kramer should be feeling optimistic. Nothing could be further from the truth. "I'm terrified!" he wails. "It's far more terrifying than Cape Town."

Poison is at Tricycle Theatre, London NW6 (0171-328 1000), from tomorrow.
