webTitle: To most people he's Alf Garnett, foul-mouthed racist. His daughters call him Bully Bottom

fields.headline: To most people he's Alf Garnett, foul-mouthed racist. His daughters call him Bully Bottom
fields.standfirst: There's more to Warren Mitchell than meets the eye,  Lyn Gardner discovers.
fields.trailText: Warren Mitchell has made a career out of playing miserable old gits. Most famously there was racist bigot Alf Garnett, the loud-mouthed, bad-tempered, working class Tory voter in Johnny Speight's groundbreaking 60s kitchen sink sitcom, Till Death Us Do Part.
fields.body:
Warren Mitchell has made a career out of playing miserable old gits. Most famously there was racist bigot Alf Garnett, the loud-mouthed, bad-tempered, working class Tory voter in Johnny Speight's groundbreaking 60s kitchen sink sitcom, Till Death Us Do Part.

Five years ago he played King Lear, an angry old man having a spot of bother with his daughters. "I know what that feels like," says Mitchell cheerily, confiding that in moments of domestic tension his own family call him "bully bottom". Perhaps Lear's daughters should have had the courage to call him "bully bottom" and told him to stop playing the fool.

Mitchell's latest miserable git is Mr Green, the anti-hero of Jeff Robson's New York comedy Visiting Mr Green. Mr Green is not a happy man. An orthodox Jew, he is elderly, infirm and lives four flights up in a New York tenement block. His beloved wife has recently died, and he hasn't seen his daughter for years. He wants to be left alone. But every Thursday night, Ross Gardiner, a young corporate executive ordered to do community service, insists on visiting him. Soon this odd couple forge an unlikely relationship.

Playing Green is a bit of a stretch for Mitchell. The old man is 86; Mitchell is a stripling at 74. Although, in his food-stained shirt and with his wild haystack eyebrows, Mitchell could easily pass for Methuselah. Mitchell's approach to character owes much to method acting. Halfway through the meal I realise that I'm having lunch with two people, both the fictional Mr Green and Mitchell. One is a bit of a misery guts who complains about the food, the other is a wizened pixie with an Australian suntan, a string of anecdotes and plenty of reasons to be cheerful.

After more than 30 years of playing Garnett, Mitchell is now hitting his prime. There's a lot of acting in the old boy yet. "You don't retire in this business, you just notice that the phone hasn't rung for 10 years," he quips. He's an actor who has always made his own luck, bringing a foolish humanity to the appalling Garnett and scarring the character into the nation's psyche as he reflected all the postwar resentment and prejudice that was swilling around in the nation's consciousness.

He wasn't even first choice for the role: Peter Sellers, Leo McKern and Lionel Jeffries all turned Alf down. But Mitchell recognised the subversive brilliance of Speight's foul-mouthed creation and gave Alf's spleen and foolishness full rein. The fact that Mitchell was Jewish was part of the joke. He likes it spread thickly, as if making up for lost time.

When he read in the paper that Jude Kelly was thinking about directing King Lear, he wrote and suggested himself for the part. He thinks it's high time he had a go at Prospero. He doesn't understand actors who get tired of the challenges. When he was asked what his idea of perfect happiness was, he said it was waking up in the morning and knowing that he wouldn't have to play Lear that night. I like nothing more than waking up and knowing I'm going to play Lear."

Mr Green isn't Lear, but it is a meaty role and one he has already tried out successfully in Australia, where he now lives for a substantial part of the year. He became an Australian citizen in 1989, warms to the people's lack of guilt about enjoying themselves, and says he has used the place quite shamelessly to get to play the roles he wants and feels that he'd never be considered for here. "I'd never have got to play Norman in The Dresser, or be in Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? here." In Australia he played Lear 17 years before he got the chance in Britain.

Visiting Mr Green takes him back to his own roots in London's Jewish East End. Like Green's family, Mitchell's grandparents were Russian Jews who fled to Britain in 1910. His grandmother opened a fish and chip shop in Stoke Newington, reasoning that whether times were good or bad people always ate fish and chips. "I've always wanted a fish and chip shop to fall back on," says Mitchell, and he's not joking.

But Mitchell is a million miles away from Green. "Green is an orthodox Jew. I enjoy being Jewish, but I'm an atheist. Green is a fundamentalist and I hate fundamentalism in all its forms. Jews, Catholics, Baptists, I think they are all potty and capable of destroying the world."

And of breaking up families. Green is estranged from his daughter because she has married a gentile. After Mitchell married his wife, Connie, his own father, by no means an orthodox Jew and perfectly capable of keeping a kosher house for 50 weeks then eating bacon sandwiches on the family's annual Clacton holiday, would not meet her for two years because she was not Jewish. "He'd ring me every day and ask me 'Are you eating son?'." Eventually time and grandchildren healed the rift, but Mitchell understands the kind of gulf that people like Green can create.

"I was lucky with my dad. He was so proud of me. He loved being Alf Garnett's dad. I once made a sitcom called Men of Affairs with Brian Rix. It wasn't good. After the first episode was broadcast dad rang me and asked 'How many did you make?' 'Seventeen.' There was a long pause, then he said: 'I couldn't go to the office this morning. I was too ashamed.' "

fields.headline: Bird brains
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: A survey by Office Angels showed yesterday that managers now communicate in language none of them understands.
fields.body:
A survey by Office Angels showed yesterday that managers now communicate in language none of them understands. This is not in itself surprising, as "management-speak" has long been a byword for babble. What is surprising is the admission that its very creators can't follow it, particularly since it isn't difficult to guess. What do the one in five office workers who don't understand "touch base" think it means? And "ahead of the curve"? They might be clumsy locutions, but when a man with a flip chart uses them, you can be fairly sure he isn't referring to baseball.

The boom in such risible jargon has coincided with a growth in the number of management positions, usually as titular substitutes for proper pay and with bracketed put-downs, such as Junior Manager (Paperclips). This has devalued managers' status and they have realised, with a shudder, that a canary, given a little training, could cover their responsibilities. Buzzwords are meant to reassure them what they say can't be accessed by the ordinary pleb in the street. Which becomes tricky when they stop understanding it themselves.

There are no second chances in catering, especially when the offence involves missiles. Thus was Claude Raude, a 28-year-old waiter, sacked for throwing garlic bread across the kitchen at a bistro in West Sussex. Claude thought the punishment unduly harsh and sued for unfair dismissal, not at tribunal but via the much fantasised medium of matches and gasoline. After causing £70,000 of damage, he was this week jailed for two and a half years, which is a long time to serve for garlic bread.

webTitle: Royle is rebuked for his view on women

fields.headline: Royle is rebuked for his view on women
fields.trailText: The Football Association continued its crusade to protect the game's image yesterday by rebuking Joe Royle for a politically incorrect outburst against women officials.
fields.body:
The Football Association continued its crusade to protect the game's image yesterday by rebuking Joe Royle for a politically incorrect outburst against women officials.

The Manchester City manager had expressed disapproval at the appointment of the Dorset official Wendy Toms to run the line at the Worthington Cup final, causing much consternation at Lancaster Gate at a time when the FA is trying to generate more female interest in the game.

"Joe's remarks are both regrettable and ill-considered," said a spokesman. "Wendy is joint top of the list of assistant referees in an independent assessment based on merit. Sadly, some people hold views which make it difficult for her when she deserves credit rather than criticism."

In his programme notes for last Saturday's match against Norwich City, Royle wrote: "I'm not sexist but I don't approve of female officials in professional football. How can they make accurate decisions if they have never been tackled from behind by a 14st centre-half, elbowed in the ribs or even caught offside?

"There is only one sport in which men and women compete equally against each other and that is equestrianism. Yet we are now going to have one officiating at the Worthington Cup final. How must many of the long-serving officials feel who have never had such a big game?

"I am going to be accused of being sexist but too many people are trying to be politically correct and no one is prepared to voice the other opinion."

Toms, 37, has been running the line at Premiership matches since 1997 and refereed last season's women's FA Cup final. She joined the FA's list of assistant referees in 1994.

Tranmere Rovers will lodge a formal complaint with the Football League after being awarded 5,000 fewer tickets than Leicester City for the Worthington Cup final. The First Division club sold the last of their allocation of 29,500 on Saturday only to learn yesterday that their Premiership rivals had been allotted 34,500.

"This really is a quite disgraceful way in which to treat one of the finalists in a major final," said Lorraine Rogers, Tranmere's chairman and chief executive. "All the advance information we received about the distribution of tickets indicated that it would definitely be a 50-50 split.

"We have now discovered that the allocations were made in this way - were decided - before we had defeated Bolton Wanderers in our semi-final. There is something wrong in this industry. The key decisions do always seem to go against the smaller clubs."

Despite having an average home gate of only 7,000 this season, Tranmere swiftly disposed of their allocation.

Bobby Robson has begun his clear-out at Newcastle United, placing 13 players on the transfer list. Stephen Glass, who asked for a move last week, and Silvio Maric are the most notable names.

Chelsea have completed the signing of the Georgian Rati Aleksidze for an initial £126,000 from Dinamo Tbilisi.

fields.headline: Baroque adventure
fields.standfirst:
Maxim Vengerov/Trevor Pinnock
Barbican, London
****
fields.trailText:
Maxim Vengerov/Trevor Pinnock
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
Arch-authenticist Trevor Pinnock on concert grand, modern virtuoso Maxim Vengerov on baroque violin: this wasn't some parallel musical universe, but half of the historical cross-dressings of this unlikely duo's recital.

The first half charted a course through the baroque in solo and accompanied works by Bach, Handel and Corelli, with Pinnock taking his more accustomed place at the harpsichord. From the very beginning of Bach's B minor sonata for violin and keyboard, Vengerov demonstrated his assimilation of baroque performance practice. The sustained notes of the opening were caressed into life with vibratoless, chaste beauty. However, even in this tiny adagio, it was obvious that Vengerov's recently acquired historical awareness was not going to eclipse his naturally voluptuous phrasing and on-stage bravura.

There were drawbacks to this baroque flirtation. Vengerov sounded unfamiliar with the older violin's smaller dynamic range. Particularly in the faster movements of the Bach sonata, and in the extrovert invention of Corelli's Sonata La Follia, he over-compensated for the relative vastness of the Barbican's auditorium by straining at the limits of his instrument's delicate nature.

If the mix of Vengerov's instinctive musicianship and the rigour of historical practice did not always achieve a perfect balance of intellect and imagination, Vengerov was still able to produce transcendent playing. The famous Chaconne from Bach's D minor Partita for solo violin was a magnificent revelation of his consummate communicative skills. He moulded the major-key oasis at the work's centre with reflective grace, and brought Bach's complex polyphony to life with vivid use of the instrument's colours.

In the second half, reunited with his familiar Stradivarius - accompanied by Pinnock on a decidedly alien Steinway - Vengerov played Mozart and Beethoven sonatas with all his habitual verve. But Vengerov's amazing ability to turn a melodic line and convey its radiant essence was enriched by a more choosy attitude to vibrato and articulation, for which his work with Pinnock is surely responsible. Even if he is still learning a baroque craft, Vengerov's adventurous spirit - he is virtually alone among modern violin-virtuosi in taking up the challenges of earlier instruments - is something to celebrate.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Alison Taylor, 38 chief executive
fields.body:
Alison Taylor, 38 chief executive

Experience has taught me the best way to make a good first impression is to make contact with as many people in the organisation as you can. When I was younger, I used to pore through files to learn, but the best way is to ask other people for their views. When you're new, colleagues and clients forgive you if you have no solutions yet and they're happy to offer their perceptions of the company. It's important when you come in as a boss to seek advice rather than say: "This is what I am going to do." That way, you build better working relationships.

Tom Lawson, 30 development funding manager

When I was younger, I was always desperate to create a good first impression and perhaps too eager. I was nervous, so my mouth would motor on. You have to remember other people are more relaxed because they're not new and what you see as a friendly chat, they can take as too much information. I remember talking to one woman and saying: "You're gay, aren't you? So am I." I meant it in a friendly way but she wasn't pleased I'd almost outed her at work. I'm more careful now. I suss out people's boundaries and try not to overstep them.

Richard Hunter, 31 financial sales director

I think being honest when you're asked your opinion is the best way to create a good first impression and I've learnt the difference between arrogance and assertiveness in your answers. Arrogance says: "I know better than you", assertiveness is constructive criticism. I remember starting a new job at 19. I was late for a company meeting because a client meeting over-ran and I just barged in and said: "Sorry I'm late, I've been seeing a client, which is more important, isn't it?" It didn't go down well. Now, I'd be assertive with the client and explain why I had to leave.

Ruth Barnes, 26 freelance marketing consultant

When you work freelance, you have to make good first impressions on a regular basis. I have a problem with people's names, so when I'm introduced to a department, I make a little seating plan with people's names and job titles on it. That way I always remember who they are and what they do, since there's nothing worse than forgetting someone's name. I also have a poor sense of direction and getting lost in an open-plan office is not clever. I focus on where the photocopier/coffee machine/ loos are, so I don't have to keep bothering people to tell me again.

Jane Edwards, 41 IT manager

Offering solutions to immediate problems always helps in making a good impression, but you have to choose your words carefully or you step on people's toes. I remember starting a new job and saying I was changing how the stationery was stored. Later I found out my staff had spent months trying to sort it out and resented my attitude. I'd assumed nobody had bothered before. Now, rather than go in with guns blazing, I discuss problems with staff and see how much has already been done to find solutions.

Interviews by Cayte Williams

fields.headline: Dickens the symbolist
fields.standfirst:
Great Expectations/Northern Ballet Theatre
Grand Theatre, Leeds
**
fields.trailText: Stefano Giannetti's first ballet for NBT looks as if it might be treading an all-too-familiar route for the company by taking its story line from the well-thumbed Dickens novel Great Expectations.
fields.body:
During the 11 years in which Christopher Gable directed Northern Ballet Theatre he re-created the company in his own flamboyantly populist image. He beefed up his dancers' acting skills and set them to work in a repertoire of big, brash story ballets, including updated versions of the classics and adaptations of mainstream literary works such as Dracula.

Gable's successor, Stefano Giannetti, is all but unknown in Britain as a choreographer. Yet his first ballet for NBT looks as if it might be treading an all-too-familiar route for the company by taking its story line from the well-thumbed Dickens novel Great Expectations.

On stage, however, the work looks very different from the plot-heavy productions that Gable oversaw. Bennita Roth's cleverly iconic designs make no attempt to mimic the gaudy, grimy picturesque of Dickens, representing Pip's childhood home by a simple silhouette and reducing Miss Havisham's cobwebby mausoleum to a white plinth, moulded like a giant shell, on which she weirdly perches. The stage is thus left artfully bare for Giannetti's own choreography, which is clean limbed, supple and, for NBT, unusually classical in style.

Yet though Giannetti is aiming to tip the balance from theatre to dance, he still has Dickens's compulsively plotted story to deal with. And though he simplifies hard, with flashbacks condensed into neatly contrived tableaux, he's left with far too much to explain within a two-act ballet. Between the dance numbers there are mad dashes of storytelling, barely comprehensible to anyone who has not read the book, and occasional episodes of overburdened symbolism. When Pip encounters the mature Estella she has, like her guardian, perched herself on top of a shell-like plinth - and Pip's fumbling endeavours to lift her down to human happiness are more absurd comedy than touching resolution: Woman Escapes from Giant Mollusc.

The haste of the storytelling would matter less if Giannetti's choreography had got more deeply under his characters' skins. But though he's borrowed some of his imagery from Dickens (Mrs Joe's spiky rushes of energy for instance), he's unable to bring it to life with genuinely intimate body language. (He's not helped either by his score, a selection of pieces by Elgar that don't, as played, add up to a contained imaginative sound world.)

It's ironic that under Gable NBT were fine actors but underpowered dancers, while under Giannetti their dancing is much improved but they rarely get to act. webTitle: Net prices yet to make an impact

fields.headline: Net prices yet to make an impact
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Although bosses of bricks and mortar companies fret about the impact of e-commerce on their profit margins, central bankers have good reason to celebrate the net's arrival.
fields.body:
Although bosses of bricks and mortar companies fret about the impact of e-commerce on their profit margins, central bankers have good reason to celebrate the net's arrival.

It has become conventional wisdom that increased price transparency and competition will make their job of controlling inflation much easier.

Why, then, are central bankers in the United States, Britain and Europe jacking up interest rates as if nothing has changed? The short answer is that the internet is still in its infancy, accounting for only a tiny proportion of business-to-consumer transactions.

Estimates suggest that on line retail sales in western Europe amounted to around $5bn (£3.12bn) in 1999, in a field where overall sales are counted in trillions.

They are therefore too insignificant to have much impact on the overall rate of price increases. The advent of "smart" mobile phones and cheaper telephone tariffs is, however, expected to boost on line sales dramatically in the coming years.

Throw in the impact on prices of business-to-business transactions, and it probably will not be long before the internet begins to have a marked downward influence on the rate of inflation.

Meanwhile, however, there is precious little evidence - other than of an anecdotal kind - that it is a significant factor for central bankers to take into account when determining interest rates.

This may be partly due to data deficiency. In research published earlier this week, the American investment bank JP Morgan pointed that that, while many European statistical offices are musing about the impact of e-commerce on the data they collect, few are actively changing their systems. In fact, only the UK is planning to incorporate internet prices directly into the retail prices index.

The process will take a couple of years to complete but the omens about what it will demonstrate are not necessarily all good.

Mindful of the data gap, JP Morgan undertook its own survey of British high street and online prices. It examined the categories of goods and services where internet usage is most advanced.

Goods bought online were much cheaper, even after considering delivery costs. "Indeed, considering goods alone, if all purchases in the categories considered migrated to the internet we should expect to see around 0.4 percentage points sliced from the RPI," JP Morgan says. Online services, however, were more expensive than those purchased over the telephone.

JP Morgan suggests this could be due to smaller relative cost-savings for online service providers and the interactive nature of telephone service provision which gives buyers the opportunity to negotiate a discount.

As online services develop a critical mass and the technology becomes more sophisticated, prices might fall - but it could take some time.

Meanwhile, the internet could even have a perverse impact on inflation.

In a recent research note Goldman Sachs said that business-to-business activity is enabling companies to achieve dramatic savings in the costs of production which will ultimately allow central bankers to let economies grow much faster. Growth in the industrial economies could be 0.25% higher a year on average during the next 10 years, it said.

webTitle: Thousands more jobs on line at Barclays

fields.headline: Thousands more jobs on line at Barclays
fields.trailText: Thousands more jobs are on the line at Barclays in plans by the bank to slash costs by £1bn.
fields.body:
Thousands more jobs are on the line at Barclays in plans by the bank to slash costs by £1bn.

Fears of the unquantified cuts on top of 5,300 last year were raised as Barclays revamped its incentive scheme for top executives to match a new management ethos announced yesterday by Matt Barrett, the new Irish-Canadian chief executive.

Mr Barrett, addressing the City for the first time since joining Barclays in October, laid out a "hard hitting" strategy to double "economic" profit every four years while cutting £1bn of costs by 2003.

The City initially reacted enthusiastically, with the share price rising 8%, although eventually they closed just 5p higher at £14.38p.

The new management plan, similar to that adopted at Lloyds TSB, was announced as Barclays - which spent much of last year without a chief executive - reported a 30% rise in pre-tax profits to £2.5bn.

Mr Barrett refused to disclose how many jobs would be affected by his aim to cut costs, saying he wanted to discuss the situation with the union.

He admitted, however, that it was "inescapable" that job numbers were declining in lower skilled sectors but stressed more jobs were being created in "knowledge" areas.

The new incentive package - which is still to be approved by shareholders - will involve a "higher risk of no pay-out", Mr Barrett said.

The bank will have to meet its profits forecasts and shares will have to perform better than those of 11 of its rivals.

The bank increased its dividend by 16% to 50p a share. Barclays said it would continue to buy back shares but did not say how many.

Mr Barrett's introduction of "value based management" is designed to allow him to use "economic profit" as benchmark to compare businesses and returns to shareholders.

Businesses that fail to meet the mark would be disposed of, he said. But he offered his backing for Barclays Capital, the investment banking arm.

"As a blueprint, [value based management] is as good as anything we're aware of for a bank of this kind," said Richard Coleman of Merrill Lynch.

fields.headline: UK inflation lowest in EU
fields.standfirst: Fierce retail competition and cheaper cars help to put brake on economy
fields.trailText: Cheaper cars and ferocious competition in the high street have given Britain the lowest inflation rate in the European Union, according to official figures released yesterday.
fields.body:
Cheaper cars and ferocious competition in the high street have given Britain the lowest inflation rate in the European Union, according to official figures released yesterday.

After decades of Britain being one of Europe's worst inflation performers, the cost of living rose just 0.8% in the year to January, down from 1.2% the previous month.

Plunging prices for food, clothes, cars and tobacco helped to drag down inflation so that Britain's rate was the lowest in the EU - only the second time this has occurred since entry into the European Economic Community in 1973.

Using the same yardstick for all EU countries, the harmonised index of consumer prices, Britain's inflation rate was less than half the average of 1.7% for both the 15-nation EU and for the 11-country single-currency zone. Sweden had the next lowest inflation rate to Britain at 1.2%, while booming Ireland had the highest inflation rate at 3.9%.

Other measures of inflation released by the government yesterday showed a more mixed picture. Inflation as measured by the all-items retail prices index rose from 1.8% to 2% as a result of the dearer mortgages triggered by the Bank of England's successive increases in base rates since the autumn. However, the rate excluding home loans fell from 2.2% to 2.1%, the 10th successive month in which it has been below the government's 2.5% target.

A breakdown of the data from the office of national statistics showed a marked difference between the downward pressure on the prices of goods, which are no higher now than they were in January last year, and the upward drift in the cost of those services sheltered from global competition, where prices were up 4.4%.

The supermarket price war left food prices 2% lower than a year ago, while the category "other goods" - which includes clothes, household goods, personal articles and leisure goods - is showing a record 3% annual fall. The extent of the bargains on offer in the winter sales was highlighted by a 6.8% drop in clothing and footwear prices and the 4.8% decline in household prices last month, both of which were the largest since records began in 1948.

Within services, the sector showing the heftiest increase in prices was "non-shop services" - insurance, rent, fees and subscriptions, vehicle tax, travel costs and holidays - where the increase of 7.1% in the 12 months to January was the highest since May 1993.

Jonathan Loynes at HSBC said that although the price pressure was concentrated in a few sectors the monetary policy committee would continue to worry about the prospect of rising inflation in the event of a sharply lower pound. "Overall, while the fall in underlying inflation is encouraging, it is unlikely to prevent interest rates from rising a little further over the next few months. But with UK inflation the lowest in Europe and our interest rates double those in the euroland area, the peak is not far away."

fields.headline: World-class atmosphere
fields.standfirst:
Stan Tracey/Bobby Wellins
Pizza on the Park, London
****
fields.trailText:
Stan Tracey/Bobby Wellins
Pizza on the Park, London
****
fields.body:
International acclaim for the UK's jazz musicians hasn't occurred for a long time - the watershed was probably when John McLaughlin and Dave Holland were swept to the US by Miles Davis in the late 60s, but in the earlier postwar years a local Charlie Parker could have emerged and hardly anyone outside Soho would have noticed.

The formidable pianist Stan Tracey and the Scottish saxophonist Bobby Wellins - together again over the weekend in a now rare collaboration - were briefly exceptions, when the tone-poem Starless and Bible Black on Tracey's 1964 Under Milk Wood suite was recognised as world-class atmospheric jazz.

Both Wellins and Tracey can make as much with very little out of disguised mid-tempo blues as anybody in the business. The saxophonist will edge his way into it as if descending a staircase in the dark, with hesitant, anxious hoots and fragmentary phrases, while Tracey fitfully nudges him with a chord, as if extending a hand to his elbow. Then Wellins gathers momentum with sly, semi-apologetic squirts of sound, briefly sunny bursts of swing as if the light has come on and gone off again, then grumpy mutters as if steadying himself for the next descent.

Wellins's method is so understated and patiently paced that some sections of a noisy audience seemed barely aware when he started and finished. Tracey's more rugged mix of hard-struck chords and hopping runs cut more sharply through, and his trio members support him with immense empathy.

Bassist Andy Cleyndert achieved this with elegant phrasing and penetrative sound, while drummer Clark Tracey called on an assortment of ringing cymbal patterns, sudden train-rhythm hi-hat figures abruptly unleashed by his father out of clunky rockfalls of chords.

The younger Tracey's showcase was an urgent mallets solo on Comme d'Habitude (a reworking of My Way), and Bobby Wellins and Tracey senior most affectingly revisited old haunts on Angel Eyes, a delicate tapestry of buoyant chords and floating, smoky long notes. Without the rhythm section to lean his reflections on, Wellins sounded again like the tenor-sax poet of old.

webTitle: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: I've never had a harassment case with so much evidence before. From: Mr P. To: Miss A. Subject: Pants. I could see your knickers through your skirt when I walked in behind you today. You're wearing a thong, aren't you? From: Miss A. To: Mr P. Subject: P*** off. Don't email me any more.
fields.body:
I've never had a harassment case with so much evidence before. From: Mr P. To: Miss A. Subject: Pants. I could see your knickers through your skirt when I walked in behind you today. You're wearing a thong, aren't you? From: Miss A. To: Mr P. Subject: P*** off. Don't email me any more. From: Mr P. To: Miss B. Subject: Knickers. I'm thinking of buying my girlfriend some lingerie. Do girls like crotchless pants? From: Miss B. To: Mr P. Subject: Calling the police. Leave me alone, you pervert. And so on, for pages and pages of email printouts. Not only does Mr P appear to be the world's daftest harasser, he doesn't know when to quit. Instead of quietly reaching compromise agreements with the three women who finally complained to the tribunal about him, he and his employer are running the ever popular "They liked it really" defence. Mr P has also followed the grand harasser's tradition of employing female counsel. She wears a resolute "I'm only going down with this ship because they're paying me to" expression, while Mr P attempts to reconcile the multiple electronic rebuffs we are leafing through with his contention that the little ladies loved nothing better than a bit of e-banter about their underwear.

Miss A and Miss B are having none of this guff and Mr P's counsel gloomily pursues the task of cross-examining justifiably indignant witnesses who have 200 pages of documentary evidence on their side. Then it's Miss C's turn. I am nervous about Miss C. She is younger than the other two and quieter. At lunchtime she gives me an unhappy look when I find her whispering with Mr P in the corridor. And her replies are much more ambivalent than those of Misses A and B. (From: Mr P. To: Miss C. Subject: Shapeliness. You look very shapely today. Is it some miracle undergarment or are you very fit? From: Miss C. To: Mr P. Subject: Naughtiness. You really are very naughty, etc.) Most ominous of all is the way Mr P's counsel perks up as Miss C heads for the stand. Counsel: Now, weren't you just a little flattered that Mr P was paying you this attention? Miss C (small voice, hands clasped): No. Counsel: But you never really told him to stop, did you? Miss C (almost inaudible): No. Counsel: And what made you upset was finding out it wasn't just you he was writing these messages to? Miss C (in tears now): No. But we know it's all over for Miss C and she does, too. When the panel retire, she says tearily: "It's just it's so boring at our work. I mean, nothing ever happens and I thought he liked me. I thought it was like that film with Meg Ryan, You've Got Mail." "Yeah, if Tom Hanks was an ugly pervert with an underwear fetish," mutters Miss B, then pats Miss C not unkindly as she breaks into renewed lamentation.

fields.headline: Coming?
fields.standfirst:
Your partner has a new job. Great! It's abroad. Not so great. Do you go or do you stay? Eleanor Bailey went. Here she examines the pros and cons, personal and professional
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Your partner has a new job. Great! It's abroad. Not so great. Do you go or do you stay? Eleanor Bailey went. Here she examines the pros and cons, personal and professional.
fields.body:
I used to think ex-pat wives spent their days teaching servants how to lay tables. Now I am one and I don't even own a table. I didn't in England and I don't in Germany. If I were to throw an ex-pat dinner party, my guests would have to eat off their laps.

Business globalisation makes working abroad increasingly easy in many fields. If you are freelance, like me, as long as you have the technology, you can work almost anywhere. It also makes it more likely that at some point you or your partner will be able to - or have to - work abroad. So what do you do when your partner gets offered a job overseas? Can his career survive if he doesn't go? Can yours survive if you go, too? And can your relationship survive either the uprooting or the separation?

My husband was offered an ideal new job a year ago. It so happened it was in Germany. This might be seen as an obstacle (friends' reactions ranged from confusion to sympathy and gifts of Marmite) but I could see no reason to stay at home. It came at a good time for me: I had sold a novel half-written and I had a deadline to finish it. I positively needed fewer lunch invitations and as a freelance journalist, most of my work was done over the phone. Based in Europe, the phone bill would obviously swell, but I figured I'd save money on daily travel.

My German was enough to be able to make German friends. But it was like the first days at college, rather random. One friend I met in a coffee shop, another at the baker's. Conversation is inevitably stumbling, less interesting, more of an effort. I spend more time on my own, which I do happily, but I need a good evening. It is harder for my husband to come home in a bad mood if he is the first person I've spoken to all day. We have to negotiate nights he goes to the gym.

As an ex-pat partner, you are initially more dependent. Eric Walters moved from the US to Germany when his partner, Claire, moved with her TV production company. Like hers, his skills were international: he is a computer consultant, English is the dominant language in his field and he knew he'd have no trouble finding a job. He now works from home, travelling to Amsterdam every few weeks.

The difficulties he is having, he says, are related to life, not work. "It was definitely a big change. I effectively liquidated my life in the States. I got rid of a big car, good job, great flat. I'd had all my comforts, all my favourite things, and I had to figure out new ones. Not speaking German is the biggest handicap. But I could either sit at home being miserable or go out and do something. I am learning the language - slowly."

He admits the couple are "more tied together" now. "Inevitably my circle of friends is made up of Claire's work colleagues. I can't meet Germans because all I can do is nod and smile. I miss having my own friends, I miss the American service culture, but it's worth it for the experience of seeing that other places are different - not necessarily wrong, just different."

For a partner, the problem is isolation. Julia Alessandro gave up her job in PR and moved to LA with her boyfriend shortly after getting pregnant. "I love everything about California," she says, "except that I am so far from my friends and family. And it seems to become more important. I know people but it's not the same as friends you've had for years who you can be boring with and not worry. I want to go back to the UK but my boyfriend is reluctant as he's doing well at work. I can't work without a permit, so I feel tied to a man in a way I never envisaged. I can't even buy him a gift without knowing that he's paying for it."

The alternative, of course, is for one partner to stay put. Email has made this a far more viable option, according to Michael Wright, whose girlfriend is working for a charity in Manila. "When Anna's mother moved to Dar es Salaam in the early 60s, she got to speak to her family on the phone twice a year. It meant arranging an appointment at the exchange. Anna and I can send each other stupid jokes twice a day. That's a lifeline."

Anna is on a two-year secondment and the couple talk roughly twice a week. Michael sighs. "It was important to Anna to take this opportunity and I couldn't stand in her way. But nor would I go with her. I was not about to chuck in my job, I hate hot countries and adaptation to a more basic way of life is not something I want to try. I need home delivery, Blockbusters, rollerblading, caffe latte. But I couldn't stop Anna. If I said no, the issue would always be between us.

"She's having a wonderful time but I do worry that she won't want to come back. The house is empty without her. We have tried to be practical: two years is a long time, I'll probably only see her three or four times. We agreed we could have sex with other people as long as we didn't talk about it or fall in love. I feel we'll probably end up stronger. Either that or split."

The key to success in the "should I stay or should I go" dilemma is, it seems, self-knowledge. Michael is honest enough to know that life in a developing country is not for him. Anna knows she needs to do it. There is a risk to the relationship, of course, but a split might happen anyway.

Colin Bailey of the charity Voluntary Service Overseas agrees. "The people who have the worst time abroad are the ones who think it will be exciting and glamorous. In fact, moving abroad can be isolating, particularly for a partner. VSO carefully vets partners as well as volunteers before they are accepted. The couples who make a go of it are adaptable and can cope with time on their own. You need initiative to make new friends and work out a new life for yourself. It is a challenge but it can be a rewarding one and both experiences, separation or travelling together, can be good for a relationship."

No one knows how many Britons migrate every year, but Jean-Pierre Garson, head of international migration at the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, says there is little doubt more are going. "It is easy to do with the English language. For example, there is lots of trade between France and Germany, and the language spoken is generally English." There is more migration from England, he says, probably because there is more opportunity.

But opportunity for what, exactly? What is it we gain by deliberately removing ourselves from a comfortable set-up and moving to an alien environment? Even in a country as close as Germany, when the shops shut at 4pm on Saturdays and housewives strip on prime-time game shows, it can seem a dark and weird place. The partner who moved for their job has reason enough: more money, better CV, sense of achievement. But the partner who moved for them - what reason do they have?

It's challenging, of course, making your own career work despite obstacles, and it is probably better for the relationship that you should experience change together. And at the very least, when you want to move to Paraguay, your partner is going to have a hard time saying no.

fields.headline: Spine chilling tales
fields.standfirst: An employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: In court with Mr and Mrs Bad Back
fields.body:
I've complained before in this column about how my accident-at-work cases always seem to fall into the obviously self-inflicted category. Not this week. This week it all looked kosher.

Mr Bad Back had been directed by his boss to pick up a very heavy barrel. He was fifty-eight and obviously unfit. He had had no proper training in lifting techniques and he hurt his back. Liability admitted.

What we were fighting about was how much it was all worth. This is where the doctors came in. The employer's eminent consultant orthopaedic surgeon was saying that the accident had caused Mr Bad Back to slip a disk about a year earlier than he would have, given the already worn out state of his spine.

Our eminent etc said that the slippage had been speeded up by five years. Both expressed their views in firm terms (by doctor standards) in their reports. There was four years' loss of earnings for Mr Bad Back to play for.

What I hadn't realised before I met him on the morning of the hearing was that our consultant was eighty-five. Not that age had withered him, just worn him away to the fine bird bones holding up his pre-war consultant's suit.

And it wasn't really his age that was the problem. It was the fact that, apart from writing medico-legal reports, he hadn't seen a patient in twenty years, as he graciously admitted in cross-examination.

Or maybe it was his graciousness that was the problem. He greeted every question from the employer's counsel with a listening bend of the head and then murmured that perhaps the employer's consultant had a point, yes.

After lunch, my opponent approached me in the robing room. "Just seen your consultant in the canteen..." "Oh yes?" "Mmmm, he asked the lady for a cheese sandwich and then when he got to end of the queue he said "I'm sorry, my dear, but I asked for a ham roll."" "Obviously concentrating hard on his evidence."

But looking at our consultant in the box in the afternoon, it struck me that his pale eyes were fixed on some horizon more distant than the back of the court. Employer's consultant gave evidence next. He was young (by consultant standards) and sharp, with the amused look doctors who know what they're doing wear when you cross-examine them.

The judge didn't have much work to do in the end. Our consultant had pretty much agreed with everything their consultant had said. Mr Bad Back looked sad but unsurprised. Mrs Bad Back shook her pot noodle perm and complained about the injustice of it all. There was nothing wrong with Bert before he lifted that barrel.

As I packed up my robes, our consultant put a hand lightly on my sleeve. It was like being brushed by a moth. "I hope that was all right, my dear?"

He was looking very white. It had been a long day for him. "Yes, just fine." I smiled at him. "Thank you very much."
